reviews.review: Small Museum With A Big Story. A must do for New Yorkers and visitors. Incredibly compelling museum. We were fortunate to meet the extraordinarily talented and inspiring museum founder - Gary Marlon Suson. A unique experience. Truly moving.

Great Alternative Museum, Powerful Experience. We went here based on a recommendation from a friend, and I'd recommend it to you as well! The images and stories captured were very powerful. We were fortunate to meet the photographer/owner of the museum as we were leaving which was very cool. You can make reservations, we were lucky enough to snag an open spot (but had to wait until the next tour/viewing time).

A Moving Experience: Reliving 9/11.. This museum is a "must-see" for anyone traveling to Manhattan. Although it recounts the terrible day of Sept 11, 2001, it is an unbelievable presentation for the events of that horrible day. It is a fitting memorial to those who lost their lives, as well as the first responders to the tragedy. Plan of spending at least 2 hours to see most of the exhibits. An incredible experience and one I will never forget. Please go and pay your respect to those who lost their lives on that day. Also, marvel at the rebuilding of this site and visit the memorial next to the museum.

A must do.... This is a great place but park your first impression at the door when you walk in. The museum is small however we easily spent two hours there....it is a must do and gives you a totally different perspective on 9/11. Recommend doing this before visiting the actual Ground Zero - the enormity of the endeavour makes more sense.

Don't Let Size Fool You!. We had the pleasure of meeting Gary Suson, the photographer of the remarkable images that you will see at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. He captured and documented history through his pictures. Each image and item in his studio, has a story that really helps you to understand what it was like for those recovery workers, working at Ground Zero in the aftermath of that tragic day in September 2001. We took our children 9 and 12 with us to get an understanding of 9/11 and they were both as interested in everything they saw, as us adults. This museum gives a deep, insight to 9/11, that is accessible to both adults and children. Thank you for a wonderful experience it is truely a really interesting place to visit. We are glad to have experienced it.

Incredible humbling experience. I visited this museum in late september 2016 with my son and daughter in law and a few friends and did not expect it to be such a moving experience.The photos and the artefacts on display put the whole event into perspective for me personally.Coupled with the heartfelt description of each photograph by the official photographer Gary Suson you begin to realise the full impact and effect this tragedy had on New York, and the USA in general.It paints a vivid picture of the task that faced the rescuers,and the respect they showed the recovered victims will stay with me forever.If you only visit one museum in NY,make it this one, I defy anyone not to be moved by the experience Thank you Gary
Must Visit!. If you take the tour of the former twin towers (Ground Zero) site, then, take the time to visit the museum it's well with a visit.

Count your blessings and say I love you. My wife lost family on 9/11...a firefighter. and this small studio on W 14th St has the most incredible testament to the NYC firefighters who lost their lives on 9/11 and their dedicated comrades who spent the following months at Ground Zero. Mr. Gary Susan curated the workshop superbly. We spent a very emotional few hours here. Highly recommend but make sure you bring tissues, you will need them. My wife had a box and it was empty by the time we left. Not just from us but others who came unprepared.

Emotional but spellbinding experience. In a small studio on W 14th St is the most incredible testament to the NYC firefighters who lost their lives on 9/11 and their dedicated comrades who spent the following months at GZ. Gary Susan has curated the workshop superbly. We spent a very emotional few hours here and were fortunate that Gary was there to answer questions. Highly recommend but take tissues!

Most Moving of Experiences - From those whose were there . We were lucky enough to have a tour with the founder Gary. This is a must a visit for anyone wanting to hear, see and feel how the firefighters, police and volunteers did the right the the right way. Shame the big event at GZ is competing with this and I wonder if there is way making sure intimate place doesn't have to close. The very best real museum that ranks with Anna Franks in Amsterdam.Well done Gary and all your volunteers.

Very emotional. We bought our tickets off of groupon and at first we thought it was to the actual 9/11 museum. It is actually a smaller museum located next to the fire station. It was very emotional and eye opening of the play by play on 9/11. You get to read people's personal stories and see some artifacts that were collected from the rubble. Like I keep saying, it was very emotional, but if you have a moment to stop if I recommend going. It is not very big and only takes about an hour to go through the whole museum.
Just in Awe!. Very sad to see and read about everything. Very professionally put together. Everyone showed respect by whispering.

A moving experience. We visited this museum after a trip to the national museum located at the World Trade Centre site. It made an interesting counterpoint to the huge scale of the 9/11 Memorial. This site is a small, single room site documenting one mans - Gary Suson - personal experience of the post 9/11 recovery operation and is no less an impact on the scale of devastation. This is a deeply personal and well told narrative of how the museum curator came to be asked to record the immediate recovery operation at the WTC site. You have to remember the sensitivities that were in place due to the bodies and human remains that had still to be recovered. Added to that, many of the recovery team were involved in searching for members of their own family. Therefore Mr. Suson was given a clear set of protocols to follow while he recorded the ongoing recovery process.As a result, he has put together a very personal and moving tribute to the people who lost their lives as a result of the attack and of those who undertook the recovery operation in what were clearly very trying an demanding circumstances.In the room there are numerous artefacts from the WTC site, found during the recovery process and numerous photographs. However what brings it all together is each part of the display is accompanied by a personal audio description by Mr. Suson which you listen to on the provided device and headphones. It is the use of the headphones which makes the visit so immersive as you listen to the stories behind each picture or item on display. I have to say I was stunned by how absorbing the museum was, the time just disappeared. The concept is different, i.e. being in a single room but that did not distract from the overall experience.One minor detail, if you do visit, it is not immediately easy to find. It is located on W14th Street in Chelsea and there is a small notice above a door but if you get there too early, access to the building is not easy. After 11 when it opens, a sandwich board is set up outside, so easier to find.
Speechless. Great tour of 9-11. The pictures and art work is fabulous. It felt so real walking through the exhibit. Very emotional

911 Rescue Services - true superheroes!. Very difficult to find but oh so worth the effort. The host was charming and very knowledgable. Great recorded audio descriptions and amazing photographs. Please take time out to visit and absorb a very personal, moving experience.
go there in silence. please go the are visit in silence and remember those who lost the chance to do what you are doing today , Being alive and free in the USA

Unbelievable and very moving.. Everyone should visit this Museum, like everyone should visit the Holocaust Museums to see the pain and suffering man can deliver upon his fellow man. Tears and more tears fell as we walked around this tribute to the fallen and the heroics of others. The detailing is perfect and although sad it is a credit to those involved in its creation. If you visit, and you must if you are in NY take plenty of tissues.

Great place and kid friendly . Kids are 9 and 11 and really enjoyed it! Totally worth going. Highly recommend! Lots of interesting things for the kids and us. We are not from NYC and wanted to see actual artifacts this place really delivered

Amazing and Powerful. Many of us (of a certain age) know about the events that took place on 9/11. This museum, however, gives you an even closer, more intimate look at the events and efforts of uniformed personnel after the day. It's extremely emotional and powerful but the museum handles it delicately and respectfully. I have been twice now and intend always recommend it to friends travelling to NYC.

A Moving and Poignant Experience, Highly Recommended!. This museum is an incredibly special experience. I brought my 15 year old son to this museum last week, who was a tiny baby when 9/11/01 changed New York and so many lives. He normally doesn't love museums or tours, but this one is a different story. When you entire the small space, you realize this is not any ordinary museum. Gary Marlon Suson, the photographer of every photo in the museum, narrates everything in the entire museum through his audio presentations, starting with his introductory video, and then continuing with the audio throughout the museum. With the headphones on you are able to hear him speak about every single thing in the museum, which makes the experience that much more close and interesting. This includes all of his photos, plus many items that he was able to take out of ground zero. An unexpected highlight for me occurred when I wanted to purchase one particular framed photo. There was only one left, so the tour guide made a phone call to make sure it was OK to sell it. She then walked over to me, handed me the phone, and told me that Gary Suson would like to talk to me. After seeing everything he had captured during the year of taking photos, and thinking about all he had been through, I was overcome with emotion and could barely speak. I am glad I found my voice because he was incredibly interesting to speak with, and I enjoyed the opportunity to commend him for the incredible work he had done. He has provided all of us with a chance to mourn, appreciate, understand, and reflect. I was blown away when he told me that he was only 23 years old at the time that he took all of these photos. Wow, a lot for a young adult to experience, and I might add what talent he had at that young age as well. I would recommend bringing tissues. When my son and I left the museum, I asked him, "What did you think, do you think it was worthwhile?". He turned to me, gave me a big and much-needed hug, and said that he was so glad I took him to see this museum.A long review, but hopefully worth reading. I could not recommend this museum more.
Vacation. The entire museum is a must see for any New York visitor. Very well done and informative. Allow at least two hours.

Wonderful. Our grandchildren ages 11 and 14 enjoyed so much and learned so much. A must for children over the age of 10. Tells of a horror that young people need to know about in a way that is not frightening, but enlightening. We saw our grandchildren feel the experience and come away with an understanding of 9-11. It provides insight and hope.
A lot to see.. There was so much to see in this museum. Be sure and give yourself time to see everything. We didn't think the short feature film was worth the wait but all else was interesting.
Pay your respects here. A great museum to pay your respects to those lost in such tragic events and too celebrate the lives of those taken from us.

As good as they say. As other travellers have said, this is really the story of the weeks after the towers came down. I didn't feel the need to go to the main memorial museum, feeling this was enough to pay my respects.

Deeply moving. This museum is outstanding. My friends and I spent three hours in awe of the personal stories, artifacts, news casts, and artwork. Had to hold back tears several times. This is a wonderful, professional, thoughtful museum which captures our history.

No words... just angst -- and seeds of healing. This is a must-see, must-do, must-experience. I attended this prior to going to the 9/11 memorial... and am so grateful that I did. Don't let the size of this museum / workshop fool you -- it is a profoundly moving and emotional experience through the eyes of photographer / hero Marlon Suson. Sheila was an exceptional guide / docent... who added richly to this powerful experience.

Recovery Efforts - Amazing Photographs!. This museum is designed to help you understand the recovery efforts made after the 9/11 attacks. It is very moving. The photographs are extremely moving and the museum is self paced. We had young children, teens and adults. Everyone in our party really enjoyed the museum!

Not Your Typical Museum. My family visited the GZWM and it was well worth it. It is called a workshop because you can actually pick up and touch many of the artifacts recovered from the 9/11 site. It is centered around the recovery efforts of the FDNY as captured through the pictures of Gary Suson. As you walk around the small museum you are able to hear through the Bose noise cancelling headphones a short narration of each of the artifacts and pictures. The stories, facts and pictures give you a once in life time perspective of being involved in the recovery efforts after 9/11 and the stories surrounding those involved in those efforts. I recommend this museum to complement the 9/11 memorial museum.

Nothing new if you've been to the Museum. Owned by the photographer who had exclusive access to ground zero and was able to walk away with bunches of "mementos" from the site. Nothing new if you have visited the Museum & Memorial. Their pieces are much more impressive and they have lots more. The Workshop was a disappointment after leaving it and going directly to the Museum.
Must see. Very emotional museum to see and hold some of the artefacts from the recovery following 9/11 and listen to tales. Teenager children appreciated this type of history museum with a difference
More of a studio for the works from the photographer.. Small, not really a museum, more of a studio for the works of Mr. Suson based on 9/11. The staff is rude.

Educational and Moving Experience. My family visited the museum and ad a wonderful experience. We were fortunate enough to have the opportunity to meet the photographer, Gary, who took the time to speak with me and my children. My 10 and 8 year old daughters listened intently to the audio tour as they took in the images. One of the kind workers sat with my 4 year old son for close to a half hour, flipping through the pages of a book about the rescue dogs of ground zero. I would definitely recommend this museum for families that are looking to understand the events of that day and the months afterwards in a more personal way, without having to endure graphic images that could be overwhelming.Great experience!

Intense, Emotional, Uplifting. Go see for yourself what was going on that fateful day that will forever hold a spot in our hearts. Pre purchase your tickets for smooth accessibility . Take it easy there, go with what your feeling, due to the such high volume of news re September 11...youll step back to where you were and what you did THAT day .
Ground zero. Excellent place to visit very moving but interesting and not morbid at all. Who brought statue of liberty find out and listen to the tour guide that free
A very good reminder. Get ready to have the memories of 9/11 seem like yesterday. My wife and I spent an entire afternoon going through. It is at your own pace here

A surprising gem of a museum. My husband visited this museum before continuing downtown to see the 9/11 memorial and museum at Ground Zero. This much smaller museum was our favorite. Our guide was the official photographer for the NY Fire Dept, and his photos and memorabilia are moving. The exhibit, although small, prepared us for the larger site downtown, and had "human interest" items, like the clock frozen at the time of the collapse. I highly recommend a trip to this museum.
must see museum. to understand what happen during one of the worst days in US.intense,emotional, this visit will give you a great overview of that sad episode

This one room is as engaging as an entire building!. This museum was one of the highlights form our recent trip to NYC. It is NOT at ground zero, but after we went here, we didn't even feel the need to go to the "real' ground zero. It is a single room with lots of photographs and artifacts from the ground zero site, including the only piece of airplane that was ever found. Every object has a number, and every visitor gets an audio tour headset. The photographer himself narrates the stories behind each photo and artifact, and so you really get a personal sense of what the years of recovery were like. I lost myself for hours in there, and even my kids (ages 8, 10, and 13) were totally engaged and touched by what they saw and heard. There are some stories that are really heart wrenching, and they have boxes of tissues around if you need them, but I would say overall it is FAR more uplifting of the human spirit than it is depressing or sad. If you want to teach yourself and/or your kids about the power of community, and how healing it can be to work together, then don't miss this museum! You have to make a reservation to go, which makes it hard if you don't plan ahead by a day or two, but this makes the experience WAY better! Instead of feeling jostled or rushed, you are just part of a small group of people, so you can see everything that you want to in a relaxed and thoughtful setting. The docents who work there are amazing, and when we were there, the photographer called in and spoke with us. He really likes to stay in touch with the people who go there, and it was wonderful to speak personally with him after experiencing just a minute fraction of what he experienced. I can't recommend this museum enough!

INTIMATE MUSEUM SETTING. Per Trip Advisor we made reservations for this museum before seeing the 9/11 Museum and Memorial. Located in one room, upstairs, holds a lot of 9/11 artifacts and pictures with corresponding stories. The photographer did a wonderful job capturing the stories, which were all heartfelt and sad. Very moving collection.
An emotional experience. The workshop was very emotional and gave you a close up understanding of the horror of 9/11. Small but intimate. I suggest you visit this before the 9/11 memorial.

Place to reminisce.. Go here and you won't be able to not reminisce about that fateful day. When you here the actual voices of the victims just before they perish will make your hairs stand at end. A must if in nyc.

Peace witnessed. Well a place to visit and feel the pain of brutality of 9/11 attack , there are debris and pieces of what leftover at that day and also the name of the innocent people and brave police, coast guard and firemen who lost their lives in that tragic attack.

Emotional. We booked prior to visiting as much as this is horrid to say it is a must to see
Very very emotional puts things in perspective regarding life
What new York went through is just so traumatizing to see your heart goes out to them we were truly moved to tears as was a lot of people

Incredible Journey Back to 9/11 Through a Tremendous Lens. Took my 12 yr-old and her friend to the workshop and they walked away with stories they would never learn in school. The lasting impression Gary's images will have on all of us keep the memory of 9/11 alive. The FDNY (along with all agencies involved) should be proud of how this tragic event was encapsulated for generations to reflect upon. This was a great location, a great exhibit and Gary is a great person!
Moving Experience ! . Wonderful experience ! So glad we went ! It's a little hard to find but worth the hunt ! Never forget 9/11/2011 & the ones that sacrificed so much !

Direct, moving, personal and candid account of the FDNY story and 9/11 by one photographer. A stormy Sunday morning in NYC. Easy to miss walking along the street so do not miss it/ ring the bell/ go up. This personal photographic and audio narrative / chronicle by the photographer Gary Marlon Suson takes you, sometimes painfully, back to where you were, in NYC or anywhere in the world, on 9/11.It is an immediate and compelling and emotional experience made more intense by the small exhibition space. Is this the most moving exhibition in New York? Yes I think so.

Museum that makes you feel the loss and the sacrifice . This museum is like a great work of art or literature in that it makes you feel. It is a small museum but its power does not come from the enormity of its collection but rather from the very personal stories it tells through picture, touch and audio accounts of the photographer creator and the men and women who served in the effort to find the fallen to return them to their families. I cried several times listening to the audio narrative for many of the images displayed here. So if you're not afraid to open yourself to the pain of the losses endured and the dedication and love of those who came after to honor the fallen come here. Few museums will affect you this way.

A must see visit when you come to New York. This is the second time I've visited this museum (this time taking my mum). This museum (through its interactive headphones) takes you back to that fateful day. Punch in the number and a description will tell you about each individual artefact. We were lucky that on our tour, the photographer and creator of the museum, Gary Marlon Suson was there to guide us. Emotional is not the word as you feel you were there on that sad day. A*******. Next time I'm in New York, I will visit the museum again. #neverforget

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. It was an experience I will never forget. Seeing the pictures and the items made itLooking at the pictures and listening to the stories, made you feel like you were right there during the recovery process. Would highly recommend it!!

Amazing and well worth the time.. Priced right, very good value for this tour. Begins with a walking tour, the the museum on your own, followed with a trip to the observatory 102 stories up. If you choose to visit the museum only, you will experience an excellent display of what must have been painstaking process to gather and chronicle items from the day. You will be emotional and drained after thistle. Not enjoyable but absolutely a must see for all!

Teach your children about 9/11 in the comfort of this NYC workshop. Intimate. Personal. Heartbreaking. Fascinating. These words describe the unique experience of visiting the Ground Zero Museum Workshop; an interactive journey that reminds and enlightens visitors about the recovery effort that took place the moment after the towers crumbled. The Manhattan skyline has been transformed since terrorists decimated it with airplane-bombs, but the little Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a big eye-opener to the fact that New Yorkers and other volunteers spent 9 months cleaning up the remains and recovering what was left of their dead. That painstaking process is explained here; in the most eloquently detailed way possible. Younger generations need to know what happened to this vibrant city just 15 years ago. This is a family-friendly museum where people from all over the world learn that Ground Zero was and still is a devastating experience. Even very young children will be able to grasp the concept of recovering after a disaster and how to honor heroes. Tucked into a corner of NYC's meat packing district, this amazing museum needs to be cherished... So make it a part of your kids' educational tour of NYC. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a fantastic, interactive way to teach 9/11 to future generations.

This seems a bit overrated.... While I enjoyed my visit to the Ground Zero Museum, I didn't consider it a must see on my recent NYC trip. What the museum is - and this wasn't totally clear to me ahead of time (I didn't really do any research) - is a single fairly small room with some photographs and various artifacts from Ground Zero. I'm a photography buff, so I would have preferred more photographs. Certainly worth a visit, but I did not find it as compelling as some other visitors did.

Small room but massive content and human stories. Was unsure as usually don't like over-hype of disasters but this museum was wonderful, being very interesting as well as incredibly moving without being overly sentimental. Would recommend for anyone who wants to come away having learnt something as well as 'connecting' with the dreadful events of that day. Please go, and help support this very worthwhile museum.
Touristy but interesting. Really enjoyed our visit here, he statue itself is only as thick as two pennies held together was just one of the interesting things we foujd out.......

Thought provoking. A huge congratulations must go to the designers and builders of this memorial. It is the most tasteful museum and display. Having been to the twin towers it is a solemn reminder of what was. A ust visit place whilst in New York.

Wow, just go.. This museum is not the easiest one to find but once you're there, it is incredibly special. I was not prepared to take my son to the 911 Memorial Museum as I was concerned about some the things he would see. This museum has done an excellent job getting to the heart of the matter without showing the gory details. When I have the best parts about this museum is that you must make a reservation so you are only there with a few people at a time. It allows for private reflection and true emotion. It also prevents you with an audio tour like no other I have experienced. Each item number and the man who created the museum tells the story of every single item as you go. You can skip anything that does not interest you but my 8 year old son and I saw and listened to the stories of every item. We were lucky enough to be there when the creator was there as well and he was able to answer questions we had. What a humble and insightful man. This museum is incredibly touching and I will hunt you long after you leave but is more about healing than revisiting the pain. Highly recommended.

Incredibly Moving. Going to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop was one of the most incredibly moving experiences of my life. It gives you a real insight into 9/11 and the incredible operation afterwards to try and return New York to normality. At times it is difficult to watch and hear the experiences but it is something everyone should do.
A must to see. Very sombre museum with a 1000 memories and facts which brings the reality real to visitors . Not a place to be missed

Choosing the one place to visit while in NYC..... Before my first trip to NYC, I was tasked with finding something I really wanted to do before my teachers' conference would begin. I started searching and came across the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I immediately knew this was it. It was the right choice. Visiting the GZMW was one of the most important, worthwhile things I have ever done. The experience was made even more significant due to the fact that Gary Marlon Suson, the photographer, was my tour guide. Listening to him share his very personal experience about 9-11 was more emotionally moving than I expected. The fact that the museum raises and donates funds for the families of the firefighters who lost their lives makes it more poignant. The experience is one that I will never forget, and I would encourage anyone to visit the museum, no matter where in the world you hail from.”
Highlight of the trip. I would have done myself a serious misdeed if I hadn't seen this - I couldn't appreciate what the people in New York went through until visiting the museum.
Visit. Great place to visit and pay respect to the 9/11 victims, great detail, very moving and good to visit if it's a wet day

Powerful - Do not Miss!. Pro's - you get up close to many artifacts from that awful day; amazing photographs; small group tour which means you have a lot of space to move around and get up close to anything you want to see; great for kids - nothing graphic or visually disturbing - power through photographs. Con's - none!We were lucky to visit while the photographer was there - Gary Marlon Suson - so to hear first-hand the stories behind his photographs was amazing. I can't say enough about what a wonderful experience this tour is for the entire family.

Excellent... We booked online to go to the museum. We were lucky that the guide we should have had was ill so Gary Marlon Suson was our guide. As the official photographer for FDNY in the aftermath of 911 Gary has amazing stories to tell. You are able to hold some of the artefacts which brings the whole thing home in a very real way. Gary's museum donates some of the proceeds from the sale of items in the gift shop area to the FDNY. Don't be fooled by the size of this museum..it is incredible and a must visit.

Hidden gem! Don't miss this amazing museum!. My wife, 16 year old daughter, 11 year old son and I happened upon this micro-museum on our way to the 9/11 Memorial Museum. By the end of our five day vacation all four of us voted it the highlight of our trip!Gary Suson was the only photographer authorized to shoot the aftermath of ground zero, documenting and archiving the effort for the FDNY. He is an amazing photographer, capturing the emotions of the responders with respect and dignity. There's not a single image in the 100+ on exhibit that was distasteful or disrespectful. He's also an amazing curator and host. He and his assistant, Kelsey, spent so much time with our family, explaining the significance of many photos and artifacts. Each of us was moved to tears holding a piece of the American Airlines plane recovered at ground zero, pieces of glass from the tower windows (very rare...all the glass found afterward can fit in a car trunk), and crosses made from the steel girders by iron workers at the site. VERY different experience than the 9/11 Memorial Museum. This was much more intimate and hands on. Gary brings a warmth and perspective and passion that isn't possible in the larger scale of the 9/11 Museum. Please don't miss this! They also donate a portion of their proceeds to the 9/11 Widows Fund! Donate generously, as many micro-museums simply can't keep their doors open without our help!Thank you Gary and Kelsey! NEVER FORGET!!! We certainly won't after experiencing your wonderful museum!

Do yourself a favour you won't regret this museum visit. We visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop (GZMW) on Friday 1st April and I have to say that I am certain that it was one of the best museums that we visited over our 14 day holiday. This museum is located in the Meat packing District and is very easy to locate.Gary Marlon Suson has created something very special and he should be so proud. When we visited we we lucky enough to have Gary as our guide and listening to him tell his story and those of the recovery workers is something. Susan's work makes it all seem real and personal.Each item has a number that you type into your personal headset, listen to the story behind the item or how the item came to be with Gary. The stories are sometimes simple and other times very moving. One such was about the FDNY brothers who were lost and their father (also FDNY) carrying out their remains. When you first arrive you are given the headset and watch a brief movie on what the museum is trying to achieve - you heard real chatter from FDNY and NYPD when the towers were first struck - so many first responders just headed into danger without any thought of their own personal safety. You are also allowed and encouraged to touch and handle some crosses that were made from World Trade Centre Metal and glass that is rare to locate from the site - they also now have a small piece of the American Airline plane that flew into building 1 for handling.I cannot recommend this Museum enough - please remember to book and consider this a MUST DO when visiting New York. I liked this better than the offical 9/11 Memorial as it more personal and the talk isn't as rehearsed. It is all about remembering and recovery.

Definitely worth a visit. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop was an amazing way to get insight of the people that lost their lives in 9-11 and the rescuers and clean up crew that worked tirelessly on the 9-11 site. A truly up close and personal experience.

Must visit. We stumbled across this hidden gem on our honeymoon by accident and debated going in having been to the official site the day before. I am so glad we went in.The workshop offers you an experience that I never thought possible.It is so well though out and well presented, attention to detail was at the forefront of the planning.It gives unique insight into the work that went on at Ground Zero following the horrific events of 9/11.The workshop is fronted by the official FDNY photographer from Ground Zero and his ability to demonstrate and tell the story is superb.If you only have the chance to visit one 9/11 museum I would strongly recommend you chose the Ground Zero workshop. The official 9/11 site is a tasteful memorial of that horrific day but to me it was a memorial. The Ground Zero Workshop is without doubt a museum that you must see.
Best Memorial in NYC!!. So in depth! To hear the story from Gary's point of view, in his voice, was truly special and moving. Intimate, tasteful, and raw.

Not a tourist trap!. I booked this tour because it was the first thing that popped on on Google. Because it's not anywhere near Ground Zero my wife and daughter were mocking me that I got caught in a tourist trap. I must admit I had my doubts too as we were lead into the room the size of a standard NYC apartment just containing some artifacts and photos on the wall. Gary (the photographer) however was there and gave us a brief introduction and showed us 2 short movies that already gave us a good idea of what was to come.The audio tour of the photos and artifacts is undoubtedly one of the most emotional ones I ever had. The voice of Gary is very touching to listen to and he describes everything in a very poetic way.My wife and daughter admitted they were very wrong and found it as moving as I did.This is truly the biggest small Museum of NYC.We visited Ground Zero in the morning and did this tour in the afternoon and found it just the right order to do things.

Workshop visit. We were privileged to meet Gary on our visit to this work shop which we visited 2 days after going round the 911 museum I found this very emotional but yet again a must do and would recommend to anyone to do this workshop well done gary

Raw and personalized accounts. Just when you think you have the wrong address, keep walking! New to the Gray line Flex Pass attraction list, this one room museum/photo gallery was a diamond in the rough find! Gary, the official photographer at Ground Zero, was so flexible and welcoming, as the actual hours of operation are noon -2, he was willing to stay open until 3 for us, and then more people filtered in thinking it closed at 4 also. It was eye opening listening to the personal stories behind each picture and artifact in the room. I didn't realize how many father/son/brothers were FDNY + NYPD. One of my favorite anecdotes was of the search and rescue dogs. Thanks again for sharing, Gary! It was an honor to meet you.

A unique and personal experience. Book ahead to be assured of your preferred day/time, and be on-time. And be brave, because this intimate experience can be an emotional one. But it's totally worthwhile for a unique and personal perspective of the horror that was 9/11 - both on the day, and in the weeks, months and years that followed.

Wonderful experience!. My friends and I went to this museum while we were on a school trip. I'm so glad we decided to go with our limited free time. It was a powerful and moving experience. When you travel to New York, you should really fit in this museum on your schedule. Also, our tour guide, Kelsey, was very hospitable and was knowledgable of the information.

Amazing experience. I first learned about this workshop on trip advisor & decided to check it out on our trip to New York. So glad we did. The exhibition is only in a small room but we spent almost 2 hours in there. Each item & photo has a number which you put into your headset & listen to the story & accounts. It is very moving. We enjoyed the 9/11 museum too but the workshop is more personal

A moving experience - must see!. Our entire family - including our 13-year-old daughter and 7-year-old son - agreed this was the highlight of our trip to NYC. The photos and artifacts - and the stories behind them - were powerful. This is much different than visiting a sterile museum - the opportunity to touch a piece of history and hear personal stories of the events that followed 9/11 was very emotional. We were fortunate to have Gary Marlon Suson leading our tour, and were moved by his photos and stories. We consider this to be a must-see for anyone visiting NYC, and have already recommended it to several friends planning trips there.

After the cameras had gone...... Make a point of visiting this amazing small museum when you're in NYC. It tells the story of the clear up and recovery after the terrible event on a personal level and you can't help but be touched by all the intimate details and tragedies that unfolded that day. Most of the displays and photos are from one photographer, Gary Suson, who, by chance, happened to be the one showing us around. Make sure you look up the opening times and prebook a tour. The daily opening hours change from day to day and it's located on the second floor of 420 West 14th St without any signs outside until it's open. Allow a couple of hours for the visit.

One of the best museums... in any city.. One of the best museums I have been to, it rivals the Anne Frank House (and was inspired by it). The lone official photographer of the Ground Zero recovery who created this unique collection was there for our visit. He's a wonderful guy to get to know, who shares his experience in a touching way. This was a great way for our kids to broach the events of 9/11 without graphic video and fear, but rather to focus on the bravery, sadness, and human spirit of the recovery. With his help, our son held a piece of fuselage of American Airlines flight 11 and shared how he felt. The artifacts and photos are poignant, and the entire experience is stunning. It is a must do for all families.

Best thing since slice bread.. We had a great time at the museum, you got to a lot of interesting things. Great pictures the emotions are definitely captured through the pictures. Getting a tour from Gary himself was great. Easy location and would definitely recommend going. It's at your own pace you get the listen to as much or as little narration as you like.
A little gem. Don't be put off by how small this place is ..it's a hidden gem, my two teenage sons loved it, I would highly recommend it to anyone..
Great insight. Great photos and story,s of the recovery ,good to actually touch some artefacts and too hear from the photographer himself very lucky.

If you visit one museum in NYC Ground Zero Museum is it! We came all the way from Adelaide, Australia. This is truly a unique, moving and interesting museum capturing the very essence of those dedicated to a sometimes hopeless rescue mission. We have all seen the same images of that horific day and this interactive display brings us closer to something very few of us are aware of. The Museum is presented with respect, care and a skillfully artistic eye. Thank you GARY MARLON SUSON for creating something that will educate those of us who remember that fateful day and generations to come. Well done to you all and your sponsors.

Take your children. I am so glad I discovered this little gem on Tripadvisor. Gary Suson was the only photographer allowed to shoot at Ground Zero, and his exhibition gives you a true sense of the brotherhood that existed among those who toiled to recover the fallen. It captures a piece of History that should never be forgotten. Hard- hitting but respectful and never maudlin, it is an ideal place to educate your kids about the events. Bite sized audio clips and being able to handle artefacts make it very accessible to them. We visited the main museum in the afternoon and found it much less impactful as it was very crowded and impersonal. We were honoured to meet Gary himself, who was training a new colleague. I consider it a privilege to have visited this wonderful place and purchased some books to help me teach the history of this event to my students in the UK. Thank you.

The tour gides where so good here. You can sit back and take the whole visit in , you need a hour or two you walk around with sadness but a feeling of wow look what they have done good local care and great locals to talk to well worth a visit

Small museum that makes a big impact. Upon arrival it wasn't as I'd imagined or expected. It was basically a converted studio apartment into a small museum of artefacts. I much prefer to do something like this than visit the 9/11 site itself. The site itself is all brand new and doesn't capture the true impact and emotion of 9/11 whereas this workshop takes you right back to the realities and emotion of what happened that day.The museum is based around the photography skills of Gary Marlon Suson who was the official authorised photographer of the aftermath from 9/11. We were fortunate enough he led the talk describing the events and the power behind his photographs and collated artefacts. Photography capturing emotion is a passion of mine and Gary really is phenomenally talented. Thanks to his talent to true emotion of that day will live forever through his books and photography.

Very Emotional and Moving. We were so pleased to have found this very small museum filled with so many artefacts and memorabilia - you are given a headset which guides you through the exhibition. We also did a tour with two firemen who were involved with the rescue operation. They relayed their story with a lot of emotion, and also walked us around the Memorial which really brought this sad day in history to life. A must-do if visiting NYC

Very Moving. Wow. A superb insight into the aftermath of 9/11. The work done by all the volunteers highlighted fantastically in pictures. The tour guide was off sick, and Gary Marlon Suson actually took our tour personally.

very moving. This is a must and very moving and paying your respects to the thousands that died , to hear the stories of the people phoning there families before the impact of the planes hitting the towers ,and seeing the photos of over 2900 people that died that day and the bravery of all the services .

simple museum yet stunning... After seeing the museum marked on a map, we made a decision to go. It is not the easiest place to find but well worth the effort of getting there. The museum although only the size of a one roomed flat is extremely moving and thought provoking. The personal headset lets you get engrossed in each and everyone of the photos and artefacts. Despite the fact of its small size we were there over 2 hours. The young guy who let us in was extremely pleasant and helpful, putting the sound on the screen so we could listen to the short presentation.
Well worth a visit. This is well done and very professional, very different to the first time we went just after 9/11. It is sombre place but also gives hope - well worth going if you have children

Small but full of treasures. The museum is a lot smaller than I expected (it's the size of an apartment room) but it has several unique treasures that - some of which you can hold and touch from the World Trade Center buildings. I highly recommend going if you are interested in 9-11. I really, really enjoyed it.

Thought-provoking, very personal and intimate. This museum is the size of an average living room. It is filled with photos, and each visitor gets a handset, taps in the number of the photo that is of interest, and hears a brief explanation of the photo, given by the photographer himself. It is a tapestry of pain and hope, highlighting known and unknown stories. I could have stayed there much longer, but at one point it just overwhelms. Highly recommended. We went before going to the 9/11 museum, which is much larger and crowded. I think that is indeed the best way to absorb it all. I have to say that the photos are stuck in my mind ever since the visit, and even though I am very well versed in the events of 9/11, this museum managed to leave its mark on me.

Unforgettable Experience. The GZ Museum Workshop allows visitors to see never before seen photos of ground zero. It also tells viewers the story behind these photos. We were able to touch real steal and glass from the twin towers. It was an unforgettable experience

Tucked away treasure. This was certainly not what we anticipated; it was far better. This tiny, studio-sized museum is very interactive and very moving, especially to people from the tri-state area or affected by 9/11 directly.

ground zero. The 911 museum was breath taking. To see all theartifacts that were saved, pictures of firemen savingpeople, videos, everything was very emotional. To seeall there things brought back instantly feelings of that day the towers wet down. Don't miss this site, well worth the effort it may take to get there.BUY TICKETS ahead of time...ticket lines very long.
my son loved this. fun memorable and educationalhe made things to bring home and show his class teacher and friends. great idea for the children

Small but good. This is completely separate from the actual 9/11 site, which is where we went initially, only to be told out was several blocks away, we should have read the instructions! When we did get there, it's a doorway on a main shopping street near the highline. You have to press a bell to get in. We had a really interesting overview and a film, them allowed to go around the room with our audio guide. Considering everything is in one small room, it's a good couple of hours worth. Really interesting and moving.

Got to be seen when visiting New York. We showed up just as Trey was closing for the day but he still allowed us to walk in and spend an amazing couple of hours in this seemingly hidden gem of a museum. Stunning photography and some artifacts that move you beyond belief. These are coupled with the story behind each and every one told by Gary in your own personal handset. We were also able to handle some pieces of steel and glass from the site which was surreal. Very in depth insight into the events that followed a day nobody will ever forget. You are able to buy some images and books which are unique to the museum. Our visit was made even more special by the arrival of Gary...it was an honour to meet him and hear a couple of his stories first hand plus he also signed our books. Amazing experience. Super friendly staff. An absolute must see while in NYC.. Thanks for a great day. Scott and Andria.

Better than the 911 Memorial Museum. We visited the 911 Memorial Museum at ground zero directly before this workshop. We much prefer the 911 workshop. Why? I found the 911 Memorial musuem had many personal belongings of the people that died on that day, which I found disturbing. The 911 workshop museum was much more focused on the recovery after the attack. It captured the spirit, the dedication of the Firemen and the painstaking recovery of the victims of this event. It did this with reverence, respect and care. The photos and stories were amazing. The whole experience was far more intimate. So if you can only attend one place. Come here.

Wonderful small museum that is well worth the visit. Fascinating collection of artefacts from Ground Zero collected by the official photographer to Ground Zero. Wonderful introduction to Ground Zero that not many experienced first-hand. Best thing is some of the profits from the museum are continually donated to charities associated with Ground Zero.

Educational. Photographer Gary Suson recap of the Ground Zero recovery process puts one at the site. Gary's photographs & stories help you understand & attempt to feel what the workers felt during this long emotional & physical draining recovery effort. Museums only downfall, it lacked signage, I walked passed the place a few times before someone finally put a sign on the sidewalk. If you decide to go (& it is worth the visit), the Asics shoe store is right beside it, wait outside for the museum worker to greet you. The museum is in a room on the second floor.
Informative and thought provoking. The story of 9/11 is told very well and the personal stories re moving. A very thought provoking and memorable visit.
It gets you!. It is really sad been there and remembering everything that happend on that day. You can watch all around people faces and it gets you.

An unbelievable experience. This museum, hidden away and very intimate, shows a wealth of exhibits from inside the devastated WTC by a photographer who captured some amazing images. The display gives mixed emotions and grilled s you from the outset. Give this place a visit above nearly everything else in the city. You will not be disappointed.
Beautiful experience. Must see in NYC! Absolutely stunning and peaceful! Words can not describe what is like to be on a such remarkable place!

The true memorial.... If you want a true representation of what occurred that fateful day on September 11th 2001... There is no other way but to experience this museum. This place can give you the all the emotions and sense of that day without overwhelming you. Not to knock the other 9/11 memorial but that place has a nasty whiff of commercial corporate about it. The ground zero museum feels it has input from those who have experienced this tragedy first hand. It is the true 9/11 memorial.

Must see. I can't write too much about the museum without getting emotional. If you're in New York, take the time to visit and pay your respects. Unless you are completely heartless, I guarantee it will be an experience that will touch you.

Incredible.. A friend and I decided to visit on our last day in New York, and we are so glad we did. The museum is tiny - just a single room - but is filled to the brim with stories and emotions pertaining to the recovery efforts in the months following 9/11. The small space creates an experience that is personal, intimate, and deeply moving. Book online, and allow ~2 hours to take it all in.
heartbreaking. To visit this is heartbreaking. To see and hear the destruction of lives is awful. I had to leave after a short while as it was so saddening and depressing.

A New York Must See. Don't miss this marvelous experience!! It is a must when you are in New York. Heart wrenching and emotional experience that will stay with you forever. One of New York's newest and greatest tourist destinations.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop > 9/11 Memorial Museum. Visited the Ground Zero Workshop the day after visiting the 9/11 Memorial Museum at Ground Zero.Of the two I would 100% recommend this museum. Whereas the memorial museum at ground zero has lots of artifacts, it lacks a personal touch and is almost overwhelming.All of the artifacts at the Ground Zero Workshop tell a story which has been perfectly captured by Gary Susson.There are some truly amazing artifacts at this museum, each of which you will learn the story behind how they were recovered from Ground Zero during the many months that Gary spent there.I would urge anyone visiting New York to visit this museum. By visiting you are also helping some of the charities that have been set up following 9/11.During our visit we were lucky enough to meet Gary who was happy to talk through some of his experiences during the recovery.
Holiday. Very moving and worthwhile. It's the only source of pics at the site he was the only authorized photographer. The audio that is with the pics is pheominib. I'm

A must see. I wondered if this would be a rather sentimental exhibition of 9/11 - I couldn't have been more wrong - it is very good, educational, well constructed and moving as well as thought provoking. I was told the average time spent here is an hour - I was there three. Well worth the effort.

Very beautiful and touching tribute.. Took my family (two kids under 12) here to show them the memorial and further explain what happened on 9/11. We went to both fountains and talked about what happened. It was a very beautiful tribute to the fallen and we talked at length about the people's names inscribed there and what happened. It was very powerful and very educational. The only sad part is that some people there were acting as though it was a fun attraction and taking funny selfies and laughing and carrying on. I saw a husband and wife remembering their lost son there (my wife asked them) during the Thanksgiving holiday, while a group of friends (10 ft from them) were talking a bunch of glamour, funny pics (e.g., like holding up the Tower of Pisa, etc.). For some it is a solemn place and for others it is an attraction to see without acknowledging the horror of that day.

Amazing.... This is an amazing and very moving collection of photos and artifacts from the Ground Zero recovery site. It is so tastefully done and well presented in an intimate setting...perfect for the subject matter. It is a must see museum on any visit to NYC.

Unbelievable. We visited as a group of five and were joined by another two couples. When Trey the tour guide explained what we were about to see I was a little sceptical. How could one small room keep us interested for two hours? How wrong was I. The time flew by. After watching a short video we were all given audio handsets to allow us to wander around listening to different narratives. The photos are just amazing! Feelings ranged from uplifted to totally horrified. This is one exhibition that should not be missed.

Great museum. This is a very small museum with not many people at any one time (unlike the 9/11 Memorial). There are many photographs and articles that are numbered. You get an audio headset and go around clicking on the numbered exhibits to hear the story behind it. All of it was interesting.
Great items to remember the museum. Be sure to take the time to explore the Workshop as well as the museum. The staff is very helpful and friendly.

A Must. While this museum is in the Chelsea District and away from the 911 Memorial, it is a short subway ride, you must go to it! It is well worth your time. Allow at least 2 hours and bring tissue. You will hear first hand stories and see photos that tell it all!While this museum can be emotional and heartbreaking, 911 was real and we must not forget it. The stories have to be told and we must hear them!
Well done. It is such a tribute to al that have fallen. There is all kinds of items found at ground zero. It is very sad.

A msut. Seems this is part of paying your respects to the victims of this terrible tragedy. Take the time to listen to the survivors. It reinforces how people continue to suffer because of this senseless occurance and to not repeat it.

Very moving,. We were very moved by the Museum. They have not sensationalised the event at all, just made you aware of the people who died, the heroism of the rescue workers and given a wonderful but sad desription of the events of the day.
Great. This place has so much history behind it but with the whole feeling of emptiness from what happened here

A SUITABLE MONUMENT TO A WORLD IMPACTING TRAGEDY. We spent about 30 minutes in a line to buy tickets and then another 15 minutes in a line to get in, however once inside it is really worth the wait and the entrance fee for a couple of old people was $18 each.The memory of the 2001 abomination is well done, considerate and touching in the extreme. We both loved it and left in a somber state.Amazing the people you meet in funny places; my wife (for all you Aussies who will understand) met Ita Buttrose in the dunny!. Enough said, if you are in NYC you must visit this great memorial to the 9/11 terrorist atrocity!

A very special place to remember. I found this amazing space shortly after it first opened. The photos capture the essence and sorrow of that tragic day and you will be sure to shed a tear. Touch glass from the Windows of the World, hold a fallen firemans helmet, see the clock that stopped when the towers came down. The small entry fee goes straight to the charities that support the families and children who lost their loved ones. This is definitely on my list of ten things you must do in NYC.

Never forget!. This place was breathtaking, my girlfriend at the time was super cold and one of the staff members gave her a jacket off her own back, and gave us a personal and private tour and run through with full in-depth story telling of how everything happened, and what happened after. The staff here have a huge passion for what they are doing,

Great little Museum. This is a very special museum - Gary Suson has captured the aftermath of 911 with amazing clarity and respect for the fallen - strongly recommend a visit from anyone who wants to understand the human tragedy and bravery of fire fighters and emergency services on that fateful day.
Very moving and sad.. We knew we wanted to see this but I was very upset at the feeling of sadness around the area, I'm glad I went but it was a sad experience.
Interessing. Excellent, great history, an informative museum for the brutal past occasion, a must place to visit.
Emotional place. Interesting place but made me feel very cold and very sad, for the people that have gone and the people that have never been found.

Great Experience. I wasn't thrilled about going to the place that something so tragic happened but it was a very "eye opening" experience for my 9 year old son. Completely worth it. We both learned a lot and he has a new found respect.
great. Great place and very interesting, allowed to take photos and audio was great, not for small cjildren

Sad memories of 9/11 but very interesting.. It was very emotional to visit this museum. I feel so sorry for those victims & family of the 9/11. This museum is very interesting. The video presentation is good.

Probably a must see.. This is an impressive and memorable venue. Buy your tickets ahead of time and download them to your phone for quicker entry.
Exhibits and displays are truly interesting, though you may suffer from overload if you spend more than 30 minutes in there.
A great tribute to 9/11. It's a nice place to visit to get a wonderful experience to remember the fallen here. It's both sad and memorable.
9/11. Must see for anyone who has seen 9/11 horribleness. Payss homage to those we lost. Tactful, serene, and very meanigful. New museum on sight is a must.

Very impressive place!. Very impressive, every item there has too much to tell about that happened in 911 ! Not matter what country you're from, when you walk in, you will feel all kind of emotions! The place smell very special, it's how everything just happened few months ago and not years!
Would go back. This shop had it all and the security person was very helpful there where books and tee shirts magnets, the motorbike was really nice just inside the front door.

Very educational. This is an eye-opener. It is a story of real people killed by terrorists. The artifacts are represented in a true to life form. It starts from the beginning of the attack and the last artifacts are from the Heros that tried to save as many people as they could and ended up losing their lives. Very somber
Ground Zero. Moving, a must see whilst in New York. Be sure to allow plenty of time to get around the Museum, there is certainly a lot to see.
New York. You must visit this if your in New York . Very moving when you visit it but well worth it. Excellent value for money $20 .
Never forget. A very sensible narration of these dreadfull hours. Some testimonies and recordings are extremely moving?.

Ground Zero. It had profound effect on us how anyone could inflict such a horror on anybody/nation.
Ground zero is now a dramatic “tourist attraction” in New York and new World Trade Tower is completed.
Jack

America still stands tall. Certainly a must to see in NY, but you have to have that deep feeling about what happened here to really enjoy. Regardless of age worthwhile & educational so much more than TV coverage.

So Incredibly Moving. Unbelievable emotional experience to relive that day. The museum is first class. Very tastefully done for such a incredibly horrible moment in time. Everyone in American needs to visit.
New and kid friendly. Something for kids to do while you are taking in the sights. Space is limited but the activities are wonderful for all ages.

Great Museum. We visited this museum before we went to the 9/11 museum at the site. I really enjoyed this museum because it gave you a lot of insight into the background stories of the people who lived through this tragedy. I found the stories of the rescuers and the aftermath of the actual event very interesting and heartbreaking too.
Great hands on museaum. Nothing to dislike. Just like they recommend on their website, a must to do, before going to the 9/11 memorial
Moving. Frey moving and very well done. Get there early to get tickets. There is free admission on Thursday afternoon if you line up and get tickets.

Don't rush through, give yourself 1/2 day.. There is a lot to read and see so give yourself plenty time. There were many people in the museum but did not deter us from enjoying it. It is very well done.

So appreciative of Tripadvisor comments 'go here before visiting the 9/11 memorial'. All because of TripAdvisor, my husband and I booked a place at this small museum. It takes two hours to fully view and appreciate the museum and its artefacts. The guide was special and completely dedicated for the group to experience the preciousness of such a place as the museum. I highly recommend seeing this museum prior to the Ground Zero memorial. I would split it over two days. First this museum, then the next day a tour at Ground Zero explaining the grounds followed by many hours spent in the main museum..
Wonderful Museum Workshop. The Ground Zero Museum workshop is very educative and worth attending. We enjoyed visiting the Museum and participating in the workshop.
Fitting tribute. This is a fitting tribute to the site. A fine facility for all the family with plenty of interactive activities.
Must see!. An enviable part of visiting NYC these days! You will be inspired and find it very interesting and impressive. Don't miss this moving exhibit and celebration of life.

Definitiely A Must See!. Our group went to the tours at the World Trade Center site before visiting this museum - that's the way to do it in my opinion. This Ground Zero tour, however, gives a different perspective to the whole event and is most definitely NOT simply a repeat of the 9/11 tours. At WTC you learn about the "Day of" experiences and events - at Ground Zero you learn about the 9 months it took to recover evidence and remains. I know, sounds like it would be gruesome, but it is done in such a respectful and UNgruesome way that makes it a beautiful tribute to the efforts of all the agencies involved in the process. The photographs by Gary Suson are placed around the walls for you to visit as you wish - each one has its own narration (you are given an audio headset) by Gary himself of what the photo is about and what was happening at the time. Just a beautiful narration! And this allows you to pace yourself however you see fit. Gary was even at the museum the day we visited, so we got to speak with him personally. It was a very moving experience - don't be fooled by the building façade - it really is the "Biggest LITTLE Museum in New York" -- DEFINITELY A MUST SEE!

Everyone should visit!. This is an amazing, but somber place. The layout was well thought out and the displays were thought provoking and made you feel like you were actually there. At most times even though there were many people there...you could hear a pin drop.

A must visit if you are in New York. The experience of visiting the Museum was for me both sympathetic and touching shows the elements of the devastation to not one God twin towers but the sour rounding area and the lives taken that day which must no be forgotten. Haunting but serene I am so privileged to have made this visit .
Very moving. This is a very moving tribute to the New York people and the remarkable way the city responded to the 9/11 tragedy. A new appreciation of the effect to the community.
for all ages. WOW! I came with my friends child and we both enjoyed! For all ages, and all interests. This is a workshop everyone should attend.

Mixed feelings there is so much history there but the memory of all the people that died there is daunting. The things at the Museum are very interesting but the memories of all the fallen and killed there is overwhelming

Good workshop. Excellent tour with knowledgeable guide. Was good value for the money and a worthwhile experience. Leant about some of the stories behind 9/11 and made the trip round the museum more interesting.

Untold Feelings. Very touching, interesting and lots of memories. You revive all. It's kind of heartbreaking and emotional at the same time. They catch everything from that day.
I recomend you buy your tickets on advance and have a time reservation too.
recommended but give yourself enough time. so powerful and poignant would thoroughly recommend. museum is thought provoking and moving - a must for anyone affected by these tragic events
very intresting place to visit. yo can know about the terrible moment tha the city had and testimonies about that day, and buy stuf that the money help victims family

Small, cozy museum. To set expectations, this museum is very small. The stories are on an audio player. You begin the session by watching a video. There are some artifacts that you can touch but there are some that you cannot. We enjoyed the museum but if you are strapped for time and have seen the 9/11 museum then you can skip this museum.
Touching experience. Well done, telling the story of the people who died there. I like how the place reflect the hard experiences suffer by the people involved on the event.

Fantastic. Absoultey fantastic. We spent the whole day at the museum, very interesting and emotional ( as we were at the World Trade Centre in January 2001 with our small children). A definite must see in NYC.

Memorial for departed souls. I was impressed by the museum of ground zero it was tiny but had a great audio visual presentation of what lead to the 9/11 attacks and what the families felt and showed some artifacts of what were left behind from that day. They made this place to keep the memory of those who lost there life on that day,.

A must for every American. Every citizen and visitor should come and experience this incredible reminder to us all that on September 11, 2001 the world changed. I don't recommend this for young children. I don't think it's fair to expect children to behave with the respect this location demands. I saw several people with children who were giggling and touching and I felt this was disrespectful. This is an extremely emotional visit. I feel this museum has done a remarkable job of respecting those who perished that day and continuing to honor the survivors and families who lost so much. Give your self time here, there isso much to take in and experience.

Very humbling and essential to visit. Very sobering and essential to visit if you are in New York. I am not an emotional person but this place managed to stir some quite strong emotions. Just remember your tissues and take your time to see everything on display.

a must in n.y.c.. i can't evevn begin to tell you how this small museum moved me,you will be in tears by the time you leave,its very hidden and you have to have an appointment,it definitely is a must!

Very well done. Didn't really want to come here but I am glad we did. It is very well done and many thoughtful ways to remember the people who lost their lives on 9/11. While beautifully done, it is a moving and sad reminder of that day's horrific events.
Ground Zero ….Super Hero's. Moving, Inspiring and Thought provoking..Makes you thank your lucky stars and pray for the hero's who's luck ran out on that day.
family friendly fun. there was a lot of interesting things to see and do-very family friendly and informative with activities and novelties everyone will enjoy

Sober experience. It is a must to visit when you are in Manhattan, New York.It is hard to fathom the reality that took place on 9/11 the enormity of the incident makes its a graphic and somber experience. The contrast of the heroism of the victims and survivors and the bottomless of human depravity for those who committed this atrocity is near impossible to describe. Another harsh lesson in Human History.
Very mooving. A very special place, the museum is incredible so much information. Bring the tissues it's very mooving. Expect to be there for at least a couple of hours.

Ground Zero Workshop. What an experience. We did it as family and it is a must to do in NY for young and old. It takes you to the time after 9/11. The memorabilia is unbelievable. After this great visit it is good to have lunch at the Chelsea Market, which is around the corner, and then from there do the HighLine walk to Penn station.
So much entertainment just in one park. So much entertainment into the park that it is not possible to visit everything (just the main topics) in one day.
Ground Zero Museum. You have to visit here and it's very quiet and thought evoking and very sad, but you should visit. It's part of our history and makes you realise what New York City went through.
Inspiring. A must on a visit to NYC, moving, thought provoking and inspiring, I went with my partner who is a firefighter in England, lost for words for most of the visit.
Moving Experience.. Great videos and details of 9/11 and many artifacts. So much to see it is overwhelming. Maybe break it up into 2 visits.
Touching and Emotional. A beautiful and sincere tribute. Touching. It truly brought to light the impact 9/11 had on all of America.

Humbling. We visited on a recent hol to NYC.. .Wanted to visit and just think and reflect. Felt it important our boys visited too having explained all about it in great detail in the months prior to the trip. We were humbled simply to be there and felt n overwhelming sense of peace and serenity which was lovely. God Bless to all involved .

1st Stop. Very educational and emotional! Tip to parents taking young children--educate them on what happened. As a teacher and traveling to the museum with teachers, we heard several young kids asking very loudly if people were dead or died and a lot of other questions. Striking WTC Photography and Artifacts - Intimate Setting. Located on West 14th Street in what had been photographer Gary Suson's studio, the Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a classic NYC setting - small and intimate - in which to show Suson's extensive collection of photos and artifacts from the World Trade Center site. He began shooting from the roof of this building shortly after the first plane struck, and he continued throughout the months of the extensive clean up and recovery effort, up close and personal to say the least, with the blessing and support of the NYFD. The work offers striking depictions of the chaos and confusion of the debris pile, and of the people who struggled so long and hard to clear the grounds and recover what they could of those who were lost. The focus is largely on the efforts and sacrifices of New York firefighters, so many of whom converged on the sight to search for sons, brothers, fathers, and friends. Many photos depict the respectful removal of remains, and it is clear that Suson had every intention of being respectful in his documentation. The photos and artifacts, helped by the quaint setting, evoke strong feelings from that historical time and place. The official (so to speak) 9/11 Museum and Memorial at the World Trade Center are, obviously, impressive must-see destinations. But to me they offer neither intimacy nor a setting that permits reflection. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop, however, achieves these remarkably well, thanks to Suson's extraordinary work.

Impressive. Very proffessionaly made. Nearly nothing was mentioned about the role of a former President G.W. Bush
Lost for words. A must visit, but be prepared to be upset. Very well laid out and thought provoking. Lines to get in were very reasonable.

Incredible experience. Words could not describe what has been done here. The memorial and museum are worth a visit if your in New York. Incredible experience and a fantastic way to pay your respects to those that have lost there lives on September 9th 2001 and 1993. I would advise anyone to go. The feeling and emotion is incredible.

Amazing, thought provoking place. A great place. Our lack of subway knowledge meant my friend and I turned up half an hour before our tour, however they were very accommodating and we actually got to meet Gary. We booked this museum without knowing much about what to expect so unfortunately didn't realise he was the founder of the museum and the one who took the many photos until after he left. Which luckily for him meant he got away without us bombarding him with questions! The museum was so touching and the way it is set out means it was very intimate (there was only two of us in the museum so it seemed quite personal). All our questions were answered and everyone was super friendly. I would definitely recommend this experience to anyone visiting New York.. it was possibly one of the best attractions we went to. I wish I had taken the opportunity to ask Gary more about his experience!
Very interesting and emotional.. Lots of exhibits about ground zero and the 9/11 attacks. Had a small gift shop. My mom started crying.

Heart-Wrenching. The outside of the museum is beautiful. Inside is a tribute to the American spirit. The quilts and the pieces of metal silenced everyone. A sense of respect was quietly displayed by all. The room with the videos and other reminders of the attack were hard to watch. This is a must for any visit to New York.

Good if you already know. Great if you want to learn.. We lived in NJ on 9/11. We had moved just a couple weeks before from NC. My husband was in the news business. We had neighbors who lost husbands, fathers, friends and other family members. So we know. It was deeply touching to review the facts of those harrowing days. If you know nothing about 9/11 you will come away with a full understanding of the human toll, the political events which led up to that day and what we have all done to respond to this tragedy. It is historical, artistic, beautiful, sad, and delightful. The power of the human spirit will move you.

Truly moving. A fine museum dedicated to the tragic events of 9/11. It's done with a lot of respect and preserves this sad slice of history for ages to come. No trip to NYC would be complete without a visit there.
Moving experience. Well worth a visit. Get there early to avoid the queues. We booked a tour which allowed us to go straight in without queuing and I think was worth the modest extra cost.

Sentimental. Please be sure to know this solely focuses on the aftermath and the site clean-up. This is still a great place to learn about the impact to NYC and the workers involved and the workers who lost their lives in the events after the twin towers collapsed.

A good 2-3 hour tour. This 9/11 memorial is great - somber but great. It is a must see. Get advance tickets so you don't have to wait in a line. The audio tour is not necessary unless you don't speak English.

Thought provoking. An amazing experience of the most harrowing type. Created below the shadow of the old twin towers this museum contains a mass of material from that dreadful day. The most thought provoking being the room showing all the photographs of the nearly 3000 victims.I came out and walked for some many yards before I again engaged my family in conversation.An absolute must if you visit NYC........

Ground Zero Memorial And Museum.. This place has changed a lot since I was last here about three years after the tragedy. The fountains are a stunning tribute to those individuals who died in each tower block. We also saw flowers being placed by the NYPD on the names of those who died from the emergency services. Tuesdays from 4pm are free entry for the museum so we queued a short while for the tickets. We didn't do a guided tour but spent a couple of hours wandering around at our own speed. You could easily spend half a day here reading and seeing everything. A lot to take in and as everyone says it's very moving and makes you realise the huge scale of the tragedy. Especially seeing all the faces of the victims on the wall and some of their personal belongings that were found in the rubble. We thought the whole idea of intertwining the memorial and the museum underground was very clever.

A breathtaking experience.. A thoroughly breathtaking experience. We spent the whole day in and around this area taking it all in and it was necessary. Physically and emotionally exhausting but definitely worth it.

Unbelievable Experience in NYC. Must see and visit, didn't know what to expect when going into the Museum but we were very impressed at how tastefully it had been done. A lot to take in from start to finish. Be sure to visit the museum. RIP
Place to visit if you want a flashback. Its a place to be if you are those people like me that want to remember everything & be part of the history.

A Great Tribute. First allow for more than the two hours that they suggest you will need. In order to take in everything you will be there for more like 3 or 4 hours. It's a must see and is very well done. There are some very intense and emotional portions so be prepared. I found it to be very informative and even though I was glued to the TV for days after 9/11, I learned things from this museum I didn't know. Make reservations for early in the morning and several days in advance.

Great historical museuem. Didnt know what to expect of this museum , but once inside and going down a level the memories began from what I saw on TV from this sad day. Great layout and lost to view and see.

911 memorial museum. very emotional to see. A very well done and respectful memorial sight to all those who suffered from this and also a great memorial for those to learn and get feeling of this tragic, historical event.

Sad. Be prepared for a very moving experience. Exceptional quality presentation and exhibits. This is a tribute to the people that lost their lives and a credit to the people of New York and the U.S. A must do.
Amazed. Brings the whole thing to life and it is most moving to see the depiction of the events. You will be surprised the details they exhibit.
