Very moving and tasteful. We didn't know quite what to expect but were very impressed at the tasteful and thought provoking way this has been done. Be sure to visit the museum. It's difficult to describe, suffice to say you will consider the effort very worthwhile.
Must go to ground zero. book the tour guide she was sensitive and well informed. We spent 3 hours there and found it moving and thoughtful.

Fantastic. First class visit. We spent about 2 1\2 hours here, for about 2 of those hours I was in tears!! Everything was very thoughtfully displayed to give maximum information but in a calm and peaceful manner. Lots of areas to sit and quietly contemplate all that was on view. Very special place, so well thought out.

Most moving experience of my life. Just go. And take your time. And remember your visit for the rest of your life. I feared a typically 'American' museum but no - this was tasteful, heartbreaking, sobering and educational. Easily the highlight of my trip to this amazing city.
Emotional & Moving. We did it fairly quickly and it took 2 hours. If you read and looked at everything plan half a day. Spend time there it is worth it. Lots of info and interesting artifacts.

A moving experience in New York City. Anyone travelling to New York must visit Ground Zero Museum. The architect has truly designed the Museum brilliantly, a moving experience of what happened on the 11th September that the world should not forget. And reminding us of the people who died. A visit here has to be made for a poignant reminder of this terrible terrorist attack that must never happen again
Excellent powerful experience. Difficult to get there...used uber...very moving experience.....use the audio tour.....visit le district afterwards.....go early gets crowded

Beautifully Done. We visited the memorial thinking we may be there for an hour or so, only to leave 4 hours later. From the remembrance ponds through to the museum, everything has been beautifully and tastefully put together. A beautiful way to remember the souls who lost their lives on 9/11. Highly recommended.

Stunning. Really brought home the shock and horror of this terrible event and made you realise how many lives were impacted , including those who helped to help others. The scale of this tragedy is really graphically presented by this excellent exhibition.
Lovely Memorial. It's a must to visit, I left with tears running down my face thinking of all those who lost their lives. NYC have done an amazing job, of keeping those memories alive.

Very emotional place. The whole experience is tastefully done, very informative and a place you must visit. When you watch the footage and listen to the phone calls from the Towers, the emergency services and the planes you will be moved.
A somber reminder. Take as much time as you need. And then take more. This is not a place to take young children Many artifacts and much much more

A Must See!. This museum has been done with impeccable taste and dignity. Don't expect to leave without being deeply moved. I would rate this as a must see in New York. Well done New York on an extremely well planned, thought out and sensitively displayed tragic historical event.

Breathtaking experience. Couldn't recommend this museum more highly. Intimate experience, getting up close and personal with some rare images, footage and artefacts from ground zero. Trey was happy to answer any questions we had but also allowed us plenty of time to look around the exhibit ourselves and listen to the audio.

Very tastefully done. As a Brit, the impact of what happened on that fateful day had never truly hit home until I visited the museum. A very emotional setting but done with the upmost respect for those who lost their lives on that tragic day.

Touching. Well worth going to see this as it is part of our history. I found it very informative but also very sobering. I found the staff very knowledgeable and friendly. Felt I could have stopped longer just out of respect.

A must. Ground Zero take some time to go through and with construction in the area, it can be somewhat challenging to get to but it is worth the trip, I would suggest skipping the 15 min film on the building of the site, but , The museum is of great value and is a must visit for all who are in New York
inspiring site. You really get the feel of what happened that awful day. Watch the film first and then be prepared to see all the memories so expertly exhibited.
Do not miss out. Amazing experience, one not to miss, overwhelming and well organised. Worth buying the gudied audio guide as it gave much more information.

Moving. It is an educational and informative trip, with exciting and moving accounts of that terrible day. It is a must see, great for kids and families. Don't be scared to be educated about what makes a city and what binds it together.
An amazingly touching tribute. Visited with my husband. We both enjoyed it & spent considerable time there viewing everything. A very touching & well thought out tribute. Well worth the visit.

A very interesting day if a bit chilling but a must do. we booked in for a guided tour and was great, well worth it. Your guide takes you around, explains things well and answers any questions. takes about 1 hour then explore museum at own pace after.
Moving Experience. We loved the authenticity of this museum. Having lived through 9/11 in NYC I found it inspiring and moving.
Hard to fine words. The museum was very nice. I had to leave the museum more than half way through. It was hard to see. I will go again but will book a tour guide!

The most poignant event of our stay. We met a tour guide from the museum at the landmark Irish Pub on the corner of ground zero 'Oharas' that became a hub and gathering spot for first responders after it was repaired. She told us her story of 911 and her first husband. It was the most meaningful part of our trip.
Beauty From Disaster. Love what the City of New York have done with this tragic location by turning a disaster area into a plce of such serenity and peacefullness the Museum is very moving

A must for everyone. Young, old, American, whatever you are and wherever you're from, this is a must in NYC. Such a beautiful tribute to the people who suffered and were involved. Very interesting in every way.
Incredible!!. a very moving experience,not to be missed, beautifully done without being OTT,staff very helpful and knowledgable

do not miss this. you cant go whithout visiting the groun zero museum,
its part of the history!! we went in group, and we all get touches about what had happend there and how it is present to visitors

Very Emotional To See and Hear. Ground Zero is gut-wrenching. Words cannot express the feelings you get from visiting the area. You can almost sense the tragedy in your mind as you walk thru the exhibits
Weird feeling to be there. It was so sad to see all the videos and the pieces of the building as well as people's personal belonging. So glad I went tho to see the museum for myself.
Very moving. Liked the fact they had a survivor from 9 11 to give a talk on her experience on the day it happened.
A must to visit. Wonderful museum very interesting and moving ,there were a lot of people moving about. Nothing to dislike

9/11 excellent museum. Do not miss it !. Wonderful museum. Need to queue 2 times but ( tickets and access) but is worth!
Consider min 3 h inside to see enough details.
Ground zero. This was a both sad and happy experience due to its nature. I loved all the information around telling you were things had come from.

Heartbreaking Photography. This was a very awesome experience. We were not affected personally from the attacks on the Wirld Trade Center, but this experience brought us closer to what they all went through.

Moving and Emotional. As a foreigner, we never truly know the magnitude of a disaster if it doesn't occur in our own city. Being in the ground zero museum was truly moving and I have a new found respect for all the people involved in the making of the museum and the fire fighters of the dreadful day. It brought me to tears. Some of the things I saw in this museum will forever be etched into my mind. A must see!
Best thing we did in New York. The museum has been done so well it was fascinating and very moving. The museum is a must! Buy your tickets in advance, or get there early to avoid waiting.

Worth a visit. very informative,and full of objects and photos...obviously put together with love and respect.Also right next to the high line so you can go to both places in the same morning/afternoon
A Must When in NYC. This Museum should not be missed. It presents the tragedy of 911 in a most appropriate manner. It reminds us of just how fragile life is and how quickly evil can take it away.
A FITTING TRIBUTE. Nothing to dislike, tastefully and brilliantly done. Great tribute to all who were affected by the tragedy

Quite humbling. We wandered around the museum and there were hundreds of people inside but there was hardly any words spoken, which I was thankful for because it was very emotional to be inside and one could not imagine what must have gone through people's mind when this tragedy happened. My heart went out to everyone of the people who lost their lives that day.
A Very Well Done Museum. Extremely moving, well done, and very educational. Our Granddaughters insisted we go, and they spent 3 hours going through the exhibits. Highly recommend!

must see. A very truly somber place but a must see to really understand the true impact, it tells now the true story of what happened with real objects as well as a cinema telling the stories of all involved and where they are today

Beautiful. is beautiful peaceful and how we New Yorkers came together As one we put thru that tragic day and we survived I'm proud to be a New York and proud of the beautiful job they did and how people respect the gifts that are left for those who passed away that day.
A very moving experience. A very moving experience. Allocate a full day to visit the museum. It was captivating and very emotional. Well worth the entrance fee. Best value of all our visits.
Moving. Very moving experience it really brings home the catastrophic events of that day. fragments of the buildings show the enormity and horror. Worth a visit.

A must do. As hard as it is to be reminded of the happenings on 9/11 this museum is very special for the survivors and the bereaved families and friends. We both had tears several times but we are pleased we decided to visit the freedom tower. Special mention goes to the wonderful survivor tree...what a story. Best curator the lady who tells the story of the staircase where so many people escaped the buildings .
Nine / eleven. Very powerful and moving experience. Brought the reality of that horrific event home. Found the transcripts and phone calls reduced us to tears.

Worth the trip.. It is a small venue but worth it. I liked the stories that you get from the photographer about the items on display. It was eerie to look at the clock from the PATH station that was stopped at the time the tower fell, and all of the personal items that might be on or in your desk at any given time and mean really very little but took on a much different meaning because you know what happened to their owners.

Exceptionally well presented. Considering the subject matter, it was presented exceptionally well. Very compelling and moving. We went with our children, the youngest of which was 7. We were nervous about whether it would be appropriate but the museum displays were excellent. Where there were more disturbing imaginary, you were given sufficient warning.Well worth a visit.

Worth the time. It's hard to say you enjoyed this museum because of it's basis but I really found it to be extremely well done. It was sobering and emotional but well worth the time we spent there. It's a moving tribute to all who risked their lives to help and those who perished simply by being at work that day.
ground zero. the thought & work that went into this project is truly wonderful. What more is there to say, except a visit is very worthwhile.
Ground zero. This spot is hallowed ground. Very moving presentation in the museum. Audio tour is good but no direction for visitors where to start . We were on #4 before we knew which way to go.

Museum. Paid my first trip to the newly opened Ground Zero Museum. A beautiful museum space dedicated to the tragedy of the victims of 9/11. Full of powerful news imagery, artefacts and memories from that tragic day in 2001. You cannot help but be moved by the experience.
awasome. We spent 7 hrs in the museum. It was the most awasome experience. This is a great tribute to the people who lost their lives.

Ground Zero Museum. Very well-done museum and our two hours there were barely enough. We could have spent two more if we had the time. The Memorial is also very moving and worth seeing when you're in NYC. Easy to get to by the subway.

Such a presence. A very moving and sobering experience with everyone displaying total respect for those involved, hero's everyone.The artefacts on display really brought it home what went on that day and although it was in total disbelief on the day it happened from where I was in the UK to see it in the museum will be forever imprinted on myself and my daughters mind after our visit.
A must when in New York. This is a must visit attraction . A quiet , calm , sad , eerie at times place . You will leave here with a feeling of sadness .

A must in NYC!. You can't visit New York without visiting the Ground Zero Museum. I have seen it take shape over the years but did not realise how huge it is on the inside.A must!If you are not moved by the visit there is something wrong with you.Only drawback-the queing if you have not pre-purchased tickets

A must do. Showing our respects to those who were involved or died on 9/11. It was very moving and informative. Suggest you take the tour to get a better insite to the day that changed our lives for ever.
Excellent. Allow lots of time as there is so much to see and read. Very moving. Try to get there early as there can be quite a wait for a time slot

Good. Is a small museum housed in a nondescript apartment between Hudson and the village Greenwcih, excellently run by volunteers contains objects and images of this tragic event from 10 years ago. It is not important for the objects in themselves to Walsour photographs, especially for the atmosphere you breathe: It seems that the attack took place the previous day by a sincere passion that guide explains the meaning of the content.
Impressive. For us Ground Zero was a homage visit to all those who perished in the 9/11 terrorist attack. It was also the opportunity to reflect on what is going on on our planet.

Very Moving. We visited the site of the Twin Towers and were moved by how well this has been completed with The footprints of each tower being covered in marble with the names of all etched into them and a continuous waterfall from each edge. Poignant for us also as when my wife was last in New York in 1999 she went to the top and viewed the skyline. Would recommend.
Heartfelt. A 2-3 hour view into 9-11. Bring tissues...you are going to need them. Extremely real. I will be bringing the kids back in the summer.

Amazing. Absolutely the best thing we did by far. It is so well done, you actually feel an attachment to the people who died there and those who survived. Spot on. Very emotional. I have a 12 year old with ADHD who usually struggles with museums but took it all in and was captivated by it. So very well done.

Tearful. As a retired firefighter ground zero was a place I wanted to visit while I was still able. I am pleased that they are building the new towers, The FREEDOM tower observation deck should be open in May or June. The museum is a fitting tribute to all the people and emergency services and the 343 Firefighters who tragically lost their lives on that frightful day. The museum is a must, unfortunately I didn't have time to look and read the messages, there are 3 film shows of about 15 minutes each. It is very peaceful even though there are thousands of visitors. It would be good if they had a 2 day pass.
9/11 Museum. The presentation of what happened on 9/11 was very moving and the exhibits were outstanding. I would recommend to set aside time to visit this museum.
Tear Jerker. Great experience very sad good to see and you actually feel the pain they must have lived through well worth a visit

My wife and. i visted the museum in March 2015.. It was a very striking and moving experience. We came in late in the evening. Limited on time we were able to spend. I would like to go back again. Would recommend to everyone.

An incredable journey into one of the worst days we ever lived. This is a simple review. The respect shown by the people who have worked so hard to make this Memorial what it is must be congratulated. The attention to detail, the presentations, the layout are so awesome that words can't really do it justice, you must go there.Allow from 3-5 hours for this trip and purchase your tickets on-line...its makes it so much easier...an of course take public transportation, the garages are a fortune and not that near by.

must do. This was a phenomenal experience. My young children were able to see exactly what happened and what America experienced with 9/11. The pieces were so moving and so sad, but definitely someone in New York needs to see, Can't even put it in words. But they have done a beautiful job with this museum.
Excellent. Well done. Worth the money and line up. Very emotional- especially remembering the day of. Tip- buy tickets the day before you go to skip ticket line.

Moving. We went to pay our humble respects to all those innocent people and their families who were robbed of their lives, could not believe how much we were moved, regardless of race, religion or political persuasion, please end hatred and indifference in the world , any one visiting New York must visit, pay their respects and learn.
Moving. Very respectful. Moved to tears. We didn't plan enough time for this. I felt 2 hours would work. Ended up staying 2.5 and could have stayed longer.
Respectful and informative. Extremely well put together, the tour and museum give amazing perspective to the appalling events of that day. Would definitely recommend.

Incredibly powerful and moving tribute. Would highly recommend a visit. The museum is small yet packed with stories, images and artefacts which easily filled a good two and a half hours. Care has clearly been taken to ensure respect and integrity to honour those that lost their lives, those that continue to live with the loss today and the many firefighters and others that worked tirelessly during and after the event. The images are strong and emotive and after an introductory video and talk from a member of staff (who was excellent), you wonder at your own pace and in any order listening to Gary Suson's narration through an audio guide. Gary came down unexpectedly towards the end of the session too which was great. My two boys, aged 17 and 12 really enjoyed (if that's the right word) the museum and were both also very touched by the whole experience. My youngest wasn't even born when 9/11 happened and it felt really important to ensure they both have an appreciation of such a tragic event that impacted on us all across the globe.This museum is very much worth a visit and we all said we preferred this to the less intimate and more impersonal, larger museum experience.

Touching and heartbreaking. We scheduled a tour which was informative but unnecessary. You are much better off going through museum on your own at your own pace. It does get rather too much for young children however. My 12 year old became upset and stated it was too much to handle after spending time on the tour and several hours in the museum. Just hearing tape recording of the victims calling their loved ones for the last time was such a heartbreak and brought me to tears.
Overwhelming. A great detailed inside look into that historic day, very recommended!Full of material i've never seen before about the kidnappers and the events that took place in that day.
Thought provoking. Easy to get to and you can feel the atmosphere , worth taking the time to visit.lots of space all around for visitors and helpful and knowledgeable people all around.
Amazing experience. They did a perfect job with this museum, it was beautiful, tasteful and a moving experience. It was even a great experience for my kids who weren't able to remember 9/11.

A beautiful & respectful tribute.. We did the 15 min video first which captures the drama & response of the city of New York that day. The exhibits are beautiful & very reflective of the magnitude of loss on that day. The wall of the names /photos of those who died was stunning in its volume and you felt you had to read and acknowledge each person.

Historical Site that is so so Sad. We learned a lot about the sadest event in history and will go back yearly to see the updates. Our children have much to say to the other children when they return home

9/11 - don't leave NYC without going here!. Amazing tour, significant video that is exclusive to the museum experience, very emotive and well documented about this horrific day in NYC's history. The American people - I salute you for preserving your history and remembering those that perished on this fateful day.

Absolutely Amazing. Didn't know about this workshop until I purchased New York Express Passes, and I'm grateful we did. Best part of the trip by far. The "tour guide" was very excited about his job, knew a lot of information, and kind. After a brief overview he left us to explore and learn all we wanted through the audio guide. I also asked him a couple questions just one-on-one, and he was more than happy to answer my questions fully. I'm grateful he knew so much that he was able to answer. A serene and beautiful look at a tragic day. As they said, it's a place for healing, and it felt like it. I would go back.
Emotional & Moving. The museum is a beautiful tribute to 9/11. It was tough to see some of the areas, but a must for all visitors.

BEAUTIFUL. So much work has gone into this amazing place.Telling a story of that magnitude and bringing the true horror of 9/11 to life with audio & pictures has been magnificently done.So worth a visit but pre book if you can for there can be queues
must see. museum is well done; must take the time to see it and work together so nothing like that happens again.
special. Such a special place, words cant describe. Breath taking... the new freedom tower is going to be fantastic. Wonderful, and so so quiet

Somber & thought provoking. Very thought provoking & a real tribute to the terrible tragedy of 9/11, walking through the displays really brings home the horror of that day but also the city's ability to recover.Some well thought out displays that help understand how this happenedWould visit again as I think you would get something every time you went

Could spend all day..... Took a spontaneous tour with a friend and so glad I did. Definitely an emotional rollercoaster but well worth it. Plan to spend a lot of time, there are endless things to look at!

Extremely moving. For those who remember this unspeakably terrible tragedy as clearly as I do it is a cathartic experience to spend a few hours in this museum. It's tasteful, thoughtful, but not melodramatic or gruesome.
Pretty place to pay your respects. A wonderful memorial to those that died on that day - very tasteful and also very sad, but definately worth a visit.
Pieceful. An amazing place, a great tribute to those who lost there lives, everything was well set out and staff very helpful.
Heartfelt expereince. you will feel the pain and sorrow million and billion of people in the world felt. what a beautiful homage and remembrance to those who we lost.
Must see.. To fully appreciate the enormity of the disaster this place is a must visit. They have put together an excellent exhibit for all to understand.

A memorable day. To call this experience a museum does not do justice to the thought and tribute at this memorial. We were overwhelmed by the feelings during our visit to this site and to the many examples of bravery shown by new York citizens. It was an unforgettable day one that will stay with us for a long time and the four hours we spent there made a lasting impression of courage and sadness.
very respectfully done. The visit to 911 was humbling and emotional so well done in terms of the history, construction and paying respect to those who list their lives
moving. How do you describe this very poignant experience without being disrespectful.The sheer enormity of this historic event is captured in this very thoughtful museum.

Simply Amazing - you must go!. This is such an incredible place. You will not be able to hold the tears back at times, you will want to see everything in there. We were there for over 3 hrs and didn't even realize it. Touches your heart, it's part of our history, our time. GO!
Must see. Deeply moving. Tastefully done. Go and pay your respects. Had a good cry. Took us four hours to tour the whole area.
First time in New York. Very humbling all the history of 9/11 was very sad worth a visit . There are 100's of pictures on the wall of missing people that was very sad .

Difficult to find but worth the effort!. This is a very intimate space full of mementos from the World Trace Centre. You are given headphones and you simply type in the number of the object/photo you are interested in, and you will hear the story behind it via the headphones. Can be quite emotionally overwhelming. I would not take children here. Very informative.

A totally humbling experience. We visited here on our trip to New York and oh my good how sad but extremely well done A credit to all that were involved in this and an excellent memorial to all R.i.P.

Heartbreakingly beautiful.. Having visited the official museum and the tribute centre I wondered what more there could be to say. As it turns out, so much more. This workshop is so very well set out and the ability to hold certain objects gives visitors a unique and very personal link to events that changed the world. I felt so very grateful that the curator and workers here are willing to continue to share their experiences with those of us who were not there but we're also impacted by such horrific events. The overwhelming impression one is left with is the strength of people's ability to unite. I dread to think how many boxes of tissues this workshop goes through. I was ok until I heard the story of the service dogs. At that point I lost it. But the young man overseeing the workshop was very respectful and compassionate. If you only have time to visit one 9/11 memorial, this would be the one I would recommend.

A must!. Going to the World Trade Center Museum is an experience. It conjures up memories of that sad day we all experienced on 9/11. The workshop is great. You get to interact and it's a great experience.

Tastefully done. Tastefully done, make sure you are not in a rush there is so much to see, I wish more museums were done in this manner. A modern take, perhaps I found it this way as it is very recent, but I think that this display will last for many years without becoming staid and dated.There is so much to see and experience one can definitely visit several times.

Very impressive, a must see when visiting New York. We were all very impressed by this exhibition of modern worlds' most shocking catastrophe. It is sober, accurate, factual, synoptic and very impressive. For our girls, born just before and after 9/11 it was an eye opener on todays history.

Best museum in NYC. Near Chelsea market,ground zero memorial is five minutes away by subway if you want to go after your tour here.The museum holds the thoughts and pictures of official ground zero photographer Gary Suson.The tour lasts about 2 hours,you watch two short films,there are tissues if needed due to the heart breaking nature of the films,it's not really suited for children also.Once watched your guide shows and shares some of there own experiences of the objects/remnants on show,you even get to touch some of the objects that they talk about,and you are even aloud to take your own photos if you want.Most of the objects/remnants on show are what GarySuson found and photographed,and each one has a number you tap into your hand held controller,your given headphones also.Each number has a narrative by Gary Suson and he explains about each piece on show,where photo was taken or where objects were found.Time and energy has been beautiful crafted to give this small museum lots of empathy and integrity.Our guide was amazing,very informative,this is a must place to visit,there are suitable official gifts to buy,the signed photos taken by GarySuson are unique and the monies taken are given back to the museum.
Rememberence. Was a very thought provoking site and enjoyed the visit some things were upsetting but then the whole event on the day was upsetting so we need to remember those who lost their lives
Moving Experience. Well organized — thought provoking — inspiring. We moved among the artifacts and personal reflections, inlcuding audio of final hours, in quiet awe.
9/11 memorial worth seeing. Pros: very moving displayseasy access from subwayeducational experienceCons: audio streaming through 9/11 app did not work
Brilliant. What a wonderful place to see. So much there to enjoy and so much to take in, interesting and captivating

So emotional!!. A very emotional and touching museum. Our guide Bob was a gentleman, tod him i was a police officer in Wales he gave me a gift which I will treasure forever, made my holiday!! Will visit again soon!! Its a must if your in New York!

This has to be seen while in New York. Anything to do with Ground Zero has to be seen. Everything about it has been done to remind people from around the world of the tragidy, the heroism, the sadness and most importantly how ALL New Yorkers came together as one
The real deal. If you want to know what the first responders went through on 9/11 this is the place to visit. Short tour worth the money spent.

Excellent well worth a visit. Very humbling experience. Costs around 25 dollars. Headsets available for hire but only pay for earphones if you have an i phone.A vast area set in the foundations of tower 1. Remains of staircase and twisted metal. A room full of photos of all who died with lots of items uncovered from the disaster, even a fire engine that was half crushed.
Very touching. A serene and special place for locals and tourists alike to visit.This is a must visit when in New York.Museum is tastefully done

A must do!. Beautifully created, so very sad to see all the faces of the people who lost their lives,but it all has a feeling of hope, very interesting to read about the events and the money paid goes to the charity. Must go if visiting New York.
Very poignant. This should be visited if only to remind us of the terrible tragedy that this was. Its very sad but personally I wanted to show support to the people of New York

I cried there. It was a very emotional experience for me...Seing all the pictures of the victims and even some texts that have being send this awful day was very sad... Only there, I really "get" what was the 11/9 for American people...

Emotional Unmissable Experience. Thoroughly enjoyed the Talk and the way the Museum is laid out. It gives plenty of time to stop and reflect on every aspect. You wander around taking the sheer scale of the atrocity in...lots of moving features like the display cabinet with personal possessions where rightly you are not allowed to take photos, instead offered an adjoining area to sit and contemplate. Thought the Souvenir Shop sold a few inappropriate ítems...tacky and crass...but got an excellent National Geographical Book of Rememberance...

A lovely tribute!. I must say I found the whole experience overwhelming but for me and I guess so many others it offers some closure on what happened after September 11 to the site and it puts faces on the lives lost. Take tissues!

Powerful! Absolutely fantastic experience!. I lived in NYC for many years and met Gary Marlon Suson a few times during my time there. He had always encouraged me to visit his museum, and I finally did this past weekend. It far, far exceeded my expectations! The museum is small, but full of incredible photos and artifacts from 9/11 and the recovery efforts. Gary Suson was the only official photographer allowed to photograph the aftermath of 9/11, so his audio tour is developed so each photo and artifact has an interesting story behind it with a lot of very personal elements. I definitely learned a lot of information about 9/11 that I did not know. One of my favorite facts I learned was that the magnitude of the collapse pushed the first 29 floors 80ft underground with floors only 10in apart (I think I quoted that correctly). I also found some of his photos & artifacts to be particularly moving emotionally (i.e. the clock from the South Tower that stopped at 10:02am and 14sec). For the spiritually inclined, I especially love the Bible page that survived that had a lot of symbolism in it (I won't spoil the story for you). I personally think that this small museum in Meatpacking is perhaps more meaningful than visiting the actual memorial site because it tells a lot about the raw experience of 9/11 from many different perspectives. I definitely have a new appreciation that 9/11 is an ongoing tragedy (i.e. due to all the health effects suffered by the first responders along with the intense pain suffered by so many of the victims' loved ones). I am now encouraging all my NYC friends to go and visit this museum. It is very impactful and reminds me never to forget. Even if this is your first visit to NYC, I would definitely prioritize going here. This is tied for my all-time favorite NYC museum (along with the Met and the LES Tenement Museum). If you do go here, buy your tickets ahead of time because they do sell out. You won't regret spending money on this!
Touching... a must go. Of course the memories are sad, but they are part of our generation. A tribute so well so neat so touching.

Intimate Exhibit fo artifacts and pictures from 911. Well worth the visit to this small museum. You have to take a train to it from the 911 Memorial Site.
Hands on artifacts and helpful staff. The photos are amazing and unique because this is the only photographer allowed inside and during the recovery period.

Such Sadness for Those who Lost Their Lives!. Ground Zero Museum Workshop would literally take the tear from a stone, (it’s an old saying). To see the twisted metal, the damaged helmets the wallet with someones I.D, the man’s wedding ring and the area where the towers formally stood with each persons name who lost there lives inscribed on the surrounding water area. It truly is heartbreaking especially when you’re walking in and you see the American Flag made up of the names of the people who so tragically died. it is so worth while going to see this living history museum there are also the videos to watch the calls to listen to but it genuinely my Top visitor attraction to see in New York City. Definitely Highly Recommended as an important place to see, don’t go to America and not visit this amazing part of recent tragic history.

Give yourself more time than you think. Very moving. Get there early in the morning to avoid the queues. The way the museum is laid out is in very good taste. Even the security personnel seem more friendly and engaging than at other places in NYC. 10 out of 10
ground zero. learned lots and enjoyed talking to many working at museum as well as visitors worth buying local 911 books as makes visit that much more meaningful

Heartbreaking, But very worth a visit.. I got the chance to visit the 9/11 Memorial site, on my visit to NYC in December 2013. It's roughly 3 minute walk from wall street, I made this one of my visits on the return journey from liberty island. Upon arrival, you're greeting by a theme park style queue. up and down little walk ways until you get to a desk. entrance is a donation style entrance, anything lower than $10 will just get you entry. Anything more than $10 will get you a remembrance wrist band. I bought the wrist band, as I followed the twin towers story none stop when it happened. Once you get past security, you're led on a walk for about 5 minutes, your next stop is an airport style scanner. remove all your belongings then you have to walk another 5 minutes. once you get inside, you're at the site. it's so peaceful as everybody is paying their respects to the thousands that lost their lives. it's got a very weird atmosphere, but breath taking at the same time. well worth a visit.

The main stop for anyone in NYC. You must go to this museum. With 13 in our group, it was very difficult to leave because of the awe struck moments taht each of us were having. Any one that remembers or even those that were not alive during the time of this tragic event finds great emotion for the events and exhibilts displayed.

Wonderfull 9/11 memory and revival. Ground Zero museum is very well designed and provides the right level of understanding of 9/11 events. Also appropriate for kids to discover history of this tragic event.
Stunning. Being here,reliving the memory made my hairs stand up! We loved sharing this with the girls and teaching them of the history which has shaped our country.

A Unique and Heartfelt Visit. Our guide was not only caring and attentive but also told the story of the loss ones in a heart warming and positive way that really touched our hearts and admired the firefighters, policemans, rescue dogs and other people who have contributed their time, their lives and perserverance and still continue to support the family who lost their loved ones. It is both emotional and heartfelt experience to share the stories, events that happened. In one room, you will listen to a presentation and then you get to visit the museum, artifacts and stories that each item represents.

Bad location. Impossible to find, took us an hour to find and we walked past it at least 10 times and not even shops next door etc knew about it. It's basically a little door where you ring a bell on second floor (took 5 minutes for an answer) then you go up and you end up in a bedroom. It has some interesting photos on the wall etc but it's very boring and not worth the price you pay at all. You watch a short film about 9/11 then you get a phone type thing where you put in the number to listen to whatever photo your looking at on the wall
Great!. We very much enjoyed this workshop, as it was both informative, educational, and inspiring. We walked away sad but inspired!

Excellent and Sad!!!!. Well worth a visit, even if it does cost a $24 for a museum. So much information, and also quite large. You will need lots of time, go in the morning and then you can have a break and take it all in.It is very sad, but very well done!!!A must in NY

Worth the Visit. This was on my must see list for New York. Although it is a somber place I felt the museum is very tastefully done with lots of interesting stories being told. Although there are warnings near some displays to exercise caution if showing children, mine aged 9 and 11 found it sad but interesting. Give yourself a couple of hours there.

Interesting. Everybody remembers where they were when Ground Zero came to be. This was very interesting to see the the photographs on display from the Ground Zero point of view. Haunting. A small museum that doesn't take up the day to go through.

Ground Zero Museum. It is a moving experience to visit the Ground Zero Museum as it is a powerful reminder that those who died live on in our memories. The photographs of all who died can be seen as can many exhibits that reflect the horror of that fateful day known as 9/11. A visit to see the Memorial and Museum is a compelling must for any serious visitor to New York.

Intimate Museum. The museum tour consists of a 15 minute video produced by the photographer whom the exhibition revolves around. It provides detail that is not really expressed elsewhere and enables a close connection to the people affected on 9/11. I think it is worth doing but don't expect anything very grand. The museum is housed in one room on the first floor of a building where the entrance is easy to miss; look out for the small pavement banner sign and anonymous looking entry door. Proceeds go to families affected by the disaster.
great. amazing.....place this has so much to see.....there is so much you have to at least stay 5 days to see it all...

Thought provoking and very moving.. We arrived at the tour by pure fluke as we thought we had booked the main museum next to the fountains and only on the day when we checked the address did we realise we had booked something different. Our concerns were soon put to one side that we were in a retail street when we were greeted by a very enthusiastic guide. He gave everyone in the group time to absorb all the information at their own speed. The audio descriptions of the artefacts were both moving and sensitively set about the room to allow everyone to discover as much or as little as they could take in on the day. It was a very moving experience which we are so pleased we booked by accident!
Must see. It's small. Only 1 room. but very interesting. There is a lot of pictures you can find anywhere else.There is part of air plain and so much more I recommend it

Better than I thought. I was skeptical about this until we arrived at the site. The museum is breathtaking. I am not easily impressed but the thought and care put into this was awe-inspiring. Winter is a good time to attend… I would imagine shorter queues. Certainly worth the money.
This is a must!. Left in tears it was an awesome experience. We didn't know what to expect but we are glad that we visited this site

Good value and well set up. I was told about the GZ MW and I'm really glad I went to this instead of the main museum.Our group were greeted by a really friendly gut (forgot his name sorry it was 5/8/14)The place is a small apt but is very well set up, very respectful of 9/11 and very informative.The background stories are amazing as are the artefacts.Well worth a visit as the area is also accesibe for the High line and Meatpackers.
A must see!!!. Highly recomanded!!! Mooving, well presented and .detailed deeply. As aught to be- inscibed in memory

Highly recommended. Words are difficult to find as I write this review. The events of 9/11 are still hard to understand. Being in Tulsa when it happened we experienced it through the media coverage. I knew that I would visit the Memorial Site during my NYC trip. I read about the GZMW and checked out the reviews posted here on Trip Advisor. I visited the 9/11 Memorial, skipped that museum and headed over to the GZMW. We had a 1pm tour, they don't open early and expect you to be on time. You meet the guide in the street just outside the building, which is in the meat packing district about a ten minute/$10 cab ride from the Memorial site.There was a casually dressed man talking to several people who were just ending their tour. He said goodbye to them and asked if we were there for the Museum Workshop. Turns out he was Gary Suson the Founder and contributor to the GZMW. Gary was the ONLY photographer allowed to document the recovery of the innocent victims of the senseless violence. The focus is on Firefighters,but respects Police and other official volunteers. Trey our official tour guide explained that this workshop is meant for healing.To me the workshop experience , was peaceful and deeply moving. A very well executed display, in a comfortable environment with professional guidance by Trey and luckily for us this day- Gary himself.A unique experience to touch rare artifacts and material from 911.  The focus is on the recovery efforts, through observed personal stories,with extreme respect for the victims their families and the tireless professionals performing grisly duties in terrible conditions. The GZMW contributes to the medical bills of these recovery heroes who have succumbed to illness as a result of their work in a toxic environment. This Museum is a must visit- your ticket supports the GZMW as well as providing support to the health of affected workers and children and widows of NYFD Responders and Recovery workers.Highly recommend.

Great memorial. Visiting the museum was very bittersweet. When you first walk in you realise the true devastation caused and it makes you feel cold. But what a great memorial to all of those who lost lives. A place to learn, reflect & pay respects. The museum has been tastefully done and I'm pleased we visited.
such a beautiful job they did. Was bittersweet- loved going there but left sad. The stories and pictures you see throughout gave me goosebumps.

Go if interested in memorials, no if interested in the event. The memorial primarily focuses on the memorials to the victims. The information on what happened on 9/11 is stuffed in a small room that is extremely crowded with people. I finally gave up trying to get through it because it was so crowded. It is a shame that with all of the space that they have it they did not dedicate more space to showing what happened on the day. If you are interested in the memorials, then go. If you are interested in the history of the event, I would not go. It was disappoint for me.

Not for the timid. We scheduled our appointment for the Museum. Not sure what to expect we showed up at a building on West 14th. Surely we were in the wrong area. But No. A young woman greets our group of 15 and takes us into the building to the 2nd floor. The tour is actually 'do it yourself'. We enter a room about 60 square feet with a few chairs and couches. There is a brief introduction of what happened that day with several pieces of the building and contents on display. You get a headset and proceed to press the button of the item / picture that you would like to hear about. It is very moving. You forget where you are and take in what went on at Ground Zero and what went on that day. There is also an extensive area given to the period of clean up and the discoveries that they made. It is very moving. We spent the entire 2 hours listening to these stories.
A moving tribute. Very moving tribute to the many people who lost their lives on that tragic day , a tasteful and respectful tribute to them all

Check if you really want to go before booking. We visited this museum after visiting the 9/11 Memorial Museum 2 days earlier. It was an interesting visit but not what we were expecting. There are approximately 100 exhibits in a single room accompanied by a handheld/headphone audio guide. some items recovered from the site, lots of photos taken during the clearing of the site, these were probably the most interesting part. You have to pre-book, you can not just turn up and enter. We spent about 1 hour in total in the museum. If I had to choose I would recommend the 9/11 Memorial Museum over this one.

New York Vacation. This was a very sobering experience, that brought back that infamous day very poignantly. The artefacts, accounts and pictures on display revealing a very personal side to this tragedy.

Sad but very Thoughtful and Respectful. We must remember. It brought back the memories of the day. My kids did not remember so much, since they were little and from Houston, and they really like walking around and learning about History.
Poignant. Brings back the surreal memories and experience of watching the collapse of the former World Trade Center.

Best 911 Rescuers Museum. This was a museum well worth a visit. At first I was shocked and a bit disappointed by the fact that it is fully contained in only one room. But the presentation is excellent, the film and the artifacts and back stories are expertly described via headset recording and touched us deeply. As a bonus, while visiting we were honored to meet Gary Susson, the photographer who took those awesome iconic photographs. A note of caution: since the museum is small and cannot accommodate large numbers, entry to the museum is by appointment only. Do not arrive too early, as you are not permitted to enter the building until the appointed time. In rain or heat or cold, no shelter is provided prior to entry.

Really Well Done. The museum has been designed and laid out so thoughtfully so the crowds can move through and it doesn't feel too crowded and everyone is quiet and respectful. Lots of stories from survivors and victims families and you hear from the victims too which is very sad - there are photos and images I hadn't seen since the first day it happened and these were displayed beautifully and respectfully.

A Must Do. This museum was the favourite thing about New York for my 11 year old son. Both boys aged 8 and 11 were fully engaged during their time there. It says so much from a small, personal space. It gave both the boys and I a moving insight into the aftermath of this tragedy and left us with beautiful stories and a feeling that is hard to describe as the museum is so unique. A great nearby lunch / brunch / dinner stop afterwards is The Diner diagonally opposite, right in the heart of the Meatpacking district across on 9th Avenue.
Omg....... Breathtaking, heart wrenching, mind blowing, empty feeling and yetSo interesting. Definitely must visit this. Spent hours in there, so much to take in. Amazing experience.

Beautiful tribute. I was so impressed with this place. It was a perfect tribute to such a devastating tragedy. It was moving but uplifting as it showed how the communities came together after to unite against these monsters who attacked American soil. It is a must do for every visitor to the city.
Great personal museum. Very enjoyable small museum with a personal touch. A little hard to find so watch for the sidewalk sign. Family friendly. No lines with reservation.
A must. Very sad when you look around and think back to what had actually happened here, sad listening to the stories, phone calls, exhibits etc.

Must do when in NYC.. Make sure you allow enough time. Two hours would be a short visit and we don't normally hang around for long. Provide a little time afterwards to "recover" the impact of the disaster hits you hard

Was it real?. It was very impressive to visit.We went with for people and all of us were very quiet after the visit.
It's better to donate a few dollars because first of all they deserve it and second ,you passes very quickly.Must do if you are in NY.
Honoring 911!!!!!. We took it all in and were impressed by the work done to honor those lives lost this tragic day. Really moved on this visit here today.
Very small but big in quality. Went to this one following TA comments. Gave a totally perspective to 9/11 focussing on the finding of bodies and rebuilding hope. Beautifully done.
Don't miss the video. The shop is only a block away mostly full of usual tourist stuff but video shown on rear wall opposite front door is not to be missed.

Very moving. We spent a lot of time here, its very moving think it was because it happened in our lifetime and wasn't thousands of years ago. Big queue when we got there but you weren't kept waiting a long time.
Amazing. Everything has been captured and remembered for all the loved ones that lost their life in the 9/11 tragedy

A fantastic, thoughtful and personal tour.. We visited this museum on the recommendation of my sister. It's not on the site of 9/11 it's a short subway ride away. It's at the studio of Gary Suson the only photographer allowed on the site of ground zero in the following months and years after the devastation. On arriving it was a lot smaller than we expected BUT as soon as you're talked through Gary's personal journey it takes 2hrs to get around and is incredibly emotional. You definitely need to book this tour in advance as they only allows a set number of people on the tour, which also adds to the personal touch of this tour. The museum is very well thought out and you are allowed to touch items which is like no other museum I've been too. The experience felt real and very raw hearing Gary's personal experiences through the audio pack, you can go through the audio experiences in any order you like which is great for not intruding other visitors personal space. We were honoured to meet Gary a few hours later at the local church next to the ground zero site, he's so humble and had all the time in the world to speak to us. We also walked past the other 9/11 museum at the site of where the twin towers were but we didn't like the sales people outside that we're wrongly forcing pictures of the towers in our faces and pretending to cry when we said we didn't want to buy a ticket. It felt so wrong and commercial compared to the experience we'd just had at Gary's museum. Overall please don't hesitate to book this tour, you won't regret it.

An Amazing & Emotional Experience. A really moving experience. On first arrival I was surprised at how small the museum was. However, I soon realised that this was great as it had a really personal feel to it and that the use of the space was done really well, with over 100 items on display all with superb narration provided. I found the emotional description of the artefacts on the headset commentary by the photographer Gary Marlon Suson to be extremely moving. It was a very emotional couple of hours that we spent in the museum and I'd highly recommend it to anyone who wants to try to experience what it may have been like on that terrible day of 9th Nov 2011.
Must visit. This is a beautiful and moving site. I love what has been built. You must go. It's breathe taking. Make sure to take your camera.

Great experience. I would definitely recommend this to someone. My husband and I aren't fans of huge crowds and long lines. This was perfect. It was small and personal. It was very moving and interesting to hear more personal moments from firefighters and police recovery efforts. The only thing that seemed very odd was the tour guide was taking phone calls during her presentation! We actually thought the first time she answered the phone that it was part of the script until we realized that she was actually just answering the phone when she told them she would call them back later. This happened twice. Very unprofessional and distracting.

Excellent 9/11 Tribute to Victims and Survivors. I've never been to a museum that drew such a raw emotion from the exhibits. The artifacts and personal stories are absolutely captivating. It was amazing to hear about the everyday people that went above and beyond to help each other. The true heroes!! A very, very emotional exhibit!!
Most moving. Spent about 90 minutes there it was very moving. With photos and objects from the towers a very good guide .Well worth a Visit. Value for money
a must see in NYC. Extremely well done and moving museum. A wonderful tribute to the first responders and to all who lost their lives.
Memorable experience. A captivating and moving experience that I will never forget. A surprise visit by Gary Suson made for an intimate exposure to the terrible events of 9-11.

Moving experience. very moving exhibition, give yourself lots of time to experience the whole exhibit, beautifully laid out exhibition with lots of opportunities to gather yourself if you feel it's getting too much for you.
A must see in NYC. This museum is the most emotional museum. Have ever visited. The exhibit lets you see and feel the devastating f this happening.
Emotional viewings. Excellent workshop and very well done with some amazing photos, artefacts & information - very sobering
A must see. I could have spent the entire day in this wonderful collection of photographs and exhibits. Small, but powerful.
Very Moving. Left me speechless particularly the displays and stories of people who died at the scene.Well worth a visit even just to walk around very sobering.
Very tastefully presented.. A very thought provoking and moving experience which I would recommend any visitor to NYC takes the opportunity to visit.
Excellent. Loved everything. Great to be able to see items at such a close up. Highly recommended to everyone to see.

A tribute to the brave NYFD and NYPD and PAPD who had to dig by hand to recover victims remains!. This museum is a collection of photos by the artist appointed to be the official photographer of the NYFD recovery efforts. He was given unlimited access to document the devastation of the attack, and emotional toll the recovery effort took on the teams. These men and women had to dig with hand tools in toxic and compacted debris looking for victims. The museum is intimate and has a collection of amazing photographs documenting the recovery effort. You learn first hand about the Fire Fighters, Police, and EMTs who rushed into this building to save people as everyone was running out, they made the ultimate sacrifice to save others.There are a number of artifacts from the towers, including religious symbols cut from the beams of twisted metal by the iron workers assisting with the recovery effort. None of the artifacts are personal belongings as was stated in an earlier review, as all personal items were returned to families of victims. The artifacts are every day objects and items from the shops, restaurants, and subway station in the towers and are included to show the extent of the devastation from the plane crashes and the subsequent tower collapses.This museum was easy to locate and is clearly indicated in all advertising as not being at the memorial site. I read the reviews of previous visitors that gave this location a poor or terrible rating and can only surmise that they were in a completely different museum than I was in. My wife was bothered by reviewers complaining about the cost of admission, they may have not realized that a large amount of the proceeds are donated to various charities for the fire, police, and emt, and recovery workers who died during the collapse or from illness from the toxic dust of this site.My wife and I visited the 911 Memorial Museum before this one, while I found the memorial museum to be informative and had a large collection it was cold and impersonal, it felt like you were not invited to share the pain of the day. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop was intimate, it included comfortable furniture to sit and contemplate the photos and artifacts, it invited you in to experience first hand the pain someone who was there everyday along side the recovery teams witnessed and lived. It is self directed with a audio commentary from the photographer about each item and photo, you can move from object to object in any order you wish and as fast or as slow as you would like.
touching. The opportunity to "hear" and feel from first hand was a unique experience. Although we are not natives it felt like it
unbelieveable. They made this just like it just happened. Some of the pictures were real, they made us feel, like it was real now. We left with a lot of sorrow.

Moving and Memorable. This one of the best things we did in New York. I gather it's contentious amongst New Yorkers who feel they don't need a reminder, but for foreign visitors its a place for us to appreciate the sorrow and the hardship for all the families who lost loved ones.
Heartbreaking. A good job has been done to such a sensitive project. Very personel and informative arrangement of items, I enjoyed it all, but very sad.
Museum experience. I was skeptical at first but it proved me totally wrong. I enjoyed the experience greatly. Recommend to all interested in the 911 moments of history that touched so many nations.

Best museum in NYC. I have visited this museum twice! It is awesome. It is very well organized, personal, and is much more reverent than the "official" 9/11 museum and memorial. I recommend this museum to everyone.

Wonderful. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a very tiny museum. Just one room, across from Chelsea Market. It is easy to miss and we were lucky to get there just as a tour was starting (10 people in the tour). After 2 short videos and a brief introduction, you can walk around the room and look at photos taken by the only official photographer allowed on the Ground Zero site, Gary Suson. Each photo is accompanied by an audio story read by M. Suson. We were lucky to meet Gary Suson at the museum that day and to talk with him. Visiting this museum is very touching. It's definitely not a large scale, touristy museum but it is absolutely worth it. I would strongly recommend it. Reviews mentionning the fountains, long lines, tour guides and gift shops do not refer to this museum but probably to the 9/11 museum.
XGiGi2014X. Amazing and spectacular experience! Sad, but educational and good. Would recommend to family and friends!!!!!!!

This is a great 'little' tourist attraction. We visited here in July 2014 on a pre-booked visit, having read the reviews on Trip Advisor - it certainly didn't disappointed. It must, quite literally, be the smallest museum in New York, set in the owner's (and official 9/11 recovery photographer's) old workshop. On arrival, it's hard to find - located a short subway ride away from Ground Zero itself, but is next door to an Aasics store.On arrival it's hard to believe that what you're in is the museum - you are surrounded by photographs and small artefacts, each of which are numbered (see photo). You are given a brief introduction by the guide, shown two short videos and then given time to make your way around, punching in numbers to a headset, to inform you of each artefacts significance. I would advise you leave about 2 hours for the complete visit (you could spend even longer if you wish). This intricate, educational experience is well worth a visit as it tells you things you did not know, about the recovery of the Ground Zero site. You are also allowed to handle certain artefacts, something other museums do not allow. All proceeds go to 9/11 charities. I would advise doing this before visiting the 9/11 memorial at World Trade Center. Enjoy.

Very touching expeirence. I liked a lot. You can see and lear more details about the sad and terrible event of Sept. 11. How that tragic event impact so manu families and victims. Very quite atmosphere.

Great Museum to Visit!!. My husband and I visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop last week before we headed to the newly opened 9/11 museum. I am so glad we visited here beforehand. It is small, but has LOTS of information. We were able to get up and close with everything without worrying about big crowds. Mr. Suson stopped in as we were finishing up. He took time to talk with us and answer our questions. My husband is a firefighter and was grateful that Suson was able to show the firefighter's perspective and the emotions behind what happened. I highly recommend this museum!!!

Ground Zero Museum Workshop in Chelsea (NYC)-You must visit.. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop in Chelsea is a beautiful tribute to the victims and emergency workers. The pictures and artifacts personalize the events of 9/11 and its aftermath in a way that touches your heart and accomplishes its objective of "Don't ever forget" in a moving and lasting way.

Remember the death people. The Museum has become a very interesting and good place to remember all the victoms of the terror and how meaningsless these actions were. It is important that the younger people see and learn about it.
Must See. Now a part of our history - the tour guide offered personal stories as well as important factual information

Wonderful intimate photo memorial. This was a wonderful intimate museum that was able to preserve, honor and share some of the experiences of the rescuers, the lost and the tragic day of 911. Even met the photographer who took all the photos. We went here before going to the Ground Zero Memorial, and it made the experience much more heartfelt.

This location is a scam. First of all there are several ground zero museums. This one it not near ground zero but on 14 Street. My family planned to attend the new museum opening on Memorial Weekend. The taxi driver approached the address at 420 W 14th. There was no signs and no people when we arrived on Saturday May 24, 2014. I called the phone number which went to voicemail. No one called me back. This tour was offered through Viator-All New York Tours which is a legit company. We decided to go to ground zero anyway. No ticket were available until Monday and we were leaving on Sunday. The person in the window said that other people had tried to use these tickets. We did find a museum on a side street which sounded like the same name. It was started by one of the fireman's father and it also had volunteers talking about their experience that day. I got an email asking me to review my experience so I did get my money back.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop is an excellent dedication and tribute.... I definitely recommend The Ground Zero Museum Workshop. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop was very, very intimate. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is one room! Photography is encouraged! Several of the artifacts can be picked up and touched. Despite the "workshop" being only one room, you can easily spend several hours there because ALL of the artifacts and pictures there are numbered and you can listen to audio related to each number as many times as you'd like (individual audio players are provided); many times the audio includes recordings of the actual person photographed. I think the best thing about the "workshop" is that due to its size, you can scan the room and decide what you want to hear first and in what order; if you want to look at artifact 2 then 17, then 94, then 5, then 80, go for it! There are well over 100 artifacts and photos in the room, each with interesting stories/insight recorded. Finally, because the Ground Zero Museum Workshop work is based on pictures and recollections made by the only photographer with 100% ground zero access, there are some really poignant stories and moments that you don't find at the National 9/11 Memorial and Museum. Again, both of the museums are thoughtful and impressive, but the Ground Zero Museum Workshop feels more "real". Plus, as I understand it, the Ground Zero Museum Workshop annually gives money to various 9/11 victims groups as part of its operation.As well, my family also toured the National 9/11 Memorial and Museum, and the two experiences are vastly different. We didn't feel there were any negatives to speak of either way. But in contrast, the National 9/11 Memorial and Museum was similarly constructed to any other museum that you might visit where it appears money was not any consideration; the exhibit halls are mostly very large and spacious, there are several interactive displays, there are huge pieces of recovered debris, and there are more facts and exhibits (including audio and video) than you could possibly read or spend more than a couple of moments reflecting on unless you have tickets for 2 or 3 days.Again, both museums are impressive in their own right, but if I had to choose, I'd choose the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Especially, since you can view the World Trade memorial/reflection pools (next to the National 9/11 Memorial and Museum) at no charge.

A must. This is an absolute must for anyone of any religion. It's so hard to describe the feelings you feel as you walk through the museum. The only thing I can say for sure is I feel a much better person having seen this. But be prepared for years to come out even if you're not usually the crying type.
Emotional. Can't believe how emotional I was. Not the tearfully type but it brought tears to me. Please nothing like this never happens again.

One of the best museums I have ever visited. It is an extremely well designed space with lots of memorabilia of the horrid event of 9/11. It grabs your heard and your soul seeing the distraction, the human suffering, the many images of the desperate, the dead. It is a "must see" for anyone visiting Manhattan. Otherwise, a very large piece of Manhattan and, actually, world history, is being missed.

Unexpected gem. When I first saw the space, I thought we'd only be there for at most 45 mins. My hubby & I stayed for 2.5hrs! Talk about being in the biggest small museum! Rather confronting to come so close to the items on display; we were allowed to touch a number of them. Definitely surreal to listen to the photographer as we were looking at the very picture he'd taken and was talking about. His stories/firsthand account got me teary-eyed several times. Great visit!

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Talk about being up close and personal with the event! We were told about this museum from a friend in Australia. Yes it was emotional and great to do before venturing down to the 9/11 site.

Very moving. This intimate museum left a huge impression on myself and my daughter. We were blessed to be their during a visit from Gary himself. The information and artifacts are shared with great dignity. I highly recommend this to everyone.
Words can not possibly amplify. Words can not possibly amplify the rush of raw emotion. I won't even attempt to write them.Without delay, GO!
A reminder.. Will bring the experience of what happened on that day in Sept. The price of admittance is worth it ...it will remind all who visit what regular people had to go through on that day.
Deep, sad, emotional, unique. It was with great surprise we were able to get tickets at short notice. The all experience is one of the most moving exhibitions I have even been to. Truly exceptional

Amazing!!. One huge story and package all wrapped up in a tiny box of amazingness! Our guide--cant recall his name, but did a super job and even got emotional himself. I couldn't believe all the artifacts and pictures they had on display. If you do just one thing on the trip to NYC, this is it! Really awesome!

Not What I Expected. This attraction is a collection of items and photographs by one person Mr. [--]. The entire museum is in one room. It is very small, mostly self guided with recommendations of which items to listen to on your device. What my family (2 teens and a middle aged husband) liked the most was the intimate stories and tangible quality of the exhibit. What we liked the least was that we felt Mr. [--] was self promoting, self indulgent and an opportunist. The exhibit, particularly the videos were repetitive. The collection really needs not to be privately held but at the Smithsonian or another national institution. It is everyone's history.More than anything, the personal stories and personal items were the most significant and touching to me and my family.

Touching museum and very tasteful. It is a very tasteful way of touching on a piece of our history as well as showcasing the heroes of that tragic day. The artifacts recovered is incredible and they captured every single moment from that day and the days that followed. It was a wonderful way of giving a tribute to the victims. The only thing that is unnecessary is the gift shop. There shouldn't be a profit from all of these deaths.
Solem but Uplifting Too. It takes hours to see it all and you leave breathless. But as a reminder of the horror of 9/11 it is not to be missed.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. We had a very moving experience visiting the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. What a fabulous little museum with so much to see and read about. The photographer, Gary Suson, has skill and senstivitiy to capture the events in photos following the 911 catastrophe .The museum was hard to find in the Meatpacking District and not at Ground Zero. But once inside this gem of a museum we found a lovely lady waiting for us to tell us all about the photographer and showed us a video of the events as he catalogued them.The museum is full of real artifacts from the Ground Zero site some of which we were allowed to hold, they are really interesting. We were given hand held devices and headphones to listen to individual stories about the people of sites that Gary had seen. We were really moved by some of the stories we heard of such bravery from the fire fighters and all involved in the aftermath of the disaster.Don't get this museum mixed up with the museums down at the Ground Zero site but this museum in the Meatpacking District is definitely worth a visit.

Go to remember so that this will happen no more!. Met families from around the world here...beautiful people with great hearts. Very individual experience...much like experience of visiting the Holocaust Museum in Houston, TX...go and remember so this will happen no more ;(

Incredibly moving. They have done a great job with this that really makes you connect with the experiences of all the people who were involved in different ways. I was incredibly moved by the some of the personal stories. Set aside at least 2-3 hours.
A must do. We took our teenagers...and they were babies when 9/11 happened. It was still very fresh for us, but so much better than a text book for the girls. Very powerful and a must do.

Sole photographer of Ground Zero, Suson shares history and his heart through the exhibits.. Suson was present during our tour. His exhibited work documents the soul of Ground Zero. As a historian, he shares his eyes to a new generation.

Excellent and personal. Stumbled on it by accident , since it is not near ground zero. Very real and personal stories and pictures of the aftermath of the disaster. Great guide and support materials. By chance we also got to meet the photographer whose work is the basis of the museum later in the day . Don't miss it.

So Moving. What a moving experience visiting the Ground Zero museum and workshop. The exhibitions are wonderful and the audio of the telephone messages made to family and friends from of the people on the day are such an insight in to the unexpected tragic events of the day are heart breaking to hear.Words cant really explain the whole experience. An experience not to be missed.
Interesting and moving experience. We felt that sadly it has become a business and just about making money. It was very well organised despite all the rebuilding which is obviously going on.
Very moving. Small group tour. You must book in advance. This was very intimate and extremely moving. We took our 10year old and even he was touched by it. So glad we went.

beautiful. The Ground Zero Museum workshop is a hidden gem in NYC. This small museum is packed with emotion and brings to life the stories of 911 which were not in the media. Beautifully presented memorial to the families which have donated artefacts and shared their stories.

Museum workshop compared to memorial museum. This place is amazing. I cannot express the emotion I felt the day my mother and I visited the workshop. The museum made it so much more real, raw, personal and emotional. I could have spent all day here. I could never imagine what everyone involved went through. Gary Suson is an amazing human being who captured so so much through his time of the recovery and I was honored to meet him and see his work. I highly recommend the museum workshop to everyone going to NY. I went to the museum at the memorial sight but this museum is so much more personal and hands on. It has really opened up my eyes and I will return again.Thank you Gary and all involved in the operation. Never forget.

An informative and moving experience. We recently visited based on a friend's recommendation. We had our 9 and 11 year-old with us, whom we had taken with us to the Ground Zero memorial site the previous day. We weren't exactly sure what the workshop would be like and were intially worried how the kids would respond given their ages and that the workshop is housed in an incredibly small space.Well - what an awesome surprise. Despite taking a while to find the place, we were all so impressed with the way in which the workshop is run. The range of materials on display and the incredibly facinating narratives associated with each and every one of them is truly moving.We were expecting that we would struggle to keep the kids interested beyond 30 minutes given their lack of knowledge on the event and the small space, but after 90 minutes we were struggling to move them on as they were so engaged.We were fortunate enough to have a brief chat with Gary - although I am certain that i displayed my ignorance around the technical aspects associated with his photography. Thank-you Gary for sharing your your work with us and for allowing us to participate in this memorable and moving experience.

Memorable. From the moment you start the tour to the very end, you could feel the pain the people who perished must have felt. We spent 3 hours going through the museum and I was so glad that my husband and I took the time to go.

A well kept secret. This little museum is hard to find but well worth a visit. Lots of photographs and artifacts from the site of the twin towers. Moving stories well worth taking time out to visit. Will only take an hour or so and is a little off the beaten track but glad we went.

NEVER FORGET !!!!. Do not miss the experience of feeling the pain & sorrow the rescuers went through....some looking for their loved ones. We were so humbled to speak to Gary Suson the photographer about his experiences and to pay our respects to all those who died that day. After 3 weeks there was a complete media ban on taking photos. Gary was asked to take photos of the recovery which lasted 9 months.There are so many intimate images of death and love inside ground zero. This is a small workshop, which you are able to touch some of the artefacts and see videos and photos of Ground Zero.
humbling experience. Words cannot express how one feels here, but it should be seen and remembered, Take your time and absorb all that is before you.

Extremely sad and poignant. It was our way of paying respects to all who perished on that fateful day. There were tissue boxes and we did need them... it was so sad to see the photos of those lost, those who are missing and artefacts found.

Waiting for the new WTC. Ground Zero Museum will tell you a lot if not all about the terrible things that happened on 9/11. The loss of life, the loss of the Twin Towers the loss of freedom to the world at large. Once in New York make it a point to go and visit

Very moving!. Very we'll done. I think everyone that sees this museum sheds many tears and comes home feeling very proud about the !New York people and all the first responders. I love New York more than ever!
Solemn. The museum was heart wrenching. Of course, the objects, images and media brought back the gut wrenching feelings from September 11. We shall never forget.

Was moving, but expected a little more. As most of the other reviews pointed out, this is not the official 9/11 museum -- won't recover that. Besides being small, I was a little disappointed by the contents given how enormous this event was for the city. I suppose it would be impossible to capture the event effectively in any space, but left somewhat feeling this was more about the creator of the museum than the event itself. This is effectively a one room apartment with a lot of small artifacts from the World Trade center. I did learn a good amount, the recorded stories are good, and the calendar and clock artifacts are chilling to see in person.
