Again, just felt a little less about the event and more about the creator.

Humbling . . .. This was a very humbling experience, they have done a brilliant job, full of care & respect . . . If you go here and do not become emotional, you must not have a heart, God Bless Everyone . . .
Very moving. "Enjoyed" isn't the right word to describe this attraction but it was very moving and the experience will stay with me for along time.
Touching. Emotions cannt express what we felt when we visited to actually see belongings that once belonged to people that worked in the towers it was our honour to visit
Very moving. A great tribute to the 9/11 victims. Wonderfully presented and very touching. Tells the story chronologically.
Unforgettable . A must place for everybody , this place is full of picture and memorabilia from the moment ... In a dark moment of our country , here you can find the willing to fight back

Excellent. Very respectful and emotional.
You could avoid the groud zero memorial, but don't avoid this Workshop!!
Moving. Very touching museum, really brings all the tough times the city/nation has seen during the attacks. They do an excellent job bringing it to life and making it memorable. A Must See
Memorable. Lots of pictures and memorabilia. Sad and triumphant time for our country. Must visit when in New York City.

I am in tears.. I went in, and follow small tour inside with a Lady, she explained everythings and she knows every single details and all the pictures at the wall. And at the end.. she said " That man... she is a Fire Fighter and he is the great man,.. and he is my Son". I saw her face, her eyes... she was and tears and i gave him a big hug and said " and you are strong mother". I took a pic with her before say good bye. The moment i will never forget...

Very Moving. This has to be on everybodys itinery. You will find it very moving and emotional. It really brings you into New York on that fateful day. We were totally engrossed and even though we live 3500 miles away we felt as though we were sharing everybodys grief.

A very moving experience. This one-room museum is packed full of beautiful photos and artifacts from 9/11. Small groups make for an intimate experience. The self-guided tour allows visitors to move at their own pace and take their time looking at the pictures and artifacts. I also loved that the photographer narrates the tour (via headset). Who else to better tell the stories behind each touching photograph? My husband and I liked the fact that the exhibits were very tastefully done. They focused more on the men and women who helped with the recovery efforts and less on images of the actual attack.Also, the tour guide, Trey, was super helpful and very friendly.

WOW. My husband is an active firefighter, I'm a recently retired police officer.This museum was excellent in our opinion - It gave us an idea of what the first responders, and other workers at the WTC site faced as they looked for victim's remains and removed the debris. I can not believe it didn't "hold the interest" as stated in another review. It was not what we were expecting, but we were really glad we decided to go. The audio tour of the photos and other items in the museum workshop really touched our emotions, especially with the narrators first hand accounts. I am planning a trip to the city with my nephew in July and will probably go back again with him. It was well worth the admission fee.

Nicely done small museum, but didn't hold my interest. Booked reservations online. The location is a bit hard to find, as it is not well marked, if you show up early there is no place to wait, so best to arrive right on time. This is not the memorial, but a location on 14th Street away from the WTC, where the photographer who had captured images of recovery effort has set up a small museum of his photos and some artifacts from the recovery. You get audio devices that allow you to view and listen to the stories behind each of the pictures and you can view at your own pace. They say you have 1 1/2 to 2 hours to view. It is well done presentation. Part of the money paid goes to the 911 family funds.The space is very small, but there is a lot of photos. I really didn't find that we needed to spend but 1 hour there at the most.

Fantastic! A very moving experience!. Set within a small comfortable setting is the tribute to 911 containing artefacts, photos and stories from those directly involved in 911. During our visit we were able hold objects, take as many photos as we wanted and were left to go around the museum freely with a head set explaining the stories behind what we were seeing. There was no pressure at all as we were left to take as much time as we wanted looking around. The group consisted of 4 people at one time making it a perfect opportunity to fully engage. The lady running the museum was a great host, really friendly and welcoming. Thank you for providing us with a truly moving experience which allowed us to really understand and appreciate the events of 911. We would certainly recommend!

Some interesting things, some moving moments.. The only thing I particularly disliked, was the tour guide was wearing a tee-shirt that was made to look a little like a little fire fighters uniform, it seems to be in bad taste. Its difficult to rate on tripadvisor sometimes, this attraction is definitely a 9 out of ten, but the tour guide's "uniform" made it easier to round down rather than up.The photographs were particularly well shot and the museum gives one a chance to touch and view some artifacts from the recovery.The museum is very small not much bigger than a hotel suite. It focuses on the the photography taken and artifacts collected by the official ground zero recovery photographer Gary. The audio tour and video from Gary gives a good insight into the feelings and strengths of the recovery workers, including some moving moments of those workers who lost family and brother offices. Its reinforced my great respect for these workers both human and K9.The museum is located well away from 911 site, website claims its only 7 minutes away from the 911 memorial, but this only reflects the time of the actual train journey. Unless one is familiar with the subway, allowing for delays and mistakes one should factor in an hour or so. The eateries and bars nearby are pleasant if you are early.

Wonderful little museum. Not a lot of advertising, and it is a little hard to find, but WELL worth the trip. Intimate space telling the story of the ground zero recovery effort from the perspective of the photographer who was there. Very moving and well done. I had the good fortune to meet Gary and discuss some of the photos that meant the most to him. Something I will never forget -what a unique opportunity to get a firsthand look at the awful aftermath of that fateful day.

Highly recommended.. An informative, yet moving exhibition full of pictures and items salvaged from the site, that gives visitors an intimate insight into the tragic event. I'd recommend this to anyone who remembers 9/11 and for those who were too young to remember it. Sincerely hope it doesn't suffer when the official museum (actually at Ground zero) opens in May 2014.

Must go!!. I think a lot of people have mixed up this museum workshop with the ground zero tour. They are different!! This is a two-hour audio guide tour. Check out their website for information before making false reviews!This small museum displays photos taken by the photographer Gary Suson and some artifacts collected during recovery that you can actually touch. (except for a piece of aircraft remain). The photo that has my attention the most is the firefighter knelt down on the ground doing prayer before he started digging. All the photos have stories behind them. I highly recommend this place!

Great collection of images from the tragedy. The museum is not the typical experience you would expect. It is a small space that thoroughly shares every moment that the victims and first responders experienced in a casual setting. Visitors are able to absorb the story behind artifacts and moving photographic images in their own personal way. I don't believe you could see this display through any other attraction in the city. Well done!

Ground Zero Museum Workshop NOT memorial ground. This museum, although it had some interesting photographs and artefacts was very disappointing and not worth $25. Everyone seems to be getting this museum mixed up with the memorial ground, which I have also visited and would certainly give that 5 points, but this, only worth 2 at best. Don't bother, visit the memorial ground and go in the shop, it's as big as the museum workshop and more interesting.

Glad I went. Tiny museum offers an intimate and emotional feel.This is truly a place for healing, recommended to all who would like to understand the suffering as well as the beauty that emerged from this horrific tragedy.

A must see. This was the saddest place I have been, but so educational and a truly moving place. I didn't realise the strength of character that the rescue workers needed to deal with the aftermath of that awful day until I visited this place. You get given head phones and you put in the number next to each exhibit and the narrator (who is also the photographer and curator) tells you about each one. I won't describe any, but you should visit and see it. It was terribly sad and I cried, but felt it just enhanced my trip even more so.

A Beautiful, peaceful place.. I was looking forward to this visit throughout my trip in new York and it certainly wasn't one to forget! The artifacts recovered were fascinating along with the photo covered walls. I was lucky enough to meet the man himself and he was very interesting. The small size of the museum made it peaceful yet comfortable for those who lost friends or relatives Overall, an amazing and emotional trip.
A must. This was brilliant but emotional, a must when visiting New York . Sad to see what people went through

Very touching. A friend recommended this tiny museum and we were not disappointed and doubt we'd have found it if she hadn't told us about it. We visited before going to the actual memorial site (some of these reviews seem to get the two mixed up... The ground zero workshop museum is near the Chelsea market and you pre-book a tour at 11am or 1pm. The website is http://www.groundzeromuseumworkshop.com) and it made me appreciate the stories behind some of the victims of 9/11 in readiness for visiting the memorial site. I can imagine this museum being very helpful in the healing process for families and friends of the victims because it is very tasteful and respects each individual story. An amazing place and well worth finding.

Emotional small museum.. Emotional small museum that gives you a look inside ground zero and what the rescue people ánd dogs were facing while digging and searching for victims from the brutal attack on 9/11.Our guide Jake was wonderful, giving room for emotions and was warm and respectful to his visitors. After that we went on to the 9/11 memorial site, thanks to the 2 hour tour we had a deeper understanding of what had taken place in the deep infinity pools.........I would highly recommend this small but big in atmosphere museum in the Meatpackers district in New York.

Small but significant. All that we experienced today was not like your average museum - just one medium sized room with poignant, respectful photographs and non-personal but significant items found at the ground zero site. We visited this small museum before going to see the actual site and it had a huge impact in terms of the reality of that day and the months and years following for the lives of people worldwide.
So sad. Grown men prepare to shed a tear. I did. A place or remembrance and respect. To my Officer colleagues who i didn't have the chance to meet.

Touching. Breathtaking! A very personal journey through photos and artifacts from Mr. Suson. This is a not-for-profit museum, the proceeds are shared with 9/11 Charities! Who knew one little room could have such a big impact.

"Amazing Insight". Very pleased we booked this via are trip to NYC.This was a very sad and moving insight into such a tragedy on a fantastic City.The tour of the Workshop was very good and my Wife & myself felt very lucky to meet and listen toGary Suson who was the perfect Gentleman!!!Wow what A Guy!!! Thank You so much for your time on the 15/02/14.Anyone visiting NYC plan two hours into your itinerary for this moving experience!
Sobering. This visit brought greater understanding of what we had previously only seen on television and the museum added to what was a very sobering experience.and one I will never forget.
Very interesting, but also very sad. It gave us more of an insight into what New Yorkers really felt during and after that terrible day. A real eye opener.
With respect.. Going through this place brings it back to you in a second. The place itself is very touching and exciting, recommended not only for every american.
Humbling. A must see but for sombre reasons, don't go if you get over emotional. I was touched very deeply by some of the exhibits and photographs on display

Jawdropping. I felt that a visit to New York would not be complete without a visit to the 9/11 site, but I'd also heard great things about the Museum Workshop which is what a lot of the reviews on this page AREN'T referrring to.The staff were extremely knowledgable and polite, but the beauty of this place is that it is so small and compact, but it tells you everything you need to know, lets you feel every emotion, helps you understand the enormity of the event and how it felt for those directly involved in the event and how it still affects people today.It wasnt what i was expecting as I walked in, but don't be fooled by the size of the place, it packs a much bigger punch that you might expect.

OK, but 9/11 tribute center is better. Intresting meusum, very good audio guide, very friendly staff but the musuem itself is just a room with few artifacs and pictures. We felt that this museum was a little bit overpriced(25$). We went to 9/11 tribute center after this and we found it much more intresting.

Worth a visit. Decided to book a reservation based on Tripadvisor reviews here. Went for 2 pm "tour" on a Monday afternoon - it was snowing heavily but we really didn't have trouble finding it via subway from our hotel in Times Square. Arrived 10 minutes early as instructed after having lunch just down the street. We hit the #3 button to the building but it was hard to hear the voice coming from upstairs. She let us in just as someone else with a key was going in and he advised that we take the stairs up one flight because the elevator was slow.We were greeted at the top of the stairs, hung up our coats on their coat rack, and used the bathroom. We were then given a headset and listened to the introduction by the photographer - who narrated everything - Mr Suson. At around 2, we were seated on the sofas and watched 2 videos on the HUGE tv screen with the lights dimmed - one was a clip of Mr Susone's Good Morning America interview and the other was a narrated slideshow of some of his more famous pictures. I teared up several times during this part - it was very well done.After the videos, our hostess pointed out several things in the museum that she called "not to be missed" and encouraged us to touch things and take pictures (no video allowed). We spent the next 1.5 hours taking our time looking at the different pictures and artifacts and listening to the narration. Most of the pictures/artifacts were numbered and you just punched in the corresponding number on your headset. There were a ton of very interesting bits of information about the ground zero site and the recovery/clean up process. The museum is basically Mr Suson's apartment. It is one room but there are so many pictures and artifacts that it was very much so well worth the visit. When we were there (4 of us), there was just one other couple there too. There was just a little bit of redundancy but overall extremely well done.

Moving tribute. Visiting the tribute centre (the official museum is not open until spring) was a moving experience.We listened to a talk given by a gentleman who was a Fireman who worked at Ground Zero for 2 months on a 24 hour on 24 hour off pattern - you couldn't help but be moved to tears.

Don't miss this!. This was so well presented, in such an usual manner. A tribute to the those that lost lives, and to the families. It was an honor to meet the photographer, and our tour guide was wonderful and thoughtful in guiding us through this national disaster. Since the space is small, the reservations were necessary.

Very worthwhile. This tiny museum packs a punch. Lots of interesting and poignant information about the recovery and clean up of Ground Zero. Very well organized and insightful. Yes, it is emotional, but the creators of this exhibit do an excellent job and not attempting to manipulate emotions. They even warn which exhibits might be more challenging to experience. Took two 18 year olds (kindergarterners on 9-11) who felt like it was important to experience. Well done.

If you only visit one "museum", make it this one. We are a family of 4 (mom, dad, 18 yr old son and 16 yr old daughter) who lost no one on 9/11, but we all wanted to visit the site, and felt that the workshop could help us appreciate what this tragedy truly meant to the city and its people. It consists of one room, you watch a couple of videos giving you some background info as well as clips of news footage and interviews, then the excellent "guide" explains that you can handle and photograph virtually everything you see, as well as listen to an audio guide which is narrated by the official photographer (the only man allowed to take photos, and unsalaried ) The staff are prepared for tears as well as any questions you might have. I would recommend this to everyone - you must go. Some of the stories will move you to tears, artefacts will send a shiver down your spine - there is a clock that stopped the very second the first plane hit - but you will come out feeling uplifted in a way I can't put into words. Truly the best little museum in New York.

A Little Jewel in NYC. We recently visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop in New York. While tiny in space, it is packed with photos and exhibits telling the tragedy of 911 and the extraordianry bravery and courage of the first responders. The docent was extremely well versed and presented the information in such a respectful manner, everyone in attendance completed the tour in silence and with reverence. We heard stories and saw items that we had no previous knowledge of before our visit. You have to know about the museum through word of mouth or from a concerege because I did not see a lot of advertisement due to limited funds, but it is very worth the hour and a half it takes to see the entire exhibit.

Informative, breath taking, emotional, and so surprising.. We reserved our tickets online for fear of waiting in a long line...my thoughts initially were that the museum was quite small for how amazing the reviews were, but after I put the headset on of the guided tour my experience completely changed. Dont let the size of the museum fool you!Within the first 5 minutes I already had tears streaming down my face. It was quite emotional. The guided tour is narrated by the photographer who took all the photos, and he explains why he took them and the stories behind them. Plus all the artifacts and the information was the icing on top. YOU MUST GO.

A great experience. Being able to get a hindsight of that very tragic day makes you realise how fortunate we are but the most terrific thing of all is the true grit and strength of the whole spectrum of people who were touched by this event I'm not ashamed to say that I cried the emotion I felt was very raw and I want to go back again x

Lovely customer service. We stopped here after a long cold day at the Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island. It's small and it was a busy place, however, in spite of that the people who worked took an enormous amount of time to tell us about books or pictures. Really anything that was asked of them. Very informative. I will say this: if they don't have any more tickets to the memorial and want to see walk down there anyway. You can still get in. Just depends if there is a line or if you want to wait.

Very moving experience. It was my first visit to NY and I could not have missed this. It brought us one step closer to what really happened on that fateful day.... I cried there. It was very moving to see REAL artefacts from the sight, the clock that stopped when the electricity was cut off as the plane hit the tower... the calendar showing the date... Real piece of Glass....

The most moving place. This museum gives tribute to a day when it seems as if the world stood still. As we watched the tragedy unfold, we froze in disbelief. The images & artifacts found here bring you back to that time and move you to tears. Touching the steel & iron from the towers that have been made into crosses & the glass from windows on the upper floors remind you of the losses from the tragedy & the bravery & courage of the recovery workers. If you visit NYC, you absolutely MUST visit.
Sad. If you wanna feel the same way New Yorkers felt that day, go to this museum. It is interesting, very good pictures. But too sad...

`Interactive Museum, PickeD up WTC artifacts'. Visiting from Europe, wanted to know more about 9/11. Went to the 9/11 Memorial Pools at Ground Zero, thought it was commercial, profiteering, long lines, and $10 for a bracelet? Learned nothing.......then, we Went to Ground Zero Museum Workshop, the tiny museum in meatpacking district. WOW. big difference...Located in a small commercial business building, tour was hands on ,, got to pick up WTC artifacts (made it more real), see images by the Official Photographer at Ground Zero. The Tour Guide was caring, professional and friendly, explaining so much. We also got a self guided handset with the stories of the remnants & pictures and before we knew it the 2 hours was up. It was most impressing..Avoid the ground zero site and go to this tiny museum if you wish to learn more stories bout what happened at ground zero after the 911... Also some of our money we paid goes to help a disabled firefighter who lost his brother on 9-11. Money well spent. Highly recommend.

Biggest little museum - powerful experience!. A tiny one room museum with a rich insight into the stories of the 9/11 tragedy.The many photos and artifacts will provide you with a very emotional and insightful experience.If you are planning to visit the Memorial, be sure to experience The Ground Zero Museum Workshop ahead of time. If you have already experienced the Memorial, visit the Museum as it will add another dimension to the 9/11 tragedy.Do not miss this newly opened museum located in the meat packing district.Make reservations in advance, and enjoy some tasty treats around the corner in the Chelsea Market before/after your visit.

A hidden gem. My friend suggested the GZ museum for something to see during our day in NYC. We were late arriving at our scheduled time and the women working at the museum could not have been nicer about us arriving late. We did miss most of the video shown ( totally our fault ) but everyone receives a audio headset with recordings explaining the photographs and artifacts discovered at gound zero. We were lucky enough that the photographer who took what I believe to be the official photos at ground zero during the recovery was at the museum during our visit. He was wonderful about answering our questions and even told us a few stories. His photos are just beautiful and just show the raw emotions of the people who worked tirelessly for months down there. It was worth the visit and I recommend stopping in.

Totally Amazing. The smallest yet most interesting museum in NYC - completely touching photos & stories of the 911 disaster - a MUST visit if you are interested in learning more about the recovery operations. Our tour guide was brilliant, very informative with the respectful tone the museum deserves.Fantastic.

An easily-missed gem. Most first-time visitors probably get this museum mixed up with the attractions at the actual WTC site, without realising that it's an entirely different experience. You need to seek it out - the entrance is a small door off the street, operated by a buzzer system. No fancy hoardings to guide you. Once inside though it's a revelation. There are so many amazing artefacts that you truly will not see anywhere else and the intimate atmosphere really brings home the tragedy of that day. It's maybe the single experience that will stand out in anyone's trip to NYC.

An intimate way to remember 9/11. We brought five 16yr old girls...who were 3yrs old when this tragic event happened. Initially, it wasn't exactly what I had expected, but after spending time, I realized that it was a perfect venue to explain the event to the teens who were with us. The experience provides and intimate way of understanding how it impacted so many people. We had thought we could go see the memorial site and then visit the museum? Didn't work....the lines to go to the memorial were huge...and getting to the museum/workshop took longer than we thought. It was a nice way to commemorate the victims and survivors of this sad event.
AWESOME. It was totally interessting and touching my soul! it was value und it was little "museum" but great came out of it would recommend to all of my friends and even go again when im in new york!

Very Moving. So glad we found this little museum,don't be put off by the size of the room, as small d as that one room is, it is one of the most moving and informative places I have been in a long time. The small you are given at the start is given by such a passionate young girl, you are already transfixed. There are some emotional recordings so beware but all in all a very moving, informative visit and think everyone should pay a visit.

Overrated and overprices. Overrated small museum.....not really a tour (as advertised). You watch a short film and here 10 minutes of a narration. Then you walk around with headsets and listen to stories matching artifacts in the room.....very moving stories thouigh!

A moving experience.. While this revise is a little late, the memories of this workshop are forever with me. If there is one museum you must see this is it. Here you can touch a piece of the steel from the towers, which puts a lot of things in perspective from that day. You are given your own headset and can roam around at your own pAce. I hope to return one day. I even bought the boom by the photographer and they posted it back to me in Australia, with his signature on it.

Beautiful little museum. What a fantastic little museum. Who knew so much information could be stored in one room! The pictures and the stories behind them were moving and really made you see what people went through on that fateful day and the years that have followed. The lady who did the introduction at the beginning was great and obviously very passionate about what she does. You even get to hold some of the artefacts from 9/11 which I definitely wasn't expecting. A moving place to go which I would definitely recommend.

Small boutique museum with so much to see. This museum is not located at ground zero and should not be confused as a government run museum.It is simply a private collection of the 9/11 artifacts and exhibits about 100 of Gary Marlon Suson's most notable photographs of the tragedy.So many items are on display and each tells a story, the pieces of rubble from the twin towers, a piece from one of the aircrafts that crashed into the towers, the bible, the clock that stopped at 10.03am, the pictures of hero fire fighters, the mobile phones,the picture of the lovely girls that came to sing Christmas carols to the firefighters...The museum is better experienced than describedVery solemn but very educative. I strongly recommend a visit to this museum.

Tiny museum with some good artifacts. My Partner and I decided to pay the museum a visit during our stay in NYC.We booked prior to arrival back in the UK.Wasn't to hard to find and you are greeted outside before going in.You have earphones and listen to some info about that awful morning and then you are able to look at some of the findings etc.A very moving day.

A MUST while in New York. This was my second visit to the Museum Workshop and it was phenomenal the second time around. What Gary shares in his pictures and stories tell the human stories of the tragedy on 9/11. Yes, so many lives were lost on that day but a good portion of the fight is about what occurred after; in trying to rescue, paying respect and honoring those who died.This museum reaches into the hearts and souls of everyone who was there. It conveys how hard the survivors worked at the site, how they also suffered in the rescue attempts.This is a must see for anyone who visits NY and a great prelude to the 9/11 Memorial. I'm also so impressed that proceeds from this Museum Workshop benefit those families. The new 9/11 Memorial won't provide that. Gary is truely a superb photographer but more importantly a wonderful humanitarian.

Very moving. Well worth going to! A very moving experience. Book advance as only a limited amount of people can go at any one time. You are talked through the artefacts and photos and then allowed to go around yourself with headphones to each piece. Whole thing is 2 hours. this museum is right next to the High Line, it was nice to go there after as it's very peaceful and gives you time to reflect!

Must see. This was an absolutely amazing little museum. The fact that you are up close to the artifacts and are hearing the voices of those who were at ground zero during the 6 month recovery operation is absolutely amazing. It was a very moving experience and I had the honor of meeting the photographer, Gary Suson. Tremendous experience that I would highly recommend!

"Very Touching". Great, Great, speakers that work there! They were very humble and knew what they were talking about. How could anyone leave there without shedding a tear is beyond me......I truly cried. It makes you realize how thankful and grateful we should be for all that we have because it could be taken away in a secon. God Bless all the families that went through 911 with a lost one :(

Small but, Mighty!. Just by trip advisor reviews we made this a must on our first trip to NYC. It was from a whole different view point with a very intimate point of view. I really do feel like it is worth the money and the time to see this very small museum/workshop. I was traveling with my five year old daughter that didn't really understand but was amused with the headsets and pushing buttons that I was able to enjoy the exhibit and didn't even have to leave early. You do have to pre-purchase tickets but, that is the best part, no waiting in line and you know exactly when to be there. I would definitely recommend this.
Very Interesting. Very interesting attraction, located some distance from the Ground Zero site. The staff were very attentive.

Must do while in NYC. A fabulous little museum that provides a sobering and chilling view of the aftermath of the destruction of the Twin Towers. Very thought provoking and moving. A must do in NYC! This is not the Memorial Pools but visiting there prior to going to the pools gives you a massive understanding of the carnage and heartbreak that occurred prior to re-build.

A must see!. If in NYC I would recommend you visit the museum. It brings all of the news reports, films and documentaries to life. It is extremely sad to see all of the things found in the wreckage and to see both the survivors and those left behind talk through their experiences.Very interesting and a must see.
The Reality of "The Pit" (Ground Zero). Videos and photographs but many artifacts found in the weeks after 9/11. Touching, informative, surprising - excellent display.
Memory. You must visit this ground zero work shop.the scars of that terrible day haunt.even though other side of the world.you will see various articles 911.

Moving Memorial. A very good way to learn about the full horror of the aftermath of the 9/11 tragedy. The small museum has gathered a touching but informative collection of artefacts and Suson's photographs. Well worth a visit

Heart felt.. This was a experience ,it was sad knowing, that the items in the museum belonged to people that perished on that terrible day ,but you have to visit so we will never forget what happened and keep the memories of the people that died. There is an entry fee ,but you don,t grudge as it goes to the fund. Minutes after you enter you feel the emotion and a sort of spiritual feeling knowing that the photos on the wall were all killed .If you visit NYC you have to visit the museum and ground zero.
Very Sad. Good presentation touching and sad. This gave a great insight into the extent of the destruction caused by these mad people. We liked the layout and were touched by the sadness.

Don't underestimate the size of this venue..... We had been staying at the Millenium Hilton across the road from the WTC sight so was already used to the 9/11 tourist attractions, tours etc that were located immediately outside our hotel. But, this gave us a wholely different perspective as it seemed a lot more personal and touching than we expected. You have the chance to see photos that have never been published, to hear personal experiences via video and taped recordings and to touch and feel artefacts recovered from the sight that you would never be allowed to experience anywhere else. I never expected to be emotionally touched so much by the experience - highly recommended

Little gem in an out of the way location but so worth it!. Our family of 5 including teenagers and younger enjoyed this small and intimate tour. In a loft location near the Chelsea markets in the Meat Packing District this ''experience' has left a lasting impression on us all. It was simply delivered by the gorgeous Phoenix and powerfully showed us Aussies what our US friends and families had to fully deal with on this tragic day. We left profoundly moved and would highly recommend this tour.

Touching.. This place is wonderful, yet touching at the same time. You wont leave with a dry eye thats for sure. It's all done in the least tacky sense and leaves you feeling a little heartbroken but good on the NYers for having somewhere like this...
An Excellent view from the roof. The view from the roof is outstanding. Definitely worth the entrance fee, and we didn't have to wait in line for more than 10 minutes.

Worth the time to stop and visit. We read on trip advisor about the Ground Zero workshop museum and we are so glad we took the time to go see it.You get to see pictures you will not see anywhere else and the story behind every picture or relic touches your heart.I read other reviews about how small it is which is true but size in this case does not matter you get every bit of your moneys worth from this one of a kind museum.After we left there it is a short walk to the above ground park that makes an enjoyable walk on the way to the Chelsea Market for lunch.

Very moving. I was surprised how small this museum was, just one room of exhibits documenting the recovery process at Ground Zero. We watched a short movie and then were free to wander around the exhibits, which were all numbered. We had headsets which played a story about each numbered item, mostly photos but also a variety of items, many with a sad story attached. We were here for most of our 2 hour time slot. A very moving exhibit and definitely worth a visit

The personal museum experience. A little off the beaten track and worth every little step. A photographic account of the ground zero recovery efforts and personal stories of the brave first responders. Their ordeals. Their accomplishments. The artifacts and beautifully documented images of this perilous journey are all appropriately tucked away in an intimate one room setting. A place to come to reflect, remember and learn more.

A must do when visiting New York. This is absolutely amazing! It is a fitting tribute to all the lives that were tragically lost on that bleak day. The small museum contained numerous photographs and artefacts from the twin towers and the rescue operation in a respectful, non commercial manner and I take my hat of to both the photographs taken by Mr Gary Suson and the way the museum has been organised. The visit is heart moving and represents a true reflection of what tragically took place. Once again my thanks to Mr Suson for creating this fitting tribute

Interesting view into WTC event. Located a distance from the original site of the World Trade Center, this one room museum offers interesting insight into the tragic event of 9/11/01 in New York City. A twelve minute video with highlights of the World Trade Center disaster set the stage for the artifacts that surround you.Headphones that allow each person to listen to details about items on display is well done. It is nice to be able to go at your own pace and select those items that are of interest. Admission is at predetermined times that are spaced about 2 hours apart. About 60 or 75 minutes is sufficient time to take it all in.After such a moving experience head a few blocks west to the Highline to take in the NY skyline and wonderful sights of the city.

REMEMBER. this tiny museum documents the aftermath of 911 with incredible photos and artifacts. It reminds us all of this horrible day all Americans should never forget. It is a very emotional experience.
Most Memorable Experience. Got to hold artifacts and hear real heart felt stories from those truly affected by that day, wonderful way to remember and reflect on all those innocent lives lost.

Moving and Excellent. This is definitely a moving experience that paired with going to the 9/11 Memorial Sight is really a day in itself. Now pay attention, THIS IS IN A COMPLETELY DIFFERENT LOCATION, uptown from the Memorial, take the subway, it's fine. They ask for a reservation time and actually call you if you're behind a minute or two to confirm you're coming (we hit a late subway, but they waited for us). You go into a small studio apartment room outfitted with objects and pictures from the 9/11 site, there is a very moving video presentation. It is well worth the trip away from the rest of the city , souvenirs are available for purchase. Yes they say you have to leave your bags there, but they are in the same room with you, just can't physically bring them around they don't want you knocking stuff over (its a very fragile room). Pictures are allowed all except 2 items that they will tell you about. Otherwise....very moving and a fantastic time, please go!
Fantastic. Truly an emotional experience, make sure you take some tissues. This was such an amazing experience to see and hear all about this from another perspective. Definitely worth a visit :)

A Fantastic tour. Very moving - great stories from people who were there on the day. Take tissues!! You can see items they have found and hear about the clean up and the amazing work that has been done.

A Must-Do Before Visiting the Memorial Site. By all means, please book a visit here in advance of your visit to the 911 Memorial site. This is an intimate and highly emotional experience...the museum is very tiny, but had an incredible impact on me and my family. Gary's stories and photographs are extraordinary. There are not words to describe this spiritual place.We are so pleased we heard about this place and made reservations to visit. Don't miss it.
Superb. Words are quite simply not enough.! A spiritual experience. A must see for all. Very moving. So pleased to have had the opportunity to visit.

A must see when in New York.. Having spent many years involved with the fire service, and remembering very clearly sitting in the bedroom one evening watching it all 'play out' this was a must see. A truly inspirational time, and one in which the magnitude of what happened was reinforced. It becomes very clear why the Americans have so much respect for all their first responders!

Never forget. After reading many TripAdvisor reviews, I decided to go to the Ground Zero Museum workshop before going to the 9/11 memorial site.Back home, I'm known as a "hard nut" where I do not shed many tears, but after visiting this place, cry I did and it hurt.I came from Australia and wondered what to expect whilst waiting outside the workshop which located in the meat packers district of New York. It is important to note, this Museum is a result of the courageous and wonderful work of a great American, Mr Gary Marlon Suson. It is not located at the 9/11 memorial site and many confuse both places/locations. Please do not take this as a negative. No one should go to New York without paying their respects to this small, humble, yet extremely powerful room. I arrived there after seeing some CNN reports of Gary's work and in the hope, I could meet him and shake his hand.After a gentle walk up stairs, you enter a white painted room with photos hanging. After the small group of guests sit and get comfortable, an introduction is played on a television screen. No graphic vision is provided, but there is vision of the effort of the recovery of efforts together with the 911 phone calls which simply, hurt me. It has been a long time when I have struggled to breathe, in trying to hold back tears that had no choice, but to fall.The staff, young, beautiful and respectful, guide you through the purposes of this workshop, provide you headphones and explain next to each imagine, there is a number which you key it into a recorded to find Gary explaining the background of the particular photo.There is no time pressure, to move along quickly, even though at first I wondered how I could continue to feel the pain I first felt during the introduction. Whether it is due to the relaxed environment, or respect for those lost or Gary's soothing voice explaining the photos, I and I imagine everyone else there, were more than comfortable to remain and reflect on the events of 9/11.To hold a cross cut from the remaining steel of the twin towers, well no words can describe that adequately. A surprise occurred after being there for about 2 hours. Gary arrived to say hello to those still there, even though it troubles him to see his own work, his efforts. Shake his hand I did, I probably broke a couple of his knuckles whilst doing it without realizing, but I am so thankful and blessed to meet this man. A man that has seen so much and done so much for those families who have lost loved ones on that terrible day.I asked Gary to sign a book I purchased to which he asked what comment would he like me to write. There were no words that I could offer other than simply, "I'll leave it up to you mate." He wrote, "To my Aussie friends, never forget."And indeed, I will never forget

Speachless. This is a must do visit as it gives you the real feel of what it must have been like 9/11 ...... This is a very special place and very well respected, you can actually feel the stillness, quietness and genuine sadness - Its hard to describe but definitely worth a visit.
Ground Zero. The world changed on that fateful September day. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop has many items that provide more information and memorialize those who lost their lives that day.

Intimate setting with interesting artifacts and a wealth if information if your curious about all aspects of ground zero recover. It's a small 2nd floor studio apartment turned into a shrine of 9/11 photos and artifacts. If you use the handheld tourmate for all the items, it can easily take up the two hour time frame. You can leave earlier though. Do not arrive earlier than your ticket time. They won't let you in. We were there five minutes before our tour and we had to wait outside. I would only recommend this museum for somebody who is really interested in the recovery efforts that followed 9/11.

Touching. This was very well done for a sad turning point in the worlds history. The workshop was enlightning and tastefully done and just a short distance to the memorial. The memorial was a must see to ensure we do not forget.

Good things come in small packages. Very moving experience! Hard to believe such a small facility could hold so much information. Reported to be 1000 square feet, seemed smaller. Excellent presentations with superior narratives at each different exhibit. Truly amazing pieces ans photos from Ground Zero. You have to go before you go to the 911 Memorial. Helps bring it all together.

Excellent. This museum is on the second floor of a building where photographer Gary Susson took a photo of one of the towers collapsing on that fateful morning sept 11th. It houses a small museum of his photographs and artefacts from the ground zero site. It is remarkably poignant and tells the story of the aftermath of 9/11 in a most remarkable way. Two videos are shown which give background to the stories explained on the walls, we were given headsets to listen to explanations of the exhibits which made this very personal. At the moment there is no museum at the ground zero site so I would definitely recommend a visit here before you visit the 9/11 memorial site. It is in the meat packing district near the high line park (which was great to walk home on). This is a sensitive and very worthwhile museum to visit.
Don't miss. Excellent and thought provoking do this as part of the water taxi package as you get entrance with your ticket

Very moving. Being a serving officer it made you realise how much the word 'family' is important with my colleagues at work. The children's pictures were moving and made a tough but like me shed a tear
Very moving. Do not miss this!. Its a tiny place, but jammed with amazing photos and artifacts from 9-11. Made even better by the commentary you can hear about each item through provided earphones.

Amazing, interactive experience.. I visited the GZMW on my latest trip to NYC. We learned of it through a friend who had recommended it. We were so incredibly moved by the photos and artifacts within this little museum. I decided to visit GZMW just prior to our scheduled visit time at the 9/11 Memorial and I am so glad we did as the visit to the memorial was vey much impacted by our experience at the GZMW. The staff at the museum at very welcoming and are clearly very passionate about their work. You can spend up to 2.5 hours at the museum with your personal headset that describes for you each and every photo and artifact you are seeing. I was one of the last to leave and I would definitely have no hesitation to go here again.

Gives justice to the site. I think making this museum was a great idea. It pays homage to the people who lost their lives and makes you feel that life is precious and we should be more grateful for what and who we have. A great concept and the pictures and the souvenirs are very touching.

A Must See. This is an amazing place to visit. Very emotional but a must to see when in New York. It is just up from the World Trade Centre Site. There is memorabilia from the World Trade Centre from that day, also souvenirs to remember, Just down from there on the way to the world trade centre site is the fire station of the first responders, on the side of their building is a bronze tribute to the firefighters, it is amazing & very emotional.

Small but powerful. Deserves it's reputation as the biggest little museum. It is very little however very humbling. Read previously on Tripadvisor to do this before 9/11 memorial site and I do agree. It brings the true heroism of everyone involved in the aftermath alive.
A place to remember. This was a place full of memories and video clips of the tragic event that took place. Lots to purchase as keepsakes at very reasonable prices. Thoroughly enjoyed it

Need a reality check? A bonding experience not to be missed.. The museum is not open yet but the 9/11 tribute center is. Pay the money to enter this small memorial that the victims families put together. Look at the walls of people who lives were taken away and whos remains were more than likely never found. Down stairs is a gift shop. I always purchase numerous bracelets that have 343 written on them for just a dollar. There is always an EMT, police officer and the fire dept who really appreciate this as a gift. A reminder of our first res ponders to the 9/11 attack. I love this city and the people in it. They deserve respect and so does our country. " This is a day when ALL Americans from every walk of life resolve for justice and peace. None of us will ever forget the day, Yeet we go forward to defend freedom and all that is good and just in our world" President George BushTeach you children to honor and respect America because one day they may be called to defend our freedoms, with pride to be American and love for this country they will go willingly as the first res ponders did, GOOD Advice! Go on line and print out your visitors pass for the memorial.

A fabulous monument to help all remember the sad occurrence. what stood out largely to us was the incredible might and determination that man has to keep. goingThis highly spiritual place while we were there certainly felt like it was surrounded by Angels
A must see in NY! Take your tissues.. Based on feedback from friends we booked a session at this tiny venue. The most moving experience ever. Highly recommend to all.
Must see. A beautiful place which is just a very humbling experience. Don't miss going there to think of the beautiful lives lost and the terror New York must have felt that day, Wonderful tribute.

Never Forget. I just got back from my fourth trip to New York City ,and every time I have travelled with different members of my family and friends. Each time I have made a point of taking them to this museum,( and I will go again and again) The first reaction is to how small the space is ( no bigger than most peoples living room), the artifacts and pictures that surround you make you feel that you are in a time capsule, and transported back to that horrifying day of Sept.11th, you stand transfixed just as you did that day remembering the exact time, where you were, and what you were doing. But you soon realize that what Mr. Suson has done is taken all these pictures, ,images and artifacts and turned this into a place to heal and find peace. Many of the families of those who lost their lives that day come here for that reason. There are no vivid plane hitting the tower pictures that were so dominate everywhere on 9/11, instead Mr. Suson has taken pictures that depict hero's--firefighters, rescue dogs and ordinary people who stepped up that day to help in spite of the devastation happening around them. The artifacts ( many personal ) that belonged to those we lost help us to remember them and their families. The pictures taken by Mr. Suson are a chronicle of all that transpired the months during and after 9/11. This museum evokes emotions, you will feel sadness ( nobody I have ever taken there comes away with dry eyes) and grief, but this is good as without these things healing is not possible. Sept. 11th should never have happened, but it should also not be forgotten.Thanks to Gary Suson and the Ground Zero Museum Workshop he created.WE WILL NEVER FORGET 9/11 Diane K ( from Canada but with her heart in New York) God Bless America and the World may we all live in peace.

A Must-See.. Wow! This is so emotional - an unforgettable experience and a very fitting tribute to 9/11 victims. Initial thought was this will be like visiting any museum. However, the photos and items on display were excellent and evoked a real sense of empathy and of the scale of the tragedy. The stories behind them bring the sense of tragedy to life in a very factual yet emotive way.If you do nothing else in New York visit the 9/11 memorial - for us it was life changing - an absolutely amazing experience.

Ground Zero Museum. This is a real eye opener and tear jerker. We did the ground zero tour with a lady who lived nearby and she gave her account of that day, remembering every little detail as though it happened only yesterday. Puts things into perspective, especially when walking around the museum seeing items of clothing and photographs of events. Definitely go and see this!

Meaningful. Initial thought was this will be quick. However, the audio clips for all of the photos and items on display were excellent. The stories behind them bring the sense of tragedy to life in a very considerate way. The museum is like the Tardis from Doctor Who - looks small but is actually huge. We also met the photographer himself Gary Suson. Very well done and worth a visit.

Beautiful Photographs & Personal Stories. We visited with our kids this summer. I chose this museum because we love photography and because I had read other reviews on TripAdvisor that said it was good for children. They were right! At first glance the museum was tiny. But in actuality, that's the point. It is a very personal experience. We spent over two hours looking at photographs and artifacts and listening to the first-hand stories from Ground Zero. It was easily the highlight of our trip.

Moving and unforgettable.. I visited this muesum with my wife. Very moving and unforgettable experience. Shocking and sad in every way , really lets you see the lives of the people around the times of the attacks. My first time in New York , so had to visit. Plenty of information in the muesum. I will never forget this place and my mind will always think of that year.

All Americans visiting NYC need to visit here. Gives great insight to non-NYC residents a more authentic idea of the unbelievable effect the attacks had on the city and the amazing heroism and spirit displayed immediately after the attacks and during the recovery period. Truly heartbreaking but at the same time makes me so proud to be an American.

Take Tissues. We went to the Museum Workshop with our children before we went to the Memorial. They were born after 9/11/01 and so they were unfamiliar with everything. They were fascinated with the mixture of boards with text and videos and began to have a better understanding of what happened. Remembering it all so vividly, I was in tears as I walked around (there are discreet boxes of tissues provided) as was my husband. There is a noticeboard downstairs with thoughts from various visitors that I found moving too. The memorial itself was very simple and elegant. I was surprised at how formal the whole thing was. I always thought you could just pitch up and have a look, but of course, it is a building site, so it isn't feasible. Whether you remember what happened or not, it is worth your time.

Ground Zero Memorial Museum. I am so glad that we visited the museum before going to the memorial. It was a moving experience to see the photos, stories and artefacts. The video told the stories of people who worked in the WTC and the part that the WTC played in their lives.

it makes a lasting impression. this is such a mixed emotions type of place- there are so many personal elements to this tragic story and this museum shows that as well as giving factual information on the tragedy- its a deeply moving museum to visit. whilst many elements are sad it shows the courage and strenght of the new york people and the bravery of the rescue staff involved

Important place to visit. Hard attraction to review because it is more a memorial. Rarely do you get to visit a museum where you can pick up artefacts and actual materials found on the site. Photographs were amazing and very emotional to view. Audio tour is self guided, allowing you to go at your own pace, chocolates and tissues are on hand incase you get overwhelmed. Staff were friendly and are aware of the significance of what occurred in 2001 and this venue allows the chance for visitors to remember and have a visual and physical connection.We also got to meet the photographer, lovely!
Beautiful, moving tribute. This is worth the line up! A respectful, moving tribute to all of the lives lost during the 9/11 attack.

Good but not worth the price. This is a one-room museum of commissioned photos with a self-guided audio tour. It's impactful to hear about personal stories of some of the firefighters, but sadly I felt like admission should have been less than $25. Would not take young children because they would be bored.
911 memorial. This is a must do wow the impact of this it pull on your heart strings I found it very emotional looking at the wall of photos of people still missing :(

tears to my eyes. wonderfully done but surprisingly not polished. This is a wonderful experience but feels like one can touch things, even though you can't. Some museum experiences are sorta cold, but this is real from the first moment in the door. Don't miss it.

You will never forget. Vacationing in New York City July 6-10, 2013 visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop dedicated to the Fireman and First Responders of 9/11. Just more the most moving 2 hours in my entire life. Everyone must visit this museum. Words can not describe how 4 of us felt during the visit and after. YOU WILL NEVER FORGET.
Dale W.

Best Stop in NYC. We were extremely impressed with this small and intimate museum. The artifacts and film brought tears to our eyes. We were fortunate that official photographer Suson was present and we were able to talk with him and ask questions concerning his remarkable experience. His mission is to honor and educate as many as possible connected to the 9/11 disaster. Families of the victims are welcomed privately in order to help the healing process. It is evident that this was a labor of love. Put this at the top of your list for New York City. It is an experience you will always remember.

Well worth a visit.. I was really impressed with this little museum and was really pleased I made the visit. I was surprised it was not more publicised as it is not in all guidebooks and the one that I found it in only had a small mention of it. The museum handled the type of material it dealt with in a sensitive and thought provoking way.

With the utmost integrity. If you want to know more about the tragic events of 9/11 and the recovery without feeling a "cheap" tourist than go visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Gary Marlon Suson was the only official photographer at Ground Zero. He managed to capture The Recovery with the utmost integrity. The host Jennifer greeted us in a friendly way and gave a clear introduction of his impressive works and the audio tour. Because the museum is located in a large room you're really taken up in the presentation. Gary walked in and told us he was inspired by the museum of Anne Frank in Amsterdam. Being from Holland we smiled.

Ground Zero, a fitting tribute. The Ground Zero workshop while very sobering, it should also act as a permanent reminder to the world of the atrocity and murder of all those innocent people. The courage of the emergency services people should never ever be forgotten. The reflecting pools are a very fitting tribute and reminder.

A must see stop when in NYC. My whole family was taken up in the presentation of the aftermath of this tragic day. Being retired from the fire service, and having spent time with NYFD, I shared their loss, along with the countless others that perished that dark day in the history of this country. While listening and looking at the artifacts, you can almost feel what the searchers felt. Very well and tastefully done.
Very sobering experience. Followed the storyline of 9/11 and saw pictures of all the victims as well as hearing some stories. It was all done very tastfully with thefamilies of victims considered.

Best little museum...agreed!. This museum is right by the highline. It is a one room museum with more information than you will find in museums more than 10 times it's size. You will walk away with a much better understanding of what happened that day and after. you are free to take pictures in the museum and touch all of the artifacts. It will certainly leave an impression.

Everyone should visit this special museum!. This was such a unique experience to reflect on what happened on September 11th and the recovery that went on for months afterwards. Very tastefully done, a quiet exhibit to see at your own pace. I would recommend this to anyone visiting New York.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop Captures Your Soul. This hands-on museum workshop is a must-see experience. As a native New Yorker, I worked across a two-lane street from the Twin Towers as they were going up. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop captures in a spell-binding way the human face of the tragedy through dozens of artifacts from the site (virtually all of which can be held by visitors) and the countless short audio stories from those who were there during the terrorist act and its aftermath. While it is moving and very emotional, it really is OK to bring children. Each person brings his or her inner being here, and the few hours spent at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop can be felt at any level regardless of age. We will be going back very soon.

Don`t confuse ground zero museum with ground zero memorial!. This sentence you can find in your tickets, but we a really mixed up museum with memorial! I was intrigued when i see "second the best attraction in NY in tripadvisor". There is a small room on the second floor of small building at 14th street. It is not so easy to find right door.There are some photos regarding the job of firemans, some items from WTC like parts of window glasses, parts of floor`s granite, personal belongins of the victims. The tour starts from short movie with pictures, inerviews,sound effects. Probably I was not very impressed because image resolution was poor. Another reason is because I am not originally english speaking and I can`t understand all explanation. The 9/11 memorial is completely different! I was very very impressed! Better to stay there to feel the volume of tragedy instead of visiting museum/ By the way, some items from WTC you can see staying in the cue in ticket office of 9/11 memorial. Sorry, it is my personal opinion, I understand it could be different opinions.

A Must See. This place exhibits the original photography and other artifacts from the search and recovery of the aftermath of the 9-11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center buildings. There is a short video and then you use head sets to peruse the photographs. The photographer narrates everthing and tells you what was happening at the moment he took the picture. Even my stoic husband was in tears as the experience is so personal and so intimate. Thank you Gary Marlon Suson - the photographer.

Not To Be Missed. This is my second visit to the Ground Zero Museum and I still found it a most moving experience. The images and the artifacts found in this small room are so tastefully done. Only a few people can visit the museum at one time so the experience is quiet, peaceful and serene. There will be other 9/11 sites to visit, but a visit to this little museum will have an incredible impact on you. It is not to be missed!

Extremely Moving Experience. "The Biggest, Little Museum in New York" is a very appropriate title for this attraction. Photographer Gary Marlon Suson magnificently captures the raw emotion, and tribute expressed to the victims of one of the most heinous acts commited and infamous days in American History. His narration of the Images and actual artifacts from Ground Zero during the recovery effort is very heartfelt and moving. His assistants are very knowledgeable and helpful in answering any questions regarding the exhibit. "Never Forget" is the caption Gary wrote in the Autographed version of his book "Requiem", as we had the unexpected pleasure of meeting him during our visit. An absolute must see for anyone visiting New York.

an emotional trip.... A very small & intimate museum but it holds a lot of information and emotions.. very touching.. a lot of artefacts recovered after 9/11, very moving stories and photographs.. It's a must-see..

A Healing Experience. My husband and I were in New York City a few days ago to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary, and took the opportunity to visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Gary Marlon Suson has done an amazing job of turning a relatively small space into a huge experience that is tastefully done, incredibly thoughtful, and well worth the price of admission. His photographs, filtered through the lens of his own respect and compassion, capture the day-to-day life of those who worked in "The Pit." He has clearly and lovingly documented their courage, honor and sorrow, as well as their small victories and the kinship they established while shouldering this unenviable task together. The artifacts were meaningful, and there was something truly comforting about being able to hold tangible things -- real things that had survived this disaster -- in my hands. Charlotte, our guide, was friendly, knowledgeable, happy to answer questions, and both wise and circumspect enough to give everyone the amount of space they needed to process their emotional responses to the exhibit. We had the pleasure of meeting Gary Marlon Suson, who just happened to be there on the day we visited. He seemed genuinely glad to have us there, and made himself available to answer questions about his work and his experiences at Ground Zero. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a huge positive experience of healing and closure encapsulated in a small physical space. We considered it time and money well spent!

Different experiences. definitely worth the $25. It has great images and artifacts that captures the historical incident. the workshop is interactive because everyone has a headphone to listen to the description of each image/artifacts. the fact that I was able to touch some leftovers pieces from the Ground Zero enable me to make a deeper connection. it was a healing 2 hours that was well spent.and yes the chocolates in the toilet is free!
very emotional. very happy that we decided to visit the museum workshop, amazing work that has been done.very difficult to grasp what people must have gone through

Wish I would have just bought the book. While the museum itself is interesting, I did not think it was worth the price tag. My biggest complaint is how hard they try to invoke an emotional response from you. It is an emotional experience, it doesn't need to be forced. Also it feels like the girls have given their speech so many times that they are robotic at doing it. Plus their super short shorts seem to take away from their credibility. They just look like college interns passing the time. While I am very glad that the images have been captured and preserved, I think I would have preferred to buy the book and have them to look at again and again. The artifacts are interesting, but nothing spectacular and the fuselage from the TWA flight resting on the floor seems irreverent. Also they make you put your purse on a shelf due to space restraints, tell you that you can see it the whole time, but you can't. Anyone can walk out with your purse as it isn't monitored when you pick up your bag. You could be looking at pictures, someone else can take your purse and be out in New York before you know it.
Ground Zero Tribute Tour. It was poignant and very informative. Guides are all people who have a personal connection to 9/11 and ground zero.

This small Museum in the meat packing district is a MUST do.. Emotionally powerful and impacts you even more so than the Memorial Pools. You will hear, see feel, and understand the people of the 9/11 tragedy in an unforgettable way, it will change you forever. Stories and information are told to you thru audio devices as you haven't heard them before. You can hold objects from the towers, and get to know individual stories like no place else. As painful as it was, we went here first before visiting the pools at the World Trade. It somehow gave us even more respect and pride, and I didn't think that was possible.

Informative and Touching. This tour, while constrained to one rather small room, is much more than just one room through its content. You are taken to Ground Zero through the eyes of one photographers fantastic photographs of very appropriate and respectful scenes at the site throughout its entire revival! Both my wife and I would highly recommend this tour to anyone who is interested. The tour guides are young and knowledgeable making a very relaxing environment. We actually could have spent more time in there with all they have to see - but nevertheless, it was wonderful. Go here!

Wonderful, Beautiful, Emotional.... Superlatives simply can't do this Museum justice - all I can really say is make it a priority to visit if you're in NY. Its small, so make sure you book a ticket in advance - and then be prepared to be put through an emotional wringer - but done in the most compassionate, caring way possible. Thank you for allowing me to visit - I feel privileged...
Brings it all back. Very emotional experience, touring the museum. It brings the day back vividly. It was very nice to see the respect given to all the victims and their families then, and now.

a moving experience. This very small (1 room) museum is packed with artifacts and photos from the 9/11 recovery effort. It included 2 videos and a self guided "tour" of photos. The museum takes a very emotional subject and handles it very well and tastefully. It takes between 90-120 minutes to get through all the info that is available to view. I thought it was sad but time well spent...

A must-see intimate approach to remembering 9/11. In this intimate setting you get a humanized view of the recovery efforts through the artifacts and pictures taken by Gary Marlon Suson. I was brought to tears seeing the displays. We visited before our 9/11 Memorial Site visit, but it would be just as moving seeing it afterwards. We took our kids who were just 3 and 4 in 2001, they learned so much from the experience. The Ground Zero Workshop Museum is on the second floor over shops in the Meatpacking District, we were met outside by the tour guide, look carefully at the address. The tour lasts 1-2 hours. It was well worth seeing.
So moving. This was the most moving place we visited, a reminder of the awful tragedy and loss of lives, and the courage of all the families who allowed there grief to be shared

Worth the visit. We booked this prior to leaving home through AAA. Printed the tickets on line before we left.Pay attention to the address, it's just a doorway!!!Once you are escorted inside you see a couple of short videos and are given a short narrative talk about how this place came into existence and about the photogrpher.Actually kind of a small place (I thought it would be larger) but interesting non the least.The photographer was there that day, a very nice man and appreciative of your being there.He signed a book we purchased there and proceeds go to the families of 911 victims.Like I said, small, interesting and worth the cost.Let us never forget what happened that day.....

Makes the visit to the 911 Memorial site complete. This small museum is full of images and stories of the rescue and relief operations which took place for many months following the attack. It brings the visitor in touch with those whose job it was to painstakingly and reverently sift through the rubble. We visited the museum on the afternoon after we had visited the 911 memorial site in the morning. We were so glad that we had included this museum. It was a touching tribute to all associated with the tragedy.

Humbled!. A must see!! We were so moved and was in awe. We had a surprise and Mr suson arrived to meet people and sign his excellent phography for everyone. Well wirth your time. No Words can really express this humnling experience!! Thank you Mr. Suson!
Just necessary. We can never forget all these incredible people. It is an amazing place to hear the stories of so many heros and to see the faces of the lost.

The best of the Best!. Really touches your heart! Highly recommend it! For both kids and adults!!!!!!!
Brings back bad mmemmories!

Worth a visit. We didnt stay long at Ground Zero itself as it was quite unnerving & upsetting for me, however the Museum Workshop was also worth the visit & Im glad we made the trip over to this location

See this museum before going to the 911 Memorial. My sisters, niece, husband, and I attended the Ground Zero museum and workshop and had the honor of meeting the official photographer, Gary Suson. The pictures and artifacts were chilling. It was encouraging that the museum was developed for healing.....which it is. You will want to go to this museum first before going to the 911 Memorial. It will make the memorial more riveting. My heart goes out to Mr. Suson because he had to go through a lot in order to document Ground Zero for all of us.

Museum workshop. All housed in one room, this is a unique experience. Don't think about doing it - just do it. Then go straight on to see the memorial pools at the 9/11 site. This is something we should all experience in my opinion.
A mixed bag.... This attraction is both heart-warming and gut-wrenching. The heroic responses of the victims and responders contrasts with the horror of the attack. You leave proud and drained.

Glad we went... ...but don't consider it outstanding. The display of photographs is very well done, as is the video they show at the start. The audiophone descriptions available for the photos on the wall make a world of difference to the experience & allow the visitor to get as immersed in the experience as desired.

A must do on a trip to New York. Everyone was largely silent as we began the workshop tour, and then as we walked around the room, listening, remembering, discovering, understanding. Afterwards, we rated it as the best experience we had during our five wonderful days in New York. A visit to the Ground Zero site is moving, but this photographic tribute to the firemen of New York is an absolute must do on any trip to New York.

Very Emotional. Worth the trip. We couldn't get to the Memorial because we didn't book far enough in advance and it was raining too hard to wait in line but having seen the Museum I can't imagine having gone to NYC and not seeing this. It is so moving and brings back many images and memories that we had seen during the coverage that time erases. It's hard to believe it's been 12 years since that day that we'll never forget but seeing things up close, melted steel beams video footage, voice recordings..........I had tears in my eyes a few times.What people must have felt choosing between dying in the fire or jumping out of that building is unimaginable to me. First responders running into that building having no idea what they were running in to. Some weren't even on duty. The uncommon bravery displayed that day and the remarkable grace with which New Yorkers carried on is amazing. To see the new towers being built now is a testament to the strength of this city and it's citizens and I find myself in awe.

Ground Zero. I first went to New York when Ground Zero was the Twin Towers and this was back in 1986 and going to Ground Zero May 2013 I found this very moving we spoke to people that were there on 9/11 and they all had moving stories to tell on how the lost friends, family and loved ones going to Ground Zero does really make you think
Thought Inspiring!. Well worth a visit. Very thought provoking but not anyway morbid! I would certainly like to visit again and perhaps stay much longer.
Very touching. Wonderful tribute to the brave men and women who worked the recovery effort. Amazing photography and artifacts. Beautifully done.

A moving experience. Af first we thought that the museum was quite small. However, after a heartfelt introduction by the host we toured the room listening to the commentary, via the headphones, about each photograph and exhibit by the official photographer himself. The fact that you were effectively in a private world listening to someone who had such a close relationship with the people involved, contributed to a moving and unique experience. Visiting New York for the first time we left feeling much closer to the events of 911 and quite emotional..

An intimate tour that is very thought provoking. The location is an apartment in the Meat Packing district. Easy to get to via 14th Street subway. Our tour consisted of 12 people and lasted 2hrs. You are greeted at your appointed time at the entrance by your host. Inside you are seated with your 'tour mate' a hand held device that provides audio commentary for the exhibits and shown a short introductory video. This is supplemented by commentary from your host. You are then free to view the many exhibits and photographs on show. The tour provides a unique insight into the events at ground zero post 9/11 at a very personal level and provides background to many of the human stories, in particular those involving the rescue workers and their families. It is a must for anyone working in the emergency services. I strongly recommend that you visit after you have been to ground zero to understand that scale of the challenge that those brave men and women faced following this terrible event and the fantastic memorial that has been built on their efforts.

Unforgettable experience!. We took the tour, which was something that will remain permanently in our memories. Our tour guide was excellent and he was the only fire fighter in his unit that day who survived. His story and the entire experience were indeed special and heartwarming. This tour is not to be missed!
Ground Zero Museum as part of tour. There were a lot of items displayed from the event and a lot of items to purchase to support the museum effort.

Blown Away. Very moving experince for me could not not listen to all the photo infomation as it is very upsetting.Hannah the guide was lovley and we had a great surpraise as Gary who took the phots just poped by and signed photos for us.If you want to get to a deeper understanding of 9/11 you must go, but take tissues.

We Must Never Forget. This museum is in the Meatpacking District nowhere near the Ground Zero site.Everyone should go to this exhibition which is a collection of images and remnants from the recovery at The Twin Towers. This powerful display was put together by Gary Suson who was the official photographer appointed by the NYFD and the only non official allowed on the site during the recovery process.This is a small museum and you need to pre book a time slot.Be prepared to be confronted by his story, but go you must. We must never forget 911.
Ground Zero. Well worth the wait and trip. Make sure you go to the 9/11 memorial. Very moving. Advanced tickets required.

Very moving experience. This small gem in New York's meatpacking district is not to be missed. I had previously been to Ground Zero which is a beautiful memorial, but this museum puts a face on the huge task that faced the recovery workers. It is only one room, but it took us a full two hours to see it, and we could have stayed longer. We were lucky that Gary Suson, the photographer, was there that day.
