He was very interesting and unassuming. The photos and the accompanying audio descriptions are extremely well-presented. There are also a lot of artifacts that bring a perspective to this horrible tragedy. Don't miss this one!
Strong Stuff. This is a one room museum with pictures of ground zero after the buildings collapsed. It's tough stuff but for my personal taste a bit mawkish.

Must See and Remember. Poignant reminder of lost loved ones and what could happen again if we don't remain vigilant. A symbol of resilient people, from all walks and nations, an amazing city and country.

Unbelievably moving and far exceeded expectations. This, in my opinion, is a must-visit. It is unpretentious and unostentatious but delivers far more than you could ever imagine. On first entry into the museum space, it is easy to feel underwhelmed - it is such a tiny space you think that you have made a huge mistake and there is nothing to keep your interest. Think again. This is a memorial and interactive experience like no other. All of the photos and artefacts from the site have their own story and help to paint a wider view of the recovery operation. I was literally moved to tears by the initial video introduction and all four of us were engaged for the entire 2.5 hours. Unforgettable.

Amazing and humbling.. I spent over 2 hours in a room not much bigger than my bedroom. 4 walls. Lots of photo's. Lots of time to think. A very simple but staggeringly well done exhibition. Note: this is not the official Ground Zero memorial at the Ground Zero site - there are a few confused reviewers on here. This is in the meatpacking district on the second floor of an unremarkable building. What the exhibition manages to achieve within such a mundane setting is truly exceptional.

Moving Experience. I went back and forth on whether to include this exhibit on our most recent NYC trip, and I'm glad we did. The space is tiny, but packed with pictures and artifacts from Ground Zero; it's the stories behind them that really make this exhibit worthwhile. It's so easy to get caught up in the enormity of the event and neglect to think of the individuals who died or lived through it. This workshop focuses on the emotions and experiences of the people involved, and I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a different perspective on the tragic events of 9/11.

Very emotional!. A must visit - my first time to New York was the May before 9/11. To see and photograph the Twin Towers (they dominated the skyline) and then to watch on TV in real time as they were destroyed and understand how we all lost some of our innocence that day - what can I say. I have been to the City 9 or 10 times since and have watched as the Freedom Tower rose up and on my last trip a few weeks ago, went to the Ground Zero Museum. It truly speaks to the resilience and humanity to be found in people.

Great place to understand the recovery effort. Found out about this little gallery from Groupon, and I am glad we purchased it and visited. This gallery details the recovery effort of the WTC in pictures using individual headsets. You enter the number of the picture or artifact you are viewing and listen to the photographer tell the story of what you're viewing. It is very emotional to hear the stories of individual people or specific happenings. It was not too dark or scary; our 9 yr old visited the workshop as well.

Great Tribute. This is a very special place to visit, all involved have done a wonderful job and no one should visit NYC without seeing this wonderful, thoughtful tribute to all who died or were affected by 9/11.

An experience I will never forget. I visited the museum with a group of friends before going to the 9/11 site and it made the visit there more real.The museum is small and very intimate but this adds to the atmosphere, the photos, artefacts and presentations gives you a real feel for what happened after the event on 9/11 and Gary Marlon Suson's (the photographer) commentary was very meaningful and heartfelt.Our visit was made even more special as we had the pleasure of meeting and talking to Gary.I would certainly recommend this museum to everyone.
A must. Not to be missed! Tours are given by those directly affected by the tragedy of 9/11 so you really get a sense of what it was like on that day.

Emotionally draining, but so worth it.. I visited this museum before taking the subway a few blocks to the Ground Zero Memorial site. I'm glad I did. Seeing the images and hearing the personal stories represented by the photographs at the workshop museum provided context for my visit to Ground Zero making it much more meaningful. The museum's mission is to promote healing from the the trauma of 911. I found the visit very disturbing because it brought me back to the feelings that I had that day watching the horror unfold: Sorrow for all the innocent lives that were so violently and tragically affected, and an overwhelming feeling that the world is not a safe place. I left feeling very anxious. However uncomfortable it made me though, each victim deserves to be remembered and appreciated. Each hero deserves to be honored. The grief of every person who lost a loved one needs to be recognized. I'm glad that I showed up to do it.  The tour begins with an introductory video. You are then free to take the self guided/headset tour on your own. The museum is just one floor of a row house, but there is a lot to take in if you are interested. It took me a bit over two hours. I was one of the last ones from our tour to leave, so it can be done in less time.
Not to be missed. This is one of the most interesting museums you will ever see. This will bring the entire 9/11 experience to life. It is educational and emotional. DONT MISS IT.

Powerful, Self-Paced Experience. Our son, now nearly 21, was in elementary school on 9/11/2001. He has Prader-Willi syndrome and mild to moderate mental impairment, but he has recently become very interested in learning more about the events of that day and how it affected people. He has watched several DVD documentaries about 9/11, but he still wants to know more. This museum was a wonderful way for him to learn at his own pace -- he controlled which photo or artifact to look at and for how long, and he could play and replay the audio tour items as necessary. On a personal level, I found the displays and the commentary to be very powerful as well as informative, and my husband did too.

Touching and very Memorable. The museum is amazing! Very touching to see all the artifacts from 9/11. My husband and I are from Sydney, Australia and have never seen anything like it. It was so moving to hear how it all came about and the stories behind each piece of history, When we visit NYC again, we would definitely revisit the museum and definitely recommend it to others visiting NYC in the near future.
Thoughtful and quiet place. Lets not forget the people who died or the people who did this tremendous job in cleaning up and buildning this very taseful area.

A Must See. This place is a must see on your trip to New York. Very moving and not a dry eye in the place. The exhibit showed pictures and items found from that horrible day. It will never leave our minds and this brought home the truth and reality of the whole thing. Defiantly a must see !!
Second visit. Moving and lovely tribute to the many who were lost on 9/11. Make your reservations ahead of time. There's still a line due to security, but it moves rather quickly.

Sad but sensitively handled.. Some of the reviews of this museum have been talking about a different place - the actual ground zero plaza - this is a museum with the photos taken by official New York Fire Dept photographer and artefacts found during the recovery period. It is only one small room but the recovery of remains and artefacts photographed and documented in a audio tour way. The photos are iconic and they have explanations of how and where they were taken. The most poignant artefact (in my opinion) was a piece of the fuselage from the aircraft that flew into the tower. This is a very sad exhibition but so important to see and handled in a way that makes you admire the courage and sacrifice of the emergency services.

A glimpse of the agony... Its on west village, 14th street. we went there to see the construction of the new trade center but our driver from embassy told about this museum and we went. You will see the recoverd items or souvenir of 9/11. good place of memory of 9/11.

never forget. very emotional place to relieve the worst tragedy in the history of our nation this is a place as soon you get in you will be in tears the museum its really great very nice pictures quite place its hard to forget the fact of all those lives lost this is MUST SEE in nyc you will relive everything that happen that day believe me there is no way you leave this place and dont think whats really important in life. very pretty museum but unfortune always be linked to this tragedy a MUST SEE IN NYC

It will bring you to tears..... To relive 9/11 was really hard for me since the three people I love most in the world were all near ground zero that fateful day......we waited on a long line to get into the museum. It was worthwhile because it made you stop and think about what really happened on that date......not just the falling of the towers and the thousands that were killed but also the responders and what has happened to thousands of other families as a result of that infamous day. We came out of that memorial strangely calm and reflective on what is really important in life. A must see for every American.
sad. touches your heart so many emotions - so sad for the united states something everyone should go to - to get some type of closure

Definitely visit this museum!. Of all of the 'touristy' things I've done in New York, this is way up there. It's actually quite harrowing but I think the only way to get a better understanding of what happened, and learn about all kinds of tragedy that resulted that you'd never even considered before. I was expecting a normal kind of museum, but it is not at all - really it is one room with 9/11 artifacts and such like and well put together short film. It is a bit off the beaten path and we weren't sure we were even in the right place when we arrived outside but it was worth the wait to get in. Prepare to leave there feeling a but subdued, but honestly so worth it.A strangely rewarding way to pay tribute to those people and animals who lost their lives, not just in the event itself but as part of the rescue teams too.

Brought a tear to my eyes. When I came here it Brought a tear to my eyes so sad to see what happened on ground zero and all the pain and anguish the loved ones went through a must place to see when you come here

A moment. The story of the photographer is great, and incredible that these are rare photos capturing a moment in time. For the most part those its piles of stuff in small crowded room without much organization. We spent 20 minutes then had to get out it was that small and crowded.

A very sensitive and poignant memorial to this terrible event. The museum isn't where you think it might be so check that firstThe 2 ladies in charge were very helpful and it was a very well thought presentation and the artefacts and pictures were really specialGo to this museum before going to ground zero as it really tells it as it was Thank you for our education and the emotional reminder and memorial

Never forget, never miss it.. A little museum set on the second storey, private and self-guided tour allows you to view the multitude of photographs and relics left from that fateful event. Touching, emotional.

Very impressive reminder. This museum is very well done to honor the fallen victims of 9-11.Many pictures, and reminders of what happend on sept 11/2011.Very well done.Do this near the end of your trip as it is a little sad, and you want to give it the attention it deserves.
Moved to Tears. I don't think I can type a good review here without crying. It's very moving to relive this expierence. This museum has taken the story and brought it to life.

Great memorial museum for 9/11. This museum is mainly a collection of photographs taken by a professional photographer who was granted exclusive access to Ground Zero. There are also small artifacts in the museum. Wonderful descriptions of the items and photographs. There is an audio tour that takes about 1 1/2 hours. It was an emotionally moving experience. Very small, basically one room, but worth the cost. We took our two teenagers and they were engaged looking at the items and listening to the descriptions. I highly recommend going to this museum.

Excellent thought provoking display. For those who, like me, are a little confused. This is a display of some artifacts recovered from the 9/11 site along with photographs taken by the NYFD official photographer. Artifacts include a piece of glass from the towers, crosses made from the girders and part of one of the aircraft. Needless to say it is a harrowing experience being told of the rescuers experiences, but in a strange way it was also uplifting to realise the lengths to which the rescuers went to recover every body. I would imagine that most of us were in tears! You have to book in advance as only a limited of visitors are allowed into the museum.

Respectful Artifact & Images Exhibit Near the Chelsea Market. 2 hour, intimate workshop. A max of 28 people at a time and two tours per day. Advance purchase/booking recommended. 2 blocks north of Chelsea Market. Informative. Honours the deceased and those who struggled in the recovery efforts.
Worth the visit!. If you are visiting the 911 Memorial site, then you need to visit this museum. It is informative and moving.

A truly humbling and moving experience. This is a very moving display paying respect to all those who lost their lives on 9/11, but also to all those that helped in the aftermath of trying to find answers, artifacts and anything big or small to put family members at peace. You cant help but shed a tear at the interviews, movie playing depicting what occurred, but most of all each piece on display big or small tells a tall of what occurred. A must see for any visitor to NYC.

Must visit. Well worth a visit... And the tour was great, emotional but learnt alot and everyone was friendly... Very difficult to find though was not sign posted didn't even realise there was a museum found it by accident.
great experience. It was a very moving display of pictures and artifacts recovered from Ground Zero. It felt very personal

Tragic yet beautiful.. This museum is tiny, but this only adds to the intimacy of the experience. Everybody knows about the 9/11 attacks but this collection by Gary Suson really opens your eyes to the human repercussions of the incident. Each piece, big or small, has a unforgettable tale of loss, love, bravery, friendship, loyalty or all.A truly humbling experience and I cannot recommend it enough for anybody who would like to have a better insight into one of New York's devastating yet defining moments.

Haunting. A moving museum, very emotional visit as you see letters, memerobilia and wreckage from the planes. Museum is very professional and although the circumstances were very sad, we enjoyed our visit and felt it was good to remember those that tragically lost their lives.

Emotional!. Me and my friend went here on our first day in NYC. The building itself is very small, which makes for an intimate, personal experience. You are introduced to the work of Gary Suson, given a headset and left to wander round looking at the exhibits. The headset tells a story of each individual exhibit. Some of them are so chilling they brought tears to my eyes. You are allowed to take pictures, but there are certain things they ask you not to out of respect.It is a truly moving experience, that I would recommend to anyone.

Museum trip with the family. I remember vividly the day I saw on TV from the UK, the planes hit the towers and the total shock and horrendous aftermath. I'd just picked my son up from nursery and couldn't believe it. Since then I've wanted to pay my respects and I've done this on both previous trips with my husband to ground zero. This is the first time I'd visited this museum and also taken the children (14 & 17) where I felt it my duty to give them the opportunity to understand fully what happened on that dreadful day, the human kindness that came out of it and to remember those ordinary people going about there normal lives that were so tragically cut short. The ground zero literature said it was a 5 minute subway ride from ground zero-it isn't. You need to allow at least half an hour. The location could be better signposted but I suppose it isn't , in keeping with the small , quiet museum, that is very understated but immensely hard hitting. It is a fitting tribute and the museum pieces and information are extraordinary. Take your tissues and listen to every single commentary for each artefact. I understand why this is a museum that the families of the victims visit-quiet, reflective and peaceful. Thank you to Gary Suson and the team who brought this together. Memorable and moving
Somber.. This place is like nop other, you cant even begin to imagine what it must have been like. Very quiet area but they have turned things around.

A moving experience. This small but very effective museum shows photos and items collected from Ground Zero during the extensive and difficult cleaning up process - it is the work of the photographer (Suson) who was the only one allowed to officially document the cleanup. It was extremely well done, very sensitively and respectfully documented - after a video and a talk by the guide, each person was given a device to privately listen to the stories behind the individual items and photos displayed. You could have heard a pin drop for the two hours I spent there. I was in awe of the courage of the individuals who were involved in this cleanup, and it reminded me that we must never forget the people, especially the first responders, who died on 9-11. Going to this museum is especially important for our children and grandchildren who would not know about 9-11 firsthand!
Very moving. What can be said - very moving, makes you think & reflect on life, bravery, sacrifice etc - not to be missed.

Heart breaking. This is one of the things that has really got to me. Been there and seeing this is so different to watching it on tv. What a wonderful job people have done. My heart goes out to all the Americans.

Eye Opener. I never knew how many people were affected by the attacks on America. It was amazing to see the stories of how people helped other even in their last hours one story that stays in my mind was the red bandana, Welles Crowther. Some amazing and very sad stories.
You will be blown away!. What a treat this little museum was. It was very touching to be so close to many of the memories of 9-11. It is small, but has a mighty impact.
Very emotional.... We visited this site and I was in tears. It is now a beautiful memorabilia. If you want a day of peace and remembrance pay your respects to the twin towers.

Sombre and Emotional. If you are visiting the 9/11 memorial I urge you to visit this little museum in the Meatpacking District. This puts it all into perspective. It was a very sombre experience and would higly recommend a visit.

Moving memorial to Ground Zero heroes. Purchasing the tickets online was confusing and time-consuming -- why need a password for a one-time purchase? -- but otherwise, it was a fabulous exhibit. It was a rainy day and we wanted to stay downtown and were tired from previous day's walking, so the Ground Zero Museum Workshop seemed like a good idea. After a televised explanation (fortunately, no images of planes hitting buildings!) and a person explaining the various exhibits and artifacts around the room, the interactive workshop was a self-guided tour. Gary Marlon Suson photographed the cleanup of the towers following 9/11 and, spending many months there, also collected many artifacts. Photos and exhibits surround a large room and he has created audio soundbites for each exhibit. Individual audio devices and headphones provided a personal way to be moved, to grieve, to remember, and to be hopeful about the extraordinary efforts of the responders.
Food for thought. Hats off to America, the tribute is simply stunning here and I would urge anyone with a heart / emotions to visit.In respect of what happened, go an visit - you'll be very touched!

So moving....left me in a blubbering heap outside.. We actually visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop in June of 2011...not sure why it took me so long to write this. I only know it was one of the most moving experiences of my time in NYC. Even more so than visiting Ground Zero....it's just a different experience and amazing how they have so much in such a small space. I didn't want to leave until I had heard everything there was on every artifact and picture. I was one of 7 in our group....the kids finished earlier as kids do but there is an Apple store just down the street to keep them busy. Not everyone was as affected as I was but it did affect each of us none the less. By the time it was all done and I had seen it all, I slipped into the hall and just sobbed. I would recommend this tour to everyone. It is important to see and know all we can about this tragic event in our history.

Emotional and Sacred. The Museum is a surprise. It is small but perfect as it allows for the experience. I was so moved by the story that it told and how personal it was. The photography and artifacts were amazing. This is a must do for anyone in NYC. Take the to go and let it change you!

Informative and emotional. I didn't know what to expect when I booked my ticket. I'm so glad I did though because it was the most emotional experience one can have amidst a group of strangers from all over the world. The stories that we were told were extremely informative, heart-breaking and inspiring. Although the media coverage of 9-11 has had a profound impact on all of our memory and awareness, the Ground Zero Museum workshop has given me the opportunity to get a much more personal insight and understanding of the horrors of 9-11.

The Real Story. When i went into the small museum i didnt really expect to be as affected as i was. The personal photos of the people who died that day, with their families and loved ones going about their normal lives, really brought home the true tragedy of 9-11. it is a really sombre and sad place. I was glad of the box of tissues that is thoughtfully supplied on the table there. A must see in New York,

Eye-Opening. Really opens your eyes to just what happened, how many people it affected and the true uproot of a city as great as NYC. How truly awful it really was but how the community pulled together brings a tear to your eye. I left the museum with one major question... Why?
Must visit. Liked the peace that was created for future understanding of the terrible and time to understand and think about the world. It is an genius construction.

moving, insightful. the photographs were so wonderful. They were so personal and it gave such insight into the experience of those who helped with the recovery. Although it was terribly sad, it really focused on the strength and hope of those who worked there day after day. When I saw the photo of the rescue dog and heard how the rescue workers saw that the dogs were getting depressed, so some of the workers buried themselves so that the dogs could find them, I just thought "wow, they have so much going on and they care about even the dogs' feelings." amazing. I was really glad we saw this before the 911 memorial.
A place to remember. This museum puts together the true meaning of the fallen towers and the significance of the new ones.

Disappointing!. Reviews rated this as 4.8 out of 5. Yes, it did offer better artifacts than the Ground Zero Visitor Center. However, it was one room; charged $25 per person; and was very hard to find and access. (we had to be buzzed into a secure building occupied by other businesses.)

Very emotional day. This museum was recommended to me by a friend and it was definitely a highlight of my time in NY. The guide was brilliant a had a great way of explaining everything. It was nice to hear the stories of 9/11 from recovery side of things..but very emotional. Getting to actually see and touch bits and pieces from that day makes it so real and is really touching. I would recommend going to this before going to Ground Zero. I definitely recommend this to anyone going to NY

Thoughtful Experience. Surrounded by the sights and sounds of the Ground Zero experience, I was so pleased to be able to see and read all of the little notes and videos relating to the events. The personalization of the museum layout does help to lure in the viewer, and I believe it was a much-needed reminder into how the events unfolded for everyone there and around the world.

AMAZING. There are no words that will explain how good of an experience today way was. I hope it never changes, such an itimate settting that captures the events and atrosity of 9/11. It focused on the recovery and really shows how far nyc has come since then. From someone who generally dislikes museums this is far more than any museum.
A sobbering reminder of what and who we lost.. this is a beautiful place to reflect and to remember who we have lost. it is well kept and the staff/ volunteers are very helpful.

The biggest little museum. Don't miss it. We visited the Ground Zero Museum today and I'm so glad we did. It is a wonderful tribute to all the people who died and those who worked on the recovery effort. The Ground Zero Museum is important so the "We Never Forget".
Very informative and moving. The best little museum! Jammed packed with interesting stories and very moving. Of all the attractions we visited in NYC this was most memorable.
very informative. was a very informative and touching exhibit. Really enjoyed reading all of the information and watching the videos.

A must do. We came here before heading off to ground zero. A must do for anyone. Take the tissues. There are no words to describe the emotions you go through. The collections and recordings have been put together so well. I'm still struggling to put words to describe this experience.
Incredibly moving. Really worth a visit, you'll be surprised by the impact it will have on you. It's strange to see the real side of that fateful day, especially the human side of it.
Great museum. A must for anyone interested in the events of Sept 11 - a very moving space filled with photos and actual artifacts from the area following on from the towers coming down.
Very impressive. The Museum was very well done--felt like it was almost a shrine--wanted to speak in hushed tones. All the pictures and books brought back the horror of the day!
Must see. Was totally humbled to see such a breath taking monument to so many lives that was lost on 9/11 God bless.

This is a No,No!. We purchased tickets to visit this "attraction" which is situated in a very poorly maintained area. Once we arrived at the "venue" we were disappointed to find that the museum is located on the second floor and after ringing the bell a number of times wthout answer. We left totally disappointed and disillusioned and I feel that this is a misrepresentation of the ground zero sight!

Take your tissues. This is just a surreal experience, so many artefacts it was so sad but amazing at the same time. Pay a visit the the deli just round the corner the pictures on the wall of the fire fighters are heartbreaking. Brings to life what happened

Very moving. This is the museum in the meatpacking district not the ground zero site as many have written reviews for, we went to both to experience the life stories that we learnt of through the museum and to pay our respect within the site.The museum is a very intimate location showcasing the work of the only photographer commissioned to take photographs after the tragic event, his images captured stories of firemen and policemen searching for their loved ones and many more. His experience was more than just taking photographs as many have written. The smallest but biggest museum in New York was a very good way to describe this experience. A very emotional couple of hours which we will remember forever.

Inspiring. I wanted to visit Ground Zero, but as a lot of it was cordoned off when i visited we went into the museum shop instead. Read peoples stories, saw remnants of things found and listed, purchased books to help the funds, saw the wall of photos of all that lost lives..we cried..but glad I went.

Wasn't sure what to expect. When you first meet outside a random apartment absolutely nowhere near Ground Zero and are ushered upstairs into what feels like someone's living room with lots of pictures on the wall, if you are anything like me you will be a bit like "am I in the right place??" But I promise you what you will see and hear on the audio tour of the photos and artefacts in that room will stay with you forever. I'm not a very emotional person but I confess I shed a few tears and find myself thinking about some of the things now that I'm back home in the UK.Very moving, inspirational museum and I'm glad I went.
Moving experience. A well presented and very moving display. Video footage and personal views from some of the people who lived this tragedy.

Moving exhibit. Ground zero museum workshop is a moving tribute to those that lost their lives in September. It is also a symbol of new beginings with the building of the new world trade centre. You must book online prior to going and the security process once you arrive is efficient and professional.

A moving experience. This visit was the most moving experience i have ever witnessed.You could not help being struck by the resilience of the American People who had suffered this abominable event in 2001. Every visitor to New York should visit this site if it's the only attraction they visit

A lot to see in a small area. Although all this is in one room it is really worth the visit. It is mostly about the people that were involved in the recovery effort at ground zero. Touching stories with some great photos.

Great Sight to Remember those lost. We got tickets and went to the Ground Zero Museum. It was a gloomy rainy day, but it was a sight not to be missed. Very moving and solemn experience. Our tour guide was very informative and took time to answer our questions.

A very emotional experience!!. I saw both tower topple, going to this exhibit was a very emotional experience for me. It is a very impressive exhibit that is a must see whether you live in the area or just visiting.

Very informative and depressing. Since we couldn't get tickets for ground zero itself, we decided to check out this museum. Was really informative about the events. It was also quite emotional and depressing to see some of the images. I even saw some people crying. Must do and free
little museum. this is a little museum but if you visit new york this is a must to do very emotional 2 hours would highly recommend
Very moving. As English people, we were very moved by the stories of the people involved and how our cousins across the pond remained strong and rose out of something so terrible

A moving experience. Don't miss this. The items housed here and the stories move you to tears. It's unbelievable how items survived and the stories of the workers are beyond belief. The spirit of New Yorkers after 911 is shown in the tributes and photos on display and make you feel proud and privileged to be sharing this experience.

Emotional. Ground zero is a very emotional place and the museum more so. We both felt very humble, looking at and hearing the last words of those who perished on that fateful day. it is a must do for visitors to NYC.

A very sentimental visit. I found this place just around the corner from the actual site and it was being run by people who where there (or at least the started the place). All the money to get in goes to the charity so that was a good thing. The place was not very large but they filled some entire walls with notes and photos.They had lots of items people had picked and several on loan from other places. There are so many moving notes and letters it is tough to get though.I was especially hit by the steel column that they have on display. As a structural engineer it said a lot about the forces that hit the building. Everyone will take away something different from the visit but as long as you remember you will be glad you went.
Brilliant Museum. Very moving tribute to the work carried out at Ground Zero after 9/11. It's only small so book ahead to ensure entry.

About right.. I enjoyed this visit. It allows 2 hours but it is prob nearer 1 hour. The museum is pretty small with lots of articles and pictures from Ground Zero. what makes this museum special is the personal touch, the personal stories. You get a good insight of how the recovery went and the personal loss of many people. The photographer had sole right to the recovery operation and you are issued a headset to decsribe each photo / article. Definitely worth a visit.

A moment to think. It is overwhelming the feeling you experience being there. There are posters showing various scenes of what happen that day. An audio of different persons narrating their experience, among other things. Must see!

Very Moving. Worth a visit. It is very informative and has some graphic exhibits (relics from the disaster). There is a good deal of film and sound which most people will not have seen before. The further you go in the most distressing it gets but you just have to keep going. Extremely well done with a lot of though and respect.
Time to reflect,,. Well worth the effort to walk to this museum that highlights the terrible events of ground zero, but also the rebirth of this site for New York city...

Great little place. This was a really sad but uplifting tour, got to see lots of artefacts and hold some of the steel from the word trade centre. The young lady who was he guide was knowledgeable and kept our interest, a really sobering visit that made me place things n perspective.

Beware, the workshop is NOT Ground Zero Museum. On a recent trip to NYC, I visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. This is NOT the Ground Zero Museum by the towers! You purchase your tickets from Alcatraz and then go to the meatpacking district in a loft. This is a rip off as far as I'm concerned and was very dissapointed. Several of the reviews written for this workshop should have been for the ground zero memorial. Just be careful when booking, so you don't have the same experience. This is very self serving to the photographer Gary Suson. The guides even say he will be "dropping in" to visit with museum guests. Ha, this of course never happened.

Somber and respectfull. Wasn't sure how this was going to turn out. Got to the studio and was very surprised! Clean, quiet, respectful. There was so much packed into the small area and everyone there was so nice and helpful and knowledgable. Definitely worth the time and money. They state that the majority of the proceeds go back to the victims and fdny...very honorable.

As if you were there. What a great museum which deserves its title as the biggest little museum in New York.This is a great insight into the rescue operation after 9/11Greta stories, fantastic pictures and many objects from the twin towers including glass from the windows and even a piece of one of the planes.Very touching stories so be prepared! Tissues are supplied
:(. Very sad, but great to see history, there is a lot of great stories that people have told on the day of the event, i would recommend seeing this...cant wait to come back again
Great museum. Great museum to visit and honour the lost ones on 9/11 if your round wtc memorial recommend visiting as it gives you whole experience of this tragic event.

Brilliant't done for such a sureal experience. An absolute must as you feel as though you are part of the rescue process. The way the pictures and artefacts are presented a very empathetic way as remembered 7/11 so vividly. It is an audia presentation and you type in a number relating to the exhibit you want to hear about. Costs 25$ and lasts for 2 hrs

Goosebumps!. This place is stunning. They have excelled themselves when it comes to remembering an event as tragic as this.
It is a place of reflection and to really understand what everyone involved went through and how harrowing it must have been. A good educational visit. Don't rush this one,give yourself plenty of time as there is lots to read.
Moving Stories of a tragic event. It is hard for me to read the stories and see the pictures of this tragic event, but this museum does an excellent job.
VERY IMPRESSIVE. this is a must see place when visiting NY.It is a place for remembrance and reflection but very sad.Again we would come back for a second visit.

The Sorry remains. It was a moving and interesting visit. What really moved me were the origami 'Peace Doves' hanging over a stairway. I questioned where they had come from. Apparently survivors from Hiroshima had donated them. What made it more special for me was the fact I had been to the 'Peace Garden' in Nagasaki underneath where the second bomb was exploded and there also were strings of he same 'Peace Doves.'

humbling. had to do this, it was a shame that they had been so badly affected by hurricane sandy, however they worked hard and were cleaning up well, very calm, quiet and makes you think, a definate must on your trip to see how well people are pulling together to put good this catastrophy.

Informative and insightful. Great for all ages, provides a great background to the Twin Towers the events of 9/11, the people, the emergency services incredible response and actions, the rebuilding. A lot of items shown of items found after the towers fell, the story behind the items and their owners, just fascinating and very informative. Make the trip. It is a donation attraction if I recall correctly all proceeds to the 9/11 charity, worth the visit for sure.
Small but interesting. This was an unexpected stop during our journey. It is amazing to see how many people this tragic event has affected.
Well worth a visit.. Done with tact and a calm yet sombre experience. I wasn't sure about going but glad I did and would really encourage you to visit here.

If you are in NYC this is a place to visit. We visited this musuem after visiting the 9 11 memorial and they are not at the same place but this was definitely worth the short taxi ride. This was an experience that I will never forget and makes you realise what the heros of 9 11 went through on that awful day and we should all be so proud of them. The other special memory of the visit was to actually meet the hero Gary Marlon Suson who was the official 9 11 photographer, what a humble man who I respect so much for what he did and for sharing his photographs and memories. it was just so moving.

Goose Bumps. I have always wanted to visit 911 or just be in the same area as it and this workshop sent shivers down my spine (not in a bad way)They captured the the moments before, during and after the attack and i felt as if i was going through it emotionally with the city.I look at pictures today from this workshop and i am moved everytime.What a great experince to but your life into the right prosptives and i think everyone should experince this.

You need to go!. We all remember where we were and what we were doing on that day at that time and it is a must visit to pay your respects to the thousands of innocent and brave people who lost their lives either going about their daily routines or trying to save fellow human beings.It is an immensley moving experience and a little traumatic if truth be told but you must do it and share the pain of this great city.
Not on the Ground Zero site. This is not on the site of the memorial. You will have a bit of a walk from here. Not unreasonable but do not be surprised.

A very moving experience. This is one of the most emotional museum exhibits I've ever seen. Extremely sad, one is reminded not only of the horrific events of that day in general, but of how individuals sacrificed themselves to save others. There is also a very touching acknowledgement from people all over the world offering their sympathy and solidarity.
Had to go here. Where else would you go? We found this place humbling. Everyone should be reminded of what happened and how many heros walk among us.
a fitting tribute. We felt a little uneasy about coming here to be honest, but we still cannot get over how tastefully done everything is. Take plenty of tissues you will need them.
A sad must. A sad part of New Yorks history but a place to go and try to imagine how it was but you simply can't imagine what people went through
You can feel the pain.. It brings back painful memories from when our nation came under attack. But it lets you realize all the time that has passed by and how strong we have became.
Small but a defo must if visiting NYC. This was an emotional experience, but something that should not be missed. The museum is small so you need to make sure you book.
Well documented photos, relics and much more!. We lived two blocks north of the WTC for 2 years - and just returned to see the ground zero memorial and found this museum which is excellent!

Intimate and moving. A lot of people mix this attraction up with the 9/11 Memorial as can be seen from the number of reviews wrongly posted here, easily done but The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is NOT located at the Ground Zero site.It is actually located in a very small upstairs room in a building on 14th Street but don't be fooled by this as it is an absolute must see and in deed your 2 hour tour is probably not enough time to absorb the display of very intimate and extremely moving photographs, exhibits and stories, compiled by the only official photographer appointed by the NYFD with full access to Ground Zero throughout the entire recovery period.

Heartbreaking and cathartic. Although this may have been harmed by Hurricane Sandy, when we visited in October it was enormously moving. Crowds stood to watch the video in complete silence, some stoic, some weeping.

Really great museum - very sad though. I nearly cried my eyes out while in the museum its so sad seeing and hearing the stories of families who lost someone on September 11th :( The photos and personal belongings make you think that could have been someone I know. A great place for everyone to see mostly what happend on that day.
Very emotional experience.. Felt numb with sadness after the visit. Made me appreciate that life is precious and make an effort to live and love life as it could end very unexpectedly.
Rare artifacts. Museum by the only photographer allowed at ground zero throughout the recovery process. There were many stories and items recovered from ground zero.

Moving. Most moving place I have visited, the photos and artefacts tell a story themselves about 9/11 and actually holding the steel and glass from the WTC was a strange experience. The photos are beautifully done, and all proceeds go to 9/11 charities. I have read a lot about 9/11, but even I saw new things at this museum.

Must See. I am sure allmost everyone knows where they were on 9/11 but standing there on the site and seeing the information in the museum is a mind altering experience that will take you back to the day it hapened and the thoughts going through people's minds who were lost and who participated in the search's for people! I was on duty with my first aid squad durng that time and waiting to be called in!

Must see.. If you are in New York you must take in this history. It was very educational for my elementary school aged daughter, instead of just reading about this in a book, she was able to see the location and real life stories of survivors and those who perished.
Informative. Although small there was a steady stream of people. A thorough review of the tragic events. Very informative and they sold quality souvenirs .

Superb but sad. An absolutely amazing experience. My husband and I visited, I do not know anyone who was involved in the 911 disaster but I was in tears in this museum. It was overwhelmingly emotional. The positive New York postcards in the basement level show the true spirit of how NYC will not be bought down by the disaster and will fight on. Absolutely brilliant.

Ground Zero Workshop Museum. We had this museum recommended to us, what a moving experience, if you go to New York you must definitely go.You do need to book before the day though as booking cannot be made on the day.
Very well done. The museum outside of Ground Zero was very well done for such a small space. Plenty of personal items and statements keeps the memory of those lost alive.

Such a humbling experience, A visit you must do in new york. So sad, but joyful to read all the herroic people, who helped others. The fire station was so close, that i understand now, how they lost so many brave men. My heart goes out to them, their family and friends,as my son is a firefighter in england, and can only guess the torment they suffered, waiting to hear if they where ok. The museum, is a wonderful place to visit, as l the funds go to the ones left behind and the ones that need help.

Extremely Touching 9/11 Memorial. This memorial is an amazing display of photo and artifacts from the September 11th attacks in New York City. The stories told by museum staff was unbelievable. Some are extreme heart breaking, while other are heart warming. On my five day visit to NYC, this was by far the most moving and heart wrenching experience. This is a must visit for anyone who want to know the stories of the firefighters and police who searched the ground zero cleanup.

Humbling Experience. This museum was well worth the trek down to the Meat Packing District. We were very fortunate to be there on this particular day, as Gary Suson called into the museum and gave our tour group a brief welcome and introduction to his collection. The museum features a short video and audio tour of many artefacts and images from 9/11. Very moving experience, some sad stories and some great uplifting ones too. Learnt many new things about 9/11. An absolute must see in New York, many thanks to Gary Suson for sharing such a touching collection.
Museum is small but nice to visit. Museum is quite small. Only one video running, it seems there should have been more. It wasn't even that crowded but it was hard to navigate in there.
Very Sad. Walking around the museum and reading all the stories was extremely heartbreaking as was walking around the Ground Zero site itself.

Most touching experience in NY. It was a very touching moment to be at the museum. Listening to the real stories from each picture and see som og the items from ground zero.A different and a "must see" attraction

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. This is a must visit when in NYC, the museum has displayed the rawness of the event in a tasteful and respectful manner to honor not only the fallen rescuers but the civilians that perished.
very moving. very oving, take some tissues and make sure you take your time and take it all in. hope to go back again one day and see it when its all finished

Must see. My husband and I visited this museum not knowing too much about what was inside. The photos which were on display were amazing. The actual stories behind the photos told the story with great sensitivity. What was really moving was for the two hours we were looking there was very little talking. It was so respectful. Museum not really advertised. This is good because it is not overcrowded.

One room museum. A one room, small but moving museum. You need advance tickets for this, we had half price Groupon's but if you do a search there are lots of money off offers for this museum. I would not have liked to have payed full price for this.You have to put all your bags on a shelf in another area to the museum room, this was odd and inconvenient as I then had to carry handfuls of wallets, passorts etc around alongside the handheld audio guide they give you.Everyone sits down and is shown a dvd (about 20 minutes I think), then you go round yourself with the handheld audio guide and listen to the story attatched to each artifact. Took about an hour from start to finish.Its a different type of experience. Very near the the High Line Walkway and the Meatpacking District for when you have finished your visit.

Very Moving. The museum is a small yet comfortable space which makes for a very warm and intimate place to reflect and heal. We were moved by the video shown at the beginning and appreciated the great care and detail that went into the preservation and presentation of the museum's artifacts that so delicately told the story of that tragic day. It will be worth your while to take time to visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop.
Very thought provoking and emotional experience. Well thought out and time to stand in quiet contemplation. We were there on the 10th Sept so the atmosphere was 'special'.

This was done right. This is a very moving museum. We were glad how right they got this. A must see for any visit to NYC. Everyone was very respectful and moved by the experience. Our prayers continue to go out to those who lost their lives in this horrific attack on US soil.

Absolutely Amazing. We selected Ground Zero Museum Workshop as one of our many tours and I must say it was well worth it. We were lucky enough to go on the day when the official photographer for Ground Zero was there. Mr. Gary Marlon Suson. His rare photos capture everything after that horrific day and they are on display for all to see.There are artifacts on display as well, that you can actually touch. There is glass from the towers and crosses made out of the steel. Absolutely amazing. The most touching experience for me was to see a display of a page from the bible and the story behind that page, makes the trip worth just going for that. Make sure and add Ground Zero Museum Workshop as one of your stops while in New York. You can find the museum in the Meat Packing district.
A truly humbling experience. Wow this place is truly humbling and you wont regret the visit. Also a reminder of how courageous people are and the resilience of the human spirit.

An unforgettable afternoon. Complaints about size of the museum and fees leave me speechless. This museum is a true memorial in every sense of the word. It honors those that perished at the WTC and it honors those who spent the next nine months trying to recover victims and answers. One small room captures how the horror of 9/11 changed lives forever. This respectful collection chronicles the aftermath. Gary Suson's photos and the collection of artifacts in this museum/workshop connect to the reality of this horrific event and those that labored so arduously to bring closure. As the only photographer allowed take images of the recovery, visitors are privileged to see the gritty, intense nine months at the recovery site.The Times Square Fire Station was right around the corner from my hotel. I revisited the station after going to this museum. Photos of fire fighters who died at the WTC were posted on the wall out side of the station. The station motto is "We've never missed a performance". A museum photo depicts a retired fire fighter and a police officer carrying out the flag-draped corpse. The victim, worked at this this station and was the firefighter's son and the brother-in-law of the police officer. One does not need a glitzy, grandiose monument to remember and honor this life changing event.

Not to be missed!!!!. Wow, what can I say about this museum? When I first walked in, I was a little underwhelemed by it's size. Do not judge a book by its cover though!! Looking at Mr. Suson's amazing photos while listening to him tell the story behind them was amazing, and heartbreaking at the same time. Being able to hold a piece of Trade Center steel and window glass was amazing. Seeing artifacts from the site, including glasses from the bar and articles from Windows on the World that were left virtually untouched was eerie. So while this museum may be small in size, it is huge when it comes to a memorial for not only those who were killed, but for the recovery works (both people and K9), who worked tirelessly to recover the remains of those who were lost. This museum is humble, respectful, tasteful and not to be missed.As an added bonus, I had the honor of meeting Mr. Suson on the street as we were leaving the exhibit. He was incredibly gracious and freely gave his time to speak with us, even though he had somewhere to be. It was easy to not only hear, but to also feel the importance this work had for him. Following our tour of the museum, we headed up to Ground Zero for a guided walking tour. The experience would not have been the same if we had not toured the museum first.
Very sad. Very sad place to visit so brace your-self but a amazing take on what happened during 9/11. It has to be visited though.

Emotional. This place brought tears to your eyes as it is so emotional reading the stories and seeing the remains that have been collected from 9/11. It is a must-see for travellers to NY. They also have a great collection of books to buy, so you can donate to the museum.

Interesting and moving. Well organised workshop with interesting videos, clear presentations from the guides and plenty of time to appreciate the photos and artefacts with the audio commentary. The workshop is interesting but you are likely to be moved by it, too

moving. This was on the top of our list to visit and am glad we did, to read the stories, see the memories from others and actual objects etc brings it all home to you how there should have been many many more that did not survive. the total itself was enough. well worth a visit

A must see!!!!. It wasn't what I expected when I first entered the room. The room is small but every space is filled with photos and artifacts from the ground zero site. They showed us 2 videos and then handed out 2 artifacts that were from ground zero. As soon as I was able to hold an actual piece from the wtc, I wanted to cry. I have been to other museums and this was the first time that I have been able to hold and touch artifacts. We all received headsets and a remote to listen to each photographs story. Gary Suson (official photographer at ground zero) narrates each story. Gary actually showed up during our workshop and spoke to many of the people and autographed many items that we could buy. I was walking each item as there were many and the stories of the recovery dogs rocked me to the core. I wanted to thank Gary for telling all the stories that would have other wise stayed silent. They did a wonderful job and the room that started so small became the biggest..I would recommend this workshop to everyone that wants an up close and personal experience....You will not regret it..definitely worth the money!
You Walk Away With Tears In Your Eyes. This is such a touching museum, that you can't help but feel like your back in time on that horrible day. Be sure to buy a tee or a something while there.

No words can descripe. This is a humbling collection of photos. To be able to see this and then walk the streets of New York. It helps to some how imagine what people seen that day. Very emotional experience.

Interesting. I am very glad we went to the ground zero workshop. I learned more than I knew, but better than that really felt like I could better understand what went on. Gary M Suson is the photographer that was allowed into ground zero the months following in the recovery. He really got some great pictures and told the story well. They also have items from 911 you can pick up and see. We were also lucky enough to meet Mr. Suson and he is a very nice gentlemen.

Some interesting photos but not worth the steep admission. This collection of photos is interesting and moving but I would recommend going to the real ground zero memorial if you have limited time. $25 is quite steep for what they have to offer.

Very interesting. This is not your usual Museum. Firstly it is in a very fashionable area of New York, and unless you knew the exact number of the property you would definitely struggle to find it. It is a very small entrance door, and then you go up a flight of stairs to a smallish room where you and the rest of the people who have booked the same time slot as you are greeted by two members of staff.When you enter the room, the first thing you see are a number of photographs around the wall. They are images that you feel you have seen many times, but what makes this different is that you are handed an audio headset, and you can hear the story behind each one.The tour starts with two video presentations, and the staff advise that they do not show the planes hitting the World Trade Centre as it is an image that they feel would be too upsetting to the relatives of the victims of the tragedy. We were there for just short of two hours, and I am glad we went. I learnt a little bit more than I knew before, and though there are obviously some really sad stories it is no way depressing.I would recommend if you have the time.

Ground Zero. This is such an amazing memorial to the victims of 9/11 - in the shop the video's and messages from friends and families are played on a big screen it is a very emotional place, and is definately a must see.
Amazing Transformation. It was wonderful to see the progress they have made and it was nice and peaceful to sit and hear the sound of the water round the memorial area.

inspiring. So emotional after visiting the sight. Pre booked before we tr.avelled which made it easier. so well organised, so beautiful to see the way that lives lost had been remembered with their names engraved around the water features

Very emotional. My sister and I both found the Ground Zero Museum very emotional. Seeing pieces of the Twin Towers, various articles of clothing worn by some of the firefighters, posters of the missing people and hearing individual stories of survivors was heart wrenching but we were both very glad we went. We also went to see the Footprint pools and saw where they are finishing the permanent Ground Zero Museum as well as the new "Freedom Tower" or 1 WTC (World Trade Centre).

Very Moving. This was quite an experience. Very well done. Should be high on your list of things to see. You can walk from here to Staten Island Ferry, do a round trip and get the best view of the Statue of Liberty and Manhattan skyline for free.
Highlight of NYC Trip. We went to New York to go to the U S Open tennis tournament. The very moving visit to this memorial was the highlight - emotional, reverent and fitting.

Important way to connect to 9/11. I took my family (kids 11, 12, and 15) to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. We're from Canada and I wanted to make sure that visiting NYC, my kids came away from our trip with a true understanding of 911. We later went to the memorial site and I didn't want them to just see a memorial but really understand what happened that fateful day. This museum has a nice intimate setting that painted a heartwarming picture for my children about the recovery efforts. Gary's photos and memorabilia were stunning and listening to the stories behind each was helpful to gain an understanding. The only reason I did not rate this a 5/5 was because we also signed up for a tour at ground zero by a person that was connected to 9/11 which was the same price at this workshop and that tour person was amazing and our kids liked that better.
Ground Zero. It was so sad to see the pictures of the people who died at Ground Zero. It touches your heart. Could not visit New York without seeing this sad place.

A bit overpriced for such a small room. While the photos and artifacts are interesting, I feel like $25 is a lot to pay for so little so see. The website describes it as a 2 hour tour, but they showed a video for about 5-10 minutes and talked for another 5-10 minutes. The rest of the time you look around the museum - which is a single small room. Some of the photos have horrible or inspiring stories behind them, but more than anything, I learned that Gary Suson was the official photographer at Ground Zero. I must have heard and read that fact about 2 dozen times. Gary Suson was the official photograhper at Ground Zero. Since this is supposed to be a photo documentation of the recovery efforts, it would have been helpful to have an organized timeline. Maybe if Gary Suson was still giving the "tour", it would be worth it - to have that personal account. The young woman who gave the short talk seemed indifferent - like this was just another tour. Did you know that Gary Suson was the official photographer at Ground Zero?

Stimulating. You can see a fil remembering facts of the 11-09 and listening the opinions and memories of survived people. You can leaf through image books remembering yourself what it was 11-09. It is like do not forget and you have not forget.

Interesting. This is something my husband wanted to do and he found it very interesting and bought the photographers book to read through at home. I struggled with the visit personally but definitely would say consider it for a couple of hours.
Best little museum in NYC!. Intimate look and feel of the events of 9/11 in a comfortable and manageable setting. Thoroughly enjoyed this!

......... Moved me to tears though the space was smaller than expected and felt like there should be more room so those that need to grieve privately could. This is not a walk through, you should feel the extent of what happened and spend time reading and looknig at the displays. Realize what our country has been through and what we have learned from it and the continued feeling of loss that all those families will forever have.

Very moving. It was a small, very moving, peaceful museum. I found it hard to speak after as it just reminds you of everything that happened and especially it draws your attention to the families and friends of those that survived. Even though it is very emotional, it is important to remember.

a total must to visit. My main reason for coming to NY was to visit Ground Zero site, sadly the museum there was not open but we found this tour and what an amazing, sad, awesome and inspiring place to visit, the absolute tops of our visit to NY was Ground Zero Museum Workshop. It is small, very personal, and very very special. EVERYONE should visit. I shed lots of tears, but learnt so so much too, I felt as if I was really there when things happened,the emotion sparked was amazing, I learnt a lot, felt a lot, cried a lot and felt so so proud of the FDNY and Gary Suson. Our eldest son was just 6 when it happened, he is determined to be a firefighter and wants to live in the US, he has been inspired and has a dream to fulfill.

A special place. I loved this small but powerful museum. The photographs, information and memorabillia were all first rate, as were the recordings that accompanied the tour. I visited this museum first and then took the subway downtown to the St Paul's Chapel to have my copy of "Requiem" by Gary Susson (the photographer who runs the Museum Workshop) signed, then took a guided tour of the Memorial Pools. What an amazing day. Highly recommended.
Well done. We found the museum to be appropriate and acessible and informative. We liked that it was low-key. It could have been huge, and isn't.
Emotional. This is a place that is not only impressive but brings tears to your eyes and a lump in your throat. the whole experiance is necessary if you plan to attend New yORK

good work. The first day we arrived in New York we entered the Ground Zero Museum Workshop by mistake but we enjoyed a lot. Is a bit sad to recall what was happening but amazing the effort shown from american people.
True Treasure. This museum proves that great things come in small packages. It was a sad day but we enjoyed the tour. what a memory.
Had just opened very interesting!!. A very sad reminder of a terrible act of terrorism.Very good as it was not huge and you have to book in advance to get a place.
Worth the wait. Nice to observe the unity of everyone there. Enjoyed the peacefulnes a nd the stories. Sad to look at the items recovered. Always be a art of history.

who would not want to come here. I burst into tears when I was in this museum, but i had to go inside and pay my respects to all the people that died in the 9/11 twin towers tradgidy, it realy moved me, you saw the clothing that was found when they pulled up the rubble, restaurant reciepts, shoes, books etc, I would urge anyone to go and pay their respects to all those that died at the twin towers, well worth a visit

Interesting and moving history related to the 9/11 terror attacks. I took my family to this small (one large room) but extremely interesting attraction; we spent almost two hours there. It's an interactive experience, including seeing and handling some 9/11 artifacts (for example, you hold a cross and a star of David cut from a beam from one of the fallen towers). The set of artifacts is extensive and touching, and the evocative photos and accompanying audio recordings give visitors a sense of the immediate aftermath of the attacks. There's no footage of the attacks themselves and no images of human remains, and it is very appropriate for children who need to learn this important recent history. You generally need to reserve in advance.

Reflective. Not sure how to describe this. was very informative, and provides a good timeline of events. Not a day you would want to re-visit, but its a good way to remember those that were lost that day
very intense. It's a very littel museum, but it's such an emotion to think about all thoses people and this museum helps understand the dimension of this tragedy

Well worth the visit!. During a recent trip to NYC, our family visited the Ground Zero Museum and was forever touched by the photographs, artifacts and telling of events that followed the 9/11 tragedy in the museum’s intimate setting. It is a poignant tribute to those who lost their lives and reminder of the humanitarian efforts of so many.

Emotional. I didnt think I could learn anything more about Ground Zero but I did and it was very emotional too. I think anyone who visits NYC should take a trip here as its a huge part of the city and its past and present!! Well worth it.

True Treasure. This museum proves that great things come in small packages. What it lacks in size it makes up with in true content. The imagry is extraordinary - really glad we went. Encourage others to makea point of visiting this true tribute to those lost on 9/11.
Sad and Beautiful. Seeing this little museum in person was surreal. The videos and memento's add a weight to this venue which makes this tragedy so real for those of us who watched from afar.
Has to be seen. of course you have to visit ground Zero when in New York - awesome to get an idea of the size of the destruction. However the security is tiresome before entering the site.

very touching. this is a very touching part of all that is going on there. its hard to believe that its been eleven years and even harder to believe the anyone could do this kind of an act to so many loving people.

Amazing!!!. My family visited the workshop and we all agreed it was very touching. Gary did a wonderful job with his photography. All the photos, as well as, the artifacts from 911 are very amazing. This is surelly a must see if you are in NYC, don't miss it, it is definitely worth your time. Also, Gary was there the day we visited and was very kind and willing to answer any questions you have about his experiences during this horrific time.
Heartbreaking. I am so glad we went to this , it somehow made it all real and not just something we all watched in horror on tv . It wasnt at all morbid just very sad , you will cry .

Wonderful Photographs Need a Professional Curator. These are photographs by a skilled photographer who had the unique privilege of being the only one allowed to take photos during the recovery phase at ground zero. The photos themselves are well worth seeing, especially the vignettes involving people at the site. What is less successful is the rather mundane, amateurish set-up of the room. It is not enough to mount photos on the walls in haphazard order, play dirge-like music, and call it a " museum". I also resented the many instances of self promotion, indeed self congratulation, that he slipped into the recorded commentary as he recounted the difficulties he had to overcome in order to get the perfect shot. The ramshackle collection of ephemera housed in showcases around the room has no place in this exhibit: a professional museum curator would have been very helpful in arranging the exhibit and giving focus to the museum. As it now exists, it is partially a photo exhibit, partially a collection of miscellaneous objects, and mostly an exploitive attempt to manipulate emotions. The constant references to religiosity and coincidence are uncalled for and cheap ---totally unnecessary.

Great Photos of 9-11. This is a more personal visit about 9-11 that is based on photos taken by a professional photographer allowed into the 9-11 site during the clean-up. We were given earphones to listen to commentary about each photo. Each story was very moving and the experience was well worth the time. Everyone should visit this museum as well as the monument.

Visited to pick up our tickets. Very crowded when we visited, but obviously very moving. Personal stories mixed with objects from that tragic day. The only downside is that the current location is small, and with 90+ degrees on the day we visited, we felt like we need ot hurry and get out.
emotional time. brilliant place to see, also a very emotional place to be. well worth a viisit

No hype just a wonderful place with real stories. I was reluctant to visit the Ground Zero Museum workshop it seemed a bit hard with pre booking & I had not heard much about it.However I'm soo pleased my husband insisted we do it. It was a truly moving experience. It's small, intimate & very moving, with unseen photo's & pieces from the World Trade Centre. It was like a therapy session to assist in us moving on from this tragic event in our recent history. I can see why they have groups of relatives & friends directly affected from 9/11. Although emotional it was an experience I will not forget & I'm very grateful to have had the opportunity to experience the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Highly recommended!

A must do. You should definately make time to do the Ground Zero Museum workshop near the Chelsea Highline. This guy was the only photographer alllowed after the aftermath of 9/11 and its well worth it for the stories and the artifacts. It only takes approx 15 people at a time. I did this before going to the 9/11 site and it was a perfect compliment. If this is the only thing you do in NYC then please go to this workshop.

Must see for any trip to NYC. Long line but it goes pretty fast. The very small museum held artifacts from the day, including items from emergency workers. The somber atmosphere and exhibit evoked sadness and empathy for survivors of this horrible event. Seeing up close what the destruction had quite an impact by making it so real and personal. A definite must see for any visitor to NYC.
911. never forget.......... this made me cry, that's all I can say

Awesome. I had visited the Ground Zero Museum on a previous trip to New York Ciry. This trip, I wanted to take my 17 year old son since he was very young at the time of the 911 attacks. The museum is very moving in an intimate setting. Both visits, the photographer was present.
small but powerful. just one room, but many emotions are generated by this private museum, and volunteers are great in covering the story of what happened, and the artifacts they hold

Ground Zero. This small but intimate museum is an excellent experience for all who plan to visit the 9/11 memorial or those who as a stand alone visit.You really get a glimpse of the horrific events by those closest to it. Highly moving.

not a good show. the info at the museum was very well done but is this the best we can do? it's a hole in the wall up a staircase cluttered with tools, ladders and cleaning supplies, is this the best we can do America???? we were told people from around the world come to visit and this is what we show??? clean it up....................
Powerful.... You will experience something more then what you anticipated walking in.
A small museum that moves you. It remembers those that we lost that sad day and honors the hero who helped.

The most interesting thing of my visit. It's would be wrong to say that I enjoyed this, however it was definately the most interesting part of my visit. It only takes a couple of hours, but it would be so easy to spend a lot more time here.

A very powerful and touching experience.. The museum exhibits and pictures tell the story of 9/11 victims and rescuers. Although very sad and tragic, the stories are poignant, touching and significant. This museum highlights the strength of the human spirit. No matter how horrible the tragedy was, always good people will be helping each other and will overcome.I felt this museum offered information and a good message to visitors. I would recommend to go to this museum before you visit Ground Zero.
Very moving. A must for any visitor to New York, a very moving exeprience
beatiful day. was the most interesting museum, very sad at beginning, but was a special place
Place you must visit. We visited the museum last week whilst in New York. It has some very emotional pictures and recordings of that tragic day. Well worth a visit.
Well worth the detour. Small, intimate and intensely moving. Wonderful to see so many small, ordinary objects and great photos. So many moving stories.

Must visit. You just have to visit and hear the personal account of this terrible, terrible event. This can Never be allowed to happen again, god bless all the victims and their families, a decade on and our hearts are still with you.

Moving introduction to Ground Zero via the sacrifices of first responders. The Museum tour was meaningful and personal because of our small group; only 20 participants-- the maximum number allowed. The photographer/organizer who has commemorated the stories of those who spent 9 months working on the "pile" greeted us and spoke about his experiences as the only photographer allowed on what is considered "hallowed ground." ...An Interesting display movingly recounted through the individual audio devices. Our visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop enhanced our later visit to the actual site. Highly recommended.

Touching Tribute. The museum tour starts with an introduction to the museum either by staff or by Mr. Gary Marlon Suson himself. (I had the privilege of visiting on a day that Mr. Suson was there and it was a special treat to meet this very humble and talented man.) Following the introduction, a short video is shown as well as an interview with Mr. Suson that was aired on CNN. The tour guide will then pass around some remnants of Ground Zero. For the remainder of the time you are free to take a self-guided audio tour of the approximately 100 photos in the museum. The English version of the audio is Mr. Suson explaining the photos and their respective stories.This museum is a must-see! The photos depict not only the devastation of Ground Zero but also the brotherhood of the rescue workers. The emotional aspects of this museum experience cannot be put into words and may be different for everyone, however, I guarantee it will be powerful and moving. Do not miss this!Note: The proceeds of this museum are donated to various charities. At the present time, Mr. Suson is saving money to donate to a firefighter who helped with the recovery at Ground Zero and is now battling cancer.
wedding. lots off great pictures and stories off eye witnesses who where at the scene ,and a great triibute to all the emergency personal ,police firemen and ambulance

Amazing Humbling experience. I honestly didn't know what to expect upon arrival, I just had a feeling it was going to be emotional! My fiancé and I happen to visit on a day when Mr Gary Suson was at the museum and to meet the artist and the vision behind the project was amazing. His humbled grace has allowed so many people to experience 9/11 in a tasteful, visual way never done before. Be ready to allow the tears to flow and the healing to begin! Introduction is a video montage of Mr Susons photos including an interview showing the heart of this hero. Not to be missed but needs to be planned ahead with reservations and they fill up quuick!

Heartfilled history. I had seen the documentary about the construction of this Museum and thought it might be to sad to go but it was inspiring too. We have so much to learn to make the world a better place.

Powerful imagery.... Recently visited the Ground Zero Museum WORKSHOP which is located in Manhattan's Meat-packing district at 420 West 14th street. This is a small but very high intensity, high impact museum containing images and artefacts from the 9/11 site and subsequent cleanup. The workshop has been put together by Gary Marlon Suson, the Offical Photographer at Ground Zero for the Uniformed Firefighters Association. It is therefore all real, raw and powerful.Your visit lasts around 2 hours and involves videos, interactive audio headsets and interaction with the staff or Mr Suson himself ( he was there on the afternoon we visited). The pictures are impressive, the audio stories bring a human dimension to the tragedy and the artefacts give a sense of the loss. Given that Suson was trusted by the emergency services his access to individuals and areas on the ground zero site make this a Must Do visit. We visited as a family with three teenagers and they were all totally immersed in the experience.This is not a quick in/ out visit - be prepared for a poignant 2 hours. We turned up on spec and were lucky - you need to book in advance normally.As an aside the area where the museum is located appears to be on the up with designer shops and lots of cafes/ restaurants around.

Hidden Gem. Bought Explorer Passes or wouldn't have known this existed. A must see along with the 9/11 memorial. It is a taxi ride away from memorial in meatpacking district,but near Chelsea Market. Took my teenage grandaughters here after seeing the memorial-collection of professional photos and artifacts and very well run. My granddaughters loved it!

2nd Visit!. I visited the workshop for the second time. I think that this exhibit makes the events of 9/11 a little but more reachable for people that are not personally attached to the tragedy. Visiting the Memorial site is incredibly moving, but I feel that it really should be reserved for families of those that were lost and the people that were involved in the events of that day and all of the efforts that took place thereafter. I had the opportunity to meet Mr. Suson yesterday at the museum and could see in his face that he has so many more stories to tell us. I will continue to bring friends to the workshop/museum every chance I get.
