Don't miss this.. Amazing collection of photographs and artifacts from WTC. Very moving! We were lucky enough to be there when Mr. Suson was there, and it was incredible to hear him talk about the photographs. Seeing a piece of one of the planes was really quite powerful.

Absolutely worth it!. Known as the "Biggest LITTLE museum in New York", this little gem is well worth the time. It is kid-friendly, but very emotional. Mr. Suson has put together a moving picture story with excellent narration of the one-of-a-kind photos he captured at Ground Zero. You must have reservations as only 28 people per tour are allowed. A LOT is packed into this little tiny museum. A not-for-profit entity, your entry fee supports 9/11 charities. The very best site we visited in NYC.
A tug at the heart strings. My heart goes out to the owner, such a lovely man. A really sad experience but one that shouldn't be missed.

Fantastic photo journal of 9/11. A great non walking insight of the days around 9/11. It provides inside views of the cleanup days and emotion that surrounded the tragic fall of the Twin Towers. In comparison we've been on the Tribute WTC tour that walks the grounds and it is led by volunteers that have a link to victims of the 9/11 tragedy. They have either lost family members or friends or had worked in the buildings. The Tribute WTC tour has a deeper emotional impact of the events of 9/11. While the Ground Zero Museum Workshop offers a lighter storyline presentation and accounts of 9/11 and has a fantastic collection of Ground Zero photographs.I would recommend this for families who have very sensitive members that would benefit from the more "positive spin" presentation of the events surrounding 9/11.

very sad, very worthwhile. Visited the Museum Workshop after seeing the 9-11 Memorial. This is a very important destination for everyone who remembers that day. Had to leave because I was afraid I was going to cry.
Sad but touching.. So much to live through and those that are still having to deal with that horrible day.

Worth the extra for the tour. Interesting exhibit with moving photos but the tour around the site with someone affected by 9/11 was so moving it makes me cry just thinking about it! The bravery of these people to do tours when they've lost family members is amazing.
Awesome. One of the best experiences I have ever had anywhere. I highly recommend it!

Educational and incredibly moving.. This was a must see for us on this trip to New York. My spouse is a Firefighter which added a little bit of personal significance for us. The museum is home to a photographic tribute to all of the men and women who lost their lives on September 11, 2001, or in the days that followed and the families and friends whose lives were forever changed. There are some artifacts from the WTC site(s) tastefully displayed with the photos and audio recording that guide you through the imagery in the room. This is a wonderful exhibit but be sure to book your tickets in advance.

An excellent take on 9/11. I am not sure what to take away from this museum. It will be different to each and every visitor. Being a fire fighter back home I suppose puts a different view on this. I felt that everything that had been done here was with taste and compassion. It was really moving and gives a insight into the recovery effort performed after emergency. This is where the focus is, the first responders and the support of the recovery. If you want a insight into what happened after the emergency, then this museum is worth the visit.

Humbling, surreal experience. This would have to rate as one of my highlights in New York. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a must see. The images, stories and artifacts are interesting, amazing and moving. Definitely put this experience on your itinerary. It's the best $25 I've spent - a high percentage of the proceeds go to Ground Zero related charities.
Very moving.. Hard to contain tears. Many momentos, photos, videos of that awful day. Yet, they were able to convey a message of resiliance of New Yorkers and the country, of healing.

Definitely check this out!. Although very small, there is so much to see at this museum. It is incredibly moving and there are some amazing stories to be heard.Make sure you check this out if you're in New York.

Although it's very intimate, it's moving and an absolute must before going to the memorial!!!. It's a small museum in space, but not in photos and artifacts!!! The two movies you watch in the beginning are so moving that I even got choked up. The photos are amazing since he was the only photographer allowed and each one comes with a story. I got to hold artifacts in my hands!!! It was perfect to go to right before going to the memorial! I was able to connect. They also sell items which procedes as well as your ticket purches go towards 6 charities!!! It's a must!!!

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. The museum is on 14th street. Do not let the cab driver try to talk you into taking you downtown to the 9/11 memorial site! Some cab drivers do not know about this museum. The museum is on the second floor of a building and the room is about 30' by 30' in size. There are photos and actual artifacts from 9/11. You view all by use of an audio headset. It is wonderful and you must go to this museum, You must have reservations because of the small space they only let about 25 people in at a time. My entire family enjoyed it.

Touching. This museum workshop was very moving and well put together. The photographs are beautiful and the staff extremely well spoken and knowledgeable. Very nice combined with trip to 9/11 memorial, although they are not close together, be advised.

Never Forget!. We took a group of 54 to experience the Ground Zero Workshop. Mr. Suson's collection of images taken during a very dark time in our country's history, will always be a reminder that we should never forget! Thank you Mr. Suson for your sacriface, we know that it has taken a toll on you as well to complete this project. God Bless...
Very sad. Such an insightful place however very very sad lots of recovered pieces and memorials for those who lost there lives on 9/11
Great. This is an awesome reminder of a terrible part of our history. Very beautiful and respectful.
Ground Zero. STill a work in progress such a shame they should have this complete by now

A True New York Experience. We live in New York City and went through all the affects of 911 but being in this museum really brought out much more of the details than anyone could ever think of. We urge everyone, including New Yorkers, to experience this great museum. P.S. We were fortunate to meet the photographer who put the museum together and that was truly a treat.

in NY you must visit Ground Zero. We all know the stories But by visiting Grond Zero you somehow have a different understanding, If you visit NY this is somewhere you just have to visit.First hand stories from familys and freinds ! You feel a presence when you are there that you cant explain
Memorable. Very moving....we were very interested in all the displays - great place to remember the terrible times of 9/11

Sober place. Its close to a subway station. You have to buy the free tickets sold outside this museum to get into ground zero where there is a lot of construction activity. A sober place to visit. Makes you realise the scale of what happened on that tragic day.

A small museum with an enormous impact.. A small room filled with artefacts and amazing 'official' photographs from 'that' day. It takes you to the heart of the attrocity itself and provides you with a very personal insight, explaining things that you would never have known or understood from a firefighter or police perspective. From first going into the room, it is a 'breath-taking' experience but very sombre. You are provided with headsets and asked to be seated - An informal setting with sofa's, chairs a flat screen TV and tissues! The initial introduction on TV gives you a background to the first calls made by passengers at 10.04hrs. There are audio recordings of original calls made to 911 and people pleading for help. They have made a decision to NOT show footage of the planes colliding with the towers, people jumping from buildings or any body who was injured or killed - a wise move in my own opinion, as the whole experience cannot fail to have an enormous emotional impact of anyone who decides to go - you feel like you're in the middle and part of the whole attrocity. After the audio introduction and short presentation from the guides, you are able to wear the headset and by pressing the number of which ever artefact you are looking at, a commentry and explanation of each item or picture is given. Well thought out, something I would never want to visit twice, but a must if you really want to undertand the impact that 9/11 has had on this country. It leaves you with nothing more than praise and admiration for all of those people who were affected by it - in whatever capacity. Photgraphs can be taken freely, but there are a few area's that you are asked to respect for personal reasons. One thing to note : You are asked to leave all belongings - coats AND bags on a shelf at the entrance of the museum. The area is in the same room and visible, but not an ideal situation if you have valuables with you. A very sad but informative and exceptional experience.

Did'nt know if i wanted to go. We did'nt know if we wanted to go but we are glad we did. It did'nt feel like we were voyors of grief or mawkish. What a mixed feeling we had i have never seen so many people so quiet. I would recomend going if you are near. Get advance tickets first of the net.

Sad. It makes you take a deep breath on entry to the museum, brings back that terrible day . There is donation boxes in there which I'm sure most people donate I wish the cashier would not ask EVERYONE who purchases goods to donate 1 dollar, dont think thats necessary.
sad. We have never been in a place with so many people yet so very quiet. It also remains a construction site, making the whole experience quite sad.

I wasn't going to go.... My mother and I were not going to see ground zero because of the saddness it means to us - when we walked by the museaum, we looked in and they told us about how it works - it is not about making money, the museum and workshop are about the memories and the significance of this horrible event, which touched so many people. Our tour guides were both significantly affected by 9/11, and they shared their story with us.
Very tastefully done. This will provide a place where people can come and remember what happened as well as providing an area of contemplation. Allow time as the queues are very long.
Very Moving. It was very peacefull, loved the experience & glad that we decided to visit

A must see in New York!. Visited this museum after been told about it by my sister, and for my husband and I it was the best part of our trip to New York. A small but intimate museum with fantastic photos by Gary Suson the official photographer for the Fire Dept New York in the aftermath of 9/11. It showed moving and powerful photos with vey interesting dialogue about the fire departments clean up of the site and artefacts that were found in the rubble of the World Trade Center. Very informative and a worth while trip as all monies raised from the museum go towards charities helping the fire department families with their loss of loved ones and those that survived.
Still upsetting. This place brings that awful event right up close and very personal, visit it before you go to the building site.
Informative & interesting. Plenty here to see and understand about Ground Zero. it does get a little busy but it's very informative.
thought provoking. this was a great experience and really bought out the other side of this terrible event,some great photography and stories
made me cry. Had a movie and it was sad and brought back all the memories, made me cry
Went in October when the memorial was newly opened. It was cramped, but the movie was compelling and helped put perspective on the site before visiting.
Emotional. This was well worth the visit. it gave information on things we had no idea about.

NYC to Boston with Six. We tried to get tickets to the 911 Memorial and museum, but it was Memorial Day weekend and the tickets were unavailable so we did this instead. Even my four sons ages 15 - 19 were duly impressed. The museum is mostly photos from the search and rescue that took place for the months after the 911 attack. Quite a few somber and emotionally challenging photos portray the cleanup. Worth the money!
Powerful & touching. Certainly the museum and memorial should be a must stop for tourists (as well as locals). Powerful and touching!
A nice tribute. Very touching. It was disappointing to see some US citizens not treating it with the respect it deserves.
very interesting. it was interesting to see all the pictures and here all the stories, makes you really think about what peopl went through that awful day
Emotionally charged. I would have liked to spend more time here but became overwhelmed and had to leave. It's very moving.

Ground Zero Tribute. The controlled number of visitors to the Ground Zero reflecting pools helps to preserve the somber, respectful atmosphere this memorial deserves. Moving, beautiful and sad. .Don't miss the survivor tree. Plan ahead to have time to get the free timed tickets to control numbers.
Impressive. Great sense of peace and respect. Make sure you call to the little chapel that survived 9/11.
Touching. Makes you cry just seeing it all again. It's going to be a wonderful memorial to all the people lost that day.

An insight to what followed the event. The workshop is a gallery of photos taken by a fireman/photographer of the long months of clearing the site and recovery of all the bodies. It is done very sensitively, but you get the full horror and sadness of their work. Allow two hours. Here in UK we had no idea what followed after Sept 11th apart from the occasional news bulletin. It was touching and also inspiring that people had such dedication to their comrades and people who were lost in the event. We are concerned that this museum will be ignored when the BIG museum is opened at Ground Zero. these photographs must not be missed. The entrance to the second storey gallery could be made much nicer.

Very moving and personal experience. My husband and I recently visited the new Ground Zero monuments and then walked up to 14th street to see the museum workshop. Housed entirely within one large room it was not what I expected, but ultimately a very emotional and fulfilling experience. After viewing a short video, you don a headset that narrates dialogue to accompany each one of the photos on the walls and artifacts displayed. I was particularly moved by the stories of dedicated firemen, brothers and fathers who searched tirelessly for their siblings and sons. The photographer captured images never seen before and a visit here is definitely worth your time.
Very nice. I was suprise to find this to be so great, itw as emotional

A very moving experience.... Would recommend. We visited the museum last week, and we're lucky enough to be in a group of just 4 (it had only just started opening on Wednesdays apparently), The floor space of the museum is tiny, but packed with amazing photos and stories of the work carried out by the NY fire department following 9-11. It was a really moving experience, and if you are able to follow it by a visit to the ground zero site it really puts everything into perspective.Be warned though, you need to book, and it is not near the ground zero site, just allow yourselves plenty of time to get from one to the other.

An important part of the 9/11 experience. We had read the trip advisor reviews and the little museum lived upto the "hype." Viewing the images & artifacts from Ground Zero from the OfficialPhotographer was an important first stop before heading to the 9-11Memorial Pools and made even more important when Gary Marlon Susonstopped in and spoke with us for a few minutes. He was very humbleand gracious and took the time to answer questions. We also were movedby the "donations board" in the hallway that lists how much they give to different9/11 charities. The self guided audio tour was very realistic with the sound effectsfrom Ground Zero - all in all a special little museum that needs to be on everyone'sbucket list when visiting nyc. cannot say enough about this museum, just "go" isall I can say. you will not be disappointed.
very moving. To see what happened here is chilling. The response of our fellow citizens to try and help others is very encouraging in this day of self gratification.

Very moving experience. This experience really added some perspective to the whole 9/11 tragedy. There were so many people affected and this was never more clear then after visiting the workshop. Extremely moving photographs and narration.

This workshop is not Ground Zero. Ground Zero Workshop Museum is not located at Ground Zero. It is a room in the Meat-packing district, (West 14th St & 9 th Ave ) in which the photographer, appointed to Ground Zero has placed some enlarged photos, objects found at Ground Zero & an audiovisual experience, which is simply, TV news reporting of 9/11.It is a feeble attempt to cash in on such a tradgic event. Save your money & time. Go straight to the real Ground Zero Museum , which runs tours conducted by real survivors of September 11, then go & view the beautiful reflection pools.

Best part of New York City trip. This is a must-do for anyone visiting New York City. It is one room, with self-guided tours. The narrations are done by the photographer himself. It was an emotional journey through his amazing pictures. I was so touched by the goodness of humanity during this terrible time. It helped to restore faith in human kind. Of all the things we did during our stay, this one topped the list. We took the full two hours, and the time flew by. We did get tickets on-line a month before our trip. You will not regret your time spent here.
Very moving. What a great way to see just a little history of 9/11 and purchase some souvenirs.

Very Moving Museum. The Ground Zero Museum is NOT at Ground Zero or the Memorial Park. It is a very small musuem but a powerful one. I bought tickets online--there were about 25 in our group. The tour is supposed to last 2 hours but after a short video and introduction, you move at your own pace. We were finished in about 1 1/2 hours. It is a wonderful place to learn more about that day and understand what the people in the Towers went through. I highly recommend it then go to Ground Zero on the subway. An easy ride.
Take some tissues. Brilliantly organised - small but really fantastic and so, so emotional. Lots to see and experience.

Must see.... The Ground Zero Museum and Workshop is separate from the 9/11 Memorial and Museum. It was opened by the official photographer for the NYFD, who was granted daily onsite access to the World Trade Center site shortly after the towers fell. It is an intimate and in depth look into the nine month long recovery process with nearly 100 photos accompanied by stories about the fire fighters and some of the survivors and numerous artifacts from the site itself. Plan on 2 hours if you want to fully explore the works. We highly recommend visiting this museum before going to the 9/11 Memorial. It will truly enhance the experience. Proceeds from the admission benefit the surviving children and widows of both the civilians and firefighters who lost their lives.

So moving and such a sensitively handled experience. By having this museum in such a small intimate space the experience is maximised and the staff handled the whole exposure for us so well. I cannot say I enjoyed this but it certainly reinforced - "We will never forget"...
Very touching. its unreal until you see it, the pictures are amazing
Very emotional. Very emotional experience - the stories etc - everyone remembers that day and have their own memories but to see stories etc from people who were there, lost, etc -highly emotional

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Firstly, please don't confuse this with the Ground Zero tribute water pools. The Museum Workshop is a very small museum set in a loft style apartment in the Meat Packing District of New York (NOT ON THE SITE OF THE WORLD TRADE CENTER)On arrival you are each given a pair of headphones and a handset. After a short yet emotional DVD you are then left to explore the exhibits at your leisure. Each photograph or artefact has a number assigned to it. To find out more about the photograph you type the corresponding number into the handset and the information is relayed to you through the headphones.The museum captures the real feel of the recovery efforts at Ground Zero following 9/11. At times it can be very emotional but coming from the UK it gave us a better understanding of the suffering that followed in the days after the attack on the World Trade Center.Whilst we were there we were lucky enough to meet Gary Suson, the photographer and owner of the museum. He was very happy to answer any questions we had and even signed our books for us.If I were to recommend just one place to visit whilst in New York then this would be it.
Sad but Interesting. This was a very nostalgic visit for me. Some great stories and made me appreciate the efforts made by some many people on that terrible day.

Emotional and Raw. This was my second visit to this museum which is is in the Meatpacking District and NOT near Ground Zero. The owner of the Museum is Gary Suson who was the official and only photographer allowed into the Ground Zero rescue, recovery and rebuilding the first year after the attack. The proceeds from the museum go to the families of the firefighters of NYC who lost their lives during and after the attack. If possible try and schedule your visit here first and then catch the subway down to lower Manhatten to visit the Ground Zero Memorial site. The collection of artifacts at this museum give a name and face to the tragedy for people that did not know someone who died that day. Very well presented with little attempt to commercialize the event. Mr. Suson deserves to be congratulated on a job well done.

A moving & uplifting experience. My friend booked tickets for this museum, prior to our trip to New York. We were not sure what to expect, or if we had come to the right place, as it was not near Ground Zero. I'm so glad we came to see this small but intimate museum. All the photos & items displayed in this small room, all had a moving & personal story to tell. It also shows the courage and positivity of human nature, that came out of such tragic events. We got to meet the photographer Gary Suson, and he explained how the proceeds go to help and support those, who are suffering from the after effects of 9/11. We went to Ground Zero after visiting this museum, which made it an emotional day. An experience not to be missed.
Very moving. Seems much ado about nothing on arrival but put the effort in to listening to the commentary and you come away genuinely moved - not often that has happened to me.

SMALL BY UNMISSABLE. The museum is in a small studio and includes many photos taken by the only photographer allowed at Grond Zero during the recovery period. There are also a few artifacts he recovered. The guide explains the purpose of the museum, then shows a short flim, after that we were given audio equipment to hear about the stories behind the photos. The visit lasts up to 2 hours and was very moving and humbling. Along with a visit to Groun Zero this is not to be missed.
Simple yet Moving!. This museum is simple and small but by the moment you step inside, it moves you.

A Spiritually Uplifting Experience. Initially, I did not realise that this Ground Zero Museum Workshop was not at Ground Zero. It is about 5 minutes away by transport - or about a half hour walk (which we opted for). The Museum is in the meat packing district (not a grand name - but well worth a visit).I had booked prior to arriving in New York and almost missed the venue as it is a discreet entrance with only a small board advertising its existence. The museum is very small yet rich in information and planned as a healing centre where those empathising with families who lost loved ones or who experienced life changing events on 9/11, can find a safe, respectful place to reflect and remember.This museum visit was an essential start to my 'Ground Zero' day and helped me to gain a greater understanding of the bravery of ordinary citizens of New York. I would recommend visiting Ground Zero AFTER this experience, followed by a visit to St Paul's church; where you are warmed by the hope and support of others.
Very emotional. A small exhibit with some artifacts put together in a small room. Only allow 25 people at a time. The video story shown was the best because it showed people who died in the disaster.
You Must Go. It is very sensitivily set out. (should have been a bit bigger) quality stck

Tastful Memorial. This was a small museum but tastefully done. The crowds were thick so try to go during down times (not sure when that would be). Viewing the exhibits did bring back some negative emotions, beware of this.

Tribute to the lost. A walk at Ground Zero followed by a museum workshop visit is a good way to pay your respect to the hunderds who lost their lives, including those who lost them trying to save others. Worth a visit at least once ! see the good work being done there

I am so glad we stopped in after the tour. The museum is tiny but I am so glad we stopped in as I was able to see a video showing the events of 09/11 and they have some pictures on the wall showing a timeline of that day.
Impressive. We were very impressed at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. You feel a bit sad when you read the stories of all kind of man.
EMOTIONAL. Bring your kleenex. It is an emotional day. Take the time to see it.

A Must See in NYC. I recently came to the museum when my parents were in town and we all loved the experience. I was very moved by the images and stories that Gary shared with us and I also appreciated viewing the experience through the eyes of a photographer. Unlike large and stretched out museums (which never fail to zap your energy), this setting was intimate but not crowded. It was as if we were forced to reflect with everyone else who had come during the same time, and this togetherness is a big message of the museum. Thank you, Gary, for sticking with the project and sharing these images and memories with us!Simply a very special New York spot and a great respite to the lights and action of the other visitor venues. Even if you don't like to think much about 9/11, this is an important place to visit and reflect in a meaningful way.

Very Moving. Visited the workshop on our way to the 9/11 memorial. Very moved by the continuous film run showing photgraphs and stories of surviivors and people lost on this day. On the walls are photographs which we all have vivid memories of the missing persons, famlies and firefighters. Temporary workshop at the moment the permanent museum is being completed currently. Would not miss this - moved us to tears.
Interesting pictures..... It kinda takes you through the scenario and has some interesting points of view from the people that were there. You get a bit of the feeling of what and how it happened.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I recently visited this museum and feel if you have planned on visiting Ground Zero and the 9/11 Memorial, you should definitely include a visit to this museum which contains artifacts and photos related to the 9/11 tragedy. It is a small, intimate setting and the experience is very moving. On my visit, I was able to personally meet Gary Suson, the official photographer for the recovery efforts at Ground Zero and am very grateful that I had the opportunity to listen to him speak about this life changing experience for him.I was not even aware this museum existed until I actually visited NYC and I am so glad I was made aware of it and was able to obtain the admission tickets. It was money and time well invested. Please include this exhibit on your must-see list for NYC.

Small Museum made Big Impact. My 14-year old daughter and I went to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop while in NYC on spring break. The museum is small but it contains photographs and artifacts that you will not see anywhere else. The official photographer for Ground Zero (Gary Suson) narrates some of the most amazing stories depicted through his one-of-a-kind photographs that really capture the human spirit.This was life-changing for my daughter who was too young to understand the depth of what actually happened at the time. It was emotional, yet very uplifting to see the love of so many who gave their lives to help others.A quote on the wall sums it up well: "Two bullets went into the towers but only love came out".
Wonderful. An intimate emotional experience that provides images and materials not found anywhere else.

The highlight of our trip to New York. The most amazing and humbling experience. Gary takes you on a journey that reaches the soul. The personal stories connected to each photograph tell so many stories. A place that remembers with the heart. When we visited the other guests were a group of teenagers. The silence over the two hours tells how deeply everyone felt. You need to prebook - we did so before we left England.

The Highlight of our Trip. We came to NYC from the midwest for a 5 day vacation and packed in everything we could. This workshop was without a doubt the most impactful, meaningful part of our trip. As expected, it was very emotional, but Gary and his staff have an amazing collection of WTC memories to share with the world. First, the young woman who welcomed us and introduced the museum to us was wonderful. She was full of empathy, and was able to introduce the exhibits with all of the delicacy they required and deserved. Then, to hear Gary tell his stories of each of the photos that he took, and each of the artifacts that he collected...I may not be a New Yorker, but I felt like I was there. Even though this tragedy happened over 10 years ago, the emotion was as raw as if it happened yesterday. I think every American needs to experience this museum. I appreciate everything that Gary and his team had to share with the world, and I think that the NYCFD chose the perfect artist to represent them.

Emotional and simply not to be missed!. An incredible museum - couldn't find a better description then as it is often referred to, "the biggest little museum in New York". It truly is a moving experience, all in a single room, a video presentation to kick things off, but it is the photos and artifacts with the commentary for each that literally will at times make you cry, feel humble and even the odd smile or laugh. This museum brings everything to life and truly immerses you in the events of Ground Zero. Visiting New York you simply must do this as it is not only a moving but unique experience and gives an insight into the events. Truly amazing, truly loved it!

A Must-See Museum before visiting the 9/11 Memorial Pools. This Museum is small yet gigantic in terms of heart and substance. It really made the whole 9/11 experience complete. Holding artifacts made it all hit home and the stories behind the images by the Official Ground Zero Photographer were compelling & not what I had ever seen on TV before. Had we just gone to the Memorial Pools and bypassed this little Museum in the Meatpacking District I don't think the effect would have been the same. Strongly recommended!!!
Moving. go...very interesting...staffed by dedicated volunteers...everyone has a story to tell
Appropriate for kids. In the absence of any narrative at the 9/11 Memorial, I brought my 8 & 10 year old here and we all appreciated the moving museum.

A fantastic, moving experience. This was a fantastic and very moving experience. The museum is only in one, small room and so we had to pre book a timeslot to visit (there are currently only 2 tours each day) and there are only 25 people allowed on each tour.The room is full of photographs by Gary Suson (who was appointed the official photographer at Ground Zero after mayor Rudy Giuliani banned all photographers form the site) and is inspired by the Anne Frank museum in Amsterdam. Gary documented the recovery at Ground Zero, 17 hours a day, six days a week for a 14 months. There are hundreds of photos and artefacts, many of which you are encouraged to hold and touch, all of which is designed to bring you closer to the events and people who died that day.The tour is interactive, so as you look at a photo or an object, Gary Suson describes on your Tourmate (audio headset) what you are seeing. It's fascinating and very moving at times. Luckily, a few of the objects are a bit more light-hearted as it can get quite heavy. We were there for the full 2 hours and listened to everything we could. Afterwards we got to briefly meet Gary and pass on our thoughts. It’s a brilliant museum and if you ever visit New York City I recommend you check it out.Note that the museum is not at ground zero but a few miles away in the meatpacking district. Don't get this museum confused with the "gift shop museum" that's currently next to ground zero.

Ground Zero Museum. Just visited the museum, found it quite average, for museum I ve visited in NY not taking into considetarion the events connected to it. There are few really good other museums in NY with free passes and excellent, helpful and knowledgable staff. I ve traveled NY month earlier and was not let in as was not avare of booking policy. This time we ve been in a group and had a chance to visit it for ourselves. I don't like the pilgrimage alike atmosphere, taking into account true facts about 9/11 dismissed in the memorial. And thats a crucial point when you visit historic place of huge tragedy and you are told untrue facts that does not show respect to thouse, who tradicly lost their lifes. Howeverthe photography they display its really nice, but museum its not just about photography it could be as well called Gallery. It all seems too commercial in a way looking at the history of the museum as well seems to me more profit related. I personally think this should be widely open to the public in different form than 'museum' so anyone could be given chance for own reflection. And please museum staff stop sending me bad attitude messages for raising my opinion.

I was blown away. I went to this museum last Saturday 4/7/2012 and didn't know what I was in for. I was truly amazed. It is such an intimate museum, the size of a studio, but it spoke to me in huge volumes. Such a great find. A MUST for any visit to NYC. I live here in NYC and would go again. Gary Marlon Suson and his crew have out done themselves. Please go. So moving and well thought out. Thank you, Heather DeVoe
Very moving. Please note that a pass has to be acquired - there's a web site.

Highly Moving Experience. This museum is small but it was one of the most moving experiences of my life. The museum provides a true look into the occurrences of the crisis with no limited access. The staff are very respectful and caring towards everyone and everything within the museum. Definitely worth a visit while visiting New York.
Short stay in New York. This is well worth a visit very emotional but must see this.
very emotional. this museum was a very interesting and emotional place well worth a visit

Very touching, moving experience. We cannot express enough just how moved we were by our experience at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. The touching stories behind every photograph and the insight it gave us was very emotional. We cannot express enough what we felt at the museum. It was wonderful to meet Gary Marlon Suson who was actually at the museum during our visit on Thursday 5 April 2012 at 1 pm and spoke to us all about his personal experiences. The Museum is well worth visiting and should not be missed when you are in New York. Just book your tickets online before you go.
Peaceful. Althouj in the midst of all the construction work on-going, we found it a peaceful place amongst the hussle and bussle of the city

Quaint Museum. I visited this 'museum' a few years ago and enjoyed it. Lots of 'artifacts' from 9/11. Tiny room with lots of stuff to look at. Informative host. Went with hubby and young son. Highly recommend.
Had all I could do to hold back the tears. What else can I say. Will return to see completed memorial in September, 2012.

A tour worth the time and money. We just finished a family trip to NYC and took in as many attractions as we possibly could. Easily one of the highlights of our trip was a visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Gary Suson has put together an amazing collection of artifacts from the tragic events of the World Trade Center. It is very tastefully done with the families of the victims kept in mind. I wasn't sure what to expect when I first got there. The museum is unassuming as you are led upstairs into a one room exhibit. A video presentation starts the tour and then you are allowed a self-guided tour of about 100 artifacts, each with it's own story. It's worth it to spend the full 2 hours to make sure you hear every story. I highly recommend this tour to everyone, although young children probably won't understand most of it. My children are 13 & 9. My 13 year old also wanted to hear the stories for every artifact and my 9 year old listened to a few and then decided to sit on the couch and play games on a cell phone. We were lucky enough that Gary was at the museum during our tour. He was gracious and answered many of our questions. The staff were also very kind and helpful.There are a few items for purchase (books, t-shirts, etc...), but understand this is a not for profit operation. Money collected from the tour and purchases goes to support families of the victims.
Interesting. Small but with some interesting details on 9/11. No charge to go in but definately a must see.
ground zero museum. This was a special experince, very moving and tastefully executed

Very interesting !. Its very interesting and you are able to get free tickets (but optional donation) for a tour of ground zero to see the work that has been done and is still in progress. There are 2 large waterfalls into the ground where the twin towers once stood.
A place to think about. It is History, but see the Ground Zero Museum workshop and the place itself you can feel what the Americans suffered and felt that day and after.

A must do before the memorial site. We were glad we took the time to do this before visiting the memorial site. It was very moving and well put together. The museum is only very small and they only let a handful of people in at a given time but thats certainly not a bad thing. Each picture/artifact has a story which you listen to via an audio set. All in all, a great experience.

Well worth a visit and very well presented. This a revised review of the Ground Zero Museum Workshop as there was some confusion with my original review. Firstly this is not I repeat not the 9//11 memorial (former site of twin towers) this is a small museum on 420 west 14th street , meat packing district 3 stops up on subway from 9/11 memorial the former ground zero site. There are no inground fountains here, no wait times, no airport style security checks or names of the victims engraved around the fountains. Some people seem to be leaving reviews for the 9/11 memorial on the Ground Zero Museum workshop, this is a small museum in a former apartment, the photographer Gary Marlon Suson, the official photographer at ground zero, who owns the museum and who's photographs are displayed together with artefacts salvaged from ground zero. Endorsed by the NYFD and some families of the victims. A place to reflect in intimate surroundings, its a private workshop with maybe 15 -20 people allowed on each 2 hour workshop, and with the use of audio headsets the stories of each picture and artefact, some heart moving stories from some of the photos etc. Well worth a visit but must book on the official website, cost $19 per person

Very moving tribute. This is a small venue but packed with memorabilia and ongoing presentations projected onto the walls. We saw it as a preview to the entry into the WTC site and, in retrospect, would not have missed it for the world, although at first it appeared too small to be of much value. Emotions are raw here and most people are visibly moved by the exhibits. Highly recommended.

Very moving tribute. This is a moving tribute and very tastefully done. It was worth seeing to be reminded of how and why the world has changed. No admission to the pre-view area but there is quite a long queue to get in. This is actually a good thing as it avoids the workshop being too crowded at any one time.

Must see before going to the main site!. To be honest i really don't think i would have appreciated the memorial as much , had i not of gone to the museum, its very small at the moment but that in now way, takes away from the very moving scene's and artefacts, everyone remembers what they where doing on 9/11 however unless you where there we can never truly understand those feelings.The museum does help to bring it home. Its sad that so many people don't choose to go before visiting the memoiral fountains.
Go and Support this cause. Great!! really informative and very very sad. It is definately worth seeing this place as it shows how well remembered all the people that lost their lives are. Very moving

Sad and interesting. I was at GZ one month after the desaster and have been there afterwords to see the progress. The museum is a great place to visit which the vidio takes you back in time to experience the event again to refreash your mind.

Well worth a visit and very well presented. We visited the Ground Zero workshop after visiting 9/11 Memorial, and found it a welcome break from the crowds and children running around at the memorial. It is a very small museum and they only allow about 15 – 20 people on the workshop. Some people mentioned tacky and gift shop, I find this so far off the mark, profits are donated to 9/11 families and NYFD, they need to sell some gifts etc to keep the place in business, and the images etc are actual real life images, as well as the remnants, not like the t-shirts and photos sold by street hawkers outside the 9/11 memorial, also the museum has been endorsed by NYFD personal as well as families of the victims. We spent two hours in the museum, listing to moving stories and paying our respects to the people who perished. I would recommend this to people who want to sit and reflect in intimate surrounds, rather than thousands of people at other museums and memorials

Breathtakingly amazing.. I travelled to New York with my school from the United Kingdom and in all honestly 9/11 had never been a major part of what I associated the city with. But after travelling there and experiencing the museum I can say 100% that I would recommend going to a friend and I would most likely visit it again with them. The owner of the museum walked around and greeted us all, having conversations and sharing his thoughts and emotion on the day and the clean up period.
Very moving. Will be excited with the museum is moved to the memorial site. Great footage of the 9/11, very moving.

A must see. It brings you back to that terrible day. Everyone remembers where they were and what they were doing. We as Americans need to remember and never forget. It needs to bond all Americans. The museum needs to and I think they are in the process of doing, is adding more info.
Excellent. well worth the $10 entrance fee - everyone should visit as it is for a good cause. Very moving....
Inspiring. This is interesting to but incredibly sad at the same time.
Breathtaking.. This is an amazing way to tell the story and effects of 9/11, but be prepared to take some tissues.
A must. A really well developed experience to see and remember the tragic events.

Ground Zero Museum Teaser. Hi, Although very difficult to find, it was really interesting to see the events in a timeline and also read people's personal experiences! Since we from Namibia it was all a bit "far" and difficult to relate to, but visiting this really brought the fear and sadness out. Most important it showed me the spirit of the American people to not just lie down and be beaten but stand together and fight, I love that in the Americans
a must visit!!!. If visiting new york, you just have to go here,....touching, emotional, brilliant. Do not miss this...!!!!

Intimate and Moving. A small studio, an inventory of pictures and memorabilia, and a recorded passage through the weeks and months after the 2001 terrorist attacks. This is an essential visit to a pivotal marker in our country's history. Highly recommended.
Touching. A must see for all who go to Ground Zero. I don't think anyone who goes into the Museum will walk out the same. Your feelings are very deep and strong.Kathy

Must see, moving exhibit. Very worthwhile.. I visited the museum with my spouse and my 21 year-old daughter, on March 25, 2012. The museum has been called the biggest, little museum in New York City. For good reason. It is a hand-on place that let's you connect with the massive effort to recover from the tragedy of 9/11 in New York City. Tastefully done, but very emotional. There is nothing in the museum workshop that I could not bring a 6 year old to. The museum is not physically taxing at all, and is a comfortable, protective place. The staff / tour guides are professional, helpful and friendly. They strongly believe in the mission of the museum.Cameras are allowed, although the staff requests that no videos be taken. Proceeds from the museum sales directly benefit six charities. Tours are two hours long, and advanced ticket purchases are required. Very fine job. Well worth your time, in my opinion.

Incredible opportunity to see "the rest of the story". We took our 12 and 15 yr old sons to this museum and I think it was so much more powerful than going to the actual site. Mr. Suson, the photographer, was the only person allowed into the site to take recovery photos so most of these pics/artifacts will only be seen here. This is a chance to hear "real stories" from responders and to witness both tragic loss but also the love, respect, and selfless care of those who worked from the first moments of 9/11 to those who are working still. We happened to visit on a day that Mr. Suson was actually there-he has received no compensation for his photos rather all proceeds go to the FDNY foundation. This really helped our kids to understand what happened though not a frightening/graphic depiction but rather a very respectful way to honor those people who gave themselves to help others. It is a huge blessing to have this for future generations. **Please note the address as it is not by ground zero but rather in the meat packing district.

Difficult but worthwhile. We visited this museum and booked a tour which was fantasic. I admit, I had some reservations when thye menitoned the tours are conducted by volumteers who may be survivors, relatives or employees - only because of the raw emotion involved - but our guide was a city worker who assisted with the clean up and he was fantasic. The tour walked around the area and the guide had some before 9/11 and post 9/11 photos so you could look at them and then look out at where you were currently standing - whcih was amazing. The museum - which I think has now closed given the new memorial has opened - was fantasic - but again quite difficult as my husband is a paramedic - I cannot even begin to imagine what the families of the lost and missing went through. Was well worth the time spent there.

I did not know what to expect and was so glad I went!. This was a spur of the moment trip to the city with a plan of going to see the 911 memorial.I bought the tickets on-line and had no idea of what to expect. I did however read some reviews from tripadvisor. They all highly recommended this museum. They were right! It's well worth going to. Don't hesitate! Get your tickets early. You will be glad you did. Also:It is a two hour tour. Be there when it starts.Call to confirm.
Emotional experience.. Informative tour that brings to heart the tragedy that occurred on September 11th, 2001. Tastefully done and not to be missed. Highly recommended when in New York City.

worth a visit. This is worth a visit. You have to pay to get in and proceeds go to the victims families. There is video footage of what happened that day and also a photo gallery of all the victims killed as well as personal belongings recovered at the scene.

A must!. Heard of this by chance. Definitely worth a visit. Very tastefully done, the staff display a great deal of respect. Those who lost loved ones can be proud of how this very sad issue is handled.
9/11 Place. I felt a huge emotion in there, seeing how the people suffered and with my eyes wet, for them and the families.

Incredibly Moving. I didn't really know what to expect when entering but the atmosphere is quite overwhelming without it even trying. The detailed accounts and artifax recovered make it a difficult read/view and slightly incomprehensible, I left feeling incredibly moved and very glad I saw it.
Moving. Museum is under construction. Present museum is several blocks away from Ground Zero.
Just okay. Not as good as I would have expected, but still worth a vist

Heartbreaking. We enjoyed this this tour but we were not prepared for how upsetting it was going to be. The museum is a great shrine to the unfortunate people who were murdered on September 11th. Worth a visit.
Wonderful. Highly recommend this tour, Remember to get tickets in advance

A very special place but sad. We visited Ground Zero in 2004 and 2008, it was great to see the rebuilding in 2012. It was important the original Ground Zero site in no being build on. The museum was great and very sensitive. To get the free tickets you to get them about 500 metres from the museum.

Don't Miss This Museum. Being from Amsterdam, the only small Museum I have ever been in was the Anne Frank House, which was tiny but moving. We came to this Museum after reading the reviews and were expecting to possibly be let down but we were not. It IS tiny, but well organized by friendly staff. The Museum itself has amazing images that we had not seen before, with accompanying audio tour units that tell the story behind the images. Picking up 9-11 artifacts was very special, made us feel a part of the experience more. Cannot recommend this "Big Little Museum" enough. We went before going to the 9-11 Memorial and glad we did, gave us a fuller picture of 9-11. Don't miss this museum.
Well done.... It was very well put together, touching, sad and heartfelt. Glad that we went to pay our respect.
What changed our lives forever. Very moving and touching. Glad we were able to see in person and realize the devastation.

Sad. You cant go to New York and not go here, we saw it in 2007 so needed to go back in 2011 to see the progress, went to the museum you cant help but cry and therre are not many people there that dont but as I said you need to go there.
Less we Forget!. It made me mindful and was yet disturbing. Photo's were unbelieveable and soul wrenching. Like one observer stated "God Bless America"!

Nicely done and something you must visit. I have visited New York and ground zero several times but visiting this museum i learnt a lot especially through the pictures taken. The small room holds a lot of information and i liked how you can listen on your own from each piece. I'm glad i went before visiting the memorial.
WTC. a very poignant visit and one i would recommend that every one should go see

Incredible Images Conveying Human Emotion. Gary’s stunning images document the tragedy of 9/11. The astounding quality of his work will ensure that we will never forget the people who lost their lives and the tireless efforts of those involved in the recovery. I was fortunate to meet Gary Marlon Suson, the Official Ground Zero Photographer, during my visit. Gary was very warm and personable and it was wonderful to meet the person behind the images that will forever live on as a reminder to all of this day. Gary has also amassed a large number of artefacts from the Ground Zero site adding further to the experience, a visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a must see when in New York.
Dont miss this, just because.... Does one really enjoy being reminded of this, NO...but it is a very good thing sometimes....be sure and buy some momentos...part of the money goes to the project
freedom tower. good and nice done for all the people that left her lifes here

Very emotional... A very touching museum. I didn't expect it to be such a small room, however it is very easy to spend the full two hours in there looking at everything and listening to all of the stories through the headset. Whether you have any association with 911 or not, you must go if you're in New York. It makes you feel grateful to be alive, and happy to be part of the good side of the human race. It's done very tastefully - I would say it would be appropriate for kids that are old enough to not get bored too quickly.
moving!!. Very organised, memorial looks amazing, a very moving experience
wow. not sure about the musuem but we went to ground zero. you have to print out a pass with your name on it, we did it from our hotels computer real nice to see it and sad at the same time.
Very Sad. We felt a little goulish going to visit ground zero, however we needed to go to see this very sad chapter in history

Very moving experience. Very interesting and moving photographs in this museum. The artifacts that were taken from ground zero were quite interesting to look at. Gives you an even deeper appreciation of the efforts put into the recovery period.
very interesting. it was a massive eye opener to see it all first hand very sobering to see all the rebuts for the sacrifice of all those innocent people
I was just awestruck. This is an amazing museum that provides the photos and memorabilia that make 9/11 come alive.

Pre Plan. This was an amazing place to visit - the feeling when you get inside was simply overwhelming. Be sure to pre plan before visit the Memorial, as tickets are sold in a different location to the actual site or the museum.
Must See. Can't wait to see the complex completed, but this is worth a visit right now. Take some time. Security is really good. Very moving.

Very Good. Excellent but very humbling. Would have liked to have seen more though and I'm sure once the new exhibition on the memorial site is up and running this will improve.
Need to provide tissues though.

A gem of a museum. Unfortunately, it appears that some people are confusing this wonderful little place with the 9/11 Memorial. Note address above - it is NOT located at Ground Zero, but is a beautifully, tastefully done museum with wonderful photographs and artifacts from 9/11. It is located on the second floor in one room beginning with a very moving presentation, and then you are left to peruse at your leisure. You are given listening devices that are programmed to coordinate with numbers on the photgraphs and artifacts - each item has a recorded explanation.We are two grandparents who were with our three teenage grandchildren - we each decided that this collection will be a lifetime memory of our trip to New York City. It is a place that truly stands alone and above all others.

A profoundly moving, sensitive and personal reflection of 9/11. If you only go to one 9/11 museum, this is the one to choose. Visits are in small groups and the exhibition takes place in a quiet room filled with Gary Suson's photographs and memories. Each visitor is given a personal headset with audio tour by Gary allowing you to walk around the exhibits in your own time and in the order of your choice. This makes the experience unique and personal and is totally absorbing. I visited with my sister and we were lucky enough to meet the man himself at the end of the tour and ask questions about his experiences. Would strongly recommend. We booked through Viator prior to our visit.
Beautiful. A lovely memorial and well worth going to see. Its amazing what they've done and are still doing.

Was a perfect way to learn about the recovery period from 9/11 in a very well put together way. I attended the museum last week with my husband and were a little apprehensive due to the size of the museum but we needn't have worried at all! We were very lucky to meet Gary Suson and he introduced the museum and the background to it. It is an amazing experience which is done in a really tasteful way. We visited Ground zero the following day and visiting the museum prior to this made the experience a much better and moving one. We would highly recommend every visitor to NYC to go visit the museum :-)
Simply Amazing and Emotional. Touching art that can transport you in time back to feel the agony of so many effected by the crisis.

moving. I was surprised you do not have to pay to visit ground zero, you simply have to donate any amount to receive your ticket. The museum is moving and you hear voice overs of victims and people that lost loved ones in the tragedy, I think if you visit New York you must visit the site. The waterfalls where the towers stood are vast and beautiful. Each person that lost their lives have their names engraved around the side of the water falls it is an overall interesting place.
Trade center. It was very emotional and I got to speak to a couple of family members that lost their love ones.

A solemn experience-but a must see!. You must make reservations online for your entrance time and they do check. There is also a security checkpoint which slows the line down a bit. It was a bit of a wait to get in but the experience is something you should do while in New York. It's hard to imagine that day, but the endless list of names brings it home.
Touching!. Very touching place ! Very well done and a lovely peaceful place
Humbling experience.. Long wait times to get it but well worth the experience.
A must do in NYC. A very humbling and touching experience. Will stay with me a long time. Glad we went.

One of the best NYC things to experience. I have visited many of the museums located at or around ground zero and they are all worth visiting. However this one is intimate and personnel. A limited number of people are allowed in for a two hour block of time. The narration of each exhibit is clear and deeply meaningful because it is spoken by the photographer of each piece. This is an opportunity to take your time and pay respect to those involved in an histrical day of ny and the country.
emotional. this is a must see, very sombre experience. it makes you realise what america went through that fateful day... it is also free entry wit ticket they ask for a donation.
A time to reflect. This was a time to reflect and a place where you need time to read the stories and take a tissue as it may bring a tear to your eye!
Speechless. Amazing to look through these photographs and items found after the attacks.

Ground Zero Museum. This is something that you need to visit when staying anywhere in NY, my wife suggested visiting this museum after seeing it advertise on a city seeing bus tour flyer. I was really moved by the video’s and photo's there as well as some interesting, dark and surprisingly funny stories that came about during the 9 months during the clean up. We were also very lucky as when we visited Gary Suson the artist who arranged the whole exhibition had popped in.Do not put off by the price of $26 for entry to exhibition as most of the fee goes toward families of civilian and service men/women and survivors of 9/11
Very Humbling. It was hard not to feel emotional while visiting.
Small, yet touching. Visited teh workshop after the 9/11 Memorial Park. Was a bit small and very packed, but had great artifacts and presentation. Recommend checking out.
Fine tribute. videos sharing the viewpoints of people closely affected by the tragedy of 2011
Worth seeing. Powerful and a strong reminder of our need to remember the price being paid for our freedom

To remember and to honour. A tribute to the most atrocious crime against innocent human beings going to work on a peaceful morning.A visit is a must for every decent person living or travelling to New York.

Tasteful Remembrance. I recommend going to the museum prior to going to the memorial instead of afterward. Having some background on the heros and individuals who lost their lives puts everything in it's proper perspective.

It is sombre.. It should be up there with Auschwitz as a place for people of all religions and ideologies to attend at least once in their lives, to witness and relive the stupidity and ignorance of the human kind. It’s a sombre place and a story about a police dog killed, touch me more than most. On the negative side, it’s a little self-promoting in some ways. I couldn’t care less who the main photographer was, but they introduced him as some kind of war hero, that we were lucky to meet.. and he was signing his book! Go, it reminds you of the futility of life. I can’t give it a higher rating… it feels weird to rate it at all!
Breath taking. Everyone who goes to New York has to come here, it is a very moving experience to come here
Excellent. emotional together with a touching experience and a must visit destination
Very moving. There's not much more to say. Glad we saw it, the museum shop was informative, the video that runs on the back wall was very emotional.

The best attraction in NY. WHen I stepped into the workshop I was captivated by the images that were displayed on the walls and the artifacts. After I got to learn more about what happened on 9/11 it almost brought tears to my eyes. I recommend this place to everybody who visits NY its really cool and its worth seeing.

Awesome. It's very educational and it's the only place to let you touch some of the artifacts.It has a very warm feeling once you come in. And that is especially great if you lost someone in 9/11.The pictures are clear and they seem to make some people feel like they are really there!The stories behind the artifacts are well detailed.And the workers there are kind and will make you fell right at home.
Surreal. went to this and it brought home the devastation of that sorry day!! but also the resilliance of NY and its people

Glad I went. Seemed a bit ghoulish beforehand but I couldn't have been more wrong. 9/11 was such a pivotal event it has to be seen, even now. Might appear voyeuristic but, after all, you're there, supporting the city in some small way and the rebuilding of the site is quite inspiring, actually.

Emotional dedication. We stumbled accros this muesum on our way to the memorial, so glad we went in. It is a bit pricey, $15 an adult, but if you are a firefighter, policeofficer, or in the defence force you pay $10. The items on display here are very emotional to see and read the stories attached. They have people talk daily, might be a survivor, a relative of a victim or a responder, but all directly affected by 9/11.Do yourself a favour and find out the stories behind the images.

So moving. This is an amazing experience. Very moving. Was here a number of years ago and it is amazing to see how much it has changed and developed over the past few years. You couldn't but feel moved while there. It was incredible.

Very Moving Tribute to 911. I am so glad I saw this. We were lucky in that Gary Suson was in the museum to give us a brief presentation and answer questions after we looked around the museum. For such a small place, this museum packs an emotional punch that won't be soon forgotten.

A memorable experience - probably one of the best small museums you can find. I recommend this tour to anyone going to New York. The photographs are great, the real artefacts from the destroyed WTC and the recovery (some of which you can touch - all of which will touch you) make this a very hands-on experience.On our visit, photographer and museum founder Gary Suson was there in person - and we were able to ask questions and chat with him for a while. All the other staff were very friendly and helpful, too.
Family Adventure. very moving. Make sure you go to St. Paul's church and spend time inside.
Ground Zero. Fantastic memorial to those who past and those who survived. A must for anyone who values life.
Excellent and Moving. Amazingly thoughtful and memorable. cried like a baby all the way around. lovely to see the memory of all the people that died that day kept alive in such a moving way!!

Sends shivers down your spine. What an amazingly emotional place this was to visit. You got a sense of the loss that happened at ground zero and you can't help but become a little bit emotional as you see the artifacts and read the stories. Heart rendering and a place not to be missed.
Sobering and thought provoking. This is a must see in New York. It is a sobering experience and a beautiful tribute to those who died.
~Emotional. really moving and worth going to to get sense again of the magnitude of this horrific event

Impactive & humbling. A real insight into the aftermath of the horrific terrorist attacks. The personal stories of those who were involved and those who lost love ones. Our guide was Gary Marlon Suson the official Ground Zero photographer and was emotional to say the least. A moving tribute, one which allows you to pay your respects to all who lost their lives.
Amazing. I can't say enough about this place. You have to go yourself to get the full experiance. I would highly recommend this to anyone.

It gives the area a focus.. You can stay as long as you feel you need to or if you prefer you can take a quick look round and take from it what you need to. My husband was in and out in ten minutes but i felt i wanted to know more and listen to some of the tapes made by the people involved in the tragedy.

breath taking, emotional, very touching. i knew visiting this museum was goiing to be touching, but i didnt realisse how much until i got there, the museum is a small one roomed place, but dont let this put you off, i was more touched by the things in this one room than i was in the 4 storey huge modern history museum or he moma etc. to be able to touch artifacts fromt he actual site is incredible, hearing the 911 recordings from the people involved was heart wrenching, it felt as if we were right there, the most incredible thing of all, is that unlke any other museum i have ever been, you are able to toch the artifacts found at the site. but let me assure you, this museum is very tasteful in its set up, there are no disturbing images and i found it to be very very respectful. during our tour we had the honour of being guided by Mr Sousson himself, the official photographer and collector of the artifacts, who was on hand to answer all questions asked. there is a charge for entry to this musuem, and a percent of the proceeds goes to the fire fighters fund and some of the families of the tragedy. PLEASE BE AWARE THIS MUSEUM IS NOT IN THE SAME PLACE AS THE MEMORIAL WATERFALLS, ITS ABOUT A 5 MIN SUB RIDE AWAY. Thank you Gary, for allowing people such as myself, from countries afar, the chance to experience what the people of america had to endure during the tragedy of 9/11.

Moving and emotional experience. This museum is quite small but it packs a lot in to it and is all very emotional and impacting. It really makes you thinks. There was a survivor of 9/11 speaking whilst we were there and his story was overwhelming. It was totally different view point to look at the events from.
Extremely moving!. This is def worth a visit, but be prepared for how emotional it will be. Cannot recommend enough.

My heart goes to the victims n family. I thought I was able to hold back....but my tears just kept on flowing!!! Reading notes of hope to find loved ones...was just unbearable. The emotion was so overwhelming. At that time construction of the ground zero was still going on. This place is worth visiting!!!
Needs to be visited. I felt I needed to visit to put into perspective the events of 9/11 and found this a powerful experience

Supreme and Solemn. Anyone who fails to be touched by this inspiring monument to that fateful day should check themselves in for a physical. A fitting tribute to the thousands of men and women who died on the day when humanity sank to its lowest depths. Gone but never forgotten.

A must see!. My husband and I went to this small museum and would recommend it to everyone. It really takes you into the heart of the 9/11 recovery and makes you truly see the heroism so many exhibited. It is very emotional, but a great museum to explore before making the short distance to the new 9/11 memorial. Those who passed on that day and those who have passed in the aftermath due to related health issues, you will never be forgotten.
ground zero. fantastic, more than what I expected. Breath taking.
ground zero. very very emotional such a fantastic tribute to the memories of all the people so sadly taken from us. well worth a visit
Must see.. Very moving. Get your tickets on-line first before going. Very easy to get.

Worth a look. An emotional visit, to see what happened and understand the feeling of loss. New beginnings are happening at Ground Zero with the rememberance plaza, the water falls, museum and the hundreds of planted trees
Very touching. This is a very surprising memorial - i'd never seen anything quite like it. A must see but make sure you don't need a toilet!
great to see but emotional. fantastic memorial to all the lives of people lost but sad at the same time a must see as this is now part of history

Brings a tear to your eyes. When you visit the museum there is a video playing of family and friends who lost people in 9/11. By the time the video ends you can experience what each one has been through.There is also a Fireman's helmet in a glass case with all the dust still on from that terrible day. When you see that a chill goes through your whole body.

emotional but worth it. when people ask me what the highlight of NYC was for me, i have to say the 9/11 museum and tour, 2 steps in and i was already trying to hold back the tears, reading a quote from a husband stuck on one of the hijacked planes to his wife was gut wrenching, and the wall of missing people was confronting but i'm so glad i did it, the tour was amazing but emotional, as one of our guides was a security guard at the twin towers on the day of the attacks, and hearing his story made it even more emotional for me. would definately recommend to anyone visiting New York.
A touching tribute.... There're actually two museums, one on West 14th St and the other is at the exit of ground zero. Both are very similar and pay tribute to the terrible events of 9/11.
Very moving,wonderful photos, so much information in a small space. Take all the time available to listen to the audio and look at the photos

Moving. All I can really say is, "wow" as I really don't know what words to use to describe this place. Very moving and emotional experience. I am glad I had the opportunity to visit and reflect and pay respect to those who lost their lives and loved ones, but sorry that such a place has to exist.
Still under construction but still very nice. Still under construction but still very nice..go see it!

Moving and worth a visit. I visited here with an American girl and we were both moved by this tribute to those lost on Septemeber 11, this is moving and a very sad place to visit but definitely worth the visit. Worthwhile experience for anyone.
Very moving, worth a visit. The film they show will have you tears. You have to go and then do something fun and frivolous afterwards to lighten the mood.

Very emotional to be there. I feel this memorial celebrates the lives of those who made the ultimate sacrifice and at the same time makes you reflect on the horrors of 9/11 what will be a very serene and peaceful setting in the middle of the Big Apple.

Tiny but interesting. At $25 this is pricey, particularly for families. Most contents pertain to the recovery efforts (of remains) in the months after the towers fell. Very personal and moving, definitely gives a feel for Fire Dept. and NYPD experience. I don't know what will happen to this once the WTC opens their museum in the end of 2012. Right now I think this is the best exhibit of its kind. We saw this before visiting the new WTC site, and were glad we came here first.
Memorable. For sure I will return during my next visit in NY as I really want to visit the Memory Center.

Sad, emotionally provactive, yet hopeful. Be sure to visit it alone or with people who will not rush you. Although the museaum is tiny, the stories told are staggering and the employees wonderful.At first, I did not want to go, but I am so glad that I did.

Moving and elegant. It is difficult to write about this due to the terrible events that created it's necessity. I found it to be tasteful, beautiful and moving. It was like being in the middle of a vale of tears. Which felt right.

A very nice tribute, definitely recommended. This museum is a great tribute to the victims of 9/11. It consists of a single room with 100+ photos focused on the recovery after the tragedy. After a short talk and video presentation, you spend up to 2 hours viewing the photos and using your audio guide to hear the stories behind each picture. The stories were extremely moving and put a very unique and one of a kind view into the recovery efforts.
Excellent. Worth the visit. Very interesting and moving! I'd recommend it to any visitors to New York City.

Moving. Went here after seeing the 911 Memorial.
It was moving, but i thought it was basicaly just a gift shop.
Very fitting tribute. Very tastefully done and well organised, a must - even if just for a short visit to see progress that has been made and to apprecite the scale of the damge done.
Somewhere you have to go. It was tastefully laid out and very moving. The site is now being built upon - the last time we were there there was just a large hole.

Worth the trip- small museum with real heartfelt images of the fateful event in our history. Make tour reservations and visit this museum in the Meatpacking district. Small, intimate museum with a collection of emotional photographs and artifacts from 9/11 and the World Trade Center site. It reminds us to never forget.
Sobering experience. Tastefully and movingly presented and inspiring what lies ahead with the construction phase currently taking place
Exciting. Exciting. Thats the word! When faced with those giant pools, tears come to your eyes.
chilling!. so amazing to the the positive progress the people of the city have made in memory of such a sad occurence. was really great but sad at the same time.

Moving and unique photographic perspective on the aftermath of 9/11. The replay of the CNN interview with Gary Marlon Suson was extremely moving and seeing his unique photos made this horrific terrorism act so close and real. The personal audio narration of each photo was brief and well done. We were really fortunate in that Gary was there in person during our visit. Liked very much the intimate museum with limited visitors and having seen Ann Frank's house in Amsterdam, fully agree with why Gary constructed his museum similarly. DEfinitely a must see attraction in NYC after visiting reflecting pools at 9/11 Memorial site .
Very Moving. Although very said glad I went as it was very informative & gave me the opportunity to puchase a momento & donate to their memorial fund, but you dont have to. Worth seeing.
9/11 Museum. this was the coldest day for an outside tour. It was fast and efficent operations and no waiting in lines to see it! I woudl recommend making reservations.

Memorable and Moving. We made reservations one week in advance. Our whole family found it moving and memorable (we have three daughters ages 15 - 21). We spent 2 hours which is about how long you need if you listen to all of commentaries connected to the photos and artifacts. You could spend less time but you would have to skip some of the stories which would detract from your experience. Highly recommend this. I happened to be in NYC on the 10th Anniversary of 9/11. My LA based friend organised this Museum visit for us on the 12th. Gem of a Museum!. They told us upon arrival that their nickname is the "biggest little museum" around. And it's true, the space is not large, which is why they only allow small groups to go in at a time. However, what is on display is larger than words can describe. My friend and I left talking about how much we enjoyed the uniqueness and intimacy of the space itself, as much as the displays. A 1-2 hour visit is plenty of time, and well worth it.

Informative and interesting. Visited this museum after reviews on here. We walked down on the other side of the road and there is only a small sign outside and this was blocked by a car - was not hard to find at all but maybe a bigger sign would help. We also got there 15 mins early, and although I appreciate it is needed we then had to wait outside in the freezing cold until just gone 11 anyway. However, it is a very interesting place and one I would recommend to everyone - I think they have a good balance of narration and self guide with an audio guide. The guides are on hand if you have any questions and there is a good mix of photos and objects. Obviously Gary Suson was the official photographer for the FDNY and the focus is on this, as this is where he had access to. In my opinion it would have been more interesting to provide more information about other people, but I appreciate this was probably not feasible. I think $25 is pretty reasonable as it is for two hours and is non-profit. Although it is in a very small room it is packed full of interesting photographs and facts and I could have stayed longer, which is more than can be said for many other museums.
Very well done. They did an incredible job. I would highly recommend taking the time to check it out.

Not what we expected. After reading the good reviews we were a little disappointed. The photos are excellent but felt the 'story' did not come across. All very one dimensional - only from the photographer's eyes, could have added different voices.

Extremely moving. We had made reservations, and I straggly recommend you do as they only take a limited number to each session. The venue is small but the display is very powerful.
