I am avoiding saying very one should start at one as this would create a problem. Time does dim memories and this collection provides the opportunity to refresh and refocus kn many aspects of that terrible day.

Do not recommend. We did this thinking it would be an awesome experience. I was totally disappointe. Its a very tiny one room meseum with photo's and a few artifacts you are better visiting the NYPD mueseum which shows similar photos and better artifacts from ground zero

A must do.. Its a shame that some of the reviews on here are mixed up with the memorial plaza at the twin towers site. This is about the Ground Zero Museum workshop - the amazing little museum in the meatpacking district. I went earlier today and after a short wait in the street,no more than 5 minutes, the group were taken up to a small room about 8-9meters square. It is a tiny museum, but that creates an atmosphere that would be missing i a larger more open surrounding. The 'tour' itself consists of a 30minute video explaining who the photographer is, why he was in the position to take the photos of the recovery work and a little about some of the photos. Then you are introduce to some of the more important artifacts - one in particular (no33) is just incredible. You then have well over an hour to listen to the tourguide (the photographer himself explaining the photos and artifacts on a headset that you wear) as you take your time and study the photos and artifacts for yourself. There were a few stories and photos that almost had me crying, such was the emotion involved. To see things up close, that we have all seen being destroyed on live television in one of the most infamous scenes in history, brings a lot of thoughts to the forefront of the mind. A very moving experience. I was the last person to leave after looking through every one of the exhibits and was lucky enough to meet Gary (the photographer) and thank him on my way out. Then, I felt the need, to slowly walk south, down the banks fof the Hudson river and visit the site itself - even though I had been before. The visit to the Workshop museum left me slightly drained, but also happy. The stories about men digging in the dirt for months on end and their respect for each other and the ground itself and what it contained were amazing. The museum is the perfect size and duration. You are not asked to buy anything, but if you want a photo or card to take away they are available to buy. You are left alone with your thoughts and ideas and allowed to look into the tragedy in your own time. I would highly recommend this museum to anyone - Children might get bored, but I would visit anyway. Go, listen, look and think about what happened.

Forever memories of a time not forgotten. It took my breath away.. A must see for anyone that was touched by this event, wants to here and see untold stories, and those that want to be closer to this time in our history. It was truly an amazing and special experience that no one should miss!

All of this helped us to better understand what the rescue teams, survivors and the families endured during those first few days, weeks, months and years. A Labor of Love. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop isn't like going to MoMA. It is housed in an old building in a small space. But don't let its location and size deter you from experiencing this place. Only about 15-20 people can be booked at one time because of the space limitations. I found this to be a good thing. There are places to sit. There are headphones and recorded information about what you're looking at, just like in a big museum. It just feels much more personal here. The young people who check your name off the registration sheet are kind, helpful, and enthusiastic. Many times, the photographer who collected these artifacts and took the photographs will come in and visit. He did so the day we were there. It is my understanding that the GZMW is the idea of the photographer and possibly underwritten financially solely by him. It truly is his labor of love.As a volunteer who worked at Ground Zero for approximately 3 - 4 weeks, the GZMW held the kind of things and showed through photography, what I remember in my mind from my time there. If you think that it can't be that great if it's not a grand place, think again. In the quiet of that 'upper room', there is solitude and reflection accomplished within your own timetable. Don't miss the opportunity to purchase the photographer's book. We bought one and it has been a source of great discussion in our home, especially around the anniversary of 9-11. I highly recommend this little jewel of a place, where you can get lost in remembrance, never forgetting that historic yet fateful day.

Worthwhile visit but would appear pricy to some. Glad I went to see the museum but i think it highlighted the different expectations of a UK as opposed to a US visitor. Having read some of the other comments (and responses) I can see that some things which don't seem to be marketing or overly religious to a US citizen seem quite the opposite to a (stereotypically) less pushy and agnostic Brit. For example you would never find reference to the fact that people see angels in the smoke clouds in a UK museum - you would just get the picture and a comment about what was being shown. I appreciate that religion (of whatever kind) was important to the museum's founder and probably many of the workers at the site and the metal cross formed by the girders was a powerful image but I'd have preferred it if the image was left to speak for itself and there was no mention of angels in the commentary. Similarly I suspect some Brits would find narration by the firefighters themselves for some of the photos more informative than having it all provided by the museum's founder. The space works well (although comparisons to the Anne Frank museum are a little stretched as that is much bigger and it draws its main emotional response from being able to visit the actual rooms she lived in rather than the artifacts) and although the museum would benefit form larger premises and space this aspect was fine. Personally I wanted a bit more guiding for my $25 - a brief introduction and video and then an audio tour doesn't equate to value for money in my opinion. I'd also have liked a bit more information about the events of the recovery process - a timeline or simply edited highlights ie. when the first body was found, when the last was found, when the hand searching stopped, what the split of bodies recovered was ie how many civilians, how many police, how many firefighters, how much rubble was removed, what happened to the scrap steel, documentation of how other faiths were built into the healing process (not just christian and jewish) etc. I'd also like to have known which part of the buildings the identifiable bodies belonged to - were the bodies all from the ground floor or were bodies found intact from the higher floors - maybe not what the museum is intended for but it would help my understanding of what happened that day without being too gruesome.I'm not sure what I was expecting but I think the workshop in the title of the museum implies a more interactive element - maybe some computer displays providing more information and the ability to find out about the exhibits that can't be displayed due to space constraints and a bit more detail about what was behind some of the stories. This might help with the comments about there not being much for children to do (as opposed to listen to). I wasn't expecting to see pictures of the planes hitting the towers as I think the promotional material is clear that the museum charts the recovery effort rather than what happened on the day. Hopefully the new museum at the WTC site will explore how and why more fully when it opens.I'd also like a bit more time to be used to explore the issues arising from the exhibits particularly the aftermath of the recovery effort and the lasting impact on those who took part in it. For example I'd like a bit of analysis / feedback about whether it was worth at least an extra 24 deaths to recover the bodies - what are the feelings of the relatives of the recovery workers who have subsequently died ? It might seem obvious that bodies should be recovered but if my husband had been lost that day I wouldn't have wanted anyone risking their life to find his body. Also what support mechanisms have been set up for recovery workers and what has happened to some of the characters in the photos - this could link into the donations made and the positive impact they've had.It would also be useful to have an indication of the total donated to charity somewhere in the exhibit - a running total on the whiteboard which shows individual donations would be helpful. I understand that the museum is a not for profit organisation and that detailed percentages would be difficult to produce but a link to the last annual report and accounts on the website would aid transparency for those who were interested. The Anne Frank Museum has this on its website and all UK charities have to publish their accounts for all to see how much they cost to run and how much of the surplus is donated.Overall though I'm glad I went and some of the stories told were interesting and moving. It does make you appreciate that there was alot of sacrifice after the day and I hadn't realised so many firefighters lost their lives on the day - I'll definitely be trying to find out more about why this happened. UK visitors need to be aware that it is very "american" in its presentation - probably a bit sentimental and not objective enough for some UK tastes. What would be great would be to see an amalgamation of this museum and the one at the WTC site when that one opens. That would allow more space to explore the recovery stage fully and show more of the photos.

Beautiful memorial site for 911. Advice is to get in line 1st thing in the morning to get your tickets to get into the 911 ground zero area! We arrived around 9:45 and werent able to get into ground zero until around 1pm that same day.

This place will make you emotional. It just hurts the soul to go here. It seems like you have to do this, almost a rite of passage, pay your respects kind of thing, but it’s going to hurt I will warn you. I never knew the first person that lost their life but once you see the photos of all those people, it hurts. Seeing the memories pulled from the rubble, seeing the suffering that those people endured. It’s tough. I’m glad to see life rising up from the ashes though, a true testament to our resolve. We had planned on simply doing to the memorial rather than the museum too but so glad we did both. They give military, fire, and police discounts which I think was nice. You would think they would let them in free given the situation, but that’s my opinion. The memorial on the side of the fire hall is captivating. The detail is outstanding. People still lay flowers and candles at the site. The Memorial Pools almost take your breath they are so beautiful. The names of those lost, and the Freedom Tower rising high above them. It’s truly a place to reflect.

Very moving and informative museum. A very impressive display of awesome artefacts and photographs that really help you understand what happened during 9/11 and what the recovery/aftermath was like. I gained a far deeper understanding from the museum, and how it affected everyones lives, way more than media reports and articles I have read in the past. As Gary hoped to do, he has really helped you feel like you forge a connection with those that were involved. Very powerful and moving stuff, well worth a visit!
Ground Zero. Very emotional actually seeing how many people died. Museum not finished yet.
Moving Experience. It was relatively easy to obtain tickets. The memorial is so well done.
Amazing and beautiful tribute!. This is a don't miss site in NY. It is truly a heart touching experience and well worth the visit.
Ground Zero. This was a very emotive experience but not to be missed.

Truly amazing work and great experience. It was amazing to see every thing thru eyes and camera of the photographer. The actual audio from the Recovery period of Ground Zero gave me chills. The emotion in each photo speaks volumes. it truly made the whole time more real for me.

Very sad but compelling to visit. Go on-line to reserve your ticket before you go...... if you don't book you can wait in line on the day but there may be long queues at the information centre and you might not get a ticket after waiting.
Amazing design. It has the appearance of a fallen building with the authentic steel beams visible from outside. Very emotional.
Ground Zero. Very moving experience. Well worth visiting and spend a little while to think about all those who lost their lives in such a sad way.

This place is amazing!. This museum definitely has the feeling of a sacred place. With the photographs and the artifacts not behind glass like other museums, you really feel close to what happened on that day. The video and the headsets are wonderful to get the real story behind the exhibits and photos. The audio headsets are narrated by the photographer himself, Gary Suson. He came into the museum while we were there and was open to talking to anyone that asked him questions. The experiences he had as the only photographer allowed into Ground Zero during recovery, changed his life forever and this museum shares his experiences with us.
Whhat a reality check. Quite a shaking of reality. Meticulously designed to the very last element. What a reality check
A must see!. Beautiful grounds/waterfalls, yet very heartbreaking.
Very Interesting. Wish I could have spent more time reading the information!

Very poignant. Walking tour 2 hours . Excellent guide in Michael Dillinger who related his experiences as well as some of the untold stories of the real heroes involved in the rescue efforts after the atrocious attack of 9/11 .

Personal record of 9/11. I was unsure what to expect however the museum was an interesting and poignant place to visit.It was a surprisingly small but compact room.The visit started with a video of 9/11 and a brief resume of the photographer who took the pictures which were on display in the museum.You were given a set of headphones and a small cassette? unit as you entered. Each exhibit had a number which you entered into the unit and you were given information about the exhibit.I found the stories and pictures heartbreaking.There were pieces of glass,cards,a phone to name but a few items which survived this terrible event.The pictures of the firefighters bringing out the bodies and standing to attention was so sad.The bodies were covered and at no time did you see any of the victims.I would recommend this to anyone who visits New York.It is a personal record of 9/11 and you will be touched by it.

Beautiful and moving tribute. The wait to get in was horrendous! I mean it was at least 1 1/2 hours. Then the security checks (saw a lot of these at other sites too). Once inside it didn't matter. Impressive!

Every US Citizen should visit the 911 Memorial. You MUST get passes on-line for specific times due to the large crowds. There is a lot of walking to get to the entrance so be prepared and wear comfortable shoes. The direction signage is terrible so ask a police officer. There is security that will check your purses etc...similar to TSA at the airport except the NYC security personnel are very rude and yell out orders to visitors.The memorial speaks for itself and is not a place for small children to run around an play. The museum is excellent and has many articles for purchase.
Ground Zero Vistit. Very somber, but needs to be visited. Speak with the volunteers dressed ina yellow vest, they can provide additonal insight.
Very Moving. A trip to NYC is not complete without a visit to this place

Poignant. You have to visit this area to feel the love and solemness surrounding the whole 9/11 event. Well done to all the NYorker's who have had to live and work through it all and well done to those involved for sharing their memories. Awesome.
9/11 Memorial...perfect.. went here (remember to sign into the website before you go and book a slot or you will be disappointed) The site is beautiful and very thought provoking. Loved it.
So moving yet great progress. Such a moving place, and you cant help but feel for those poor people that lost their lives, but work is coming on at pace and it will all rise again from the ashes.
Lots of Emotions. The museum is very small, but is highly emotional, every picture has a story. Make reservations.

Very moving. WE just turned up in the morning around 11am and there were plenty of free tickets to go into the site (I'd tried to book online but it appeared they had 'all gone'). There are 2 shops/centers with moving accounts and items for sale etc, 2 nearby churches and then the site itself to see.
It's a powerful experience. There's a strong closeness to those who died or were missing. It really hurts.

A Must See Experience. This was an experience I won't soon forget. It's a very intimate setting with a limited number of guests. The truly remarkable thing is everything here has been put on display by the individual that was actually there, he was there as honorary battalion chief and he is sharing his experience with the world. The pictures, videos and recordings put you at the scene and are very moving. The items that are on display are obviously rare to see and make this experience even more worthwhile. You have 2 hours to move at your own pace with a hand held audio guide that gives you information on the displays. I recommend that everyone see this, I honestly feel it is a must see.

One of the best museums I've ever been to!. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is superb! It's incredibly small but the photographs, artefacts and stories behind them are so moving that it is easy to spend hours there. I was the last in my tour group to leave! The staff are helpful and the audio tour detailed and told by the photographer himself. If you do one thing in New York, go to this museum!

Very Moving and a fantastic experience. Me, My Mum and Sister went to New York for her 21st Birthday and were recommended to go to this museum by our Dad that had seen some great reviews on Trip Advisor, The Museum is in a small white room that is packed with information and some very moving artifacts as well as plenty of eye witness accounts. The whole experience was very moving and as an added bonus we were also very honored to meet Gary Marlon Suson who was there. Highly recommend anyone going to America to go and see this!!!

May be small - but there's a TON of info and things to see!. How can ANYONE say that there wasn't "that much to see??" I'd guess that as small as this museum was, there was probably over 100 artifacts/pictures and 75+ informative guides to listen to. This was a great museum to go to and see and allowed for an "outsider" to witness Sept 11th from an up close and personal view. I was shocked at how much there was to see and hear about. If you have time, a must see!!

Small venue but Enormously moving experience. It was very moving to come face to face with actual remnants of the 9/11 disaster. Also very touching to hear the stories behind the pictures and learn more detail. I can't imagine the toll taking all that aftermath in must have been on Mr. Suson but his documentation allows the rest of us to grieve and empathize more with what actually occurred. It was a very somber and moving experience for myself and 3 teenage boys I brought with me. My son is in training to be a firefighter and the tour guide was kind enough to get me the address for Rescue One in Manhattan. We visited there right after the tour and were welcomed so kindly by the firemen there (who sadly lost 11 of their own that day). After your museum and then meeting these men and seeing the firehouse with pictures of those they lost on the walls, it was a very powerful day that gave us new found awe and admiration for the FDNY and all of those involved in coming to the aid of their fellow man without question, even at their own peril. We will never forget the experience.
emotional. this place gives an insite into the after effects of the disaster , videos of family and friends of those lost , artifacts left at the scene...... brings it all home.
very emotional.... you are really brought back to 2001, all emotions are coming up.

amazing photos and lots of info. I loved my time in this small, one room museum! it is chock full of pics and info and you get to see and hold (certain)items recovered from Ground Zero. It was a great experience, and i purchased a book there with a lot of those pics in it.
good. I liked that it keeps reminding us what human being is capable of.

A Small Museum yet an Abundance of Tragedy, Humanity, Hope, and Patriotism. What an amazing museum!! I don't even know if you can really call it a museum, though. It's only one room about the size of a living room. Therefore, I'll just say "what a great attraction!!" After the events of 9/11, only one photographer, Mr. Gary Suson, was granted the right to photo the recovery efforts. He has taken his photographs along with many other artifacts and created this wonderful room of memories. This is self-guided tour where each photo/artifact has a brief narration by Mr. Suson on the experience or history of that piece. Along with his narrations are actual sounds from the recovery efforts. Mr. Suson has done a wonderful job of creating an experience that is informational and emothional, and, more importantly, one that truly honors those that perished on that day. We were lucky on the day of our visit. Mr. Suson was there and gave us a brief history of his experience and we were able to get to know the man, at least briefly, responsible for this small treasure. The fee is $25. A bit steep at first thought. But then again, he shares a bit of this amount with various organizations. One that is currently helping with medical expenses for a NY firefighter who developed cancer, most likely from his efforts in the recovery.I highly recommend this to anyone!!

must see. Wonderful exhibits. You will not see more in such a limited area. Great staff. If you have time , at least 2 hours, this is a moving tribute to the fallen and the survivors of 911, New York..
very emotional !. When you enter the museum, it's immediately very emotional with all the witness stories, images, memories ...
Very Moving and A Definite must see. This piece of America's history is not to be missed.

A must do if going to new york!. They are referred to a the biggest little museum in ny...and that they are! While in ny this was the best thing I did! Very interesting to here stories of ground zero during recovery period, and seeing some artifacts never seen anywhere before. There is also a small gift shop on site, and I highly recommend purchasing the book by Suson; which has his photos and more stories in it...great keepsake. Also easy to get to by subway!

Moving and Meaningful Place to Visit. We thoroughly enjoyed our time at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop and found the displays and recordings to be informative, meaningful and very moving! The museum itself is quite small but provides the viewer with an intimate and personal account of a very difficult time in our country's history. It also provides insight into the character of Amercians and our deep rooted desire to help and serve. We would highly recommend this museum and hope that many individuals take the opportunity to visit.

AMAZING!!!!. One of the best places I have visited!! It is such a small place but a lot of information in it!! I would recommend this to anyone that wants to learn more about 9/11 and to see what actually happened. The pictures are so life like and its a very emotional place. On a scale of 1-10 i give it a 20....something that people need to see while in New York City!!!!!

powerful and emotional. It was an intimate room with stunning pictures and artifacts showing the true strength and beauty of the American people. I went with my husband and baby (7months). I did need to leave the room when she got a bit fussy as it is important for people to enjoy this exhibit in the tranquility that it is set up in. It is touching and moving.

A Very Moving and Worthwhile Museum. This was one of the Highlights if not THE Highlight of our NYC trip. We had 4 teenagers with us and even they thought is was very good. We were lucky enough to have the actual photographer present during our visit too, which made the whole experience even better.The museum is rather small like other reviews mentioned but the presentation is quality, once you experience it for yourself you will know what I mean. I highly recommend this museum if you are traveling to NYC.

VERY POWERFUL. We went to this museum on November 12, 2011 on our last day of our 10th wedding anniversary trip. My husband is a Fire Chief in Canada and let me tell you that we were both very emotional for the rest of the day. Looking at the pictures, artifacts and listening to the stories related to the pictures and artifacts in this room was quite the experience. It brought back soooo many memories of that day. So if you're in New York and want to visit something meaningful, go visit this small but very powerful museum and don't forget to visit the real ground zero site as well. Well worth it!!!

Worth the visit. Not really a museum, although they do have some artifacts from the Towers. The photographs and the stories (listened to over a headset) are truly incredible. We got to met and listen to the photographer when we visited. It is absolutely riveting to hear the stories about the victims and the survivors of this tragic event.
very moving. totally enjoyed this , even though its very sad with everything that has happened here
Well worth a visit.. Until you see the extent of the damage does it hit you, as to what some people are capable of.

What an amazing experience!. The museum tells the story of such tragedy that our country had to face. Gary captured the essence of what was happening during that time. He caught the fear, the sadness, the relief of finding missing loved ones, the devastation and the love and comraderie throughout the process. The museum is a must see on your visit to NY.

Not what I was looking for. I respect this place but it was not a museum at all. It was an info session of 9/11 in a tiny room. The room is filled with 9/11 photos mostly about firefighters with audio explanations with each of them. We watched a video and walked around the room looking at photos and listening to our own audio headset. I regret the money and time spent there and if I can choose again I rather go the the actual ground zero.
Emotional site. The silence and respect to the place was just amazing

It was an incredibly humbling and moving experience. My husband is a retired Captain for FDNY, and we went with several other fireman and their families. We were all so touched by the experience. From the moment you walked in the door, you knew that it was going to be different. The tour guides were phenomenal and the environment held an air of reverence and tranquility. As you moved through the many artifacts and listened to the stories, you knew that everything was handled and placed in that room with such love and complete respect. Gary Suson is blessed with a rare and special gift and he gives that back in his stunning photos and the work that he has done in this Museum Workshop. It was an honor to experience it. Thank you
Ground Zero. incredibly moving experience. you need to book on-line 24 hours before visit.

Very moving, interesting, and a must see museum. This was recommended to us by family members, and is a must for any visitor to New York. It is the biggest little museum in New York.Situated in the Meat packing district.There are images and articles found at the 9/11 site.A very moving experience, and they do supply boxes of tissues. You are allowed to take photos, but not video taping.

Well done, emotional, and informative of a time the USA will never forget.. This is a one room museum filled with so much information about 9/ll. I was impressed as to how the workshop was put together. It is a small group of people allowed in, so book early. You are met with an overview, film, and then the room is filled with relics and photos that are numbered and you have a headset to select that number and you are filled with information from that very emotional day. It was very respectful and ideal for children as well as adults. I was tearful at times but came away with great thanks and respect for those who lost their lives and served on that day. May they rest in peace!

A moving and illuminating exhibit, not to be missed.. Though it is not at Ground Zero, the photographs and accompanying recorded narratives provide a dimension you will not otherwise see. It is a relatively small space, with carefully limited tours, and the effect of the images, the impact of seeing actual artifacts, including a piece of one of the planes, is cumulative and immense. I went by myself in March of 2011, then returned in October of 2011, with my husband, who was equally moved. Though I thought I was prepared for this second viewing, I saw and heard things I'd missed on the first tour. I cannot say enough about this deeply affecting exhibit.

Very touching for my family, an experience we will not forget.. My family and I were glad we decided to pay a visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Both my children, ages 13 and 16 got so much from it, an experience we will not forget. Having being able to hold a steel cross that was made from the recovered steel was powerful. The photographs tell the story in a way that pulls at your heart. You can here about each photo and artifact as you walk around the room, and go at your own pace. It was a special treat for my family as we were walking out to actually meet Gary Suson, the photographer. We want to thank him for taking a moment with us. Definitely a highlight for us!
Make the time to visit. This was really good and very moving to see parts of the towers preserved. Lots of info about the new development and how people have helped those affected.
impressive. thought provoking. lots of people and still an atmosphere appropriate to the topic of the exhibition. But nothing can capture the horror of that day.

Amazing insight into the greatest tragedy of modern times, not to be missed.. Like the Ann Frank museum in Amsterdam it gives you a different personal perspective to tragedy. As the only photographer throughout the clear up operation he captured all of the amazing heart felt stories with his tasteful pictures. To see artefacts recovered from the site up close made the whole thing come alive and none more so then when I sat on a stool inches from part of the fuselage of flight 11. Not your normal museum but this is not a normal historical event.

definitely worth a visit. I was a bit unsure when I initially booked my tickets - I was worried that it was a fake website. However, we followed the instructions that were sent and it worked perfectly.The 'exhibition' is organised very well and allows you to view the artifacts in your own time and order.The staff were very clear and helpful and the overall experience was very moving and interesting.Having been to this museum and then travelling down to the Ground Zero site we decided not to actually visit the 9/11 memorial on this occasion. Although it would definitely be on my list the next visit to NYC.
911 Memorial. Beatiful and somber memorial of the 911 crash. Highly recommend a visit and you must have reservations to get in, tickets are free.

Thoughtful and moving.. It would have been so easy to go over the top with this. I had my own prejudices about Americans overdoing the emotions so wasn't sure what to expect. They've thought it through very carefully whilst still conveying the sadness of what happened. The photos and artefacts focus on the rescue and salvage carried out by the FDNY, with the many stories they tell. Something in there will move you. We were lucky enough to have the photographer himself come in as we were leaving and spend a minute talking to us.

This is not the official 9/11 memorial site - don't get confused. I can see from some of the reviews that others are as confused as I was about this "museum". I booked for this only to later realise that is not at the Ground Zero site. If you want to go to the actual WTC/Ground Zero site you need to book for the 9/11 Memorial. Whilst the "Ground Zero Museum Workshop" was interesting, I think it is a bit of a misnomer to call it a museum - it is one very small room with admittedly some very moving photos and artefacts from the site. If you have to choose - I would suggest you go to the 9/11 Memorial instead and make sure you call into St Paul's Chapel - it's become a memorial in it's own right to the firefighters.
Very sad. It was a very sad experience, but worth it. You really don't understand what people went through, and are still going through until you go here.
better to book ahead for remembrance site. very interesting and moving. queues did not take long. be respectful while queueing as there could be family members of people lost in the towers nearby.

Sad but true. I had been to the twin towers a long time ago. It's hard to believe they are gone. It's a nice museum, makes you think. After the visit I felt some sadness regarding what happened here...
moving. so moving would defo go back so much to see and many things to buy
Great Exhibition. Very moving and poignant. Incredibly classy compared to other parts of the city.
Very thought provoking. Visited the new memorial site. We must never forget!!!
Everyone should visit.. I like the messege of hope the new memorial projects.
A MUST SEE MUSUEM. This was a moving expierence for the 8 of us who visited. It was 1000% more then we expected. Sad but nice done
Interesting. A very interested museum, slightly small but for free its a good 20minute outing!
Ground Zero. Still very moving, go early and pre book to avoid queues

Moving..... You must go!. Wasnt too sure what to expect, but this has to be one of the most moving places i have ever been. The workshop is a very small room with a maximum of 20 people allowed in at one time.Its mainly images of sept 2011 and stories from people that were there, ie police, firefighters, people that survived etc, you go around the room for 2 hours with a headset and listen to each story individually.The workshop has a purpose to make sure people never forget what happened on sept 11th, and they have made a fantastic memorial here, it does touch you're heart and i did get upset but i think that is expected it was nice to be able to pay youre respects to the people that lost there lives and listen to the heroic stories of everyone that helped when it happened and still now!Not to be missed!

The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a not-to-be-missed moving experience. Be ready for a multimedia emotional experience. From the moment you enter the space, you are experiencing the events of 911 as a first hand witness. Every project is well-crafted: the video presentation, the found objects, the personal quotes, the Tile Project, the origami to name a few. You have the opportunity to be part of the exhibit yourself and to debrief either by sharing your recollections of the unfolding horrors of the day or how it has changed you. An added bonus was inclusion of tickets to the Ground Zero site in the museum's admission price when individual tickets to the site alone were sold out for the day!
ground zero. the museum wasn't open yet but the sculpture were - very evocative and symbolic
Very well done. Interactive displays were nice - things you could touch, or pick up a phone and hear people's stories.

Perfect atmosphere. I liked the atmosphere of the place, it is very well suited for remembering all the people who died there.I disliked the security, it is stupid - you have to show your ticket (tickets are free) at least ten to fifteen times to different security workers during the way to the 9/11 memorial area (after the real security check at the beginning) ....
Its a must!. This was the high light to our trip. We even got to meet Gary Susson. Interesting, and very moving, felt so privilaged to see the photo,s etc.

Just go. Because of a post here, we got tickets to go in and see one afternoon at 5 pm. And it was maybe the best thing we did for the whole week we stayed in NYC. The way it's made made a huge imression on us, and it's a respectfull and beautifull memirial that made us think of all the madness in this world. Beeing Norwegian after what happened in our hometown this summer, it was valuable to see that it's possible to make a place to remember and think. So hopefully we can get that in Norway in the future too

9/11 Memorial. There is still a lot of work to be done at the 9/11 site. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop offers a great place for visitors to gather. I look forward to returning once construction is completed
Very emotional. Very emotional. Brought home this great tragedy. Very personal stories. Felt for people who provided all their stories.
Emotional. A very moving experience. Nothing else needs saying.

Incredibly moving.. This is a very beautiful and poignant place to visit. My friend and I were both moved to tears when visiting this intimate and unforgettable museum. Gary Suson's photographs capture with great sensitivity both the pain and heroic love of the days and months following 9/11. A must see when in New York.
Very interesting overview of the events of the day. well worth the time, interesting, sobering but made me want to remember these tragic events

A great tribute and must-see. I am so glad we visited Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I felt in some small way we were able to pay our respects to those who lost their lives. The people who work there were so friendly and we were fortunate that Mr. Suson was there for our tour, the photographer himself. Besides the amazing photos, there are also artifacts from Ground Zero on display, including a clock from one of the towers stuck on the time when one of the towers collapsed. It was also nice to learn some of the proceeds go towards the victims' families and also to a first responder who got throat cancer. A sad, yet beautiful place to visit.

Relevant Memorial. We were visiting New York for first time celebrating 3 Pearl Wedding Anniversaries so we have seen a bit of life. My daughter visited this memorial 2 years ago and almost used my card to buy tickets, she was so insistent we went. She was not wrong and we all concluded this was a very worthwhile visit because Gary records the recovery, which was such a major event for New York Emergency Services, in a small but highly significant way. If you walk the streets for hours this is an easy way to "relax" and visit such a significant part of New York history. It tries not to dwell on the destruction. We visited Ground Zero later in our trip. Difficult to comprehend why anyone would want to be so destructive!
Awsome. Fantastic experience, very sad but interesting and informative. A must do if visiting NY. Small but excellent.
Heartbreaking but heartwarming. This was a really emotional place to visit but we thought it was fabulous and cannot recommend it enough.

A museum for the records. For our first time in NYC, the 9-11/ground zero memorial was on top of our "must see" list. Of course, we knew what happened in 9-11, but we were expecting a normal museum with little emotion involved, simlar to a reaction of an old war exhibit (for a past tragedy and just there to learn more). After about 30 minutes into the audio tour, listening to what each artifact and photo represented, we were both reduced to tears. The detail, beauty, sacrifice, and unbelievable stories of Mr. Suson - we became humbled and were in true awe. We would highly recommend this for anyone who is not clear on the history of 9-11 or would just appreciate a reminder of our nation's tragedy/strength. This museum may be only one comprised of one room, but it has the impact of the Metropolitan Museum in Central Park. Also, the staff of Ground Zero museum are excellent and helpful.

Don't mix this up with the 9/11 memorial.... This museum is fantastic, and well worth the effort. As it's small in space numbers are limited - but this doesn't diminish from the volume of information and photos you see. For the rest of my life I'll never forget seeing the piece of the fuselage of one of the planes, just standing next to it gave me a very strange feeling indeed. The museum is respectful and, most importantly, accessible to the public to get an insiders view. I think a job well done, and would recommend anyone to have a look. P.S. - this isn't the 9/11 memorial which is now open at the WTC footprint site.
a must see no excuses. A must just because we all need to show our support and respect the history of what happened
Forever remembering. Very interesting visit,it needs previous booking by web.
Don't forget to schedule your visit. You have to access the website and schedule your visit there, otherwise you can't come in.

Shrine to firefighters but no one else.. The pictures in this museum were exquisite. The display small and intimate. A place all families and friends of all fallen firefighters should see and experience. However, this place is not for survivors of the other 1500+ who also lost their life that horrific day. The story that is shown reveals a disturbing picture of how firefighters took over ground zero as a shrine and place for their fallen. The absence of stories of everyday people and everyday heroes of 9/11 was heart wrenching. Families of other victims were kept from ground zero while retired firefighters and those firefighters not designated to work the area were allowed free access to ground zero to pray for and seek the remains of their loved ones. The access of the photographer was kept secret from the media until the recovery was complete. Why? The pictures of honor guard ceremonies were said to have been held for all recovered victims but those were left unphotographed, undocumented. You can not help but to feel the pain as you look at photographs of the “Band of Dad”, a group of retired firefighters who had all lost a son on 9/11, searching for their loved one. However, as the curator explains how other families offering to assist were turned away because they were not of this group; you are left with a pit in your stomach as you wonder where they were sent to grieve and pray, robbed of the opportunity to assist in the search.
Interesting...but it shouldn't be just about raising money. Very interesting, but felt it was quite 'money grabbing' sorry to be harsh!
Great visit, images were amazing.. Great visit, images were amazing. Would recommend everyone who is NY visit.

The Reality of It All. We all watched the devastation on TV in disbelief and could not imagine what the people of NY were going through. This Museum brought reality of this tragedy to all of us with the great photography of Mr. Suson. I have such sorrow and admiration for all the family and friends of all who have lost their lives on 9/11 and especially to the brave children of those lost. God Bless them all!
Everyone should see this. Biggest museum in a small room! Very touching, glad I had the chance to see this.

Experience exactly how it was in a truly moving & respectful way. We really enjoyed the museum - it was such a nice environment to be in whilst learning more about Ground Zero. The museum is completely respectful about the people who lost their lives and their families and everything is displayed and discussed in a tasteful way. Being in control of your own tour means that you can go around the museum at your own pace and take as long as you want at each item in the museum.

My life is forever changed.. I had the opportunity to visit the Museum workshop this October. From the moment I arrived and was greeted by the ladies there I knew that I had entered a very special place.I did not know the others in my group and yet I feel that we shared something very special together.There was a true feeling of healing and understanding.I knew that I needed to and wanted to pay tribute somehow on this first visit to New York.I was not sure where to start and somehow I saw the information during a tour and immediately went back to my Hotel and called.I will treasure the stories and the respect in the way that the images/ artifacts and stories were told. Thank you so much for this.
Important place to visit. Anything to do with Ground Zero felt important to take a look at, this is no different.

An absolute must for any visit to new york. If you only have time for one thing in new york this is what I'd recommend. It was definitely the highlight of my trip. There is so much packed in to the tiny museum - I spent hours there. So many stories are brought to life through the photography and objects found at ground zero, probably the most moving 9/11 tribute there is.

Absolutely Amazing!. I bought the tickets for my boyfriend as our anniversary present. Because of 9/11 he became a firefighter and both of us were left speechless after our tour. For how small the room actually is there is so much information. It touches the heart whether you have a personal connection to 9/11 of not. The photos are amazing and the best part is the fact that Mr. Suson narrates the entire tour himself. Definitely would recommend this to everyone and would even do it again!
emotional. An amazing place to go and very emotional as they play a video of the day it happened.

A must see!. I booked a ticket to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop after my parents had visited the year earlier. They advised me it was a very small room, but I was still surprised when I walked in at just how much they had put into such a small space. I wasn't sure how I was going to spend much time there. After introduction speach we had from the lady that worked there, we were shown an interview with Gary Marlon Suson. You could tell that everyone that worked there was very passionate about their job, it wasn't just a pay cheque for them. We had our own head sets and we were given plenty of time to walk around the room and look at the hundreds of interesting things in the room. By typing the corresponding numbers into your headset, you were told a story by Gary about what the picture, object etc meant and why he took the picture or took the object. It was a very emotional place. The museum was set up in a very respectful manner, and wasn't about dwelling on the sadness of 9/11 but rather the recovery and progress made.I could have stayed longer but my friends were ready to go and there was only 2-3 other people left in the room.I was only 12 when 9/11 happened but have always felt very effected by the events of that day, and the museum was a very therapuetic experience for me.
So Sad. This place is so sad. It really hits home when people around you are openly crying just what a waste of human life this was. The tributes are amazing and the video very moving.
Ground Zero Museum. Exceollent workshop:Great visit to the workshop museum. My friends and I had a great time.Annalisa and Jen were outstanding tour guides.All proceeds go to 6 different charities.

Small but Powerful!!!. Although the Ground Zero museum is small in size it is huge in the effect it has on you!! It is very emotional to see these pictures and items collected at ground zero. You get a tiny glimps of HELL that the recovery team and all those involved must have went thru.
Good attraction. Historical visit.. Well worth a visit. Emotional...

VERY POIGNANT. This museum is tucked away and not very obvious to visitors. It consists of one room full of previously unpublished photographs taken by the official FDNY photographer. the only photographer allowed on site. and momento's of that fateful day. You cannot help but be moved by what you see and the accounts of bravery and grief you will here. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful.There is no real time limit for how long you can stay in there however I would say 90mins would allow you to take it all in. You will leave the museum in absolute awe of what happened that fateful day
Very moving experience. For the smallest museum I've ever been in, it packed the biggest emotion. Seeing the artifacts, pictures and hearing the stories is something we will never forget.

So Worth Going to. We were so impressed and moved by the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I was on a girls long weekend to NYC and we weren't able to get tickets to the ground zero memorial so we were super bummed out. I found the Ground Zero Museum Workshop online and so we booked that instead. We ended up LOVING the Museum Workshop and preferred going to it. The photos and stories were amazing!! Thank you so much.

Powerful, moving, a worthwhile experience. My husband and I went to the museum after reading the reviews on here. It was a little difficult to find and there was not a banner that showcased the location. luckily, we found it. The two women who were "tour guides" were friendly, somber, and polite. We watched a short video and were given a lot of time to view all the different pictures and very moving artifacts. The reason, they explain, for the small space is for a level of intimacy and comfort it brings to fellow surviviors or family members of lost loved ones. It's a cozy and warm place.I met the photographer and was honored to have talked to him. Free chocolate is available in the bathroom and letters from children to the founder are on the wall.A must see in NY!

Small Museum that packs a punch. When we first got into the Museum, we were quite surprised at how small it was. But, this small museum packed quite a punch. Hearing the stories behind each of the pictures and then being able to touch some of the artifacts from the World Trade Centre, well, it was quite amazing. Thanks for sharing these pictures with us.

Don't Pass This One By. Go ahead and stand in line for this. Great pictures on the walls and a poingent film playing. They also have a nice little gift shop on the premisis. The only thing that could make it better would be if it was larger, but I know that space in NYC is at a premium.
Very informative. Interesting little workshop/ museum which tells the story of the 9/11 in words and pictures. Very touching and worth a quick visit.
Need to see.. It was very benefical to help children understnad 911. It was heart stopping.

Broaden your horizons. We visited on September 11th, and I could not think of better way to spend our evening. We were fortunate to meet Mr. Suson and listen to him speak about the days events and the enormous recovery efforts that followed. If you'd like to understand and appreciate the complexities of what happened after 9/11, and meet the unsung heroes throughout it all, take the time out of your day...........

Not that attractive as claimed. I'm really of a different opinion on this one, I was motivated to visit after seeing good reviews, but honestly, there's really nothing much. A very small workshop, a short video is played and the rest is self guided audio tour. The owner is very much commendable and should be given credit as the proceeds go to charity but for me, I do not really think it's worth travelling quite far here for this.

Great place to see historical items. I booked this tour before traveling to NYC - thinking it was at the WTC site. it's not - its in the Chelsea area on 14th street - not close to the WTC site. However, it was a good place to go and see many artifacts, pictures and items from the actual site. Be forewarned - you may have a hard time finding the actual place - it does not have a sign outside the door - you just have to find the address. You go to a non descript door and it's up on the 2nd floor. Don't be late to your time - they start a video that you won't want to miss the beginning of. The concept of how they do the "tour" is unique - you wear headsets and walk around the room (not a huge room either) and you see pictures, artifacts and other items with numbers on them. You enter the number of the item you want to learn more about and you hear someone telling you the story of that item. It's very imformative and a good place to spend about an hour - but I wish I had known it wasn't anywhere near the WTC site. We were late getting there since we were unfamiliar with where things are in the city. If you have extra time, by all means go. Book online to make it easier on you.

Genuine and sincere. We arrived and were initially suprised by the size of the one room museum. This place is a fine example that quality is better than quantity. The photos were exceptional and I was so impressed with Gary Marlon Suson's audio guide; his comments about the photos, the situation, and the artifacts were clear, genuine and sincere. This audio-combination with Gary doing the narration captured my attention for the struggles of these heroic recovery workers, specially the pains of those who were looking for lost siblings or sons. A touching and necessary reminder of that horrible event.

Breathtaking. It really is a very small museum, but it is a very unique experience and the stories of the photos are spectacular. If you are not a New Yorker, you do not truly feel the impact of 9-11 until you experience the museum. Highly recommended for a "must do" in NYC!

More than just a museum. I saw this museum back in 2007 and made it a must see this time around with my sister. We were extremely fortunate that Gary Suson was there to talk briefly before our self guided tour. What amazed me the most this time was how many people in New York don't know about this place, and yet it is a moving, touching, sombre memorial to the events of 9/11.

Nice to see but NOT a must see. I visited the museum at the urging of my friend who wanted to see it. I really wasn't interested in paying the $25 but she wanted to go so she paid for my ticket. HONESTLY: That is the only reason I went. It is an awesome collection of artifacts and photo's from the aftermath of the attack. There are significant stories to each photo and display. When we first entered the room ( the museum/workshop is a small room, yes only ONE room) I was thinking, "I am so glad I didn't waste my money". They give you headphones you watch a video and are turned loose to walk around the room and listen to recorded stories ( I believe there are over 50 stories) that match up to the displays and photo's. They say the money goes to help victims and I hope that is true because that would be worth it.

Moving and emotional experience ` one I'll never forget. My 13 year old daughter and I visited the Museum on 9/11/11, and we were both very moved and emotional by what we saw there. Gary Suson was thee ONLY photographer allowed to capture the effects of 9/11 on film. He had done a remarkable job with the images he had captured of fire and rescue personnel, priests, Ground Zero, lay people, etc. One has to be at the right place at the right time in order to capture these images, and Gary succeeded. The somber faces of the firefighters who were exasperated having had tried to collect what remains they could of those who perished just made me cry. The artifacts collected from Ground Zero is remarkable! There was a doll that someone had kept in their desk that was completely intact. Bibles were intact. Wineglasses from a bar at the Twin Towers was intact with the charred black tint on it. There were huge pieces of glass from the Towers that used to be the windows. A chuck of one of the planes that hit the Towers is here. The list goes on and on. The Museum doesn't only house photos, it houses personal items that had belonged to those who perished on that tragic day. Having visited the Museum gave me a sense of who was there in the Twin Towers, i.e. mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles, wives, husbands, daughters, sons, etc. The Museum is a place for healing. There are candles lit throughout the museum and a box of chocolates for guests to help themselves with because chocolate is known to curb depression and sadness. The Museum also has tissues in various spots because if you're human, you'll need to use them. Although the Museum is small as SP said, it is just the right size.I highly recommend making the Ground Zero Museum Workshop one of your stops when you visit NYC! You won'[t regret it. It'll be a memory engrained forever!

Very emotional visit, well worth it.. This is the most amazing place, with actual pieces of history from the site to see, like an aeroplane window! Allow plenty of time to see this as there is lots to take in. Very emotional to hear from relatives and rescuers of the victims.
A Must See in NY. A small museum with a powerful reminder and remembrance of 9/11

Touching, Tasteful, Poignant, Inspirational. A very emotional experience from touching artifacts to viewing photographs and memorabilia from the 9-11 site. Contained in one tiny room, one is able to choose specific areas of interest and listen to commentary from the photographer via headphones. Despite the sad reminders, one feels such hope to see the actions of the First Responders and the reaction from the rest of the world. Follow this up with a trip to the 9-11 Tribute Center - a poignant day but one that still fills us with love and hope.

Worth it!. This is a must see! For those of us who do not live in New York, and watched it on television, it is not the same as seeing it first person at this museum. It brings home to you exactly what occurred and what the people in the area and the Firemen and Policemen and women went through. I highly recommend this museum to all who intend to visit Ground Zero and the Reflecting Pools BEFORE you go there. It will make the Reflecting Pools and that area seem so much more sacred and awe-inspiring.

A journey into the magnitude of the "recovery" operation. I had read so many great reviews of this facility that it was a must-see on our NYC itinerary. We pre-booked our tickets via the website weeks before leaving Australia, which I would recommend you do as "tours" sell out fast. Initially I was surprised at the size - or lack of it - of the museum, however, we comfortably spent around 2 hours there which is an indication of the number and quality of photographs & artifacts on display. We were fortunate to meet Gary Marlon Suson on our visit & he was perfectly charming. Gary was the only official photographer permitted at Ground Zero during the recovery. Behind each & every object there was an interesting, moving & emotional story - all accessed via a handheld digital device & headphones. After the initial movie and guide presentation, you are free to roam & listen to the wonderful stories at your own pace. As Australians, we had very little appreciation for the magnitude of the recovery operation - it was wonderfully educational. Our teenage children spent the entire time fully engaged (rare at any time - even more especially when touring around with the parents!). I would highly recommend seeing this museum before heading down to the WTC Memorial as it will make your visit all the more meaningful. I can't recommend this venue highly enough.

Don't miss this little piece of history. A must see!!. This is one of the best museums in the city. You actually got to touch the artifacts from 9/11. The tour guides were very sympathetic to the situation and knew their stuff. The photographs were awesome. The price was right. Don't miss this "one of a kind" museum. I just wish there was a donation box so I could have given more money.
This was GREAT, a must see.. Gary Suson is one talented photographer! Please take the time to go to the GZMW. This display of photos is done so tastefully. Thank you Mr. Suson.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a MUST SEE. I cannot express in enough words this one place must be attended while in NY, especially before going to the site at "Ground Zero" is this Ground Zero Museum Workshop Tour to really understand the devastation and the reaction of those involved in anyway in 9/11. The opportunity to actually hear (through head phones linked to each picture) the photographer, Gary Suson narrate in his own words where and why he took the pictures during the clean up at Ground Zero left me with such a deeper understanding of what took place. He spoke with passion and concern of what his mission was to express through his pictures. The many items displayed from the actual clean up he had collected just made me feel the destruction and the emptiness of seeing them, never to be claimed by their owners. I will never forget the whole presentation, because of the content and the sensitivity of the personnel in explaining what this "tour" was all about. My advice is see this first, then go to the actual site, you will not regret it. Grace Fortuna

Very disappointing experience. The all "Museum" is one small apartment room containing a few artifacts from the Ground Zero site (which, in my opinion, should not be there exposed for an overpriced ticket). The “tour” is basically a self-tour: you watch a fuzzy video (that is basically a repeat of an interview from a TV show) and listen to prerecorded details of photographs.

let the artifacts tell a story you've never heard.. you will learn about the recovery effort from a totally unique perspective. you will learn the names and stories of rescuers as well as the deceased in addition to learning interesting facts about the twin towers when they were being built. you will also learn the importance of faith and endurance for so many people, and evidently rescue dogs, that searched relentlessly for loved ones and all of those who participated in the rescue and recovery effort. every new yorker should see this museum in addition to every visitor. i brought a group of 15 young adult english learners from japan brazil korea paraguay puerto rico taiwan china and the dominican republic. it was very special for me to bring them to this museum and share the story of new york on september 1th and in the months to follow. you will find a very human element at this museum and a very gracious proprietor and staff. the room is very small but there is so much to see. the guided tour and individual headsets were particularly well suited to the english language needs of our students as they went at their own pace and could repeat stories as much as they needed to. this museum is in a great part of the city and you should definitelyh fit it in your schedule . though the time slots are limited the very apreciative staff can and will add a later time slot. when you're through walk one block to walk through high line park and shop in chelsea market. theres restaurants and bars galore in the neighborhood nd union square is a hort walk away. this museum in this neighborhood is truly the best the city has to offer.

Overshadowed by a visit to the ground zero memorial park. The power and healing that this workshop offers is now overshadowed by that offered by a visit to the ground zero memorial gardens (and forthcoming museum). The staff at the workshop were very professional and helpful, I am sure those directly affected by 9/11 have felt the benefit of these workshops.

Awesome Experience. Everyone needs to visit this museum. My mother and I were so happy we chose to fit this into our vacation. The pictures that you see and the stories that go along with them are breath taking and nothing you could ever imagine. A MUST GO SEE !!!

A little museum with enough information and history to fill the largest museum in the city.. We visited the museum with three families on September 29, 2011. My husband and the other two dads are FDNY firefighters. We had the honor and pleasure of meeting Gary Marlon Suson on that day. It was the cherry on top of the cake! His work is tastefully displayed, each photo including an audio explaination. There are many stories to be told and many of them have been captured here. From rescue dogs, firefighters, police officers to sweet little angels you really get feeling of what went on there. The museum has many actual items recovered from the site as well. This is not to be missed when visiting NYC. Thanks again to Mr. Suson and the wonderful staff for a great experience.

very moving. One room museum of artifacts and photographs from Ground Zero. A very good video and guide presentation at the start of the tour sets the stage. The photographer who put this together seemed to make the overall tone more about him than his subjects is my only negative. Worth seeing!

Packs a Punch. First impression was amazement at the relatively small room the museum is in. This quickly turned to admiration as we worked our way around the photographs and items on display. The informative video and sound tracks were excellent. This is a must do on your list of things to do while in New York. A bonus is the nearby location of the high line walking "track" which takes you along the old railway tracks suspended above street level. All up a great morning. Congratulations to the photographer and the staff who run the museum who were efficient and professional.

Incredibly emotional, best thing i did in NY. OH MY GOD !!I never knew i was capable of emotion such as that, as a 22 year old male from England although i was equally shocked and saddened by the tragedy as anyone i felt that the emotional connection would be far stronger to the American audience, but we were all equally humbled, fascinated and devestated as we listened to the fantasticly presented stories, and viewed the fantastic photographs and artifacts.Being actually able to hold such historic pieces such as shards of glass and the crosses made from the iron was a truly unreal experience and different from anything else i have ever experienced. Our tour guide was a lady called Phoenix, she was fantastic ! All credit to her for having a positive attitude, you could tell she really was passionate about her job which often makes all the difference, all the staff were great, and its not an easy job due to the obvious emotional significance they see every 2 hours.Marlon Susan a personal thank you because as i am travelling i am visiting New York on my own, and although i had seen nearly every site before this i often felt left out and unable to emotionally connect because i had nobody to share it with, simply not the case here i felt a family atmosphere and the warmth of the staff allowed me to feel secure enough to let myself get lost in the stories, i genuinely havnt cried like that since my dog passed !Thank you for an incredible exhibition, and please please people do not be put off by the size of the museum, it is like that for a reason and it works perfectly 100 out of 10.

A MUST DO WHEN IN NEW YORK!. My husband and I visited the Ground Zero Museum recently. The whole experience was very moving but something we both felt we wanted to do. Although the Museum is small, there is so much to see. We were shown a 20 minute film beforehand and then we were able to go around the room on our own. Each artefact had a number beside it which you keyed into a hand-held remote control, you then heard a commentary on the headphones provided . The artefacts on display were very tastefully displayed and the photographs themselves re-told the tragic events of 9/11. Being the only person granted permission to take photographs post 9/11, one can barely imagine what Gary Marlon Suson witnessed at Ground Zero. His photographs, which were seen around the World, will leave lasting impressions on us all and he should be very proud of this amazing museum! This museum is well-worth a visit on a travellers visit to New York.

Wow, Powerfull, Moving, A must see. A very moving and humbling experience. The photos are incredible. There are artifacts that you can touch...actual steel and glass from the Twin Towers. The audio that goes with each photo or artifact makes them come alive. The "Micro Museum" not only tells of the events on 9/11 but also what happened in the following weeks and months. Don't miss it.
Extremly emotional. We went as part of a tour of which the guide was extremly knowledgeable

Unforgettable images and a moving experience. I visited NY with friends the weekend after the 10th anniversary for 9/11. Our group had visited the memorial the day before our scheduled visit to this museum. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is not in the same place as the memorial, but it's well worth a small trip on the subway.The museum is quite small (about the size of a loft), but don't let the size fool you; our group stayed for about 2 hours. It was such an unforgettable experience. The images and artifacts that are on display can't be found in any other museum in New York or the world. Visitors are brought into the museum in small groups and are given listening devices. The images and artifacts are numbered so that the listening device can provide you with a story of each item.I found that I preferred this small room with a small group. It made it feel more personal and safe to become emotional. Our group was lucky the day we visited; the photographer, Gary Suson was there and spoke with our group. A portion of the proceeds are donated to 9/11 charities. This museum is definitely something that shouldn't be missed! My only regret is not purchasing his photo book while I was there so I could get it autographed. =(

AMAZING, TOTALLY HUMBLING, NOT TO BE MISSED.. Please do not be put off if your first impression is negative based on the size of this workshop. This is the most rewarding and informative museum I have ever had the pleasure of visiting, it left me totally humbled and emotionally drained. This may be housed in a small room but by no means is the experience small, I cannot attempt to comment on the content as I would not do it justice, you have to see it for yourself. We also got to meet the official photographer for ground zero who is behind this project and purchased the official Ground Zero book, please take time to visit.

Meaningful, respectful and moving. I was a little worried about this museum and afraid that I would feel a little voyeuristic but this museum is really respectful of the tragic events of September 11th, its victims and friends and family. The photos are poignant and have stories that you can listen to with the headsets along with artefacts from the world trade centre. We watched two short videos to start and then were given time to look around and listen to the stories independently and in our own time. It is a small room and we were told it is used for support groups also and that some of the money made from the photos is given to wives and children of 9/11 victims. I would really recommend a visit here as it is so powerful and informative but incredibly sensitive and respectful.

A moving and humbling experience. A must do while in NY.. I thought I was prepared for the emotion and sadness I would feel at being in NY for 911 and our subsequent visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I wasn't even close. The museum is amazing. From the moment my husband and I walked into the room we were over come with emotion. While watching the introduction (on personal head sets) I suddenly realised I had tears running down my face and looking around the room I wasn't the only one affected by this narrative, tastefully done, by Gary Suson. While only a small room, there is more atmosphere in that one room than in the whole of NY. You get to self pace through every picture or every story you want to know more about. It is an ideal way to spend a a few hours (realistically 1.5 hours of wandering once you have watched the introduction) lost in your own thoughts, remembering the fallen from 911. It was a humbling experience and I am glad we made the time to go. The guides were knowledgeable and friendly. I would highly recommend taking the time to visit. I am so glad we did.

Highly Recommend!. This should be at the top of your list of things to do while in NYC. This was my second time visiting. I took friends and they loved it as well. Not your typical museum. Very unique and well done.

Very moving museum, great way to remember 9/11. Museum seemed very small in the beginning but could spend way over the 2 hours there. They had a great introduction video and images and artifacts from that horrific day. They have small group sizes so it's not cramped and everyone can get around to see everything. They even let you touch and hold these monumental artifacts. The tour guides were very informative and helpful. We even got to meet the man that made this museum possible! He was very welcoming and willing to answer any questions. I would definitely recommend this museum to anyone that will be in the New York area.

Poignant, interesting - must do. I know why this is currently the top thing to do in NY. Run by the official photographer of the search team it allows you to see first hand the emotions felt by the rescuers, access artefacts recovered from the scene, and feel the enormity of the whole event. It may be small [all in one room], but you spend a good 2 hours there. Even get free chocolate!!!

Once I'n a life time experience. There are so many great exhibits at this museum. The information is very informative and interesting. I would recommend this museum to all my friends. It changes your life.

Enlightening and Informative, must see!. This is a small museum, but full of very personal exhibits and great photograhs and after visiting you cannot believe how big the content is, with personal accounts relived through the headsets of each item and photo in the workshop.A very emotional tour and one which everyone can relate to.Great work Gary and Staff!

Make time to visit this little museum.. Loved this little museum. Intro video very informative and emotional. Grab a tissue on your way in because it hits you the minute you step into this room. I'm so glad we made plans to see this. Even my 12 yr old was interested and moved by the artifacts and photos. Personal audio equipment makes it easy to go at your own pace to obtain more info on objects/photos you are interested in. Only drawback: it's upstairs (i have bad knees) and you are required to leave your purse/tote bags in cubbies at the door.

Respectful memorial to the memory of 9/11. As someone who was part of the response 10 years ago in Washington DC, and a native New Yorker, I came to the 10th Anniversary with a lot of powerful feelings and emotions still to be processed. I wanted to express thanks to the owners of the museum for being conscientious and respectful to the memories of the event by keeping the museum as a place of healing for all, not just a collection of artifacts of a newsworthy story. The area was small and personal, and the staff very warm and caring. Allowing us to touch some of the artifacts was therapeutic and personal, maintaining a connectedness to a critical day,.. the dedication of Gary Suson and staff to the rescue efforts and continued care of the survivors is clear in the exhibit,.. thank you so much you guys,..

Moving experience. My husband and I visited on the ten year anniversary of 9/11. It is a very small and intimate museum with a lot to be seen and heard. It was a very emotional and eye-opening experience.

The true meaning of a hero. I am a 9/11 survivor and decided for the first time to attend this museum and I was not disappointed. It really is 'the biggest, smallest museum in Manhattan (basically an apartment), but is well thought out and inviting. I really did not need to re-live the experience, but did help me cope and deal with the events of that day through the eyes of Mr. Suson, who spent many months at Ground Zero.Each picture, each item tells a story and you can't help but feel so proud of the FDNY and NYPD and their rescue efforts, including the four legged rescuers.This is NOT a tourist attraction, but an in depth look at the happenings of not only 9/11, but many days following and the agonizing task of 'digging for a needle in a haystack' and the mental anguish these men and women went through. You won't believe the strength and courage of these individuals and what they will live with for the rest of their lives.It's heartbreaking yet heartwarming and can not be missed.

This tour was great well worth the time and money and Gary Suson was amazing. The size of the museum was increased exponentialy by the friendliness professionalism and the fact that Gary Suson was there to expand even further on the amazing photos and item's on show highly recommended .

You Will Never Forget. Tour started promptly, with a very friendly staff. A few of the artifacts were able to be touched and photographs were allowed to be photographed. A very humble Gary Suson was present to answer questions and was friendly, sharing stories and words only a man who was there could provide. He is doing the public a great service by sharing his talent for photography and his ability to capture precious moments in time with us. The events of 9/11 changed the nation, the Museum will change you in another way. Small space but well worth the time and price of admission. Remember to Love... & Never Forget NYC.

Ground Zero made real. the most amazing place to visit in the smallest museum imaginable. the images you see and the objects from Ground Zero are shocking and really bring home a sense of what happened there and the aftermath for the people who helped in the recovery. truly worth a visit.

A beautifully moving experience. No amount of words or descriptions can encapsulate what one will experience once inside this museum. Thought provoking, emotive and enlightening, this museum offers a deeply respectful insight into the depths of the tragedy caused by the events of September 11th. I could not possibly recommend strongly enough for anybody to go whilst in New York, it is the best money you could spend whilst there. 5* all round.

Moving account. When my friend said she had booked us on the workshop, I confess that I had a feeling of dread. My concerns were that it was going to be a way of someone cashing in on the 9/11 disaster and I couldn't have been more wrong. All exhibits were informative and tastefully presented. It was incredibly emotional and me and my friend shed a few tears during our two hours.As you are self guided through headphones, you feel as though Gary Suson is taking you around the museum himself. we were lucky enough to meet Gary and he was an absolute delight. I'm not sure I can say that I enjoyed it as it's not 'fun' but it was tasteful and not at all tacky. Very emotional - worth a visit

Most amazing intense experience in New York!. Mr Suson the owner and photographer is great. Welcomed us and hung around for us to talk to. Staff are great, friendly and knowledgable. So much information is such a small space. One of the highlights of my trip to new York. Thank you!

very emotional and informing. This is a must when you are in New York City! it's a small museum, but it has so much info.
You learn more about 9/11 here than on TV.
The view of the fotographer is unique!
It was moving me to tears, it gets under your skin.

Very intimate surroundings. We visited the museum after our Statue of Liberty visit. A very intimate tour. A few visitors even cried during the opening presentation.
