We got to handle some of the artifacts and picture cameras are allowed. Oh and we were lucky enough to meet Gary Suson and got a personalized autograph.
Definitely worth the visit!!!

Most meaningful part of my vacation.... This museum is one room but has so much to offer. I got more from this Museum than I have ever got from TV, reading, etc. I believe it is appropriate for any age since it is self-guided. You don't have to hear anything that you don't want to. Each tour is for 2 hours, which is the perfect amount of time. The stories and descriptions will take you back to that day...it was very emotional. This museum should be experienced by everyone. I was fortunate that Gary, the photographer and owner of the Museum, was there that day. It was really nice to hear him speak and tell his story.

Not Sure Why This Has Such High Reviews Except People are Clamouring for Anything 9/11. It's not bad, it's just...not what you think. This is not a 9/11 Museum. It's a Gary Marlon Suson 9/11 exhibit. This is a room filled with a photographer's work around 9/11. A wonderful photographer, don't get me wrong, and the official one assigned by the FDNY. There's really nothing you'll see in that lone room that you won't find on the site, except the stories behind the photos, some of which indeed are very compelling. They start the two hours with Suson himself--and he was great to hear (although he's usually NOT there; he just happened to be there working on a project). Then they follow it with a grainy CNN VHS video of an interview with him. Then they turn up the lights and a museum worker starts telling us why this museum is so worthwhile. 'We have artifacts no one else has. You'll be able to touch this and this..." It was marketing at its worst. I already bought the tickets, I don't need to hear you market the museum. Just let me look around.You are given a handset and headphones and each photo or artifact (or group of artifacts) has a number so you can key the number into your handset and hear the recording by Suson of the related information and background. It's fine it's just...maybe we went wanting more? Expecting too much? It left me wishing I could go watch a Brian Williams documentary on 9/11 to really explore the event.The proceeds of the exhibit go to help injured and fallen firefighters and I was glad to spend my money on such a cause. But if you're going for a cathartic experience you may be left wanting; if you're going to see excellent 9/11 photography, then you should leave very satisfied. My only advice for those running the exhibit is...sell it on the site, not in the room. Leave the marketing outside.

Truly the smallest museum with the biggest impact, bring tissues.... We visited last week, one week before 9/11. What your initial impression on the lack of size will soon disappear and you will wonder where the 2 hours go. A vivid account in words and pictures of the world trade site clean up as looked at through the eye's of the fire fighters and captured beautifully by Mr Suson.I don't want to go into too much detail as not to spoil your visit, but will say that is worth every penny and it will get emotional.

Very moving experience. The museum workshop provides an extremely moving experience, detailing the recovery at ground zero. Through each of the photos, you're provided with the story behind each picture. The photos are truly touching and the workshop helped me get that bit closer to what I had only witnessed on TV at 11 years old. Would definitely recommend visiting the workshop, and booking in advance.

Moving, respectful and something all NY visitors should see.. This museum is quite small, but the space that is there is full of emotion and beautifully presented stories from the ground zero recovery operation. The photography of Gary Suson is superb, and in our view is a suitable tribute to the New York Fire Department members who conducted the recovery. An audio tour narrated by Gary describes the circumstances of each photograph. You also have the opportunity to handle some artifacts from ground zero. This museum helped us understand the magnitude of the loss suffered by New York, and the Fire Department in particular. We won't forget this experience any time soon.

Very touching experience. I took my husband here for his birthday and we were both very touched by the experience. The tour leaders were very nice and explained the museum, what we would be experiencing, and even allowed us to hold some artifacts that came from the towers. After we watched the initial introduction video there was not a dry eye in the place. We were then able to walk around the museum, at our own pace, choosing which personal stories to hear by punching in the number next to the photograph or artifact on the wall and listening in on our headset. The stories were very moving and truly humanized and brought the events of 9/11 closer to home. I would highly recommend going to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop whether you are visitng NY or even if you live here and want to honor the memory of those who lost their lives that day.

You will regret it if you come to New York City and not visit this Museum. My husband, 12 year old daughter and I were in New York for a 6 day trip to see the US Open. We each listed 2 places to see or things to do as "tourists" while we were in town, as we are from California. Our hotel suggested this and we did not know what to expect. We stayed as long as we could and did not want to leave. Please don't let this opportunity go by if you are in town. It is truly amazing and the photographer, Gary Marlon Suson, happened to be there that day and was wonderful and gracious. You will learn so much and understand even more. Thank you Gary for giving your time to record this event and prepare the museum experience for all of us to continue to remember . . .
History. Excellent! A must see! Very sad however very interesting. Alot to take in. Don't miss this! Visit the church while you are there. Most informative.
Amazing museum & emotional experience. Guides were excellent and very friendly! Definately glad we went to this museum.
Powerful Place. The photos and their descriptions are very well done. No one leaves with dry eyes!

An excellent, touching way to remember 9/11.. It was incredible to speak to someone that experienced the tragedy of 9/11 first hand. His pictures really captured every aspect of the situation, and combined with the audio guide, it was an extremely powerful reminder of what happened. The part which really influenced me the most was seeing part of, one of, the planes. - An absolutely incerdible place!

A truly moving experience. Although the museum is only very small it is very informative and very moving at the same time. It truly was a humbling experience seeing the pictures of 9/11 and hearing people's experiences of that day. We also got to meet Gary Suson who was the official photographer for FDNY and who's pictures are in the museum, he was a very humble man too. You can't go to NYC without visiting this museum to appreciate the true impact of 9/11...a real must.

Best museum. Period.. Words cannot express how deeply I was moved. I have to admit that I cried when I saw those amazing rare pictures.We shall always remember this part of the history.Gary Suson is a wonderful photographer and a wonder person!I would strongly recommend this place to everyone.

It was an amazing experience for me and my son.... It was a very moving experience. We didn't know what to expect going there. My son is only 8 years old but he's been asking questions regarding 9/11 once he saw the news about Bin Laden. A few weeks after the news, we went to visit my family in NY and they took us to this museum. It was informative and well thought off. We were lucky that Gary Suson was there and signed my son's baseball cap (which was an odd request but my son thought that it was cool). Mr. Suson was kind enough to sign it. I highly recommend a visit to this museum when you're in NY.

Lost in a moment of time. Quite an amazing experience. Just a small room but filled with nostalgia - artefacts, photographs, personal stories and heartaches, recordings. The museum concentrates on the aftermath of the tragedy and highlights heroism at the same time as depicting the extent of loss and personal grief.You should follow the workshop with visits to the actual Ground Zero site a few miles away and the church opposite that withstood the collapse. If you want to learn more about the attacks and memorials throughout the world togrether with current plans for the memorial site at Ground Zero there is an excellent exhibition opposite the church.If you visit all 4 of the above you will have a better understanding of the tragedy - one that you will never forget.
An experience without equal. I was moved to tears. But it was important that we visit this heart of New York. It felt like a pilgrimage. It has to be done if you value freedom.
Simply stunninh. An excellent experience, which totally blew my mind because of the wealth of information crammed into a tiny space, highly recommended!
Fascinating!. It brings us closer to the event, especially to those who were not there, to feel the pain and the shock, to mourn together and to face the future together.

AMAZING biggest LITTLE museum!! Highly recommend it. Gary Suson is an amazing photographer. His pictures are truly emotional and its true what they pictures say a 1000 words. The museum is such a different experience you get to touch many artifacts from the twin towers. Definitely touches your heart. MUST see!!!

MUST SEE IN NYC. Really gives you an inside look at what the people of NYC went through after all the media and cameras left! Great cause with all the charities they are able to help out, benefiting the families and workers of 9/11.

Hidden Gem. Tucked away in the NY 'meat packing' district, not too far away from Ground Zero, is this beautiful and intimate room exhibiting extraordinary photographs and artefacts. Museum founder Gary Suson was the official photographer at Ground Zero, where he was able to capture and document the recovery phase following the unimaginable events of 9/11.We purchased our tickets in advance of travel and were met outside the museum by a guide who took us upstairs to view a very tasteful, extremely moving exhibition and audio tour. We were among a small group of around 20 people and we were lucky enough to meet Mr Suson himself while visiting. My husband is in the UK Fire and Rescue Service and we both found our experience very emotional and memorable. This is a non-profit museum which helps and supports the survivors and bereaved families of 9/11. Excellent and well worth a visit.

Moving and intimate tour of a fine collection of Ground Zero recovery period photos and artifacts.. This was an excellent way to expand my 10-year-old son's knowledge of the aftermath of 9/11. The space is very small (though crammed full of meaningful content), and the presentation is deeply respectful. They have created a safe environment to react to photographs and items that demand thoughtfulness and reflection. There are no images of human remains, planes flying into the buildings or anything graphic that would unnecessarily upset kids. I highly recommend it to anyone seeking to broaden their understanding of the recovery period and the event itself.

Intimate museum atmosphere with an emotional impact. My son was only 4 months old when the towers fell. Going to this museum was a wonderful way to have him understand the enormity of that day and the months that followed. We had the privledge of meeting Gary who's talented photography will stay with me forever. Must see to augment the trip to Ground Zero!!

Moving experience. My husband & I were very moved during our visit to this memorial venue. To read peoples personal stories & visit the church displaying FDNY uniform & other memorabelia was just the most amazing experience. It is also great to see the re-building that is taking place. Really worth the visit.

Gary Suson captured the emotions of 9/11 and touched all eight members of my family.. This museum workshop requires advanced ticket purchase and limits the number of people attending at a given time, thus making the experience much more intimate. The 9/11 experience is documented with artifacts and pictures (bring a camera as photos are allowed). But the most important part is the story that goes with each piece told by Gary Suson. On the day we visited, he was there to interact with our family and other visitors. This is a must visit museum workshop.

An experience I will never forget.. We visited the museum this past weekend and had the privilege to meet and speak with Mr. Souson. This museum (or "one-room wonder") is an initmate look into the stories of 9/11. I was so touched to watch my 13 year old daughter, who was 3 at the time of the attacks, listen to the stories about the people who lost their lives. It was a history lesson she will never forget,.
Intense. I wasn't sure how this would be but I have to say it is well worth the visit. Yes it is emotional, but it gives a perspective that can't be gained elsewhere. Tastefully done.

Absolutely Moving.... This is the place to come and reflect what happened to our world on 9/11. A must see. The ground zero site where the construction work is going on has been become a place for greedy sellers to sell you their crap and play on your sympathises.This museum which is on 14th Street near the Chelsea Market, created by Gary Suson has a quiet dignity and very respectul to all the victims and their families. My second visit and when I come back to NYC I will come and visit again.

Very Interesting Even For Teenagers. Even our teenage boys enjoyed this. There were a broad variety of photos from after the 9/11 site - all were taken after the tragedy so there were no graphic/bloody photos. All the photos had a meaningful and moving story associated with it, plus many interesting artifacts. You can go at your own pace, too. You need at least one hour - we took 2 hours (but looked at every photo!)

Priceless. Excellent exhibit, allows for children of all ages to experience something that carries such strong memories and allows them to comprehend at their level. I will definitely be visiting again when we are there.

Extraordinary, thought provoking/emotional, Truly Impactful. Suson takes your breathe away with his extraordinary photos and stories. Many of us around the world watched on tv as 911 happened and couldn't even fathom what those involved went through. Suson brings us as close as possible with his photos. Truly moving, Suson captures not only images but emotions as well. There are no right words to describe what he brings to the memory of 911! Every image, every words shared, items found on the site shared with us, and so much more. He himself is a hero for what he did for the families of 911 and for New York in those 8 months of being in the middle of it all. Quite humble, Suson is truly an amazing man. The museum was intimate and overall extraordinarily moving. It is a "must see" when in NY!

Wonderful and sad experience all rolled into one.. My Mother, my two teenage daughters and I were touched and humbled by this extraordinary museum. Words cannot describe how we felt listening to the stories about the photographs and items in the museum. It is all a true testament to the human spirit and the greatness of our country. What the four of us found strange (for lack of a better word), was that none of us felt "right" about photographing any of the items or photos. It is such a solemn and sacred representation and one we felt we wanted to keep in our minds and hearts rather than on our own cameras. It isn't something you can really "show" anyone else but something everyone should experience on their own. We will highly recommend this museum workshop to friends and family.

Every American should visit this Memorial. While on a recent visit to NYC, I'd heard about the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. It is a short distance away from the World Trade Center site, which is completely under construction. I was not sure what to expect, but wanting my children to understand the worst terrorist attack upon this great country, I signed us up. The experience lasted about 2 hours. You are escorted to a large room covered in artifacts from 9/11. The gentleman who created this was the sole photographer allowed entrance to what was left of the trade center, and many of these images have not been seen before. The introductory video was very touching, you could hear a pin drop in the room. Even my teenage children were glued to the screen. It brought many to tears as we revisited that fateful day. Upon completion of the video, and additional commentary by the host (who was excellent), you were allowed to view the artifacts on your own, and were provided a headset with which to understand the story behind the images. For me, seeing an actual piece of the plane that hit the tower was something I'll never forget. There are many stories behind those artifacts, and this is a "must see" for anyone visiting NYC. Thank you, Mr. Souson, for telling this story....especially as we approach the ten year mark.

Absolute must see, Extremely moving experience. This is was the best museum experience I have ever had. This museum gave me a personal connection to 911. Seeing the photographs and hearing the heart wrenching stories of our heroes was a very moving experience for me. Actually being able to hold some of the artifacts from 911 was a very humbling experience. It was also great that we were able to take pictures. The icing on the cake was being able to meet the amazing photographer Gary Marlon Suson . I highly recommend this must see museum! It gave me a different perspective on life, strength and the meaning of being a true hero. Andrea Scott, NYC

emotional but necessary!. We visited the site where they are building the new skyscaper but the museum is a must.We have all seen the pictures on TV but to see what is in the museum is very emotional.It is so hard to imagine what it must have been like on that dreadful day but this certainly is a must to experience when in the city.Not sure how log this museum will be here as I know the New Yorkers want to move on!

An exceptionally moving experience. I thought I understood 9/11 until I attended the Ground Zero Museum and saw for myself the magnitude of the horror of the crime. The victim's stories were incredibly moving and put faces and histories to the statistics. Expect to leave with a different perspective and a great deal more understanding of America, its politics and its people.

Definitely Worth Seeing. A very interesting museum experience. Really didn't know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. It was very tastefully done. I liked the fact that you could take pictures and that most of it was a self-paced experience. I bought the book - smart of them to have one available to preview. Would definitely recommend this to others visiting NYC.

Absolute Must Do!. This was by far the most wonderful, moving day and we were all so glad we went. A fantastic way to go behind the scenes and hear stories that belong to the pictures that had become so famous and synonomous with 911. Very sad, very moving, very interesting and yet a place of hope, love, and the best of humankind. Definately learnt a great deal and feel we have a greater understanding of Ground Zero and the reality that became the rescue, recovery, and re-build. Thank you so very much for an amazing experience and our teenages have even rated this as a top trip highlight.

Highly Recommended. This is a very worthwhile place to spend a couple of hours. The photo and artifact depiction of that day's events and the heart-breaking stories that ensued is amazing. It is an emotional experience as you see the impact on ordinary people who were called to the extraordinary in the months that followed the attack. The presentation is appropriate for all ages and is self-paced with an audio tour for most of it. Guests touch pieces of glass and beams from the World Trade Center but most of all are touched by the stories and photographs. HIGHLY recommended. You will not be disappointed, but be sure to book ahead.

One must never forget that healing and moving beyond the pain are those survivors who need us to listen.. A powerful way to spend time learning how to heal and reach out to others can be found in New York's Meat Packing District. The Ground Zero Museum is a powerful little heart beat that resounds high above the excitement and beauty of the Meat Packing's trendy cutting edge fashion section of New York. It is a place to learn, a place to reflect and a place that touches one's heart with the stories of so many fallen angels. It definitely captures the Best of Americans who so many times selfishly give of themselves in the spirit of helping others. It is a perfect education experience and the elevator makes it accessible to anyone open to learning. Definitely a five star experience, but don't tqake my word for it, take the time and see for yourself. My favorite addition is knowing my visit helped to support the children of the Fallen Firefighters who selfishly sacrificed thier time, life and health along with other cancer charities. It is a win-win vacation hot spot.
Amazing images and incredible experience for our entire family. Reserve your tickets in advance. Extremely kid friendly and very tasteful museum on 9/11.

Rather Small Room with Photos and Artefacts from 9/11. This was OK but there was a lot of repitiion. They gave out a newspaper article about the place then the guide talked about the same thing. They have an audio gutde but several of the presentations on the guide were also presented first by the girl who was the guide. We had seen many of these things before. But if you go the Ground Zero, there is really nothing to see but a large construction site.

Very professional, poignant, thought provoking..a must see but be prepared. Very well done presentation of the recovery effort with hearfelt emotional stories of the impact this tragic event had on particularly the emergency services but also from some of the victims. Avoids being either a graphic horror show or a sentimental journey.A must see but not for voyeurs, you will think and you will cry.

Moving experience ;(. From the moment we stepped into the museum you couldnt help by be moved by the photos, video footage, building parts and witness testimony, it was truly a surreal and spiritual experience.One could not help but be reduced to tears especially seeing the faces of all the innocent lives that were lost.This for me was the most moving experience I had while visiting NYC.I couldnt put it any better than Jay-Z..... Long live the World Trade Centre :(

Not a museum. As opposed to being the emotional and moving experience I expected, visiting the Ground Zero Museum Workshop left me feeling confused and uncomfortable. I don't think it can quite call itself a museum, as unlike a museum which aims to inform and educate about an historic event/period the GZMW really just informed me about Mr. Suson and his experience. The staff there did speak of workshops for families of victims of 9/11, so perhaps that's where it gets it's workshop title from, but for an average visit I don't think is is relevant.You enter a small room where you are seated whilst everybody gets handed out headsets and audio tour equipment. The first thing that left me feeling a little uncomfortable was reading a quote printed around the ceiling. Within the quote was written 'Love is the grace and charity shown to us by God' (or something very similar). I don't have any problem whatsoever with religious belief, and if it is comfort to people then so be it, but to have such flagrant religious leanings in a 'museum' stops the experience being inclusive. The 'museum' begins with an introduction by a very professional and earnest guide who speaks about the history of the museum and Gary Suson. There is a little bit of information about 9/11, so I expect more to come when the guide plays the DVD intro. I am mistaken, as the first feature is an interview with Gary Suson and the second a slideshow of images with some audio clips played over the top. Gary Suson really was the main focus, and his Christian belief was the lens through which we were all being forced to look. We heard a story about his struggle to continue photographing when it became emotionally taxing, but how he stumbled upon a bible in the rubble, opened at Genesis 11 with the title of the passage 'The Tower of Babylon' (or something of similar effect, forgive me if I am wrong) and saw this as a sign to keep going. Interpreting events as signs can be of great personal meaning, but if you are creating a museum that is supposed to welcome and educate everybody it is inappropriate; it only serves to distance and disengage people who are not of your belief.The audio accompaniments to the photos were also not what I expected. There was some factual information to tell you about the story behind the photos, but more often than not this was laced with Mr. Suson's emotional reaction. A photo should tell a thousand words, should it not? I don't need Mr. Suson telling me how this sight choked him, or how this brought him to tears. It was distracting from the real focus.It is perfectly fair enough to have an area selling memorabilia items from the exhibition, but I found the large number of autographed postcard size photos distasteful. There are definitely good points about this exhibition: well organised once you are inside, good number of people admitted for the size of the room, a very professional guide and of course some of the photographs are ones you probably won't have encountered before and so are interesting to see. The guide did seem to focus on the 'healing' purpose of the space, but this wasn't particularly relevant to me and there may be other reviews that offer more on this aspect of the GZMW.I would say head to the preview of the new memorial museum that is to open in September 2012 over at Ground Zero and make a $25 (or whatever amount you can afford) donation there instead. I implore Mr. Suson to listen to the criticism people have to offer on trip advisor, as there are some good photographs that are being overshadowed by the 'museum' experience.
Excellent experience. Worth doing, really touching, helps you understand what actually happenedReccomend it A+
Lovely. This is a must when you are in New York to pay your respects but i found it quite upsetting. But please have a visit.

An Amazing Experience. Words cannot express the reality that has been created in the largest, smallest museum. Although I was not impacted personally, seeing these pictures and listening to the stories brought me to tears. I was also lucky to be there on a day the photographer was there. He is truly a special individual, with a gift. This museum is something everyone should experince while they are in NYC.

A Moving Experience!. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop was one of the best museums we have been to! We have visited the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam and Dachau outside of Munich and like these museums you left feeling like you knew the faces in the photographs and felt their pain. Unlike other museums you are encouraged to touch glass from the windows of the tower and other items found at the site. Comfortable couches and stools invite you sit and reflect on the images before you as you listen to the taped voice of the photographer describe why the photo was taken and what he was thinking when he snapped that particular moment in time---the story. Our 16 year-old told a friend "it was a very intense, emotional experience that really opened my eyes to what 9/11 was like." I appreciated the boxes of tissues that were close at hand. We thank Gary Suson for sharing with the world his gifts and impressions of an emotional journey so that we "never forget". Do NOT leave NY without visiting the Ground Zero Museum Workshop!

Most amazing display that allows the public to grieve and renews your faith in humanity!. My mom and I attended the Ground Zero Museum Workshop on Sunday July 24. We were overwhelmed by the pictures and stories. It is a very small museum, but the most impactful one I have ever been to. Although I was not directly impacted by 9/11 I still felt a huge loss. It was the biggest event to occur in my life and changed the world as I knew it, as it did to many. I found that this museum allowed me to grieve and come to a place of peace. The heroism and solidarity that came out of this tragic event is amazing and renews my sense in humanity.The photographer, Gary Marlon Suson attended the museum approximately half way through our tour and stayed to answer questions and take pictures. He is a very humble man and spent time to make our experience special. Although my mom and I were not finished looking at all of the displays before the next tour began, he allowed us to stay until we were finished and took time to speak with us afterwards.Thank you Gary for sharing these emotional pictures and experiences with us. I cannot imagine how difficult this was, and continues to be, for you and am grateful you decided to share it with the world!! I highly recommend this museum to anyone who was affected, in any way, by the events of 9/11!

Nice, small collection of artifacts. If you need to get your fill of September 11 imagery and artifacts, this is probably the best place to go. At $25, it is pricey. The museum is probably about 800-900 square feet...tiny. The group size limits are about where they should be. You watch a video at the start and then take a self-guided tour around the facility punching numbers into a digital player to hear a bit about a particular artifact or picture. 2 hours is the time allocation they give you, but you could do it in much less time.
Emotional. A very sobering display. It brings the Reality of 911 to your Being. The Tragedy and the Heroes

A Bit Self-Indulgent, but an Interesting Experience. The photographer never lets you forget that he was the only one allowed at the site. It's in the opening lecture, in the television interview, and in tons of the tales told through your listening device. I found it to be a bit repugnant, myself. The good news is that it doesn't fully detract from the mission of this little room of memorabilia. It's an interesting couple of hours, and gives a different perspective on the tragedy of that day and the following months.

visit this museum before going to Ground Zero...highlight of our trip. This museum tells the story of human compassion in the face of tragedy without the gory images. It was very moving to hear stories of those who worked tirelessly around the clock to recover whatever they could. We left with a deep respect for our courageous men and women who work in public service. In addition, this was a wonderful learning experience for our children who only remember the image of the planes going into the buildings. They left with a greater appreciation for our Country and for those who protect it. Visited July 2011

Worth a visit!. My husband and I visited in June after reading the reviews on trip advisor. We found the video very interesting and were lucky to have Gary Suson there on the day so he gave us some extra insight into the photographs and the other articles placed around the museum.As others have mentioned it is all within one room but because there is only a limited number of people there it is no problem to move around looking at everything. I didn't think that we would stay the 2 hours when we first arrived but it was surprising how quickly time passed. We did find it all very touching and sad and it has been done very well. It is good that all the money goes to help people affected by 9/11, Gary said they were raising money at the time we were there for one of the firefighters who had cancer, most probably caused by his days spent at the site, that in itself is a good reason to go and visit!

Very touching experience.... Very touching experience as we watched the short video and listened to the stories behind each photo and article. As a bonus we met Mr. Gary Marlon Suson at the end of the workshop and took a photograph with him!I've been to the WTC Tribute Center and this is quite different from it. As this was a photo exhibit of Ground Zero (exclusive) whereas The WTC Tribute Center displayed photos and articles from the people who's loved ones were sarcrificed in this devastating atrocity. I think both are worth seeing if time permits.

Not impressive or emotional exhibit. Maybe, I had high expectations due to other reviews. It was 2 adults and 1 teenager. We did learn a few things that we didn't know about the recovery period. However, it was not very good artwork and didn't give us a feeling of the emotion felt those days after. We thought it was a weak exhibit.

AWESOME TOUR AND DISPLAY. I enjoyed the tour very much, well worth the trip....... Myself, my daughter and her son (15) and another (15) year old , we live in California. I come to New York every year and I would go back to Ground Zero Museum Workshop again.

Ground Zero. Never forget what happened there 9/11. 911 should never be forgotten, and the Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a wonderful tribute to all those who sacrificed their time (and for many of the worker, their lives) in the massive search and rescue mission. The photographs and the moving audio tributes and memories that accompany the photographs take you there. Take the time to discover this museum, which is located in the meatpacking district of New York (a 20 minute subway ride from the actual Ground Zero).

The whole family had this activity right up there as a highlight of our trip. This was a really worthwhile activity - our kids were 8, 6 and 5 on September 11, 2001 and whilst they know what happened they didn't really realise how big a day it really was.Everyone thought this was a really worthwhile activity and listed it as a highlight of all the things we did on our trip to the states which included LA, NYC, San Francisco and Honolulu.

Amazing, Informative, Touching. The images were so amazing, photos I never thought I would see. The information that was provided answered a lot of questions that I had. The stories about the rescue workers, FDNY, NYPD, Port Authority, random good samaritans....all touching. The day we went, Mr. Suson happened to be there, which made our visit extremely special. If you get the chance to visit New York, please take the time to stop by and take the "tour". A very worthwhile experience. I will never forget it.

A Must see in New York City! Don't miss it!. You need to put this on your list to do in NYC. Fantastic displays and images, along with personal stories and heartfelt moments. We did so much in New York and this is definitely on the top of the list as the best thing, hands down. Check the website and order your tickets as their tours are selling out daily! Plan ahead and don't miss it!

Very touching and insightful.. This museum touched me. The photos bring the ground zero clean up into real life you get a real sense of what all the family members, firemen, policemen, and other workers went through. Make sure to leave yourself time for a drink afterward. You will be shaken.

Wow...what a great museum to visit!. Didn't have this little museum on my radar...if it were not for a Groupon. We would have missed so much if we had skipped this one. It was so well done...very respectful...very personal. The photographer was there during our tour and he spoke of how this museum got started. There was plenty of time to look at the amazing pictures, hear the stories behind them and sit and reflect before our time was up. Well worth the trip!

a tearful experience. A huge surprise! It will grab at your heart. Very tasteful. A studio covered with photographs never seen before with audio to tell the story of over a 100 scenes and artifacts. Everyone needs to experience this. It was something very important to me and it was important to share with my kids.

Powerful emotional effect-- must see. Very powerful stories and images, strong emotional effect, not to be missed... this is probably the most important thing you are gonna want to do when in NYC... no cliche. I'm dead serious here.

This is an Inspiring, not-to-be-missed site, especially for residents of tri-state area.. The GZMW is a loft-size space with interactive exhibits for all age groups.Coincidentally, the photographer who came up with the concept for the museum happened to be there the day we took the tour, being interviewed by a Shanghai newspaper. His presence added an even more personal touch to our visit.Even with the limitation of only 28 people at a time, it was a little crowded as we moved about.Photographs, but not videos, are permittedTour takes a maximum of two hours to make room for the next group to come in.
A totally unique experience. Very moving and done in a sensitive, educational manner. Well worth seeing.
Must see!. Intimate, up-close look at the recovery effort through pictures, stories and artifacts. Do not miss this!

Thank you for assuring that we will "always remember".. Our visit to the museum was the highlight of our recent NYC stay. Words to describe what we experienced there are: sensitivity, tastefulness, human, humane, a story that needed to be told, beautiful narration, unforgettable images, spine-tingling artifacts. We will always remember the stories of families, the airplane remnant, the Bible page, the clock, the photographs of humanity at its best in the worst of times, the heartwarming and heartbreaking quotes inscribed on the walls. Thank you, Gary and staff. We will always remember.

Don't let first impressions fool you.... When we first walked in, I didn't think much of this "museum". But after spending about two hours there, I was completely pulled in by the artifacts and photos and information that we saw while we were there. Even my two kids, 11 and 7, loved it. We ended up buying the coffee table book, while quite expensive, was so worth it and 7 months later I still enjoy sharing it with other people. It contains photos in there that were never released to the public and truly gives you a behind the scenes look at the aftermath of 9/11.Bottom line is I HIGHLY recommend visiting this while you're in New York. It's impossible to put into words how amazing and moving this museum was.

A MUST SEE IN NYC!!!!!. My husband and I visited the museum on July 10. Mr. Suson was there during our time to visit and answer questions. This was a nice surprise! There are really no words to describe this museum fully. It's very well-done and is definitely a must see when visiting NYC. We actually recommended it to another couple the next day.

Really showed me the personal side of 9/11! Emotional! Awesome!. My friend and I really enjoyed the tour!!! To see what happened through Gary Suson's eyes the way the emergency teams did that day was touching! All the artifacts and the photos truly took me back to 911 and what it must have been like to be there. Thanks again Ground Zero Museum Workshop Staff and Gary! It was great to meet you!

Everyone who visits New York should go to this museum. My husband and I visited the ground Zero Museum Workshop on the 10th September last year. I personally feel that every person that visits New York City should visit this museum - it is only afterwards that you can truly appreciate what it must have been like for the people who worked tirelessly for months to clear the former World Trade Centre site. It is a very emotional exhibit and understandably upsetting but is tastefuly presented and portrays the aftermath with a message of hope rather than despair.
you shouldn't miss it if you want to understand the event of 911. They provide artistic, personal and factual photos and artifacts for you to emphasize the event of 911. They are really cool.

This is a must see when in NYC!!!!. There are not enough words to describe how incredible this museum is. Be aware that this is a very intimate and emotional experience. We were fortunate to meet the official photographer, Gary Suson, who usually isn't there as a tour guide. His capturing of the events of 911 are incredible and very personal. The photos and artifacts were amazing and it was great to be able to hold and take pictures of some of them. This is a definite must see when in NYC. Thanks Gary!

Best Attraction in New York City. We went to the museum based on ratings on Trip Advisor. We are a family of 5 including two teenagers-so you know they are hard to please. When we arrived we were surprised at how small the space was. We watched a movie presentation first and then had an audio tour that was self guided. I was so moved and emotional during the movie. My kids were young during the 9/11 attacks but have seen news reports but this was amazing. We were able to get a first hand account of the aftermath in a tasteful way. We stayed for the whole 2 hours and my kids were never bored. They thought this was great!!! It was definitely worth the money and portions of your admission goes toward the families of 9/11 firefighters families.
Impressive, emotional, and educational. Very well done. Never before seen photos. Brings you right back to 9/11/01.

Very moving. We visited just before going on the walking tour of Ground Zero and felt that it was the perfect way to set up what was to follow. The museum was set up by Marlon Susan, who was the only photographer allowed on the site following the collapse of both towers. You will see some highly thought provoking pictures and I would defy anyone not to be moved by both what they see and hear, especially the jacket worn by the chaplain Michael Judge.Although a little tricky to find, this hidden gem is a must to see.

AWESOME!! MY CHILDREN VIEWED HEROISM. We took our 8, 11, & 13 year old to see the museum, who have seen images and talked about 911 in school but really didn't understand the magnitude until they went to the museum and ground zero. The museum was small but who cares you weren't overcrowded either. Gary's photos, displayes and stories showed what happend that day and the rescue and recovery the days and weeks to come. My children have not stopped talking about it. Highly recommend for all ages

Fantastic intimate tour, everyone should experience.. My Husband, two young children, and myself visited the museum. Although it was a small space, it was filled with the emotional experience of 9/11. May God Bless New York Fire Department & New York Police Department.

Moving, but felt overly self-promoting.... We visited the museum after reading about it on Trip Advisor, therefore we weren't surprised at how small it was, but we were very surprised that it was located in the pricey/trendy meat-packing district, just down the street from Mr. Chow and across and next door to several couture clothing boutiques. In hindsight, maybe that should have been a sign. Hear me out...This hands-on memorial does pack a lot of punch into a tiny little space. And at $25 a ticket, as well it should. There were a lot of things to look at, listen to, and touch, but nothing that would warrant staying over the two-hour time limit allotted with your ticket purchase. The MOMA, on the other hand, charges $20/person and you wouldn't be able to see everything in one day if you tried. I can't help but wonder if the ticket price would be a little more reasonable if the museum wasn't in such a high-rent locale, but that's just me. It was definitely never made clear exactly how much of the profit from ticket sales goes to 9/11 victims.When you enter the museum (and you cannot enter prior to your ticket time), you are accompanied up some narrow stairs to a room the size of a small studio apartment. It did feel a bit crowded, even though there were only 12 people total in our group, plus 2 Workshop employees. After a brief video is played on a big-screen tv, with a voice-over by Mr. Suson, you are provided with hand-held listening devices and allowed to peruse the museum at your leisure. The photographs in the museum are all stunning, and Mr. Suson is obviously a very talented photographer; many of the photographs you will have seen before, but some of them have not been as widely published, and a good majority of them are accompanied by a recording you can listen to on your hand-held device, giving information about the who/what/when/where involving the item you're viewing. It was hard not to be moved by seeing and touching things that had been salvaged from the wreckage of 9/11.Aside from the high ticket price and the tiny space in which the museum is housed, we left the Workshop not with disappointment about its contents, but rather the feeling that the museum was set up more for the self-promotion of Mr. Suson's work than anything else. For all I know, he may donate 100% of the proceeds to the victim families (unlikely, since the amount seems to be something never specified on the site or by the employees when asked), and that might make me feel a little differently. At the beginning of the tour, the guide speaks for about five minutes about how wonderful Mr. Suson is, how renowned his work is, how exceptional he is in that he was the only one allowed in to photograph the aftermath...which is fine, but then a video is shown with scenes from the aftermath, in Mr. Suson's own voice, which says pretty much the same thing about his great abilities, experience, and privilege; to top it off, all of the recordings on the interactive exhibits are also in Mr. Suson's voice. For our entire party, it lent a pretentious feel to the entire experience. We would have preferred to be moved by reflections of the experience of victims, their families, of those who lived and worked in NYC at the time, as opposed to the majority of the focus being on Mr. Suson's own personal experience (there were, admittedly, a few personal stories - told by Mr. Suson - about the experiences of others...but not many). I also have to wonder about the TripAdvisor rating, because the employees very heavily pushed visitors to leave feedback on the site, going as far as to hand out strips of paper asking for reviews and mentioning the review process several times during our visit.We didn't come away feeling like our time was wasted, but we definitely walked out of the Workshop wondering if there would have been a better way to pay tribute to the victims of 9/11 and to learn about the aftermath. We will be coming back to NYC once the 9/11 Memorial is open, and urge others to also visit and make donations to charities willing to document the relief provided by those who give.

Touching but Tiny. This museum was a little less than expected, but very touching. It is a TINY space and can be a little crowded and hard to view the items. The museum is part self-guided and part shared experience. We were unable to see everything because of the amount of people in our group. Also, VERY difficult to find. You may have to call in order to locate it and you must wait outside until your exact reservation time. You MUST schedule ahead of time and must have a reservation. You also must trust putting your purse, bags, or any belongings in a shelf outside the museum door.

A must see when in New York. We visited this museum after reading reviews of it on Trip Advisor and can say it was an informative , humbling and emotional visit.As previously mentioned we were surprised by how small it was, however it was full of amazing photos and heart wrenching artifacts.Every photograph had its own story and the audio tour told you that story , narrated by Gary Suson who made an appearance during our visit.We felt the Museum Workshop was the highlight of our trip to New York and gave us the opportunity to view images we will never forget of an atrocity that should never be forgotten

Small Museum, but definately a must see. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop was a highlight of the trip. It was much smaller than I expected, however, there is a ton of information and artifacts to see in there. The staff was great and I liked that you can look at each exhibit at your own pace. It was amazing to see some of the items that were collected after the 9/11 attacks and is also a great tribute to the rescue workers.
Never forget !. Never forget is the motto for the occasion and after visiting the GZMW you will be transported back to 2001.It is not an easy place to find but is well worth the effort.

wonderful experience for my daughter and me. My daughter and I went to this museum based on high ratings and positive reviews on Trip Advisor, and the experience STILL exceeded our expectations. I highly recommend this for families with teenage children, as it's a meaningful, tasteful way for them to learn about and really understand the impact of 9/11 on real people. It brought back powerful memories for me, and the pictures, artifacts, and stories made this museum a moving experience for my teenage daughter too (she was only 4 when 9/11 happened). Can't say enough good things... you should go!

Emotional and inspiring exhibit. Highly recommended!. We went to this exhibit because we came across a groupon for it, and we were so glad we did! I really enjoyed that while you are looking at the photographs you can listen to the stories behind them, and through his narrating, you get an idea of the emotions that he and other volunteers must've experienced during the recovery. The staff was very informative, pleasant, and respectful. I would definitely recommend visiting this beautiful tribute!

Best 2 hours spent in NYC. WOW! Absolutely amazing! Well worth the time and money! Very emotional yet you leave with a feeling of hope and inspiration. Highly recommend this museum! As a Texan, there were moments I almost felt I were there.

Very emotional and moving, so glad I went!. This is a small but very powerful museum. The photographer who was the only one
allowed during the rescue and recovery attempts at the 9/11 site shows his photos
and perspective. Very emotional, but inspirational with the telling of regular people
doing such wonderful things!

Emotionally Inspiring Exhibit!. I visited the GZMW on Father's Day with my wife and daughter. We were fortunate to meet Mr. Suson personally. This is definitely a "must-see" if you are visiting NYC. It was a truly emotional experience to see the amazing photographs and hear the stories behind them. We spent the entire visit in near silence, overwhelmed at what we were seeing. I never imagined that I would be holding an actual piece of the WTC towers in my hands, and the feelings were intense. As we exited the museum, my daughter and I realized that neither of us had taken a single photo......we were so involved in the experience that we didn't even think of snapping pictures. Thanks to Gary and his staff for a wonderful Father's Day gift!

Memorable and Moving Exhibition.. This museum is small but you can spend a few hours in there.It gives you a real connection to the twin towers and supporting this museum means we will never forget what happened on Sept 11 2001.

NYCs finest museum - this is a must-see. I didn´t know what to expect from the tiny museum located in the Meatpacking District, but our visit became the most unforgettable museums-visits I´ve ever had. Gary Marlon Suson is a man with a huge heart and it shows in his photography. The heartbreak, grief, but also hope is found here amongst memorabilia from 9/11. I cried when I read a few quotes and looked at the photos. It´s overwhelming, but so beautiful. I would recommend this to everyone - young and old who visits the city.

A 'must see' experience. A tasteful & moving tribute to all those who lost their lives in the disaster. The presence of the official photographer Gary Marlon Suson, who could relate some of his experiences, made the exhibition much more personal & intimate.A worthwhile visit & one never to be forgotten.

Awesome and emotional. Ground Zero Museum. New York. Tasteful and emotional museum dedicated to the rescue workers and victims of 9/11. Take a camera and some tissues. The small museum only allows about 20 people in at a time, you must book. Artifacts and photos of the rescue are on display. We were fortunate to meet the photographer. Very moving experience altogether. A must see.

We all found it touching and meaningful.. We found the audio tour very helpful, so that each of us, spanning three generations, could select which of the photos and artifacts we wanted to know more about. The photographer, Gary Suson, happened to be there, and his remarks added to the feeling of direct connection to the horrific event and its aftermath.

Best museum I've ever visited!. This museum is one of the most informational and emotional places I've ever visited. There is a strong feeling of respect for all those affected by this tragedy. The photos, the artifacts, and the audio combine to make this one of the most awesome and respected museums visited. It is a must see. It may be small but it packs a wallop!!

Amazing Experience. I would highly recommend anyone visiting New York to take time to go to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. It was very inspiring and really brought reality to this American tragedy. It was difficult at times, however totally worth the trip.

Very Moving Workshop. Not a traditional museum but a series of displays with narration of artifacts and pictures made during the recovery of human remains and the clean-up of the New York 9-11-01 site. The stories and the incredible display of humanity during the clean-up of this tragedy of the event were told in a very poignant way.

A moving experience. As an Australian, I never really felt the full emotional impact of the whole 9/11 tragedy, until I visited this museum. The small room is a like a shrine of remembrance - compelling in its simplicity yet undeniably dedicated in its goal to make the world understand what Americans experienced and what went on at Ground Zero in the aftermath of this terrible act. No-one can visit this museum and not be emotionally affected. The photography and commentary provided by Gary Suson give the visitor a very real insight into the hope and despair he encountered during the time he spent side by side with the recovery and rescue teams at the site. His photography conveys these emotions without sensationalism and with the greatest respect to all those involved. It was wonderful to meet him in person.

"Little" known Museum A Must See in NY. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is the best 2 hours you can spend in NY. This little one room museum of photographs and images gives the personal account of the recovery of Ground Zero and is tastefully done. Done in small groups, it is an intimate emotional experience with the use of headphones and there are plenty of seats for those who are handicapped. Book ahead as tours sell out quickly.
Moving tribute.. Please do not miss this attraction. It is totally unique and excellently presented. Truly outstanding.

A hands on museum that gives closure to the tragedy on 9/11. A little museum with a great impact, we had the opportunity to meet the photographer in person. There are some very moving pieces, would highly recommend, not suited for some children.

Very Moving. Spent two hours studing and reviewing all the photos and aritfacts. Mr. Suson, the photographer who spent six months at Ground Zero taking photos put on this wonderful display, was there that day to give us a brief description of what we were about to see.Since we knew someone to died on 9/11, it was especially moving and done with taste. We recommend this Museum Workshop.

A teaching experience. Our visit on "Father's Day" 2011, ten years after the initial attack, was a very moving experience. The significance of the day was not lost in the realization of how many lives were impacted on that one day and forever more! Gary Marlon Suson tells this story through the lens of his camera and his heartfelt words. If you did not experience this day, as our grandchildren did not, on 9/11/01 this museum is a teaching tool. It is a gentle way to show our future generations what their forefathers endured and triumphed over. It is our responsibility to pass this information on in a respectful and factual manner. This museum does that and opens the door for conversation with your young ones about this event in our history that changed everything. LET US NEVER FORGET!

amazing and moving experience.. Our entire family ages 12 and up thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop in NYC. The museum is easy to get to and has parking options close by. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The museum although very small is surprisingly packed with ground zero photographs and memorabilia. Seeing these things through the eyes of Photographer Gary Marlon Suson makes the entire 9/11 experience touch your heart in a way you cannot imagine until you experience it.

A very Moving, Fitting Tribute, to all affected by 9/11. Simple yet powerful. Gary Suson's assembly of video, pictures and artifacts from Ground Zero are a must see for all. It is a quaint little museum that evokes a sense of community with and pride for those who lost their lives and loved ones on that horrific day.

Seeing is Believing. If you get the opportunity to view this exhibit do so. While it is not on the Ground Zero site (about 15 minutes away) it is something to behold. It is well arranged but not morbid. I think that it really is a tribute to all that perished on that horrible day.Small groups make it more intimate.

Unique Museum - Unique Experience. So glad I visited this place. It was not what I expected. It's true, it is one small room but the photos, artefacts and emotion that are crammed into that space make it an intense experience. I knew I was in for a rough ride when I noticed the boxes of tissues strategically placed on the ends of the sofas. It's well organised, informative and very moving. Please go, it is so worthwhile. On leaving I felt drained and humbled but uplifted.

Don't let the size of the museum fool you..... This museum was one of the most interesting and informative museums I've ever been to. Sure it might be tiny but it sure was an experience. We went on June 13th, 2011. Well worth every penny.

Interesting But Not Something You Absolutely Have To Experience. I made it a point to visit the GZMW since it rated so highly on Trip Advisor. My conclusion after visiting the Museum is that while it is a worthwhile attraction, if I had to do it all over again I probably would have spent the time elsewhere or at another attraction. The photos are beautiful and the artifacts that are on display are very interesting but the Museum is basically a small room on the second floor of a loft in the Meatpacking Dist. in a building that is undergoing renovation (we had to walk around construction workers and mounds of drywall). It gets a bit cramped in the room trying to take the audio tour and take pictures. Again, I would say that visiting it is a worthwhile venture but just understand what you will encounter.

A great and humbling experience. I was spending 4 nights with my Wife in New York in April and this visit was pre booked. I would definitly pre book such is the demand for places.We were not sure what to expect but were totally blown away by the experience. Although not a big display everything is captured in a single room which makes it easy to manouver around and keep check on what you have already seen. There is a very informative explanation given on each artifact over your headset. Also the crowds for each tour are just about right so it is easy to move throughout the visit.An added bonus was Mr Suson being present on this day. We got to listen to him at the start of the tour as the BBC were there doing some filming on the museum.Would recommend this to anyone who wanted to escape the hustle and bustle of New York City for a couple of hours. You will leave a better person for your experience.

Humbling, chilling, amazing...more must see than Broadway. Visiting Gary Suson's small, amzing museum was the highlight of our week long honeymoon to NYC. The quaint, one room museum can show, teach, inspire and heal in a way that no other museum, documentary or book can ever do. We had the fotune of meeting Mr. Suson at the museum that day. His humbleness and sincerity in describing his role in creating this museum reflects itself in the presentation of the horrors of 9/11 and the spirit of the heroes who worked in "the pit". Much of what you see and hear in the museum is heart-wrenching, and you will surely be brought to tears the same as we were. Most importantly, upon leaving our 2 hour experience, I want to convey what Mr. Suson and the many firefighters who grew to respect him and gave him the honor of standing by their sides as they searched for their brothers and civilian victims,that is the love that it took to complete their mission. And surely, you shall leave this AMAZING museum warmed with the love that Mr. Suson's work, care and humility has created. Thank you Gary Suson, NYPD, FDNY, PAPD and all of the iron workers, laborers, etc for allowing these images and stories to be shared with us who did not and could not do what you did to help us heal. PLAN YOUR TRIP TO NYC CENTERED AROUND EXPERIENCING THIS MUSEUM!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Amazingly Breathtaking..... I visited the museum on Friday, June 10th. I had read good things about it but was not prepared at all for how amazing it actually was. The museum is only one room but it is the most powerful room I have ever been in. It is full of stories and pictures from ground zero that make you think and make you feel. I am not usually a crier, especially about thing I don't have a personal connection to but I was choked up more than once standing in that room full of pictures and artifacts. Amazingly awesome. One of my favorite parts of our entire trip to New York.

A little neat area we may have never of found without this visit. My daughter, 2 granddaughters (13 & 16) and I decided to go here since it was rated #3 on Trip Adviser. I thought that it would be at Ground Zero and was surprised it was in another part of town. They only allow 20? people and it's a small quant room but the impact of these exhibits blew me away. The day we were there Mr. Suson, the Ground Zero photographer was there to autograph photos and get a photo of him and my granddaughters. The work he has done is just incredible as he truly captured what happened in the days following 9-11 with his photos. Also there were so many items taken from the actual sight and history of stories behind all his photos. A very emotional museum and a must see!Then as we walked towards the Hudson River we found the new Highline Trail that was just awesome...a wonderful trail for a nice walk. I wanted to check this out also and just stumbled into it. This was great. As you walk past the museum, make a left then a right on the next street. WONDERFUL photo ops of some beautiful mural work on the wall in black and white. We just loved this little area. Wish it wasn't so hot the day we were there with 100 degree weather. We would have enjoyed this much more. Also lots of nice high end clothing stores for window shopping.Thank you Mr. Suson for your dedication which captured the moments of our nationals worst tragedy so “We will NEVER forget!”

Incredible and Intimate. We (3 girls on a girl's weekend from Kansas) originally thought that it was going to be in the actual area of Ground Zero but we were surprised it was in the Meatpacking district in a plain looking building. Once we got inside (and it truly is, the biggest LITTLE museum) the museum was the most touching, thoughtful, inspiring museum I've ever experienced. And we were actually lucky enough to actually meet Mr. Suson and able to shake his hand and get our picture taken with him! That right there out-trumps the celebrities I wanted to find in NYC! He is a true American hero. At first I was leery about going to a 9/11 museum because I am still shaken everytime I see the planes crashing into the World Trade Center, however, the very first thing our tourguide says is they will NOT show anything relating to the planes crashing or any of the horrendous actions that we all saw through the media on 9/11 and still to this day. And for that, I am very thankful for. I highly recommend this workshop as a MUST DO when traveling to NYC. I've even recommended this to a friend of mine who is in NYC right now looking for things to do. Two thumbs up - way up.

Unbelievable. I didn't expect to enjoy the Ground Zero Museum Workshop as much as I did. I became quite emotionally talking to Gary afterwards. It was just by chance he was there. The images were stunning. I didn't realise there would be so many artifacts. They really took the experience to another level The museum's set up was intimate and focused on the recovery efforts in the months after 9/11. Definitely a highlight of my trip to New York.

June 5, 2011. I visited this museum on June 5th and was very pleasantly surprised. Even though it is small it is very intimate and informative. The photographer was there the day we went and he was very welcoming and answered all of out questions. I love the fact his work did not dwell on the planes hitting but of the recovery after the tragic event. We were able to have a look into the lives of everyone that gave their time and efforts to help everyone involved. This museum helps with the healing and helps all of us that were not there know what it was like during this time. I feel he captivated the emotion and all the support involved in this long and emotional process. I would recommend this to everyone that is going to NY. Even though the museum is in the Meatpacking district I feel it is still the best one to go to. With this being a 2 hour event I was worried at first that we would have a tour guide that would walk us through everything and instead I was able to move at my own pace. And the guides were always happy to help or answer questions when we asked! Thank you again for this wonderful museum and letting all of us be apart of it!

Informative, Intimate. The pictures and artifacts were very interesting and informative. Learned a great deal about the recovery effort. It is obvious that Gary Marlon Suson shares this us from a deep love for the firefighters and the families. Setup of the museum is great with audio commentary on each artifact and picture.

Unbelievably emotional exoerience. First time to NYC and recommended this trip by friends, must say it was the highlight of our trip, such a moving yet incredible experience which we will never forget. Everyone visiting NYC must go to the workshop, you'll regret it if you don't go. Thankyou gary suson for making an extraordinary memory fir NYC x

Worth the visit. Very quaint environment with up close and personal docents providing the stories behind the photos taken days after 9-1-1. The day we visited the photographer was present and talked to us. He narrates the audio tour and provides very emotional detail about the photos. The artifacts are worth seeing but not nearly as compelling as the photos and audio tour. Very personal stories are shared. I felt like I was present in the days following. The museum is located in the meatpacking district. While there take advantage of the shopping and the trendy restaurants in the area and then take the subway downtown to see what is happening at Ground Zero.

fantastic - not to be missed. we discovered this though the Explorer Ticket purchased in the UK. You need to book by phone before hand,but we only booked about 36 hours before the visit. Easy to find from given directions. The museum itself is rather small-more like a lounge - with en suite facilities but as there are only about 30 of you in there at a time it doesn`t feel crowded. We were lucky enough to meet Mr Suson, its` creator as he was there during our visit. I felt very priveleged to visit - almost as though i was allowed to view something personal. After seeing the scenes in the media of New York celebrating Bin Ladens recent death I was pleasantly surprised to find that there was no blame attributed to any person or cause. Altogether a very calming and thought provoking environment which was the highlight of my trip.

Not what we expected but very informative..... Not sure what i was expecting but it is just a room with artifacts and a headset but you do get a feel for what happened. You also watch a couple of videos but none of the actual towers or the plane crashing into them. Feels like it should be free but was very well executed by the staff although we were supposed to have priority seating and skip the line and we didnt have either!!! Worth a visit if you run out of things to do.

Incredible, moving-Do not miss. What a poignant and moving experience visiting the Ground Zero Workshop Museum! The attraction is truly an experience. You will see pictures and hear stories that will speak to your heart and your soul about 9/11. One of the saddest events in our nation's history, it also inspired incredible acts of bravery and kindness that demonstrate the beauty of our incredible nation. Gary Suson captured the heart of every American with his incredible photos and displays. Thank you!

Eh.... Not as inspiring or moving as I thought it would be. The photographer's photos are amateur at best! I could have taken better photos with my point and shoot. He also calls himself "Chief", which is a very offensive title for someone who is not a firefighter nor helped save lives on that dreadful day! Liar! Due to his self-centered, egotistical and condescending attitude, I will not recommend this museum to anyone as he is obviously in it only for the money. For someone who is so moved by patriotic moments such as this sad day in American history, he sure has a poor way of showing it in how he treats his fellow citizens.Get off your high horse, Gary (not Chief), you are not the only one who has contributed to 9/11 and you are not the celebrity you think you are. Stop comparing this museum as "The Lion King". How sad! 9/11 is not something to be compared to as a cartoon!

Great find,unique approach to remembering an awful day.. Very well run, organized musuem with a plethora of information. It was clear to us that the people running this museum love their job and really want you to enjoy the experience. A bit boring for little ones, I'd say under 10, but our 9 year old twins, hung in there, our teens really enjoyed it. Highly recommend and remember to get your tix ahead of time!

Excellent for students!. We took a group of college students who all remember 9/11, but it certainly didn't happen during their adulthood. This museum provided a very personal look and allowed the students to really experience 9/11 and the recovery in a very respectful way. I would highly recommend this tour to everyone, but I think that it is an especially valuable learning tool for highschool/college age students.

Love Conquers Evil. When remembering the events of September 11, 2001, there is a tendency to think mostly of the tradgedy of that day; the planes crashing into the twin towers and their eventual collapse. The photos and artifacts contained in this small space respects and accurately conveys the reality of the day's events without "replaying the film" of the tradgedy of the day. How, you may ask? The answer to that question is in the nine month recovery effort that followed; counter-acting and destroying the despair and evil that abounded that day. The poignant photos of this recovery effort tell a story of faith and love that leads to a place of restored hope for humanity.What enduring love is it that would compel so many to perservere in searching and recovering those who perished - many of whom layed down their lives for others? What enduring love is it that labors to acknowledge and restore the dignity of every life lost in an honor guard procession done with reverence and respect? What enduring love is it that brings brothers, fathers, siblings to ground zero day after day to search for their victim loved-ones with devotion to the cause of their recovery, even if it meant they themselves would be completely spent? What enduring love is it that sustained them so that at the end of the nine month recovery effort, all who labored could at the very least say to their fallen brothers and sisters in a whispered prayer: "I did all I could and I will never forget you?"When I "replay the film" of the actual, tragic events on the day of 9/11, I shed tears of despair and hopelessness. Now I have the photo images in the Ground Zero museum to "retell the story." It helps to transcend the despair and hopelessness of that day. The tears shed are now healing and this is a tribute to those who labored in the recovery effort. Their example continues to exemplify what it is to have faith; what it is to have hope; what it means to love with an intensity that conquers evil.I recommend a visit to this museum to all who would like to move past the tradgedy and despair of that day and walk with those who labored in the recovery effort to a place of faith, hope and love.

Do not miss this stop!. My group waffled on whether or not to visit this workshop. When we left we were glad we stopped. Of course, being there in the midst of artifacts - a burned and damaged airplane window, numbers from the elevators, photos of the victims, it was all heart-wrenching, but definetly a must-see event. Luckily they had boxes of tissues available. At the end of the exhibit they have comment cards that anyone, children and adults alike, can write comments on their experiences. Many comment cards were posted on the wall. You will not leave untouched.

It will give you a new understanding of 9/11 and the losses involved.. This place is tiny, small but boy does it pack a punch. I didn't ever shed a tear over 9/11 at the time, it was more just a shocked reaction but I certainly shed a few today. I was doing ok till I listened to the audio guide for the Band of Father photo of the Dad holding the Harry Potter book and it just undid me. I really don't know how those guys did it or how the photographer went back day after day to deal with it. Well worth 2 hours of your time.

Must be in your to-do list for nyc!. First time to nyc and had a lot of our list to see. Our last night and last place to go was the ground zero museum workshop. I had bought tickets for this off of groupon and really wasn't what we were in store for. Its in a very small room with tons of artifacts and info about 9.11. Staff were very informative and friendly. There is a lot about 9.11 I never knew before attending this museum. I can't express enough to anyone traveling to nyc to make this in their top 5, if not ranking it as their number 1 stop!

Beyond Expectations. This museum is absolutely amazing! Gary Marlon Suson's amazing photography skills and carefully compiled collection of artifacts allows viewers to witness the raw emotion of humanity through the catastrophic event of 9-11. Was also pleasantly surprised that Mr. Suson took an active role in both scheduling our tour reservation and in making a personal appearance during our tour. Would definitely go see again.

Do not miss. Perfect antidote to all the neontastic sights you come across in Midtown. Will make you fall in love with New York in a whole new way. Great insight into firefighters and real new yorkers. Amazing people.

Amazing..... Words really cannot describe the experience one has at this museum. The artifacts include an actual piece of one if the hijacked airliners. The stories behind the photos and artifacts on display with leave you breathless. It was one of the most amazing experiences I’ve ever had. It will make you cry, but it will also give you hope that if America can survive this, we can endure anything. Gary Marlon Suson is an incredible photographer.

A beautiful tribute to 9/11 recovery workers. Gary Suson's labor of love is a must-see for anyone coming to New York. Unlike other 9/11-related sites, this one does not focus on the actual event. It is a respectful, emotional, and ultimately uplifting tribute to those who (unknowingly) risked their health and lives to honor the victims. You'll come to know the men and women (and dogs) who devoted themselves to the recovery effort. It is completely unique and amazing. I recommend it highly.

This museum brings all those that visit to common grounds..... UNITY. Gary's photograph's and personal connection to his work, the people, their stories, and the emotional feelings associated to this historic event brings to life the committment, love, and unity amongst the people of this world..... this museum will bring tears to your eyes and tug on your heartstrings throughout the entire tour and for hours after as you scroll through your pictures and visit other sites of NYC. The whole world remember September 11, 2001 and these images from this tour will burn in your heart forever. Thank you Gary for your beautiful photograph's and the stories they tell.

Emotionally Inspiring. Our first visit to NYC wouldn't have been complete without a visit to the Ground Zero Museum and Workshop. Unfortunately, there wasn't much to see at the actual location as they are currently building on the same spot that once housed the World Trade Centre. This museum was/is your best bet to really getting up close and personal with the people and events of that fateful morning. At first, I wasn't sure what to expect from the museum but when we arrived I knew I would have a difficult time holding back the tears and remembering the day the towers came down.The museum is teeny-tiny BUT the self-directed audio stories narrated by the photographer himself of each photo and/or or remnant left behind by the attacks as well as the artifacts themselves were both emotionally overwhelming and inspirational - "Two bullets went into the towers but only love came out". I LOVE this quote and if this museum did nothing but prove this point, you must include this experience on your next trip to NYC.Thank you!

Emotional and a must. Great work to pay tribute to the victims and to the heros who worked so hard to make sure they would rest in peace.Loved the small group formula, the self-paced experience, the intense respect that this place inspires.Thanks to Gary Suson and staff for a great achievement.

Don't miss this emotional but compassionate look at Ground Zero!. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is in the former studio of the photographer, Marlon Suson. Mr. Suson was selected by the New York Fire Department to be their official photographer, and spent about 8 months photographing the work done at Ground Zero following 9/11. Don't let the small size of the studio fool you -- there's artwork, artifacts, and accompanying descriptions everywhere (including the bathroom!) that are an excellent representation of the recovery work done at Ground Zero, as well as the personal stories of those involved.The "workshop" consists of 2 parts: an introductory speech and video, followed by a headset you can use to listen to descriptions of the art and artifacts. The headset allows you to go through the art in any order you like, at whatever speed you like. The narration is done by Mr. Suson.
