The photographs are amazing--everything from photos of the fire department's honor guard watching removal of a body covered by the American flag to canine units to subways destroyed underneath the Twin Towers. We had two teenagers with us and they were fascinated by the exhibit, but without feeling overwhelmed. They were 6 and 7 years old when 9/11 occurred, and this was a great way to give them a fuller understanding. We came in thinking we'd just take a "quick look", and ended up spending almost 2 hours there.Call ahead for times--there are about 25 people per group, and groups start at specific times. We called the morning we wanted to go and got in with no problem.

You MUST come here!. We recently visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop, tucked away in the Meatpacker District of Manhattan, New York. Called "the best little museum in New York,” the Ground Zero Museum Workshop, by design, is a small and intimate space that impacts its visitors in a big way. Although it was much smaller than we anticipated (one room of about 1,000 sf), our allotted two hours was barely long enough to take it all in. This tiny museum was originally the studio of photographer Gary Marlon Suson. Following the attack on the World Trade Center, Suson was invited to be the official photographer at Ground Zero for the Uniformed Firefighters Association and the Uniformed Fire Officers Association. As such, he, alone, had full access to the Ground Zero site, where he respectfully documented the recovery efforts. Many of his photographs are on display at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop, along with remnants from the Ground Zero recovery.After a brief introductory video, including a segment with Mr. Suson’s interview on CNN, we were turned loose, with headsets and a control box. We would stop at each exhibit and enter the exhibit number; a recording by Gary Marlon Suson (who is also an actor), told us, in detail, about the photo or object or collection of objects we were seeing. (Nearly 100 exhibits).It is hard to explain what we saw and heard and felt as we toured the museum. Mr. Suson's photographs and displays show dignity and respect, for the victims, survivors and the rescue workers. Interesting and informative, appropriate and accurate, intimate and humbling, showing reverence and heroism with an occasional touch of humor, the audio tour made me feel like I was having an intimate discussion with Gary Suson. The personal accounts made the rescuers real, and not just bits of news briefly shown on TV … a TV documentary could never convey the emotions that this tour brings.While it has been nearly 10 years since that tragic day, this amazing photography exhibit made me feel like I was there in those difficult months in the aftermath of September 11, 2001. It brought back some of the sadness and raw emotions of that day, but I also felt Hope. Peace. Spirituality. And even God’s Presence.Admission was $25.00 per person, but was well worth it. Bear in mind that this is a Not-for-Profit museum; the admission price goes to six charities related to the tragedy.You must make reservations, and pay for your tour in advance. Some tours are sold out, as there is a limited number of visitors allowed in for each tour. (I am guessing that there are no more than 100 people per day, divided between the three 2-hour tours.) Photos are allowed, but videos are not. You must put your purses, backpacks, etc. on a shelf when you walk in; but, once we saw the setup, we were comfortable leaving some expensive camera equipment and a purse on the shelving.We are very glad that we found the Ground Zero Museum Workshop for our short stay in NYC, and wholeheartedly recommend this museum to everyone old enough to understand this experience. Thank you, Mr. Suson!We followed our visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop with a stop at the Tribute WTC Visitor Center. While Mr. Suson’s museum focused primarily on the rescue and recovery operations, the Tribute focused on the victims and survivors. We had a moving and informative tour of the WTC site, led by a survivor, who told us her story of that fateful day.Both museums were individually fantastic. We, personally, were glad that we chose to experience both, as it gave us a truly well-rounded picture, of the past, the present and of a hopeful future.We will never forget!

Awesome. Great place must do for sure! We were right downtown the day obama came it was crazy. The ground zero area is still in construction, but this museum is great stop in and check out the models of the new ground zero.

An Emotional Journey. After visiting the Ground Zero Museum Workshop it was difficult to think of how to review this kind of "attraction." Nearly 10 years ago my husband and I remember (like so many) where we were when we learned that the United States of America was under attack. On our trip to NYC we felt it only fitting to honor the memory of those most affected by this tragedy by keeping the memory alive. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop allowed us to do just that. Within the museum there are countless photos and artifacts which capture the true human emotion of the day. The audio clips which accompany each object add to the story. We recommend visiting this Museum for anyone who was touched by the events of 9/11.

Excellent Exhibit. I highly recommend this museum. It is intimate and moving. I imagine nothing could have prepared Mr. Suson to memorialize this recovery effort; that is, for the emotional attachment captured so beautifully in his heartrending images. The images combined with the selected artifacts provide a poignant insight into what the men and women involved faced. You will leave carrying what I’m sure is just a small part of what he, and all of those involved, now carry with them forever. Thanks to Mr. Suson, (who made a point to introduce himself at the start of our time in the museum and be available at the end) and the staff for making available such a touching exhibit.Practical tips: you are allowed to take pictures, you must make reservations for a specific time slot; because it is located in an intimate space the door at the sidewalk level is listed only by a small sign by the floor you buzz to get in.

This museum affected me more than any other on my trip. This is a must see.. This small museum impacted me in a big way. September 11th/2011 was a human tragedy for all of us, no matter our race, religion, nationality of gender. I wanted to visit this museum as a way to pay respect to the people who lost there lives that day, and after (from the recovery). I have an unending amount of respect for the recovery workers and my heart aches anyone who lost a loved one. This museum helped me to connect on a human level; to see the reality of the recovery experience and healing.

Do not miss an opportunity to visit!. I've been trying to write this review for a day or two now and I just can't quite find the words. Without question, I would reccomend you make this a "must visit" part of any trip to New York. The journey that this place takes you on will be different for everyone, but one that should be taken. Thank you for sharing.

could have stayed another two hours!. We booked tickets over internet (only a limited number of places per tour) the museum it's tucked away through the door of number 420 off 14th street on the 1st floor. ( no big museum building to find,) And I can only say this museum is small but full of emotion. It was one of the most moveing and interesting places we visited in NYC, an outstanding 2 hours!

MUST NOT MISS, you profoundly feel like you want to know each person and help anyway you can. This venue is small with so much to see. Actual belongings, magazines, papers of that day, photos that just capture you.We must NEVER forget and this museum will keep all of those lost souls alive in each one of us.

I was on the other side of the ocean on the day of 9/11, but this museum made me feel like I was right there.. I was on the other side of the ocean on the day of 9/11, but this museum made me feel like I was right there. Because the museum is in just 1 room, not that big, and you are with a small group of people, you really have the chance to experience the museum to the fullest. The video you get to see brings you right back to that day almost 10 years ago. The artifacts and audio story´s make it all very real. What I really liked about the museum was that it focussed on individual story´s, story´s you never heard before. The museum doesn´t just show the footage of the airplane crashing into the WTC, but gives all the victims and the recovery workers a face and a voice. A must go to if you visit New York!

In fact the biggest little museum in New York. If you are in New York just cant miss the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I did it the secont time yesterday and I would do it again if I return to New York. The pictures are incredible and just get real inside looks on Ground Zero and the recovery. It really touched me a lot.

Makes you feel like you where at ground zero yourself. As a European 9/11 always was something terribly that happend far away from my safe home. Visiting the Ground Zero Museum Workshop made me feel very close to everything that happened that day. All of the sudden it became something very real and not just something that you saw on tv. With all the beautiful pictures, the audio tour and the fact that you can touch some of the artifacts makes it a special experience. \everyone who visits New York should go here!

Breath-taking and emotional must-see!. When you first enter you wonder what this little room can possibly hold, then later realize that this little room is filled with so much more. Love the interactive part, love that you get to see/hear the photographer's views & experiences. Young and old, A MUST if you're in the NY area!!!

Timeless Photos of the 9/11 tragedy. The photographer, Gary Suson, has captured this tragedy with his camera for the world. The many photos chronicle the emotions, work, and depth of destruction. The video shown at the beginning of the workshop captured the essence of the event and brought tears to our eyes. As you watch the video, view the photos and artifacts, you will experience the emotion of the event. The trip to ground zero and to the workshop museum was the reason for our trip to Manhattan from southern Illinois.
Definitely worth a visit. Very informative, interesting and moving. Not to be missed, to learn & understand so much more about the tragic events of 9/11.
DO NOT miss this!. this was the most moving and worthwhile thing we did on our one week visit to NYC. DO NOT miss it!

best museum in NY. we have been to many citys around the world and many museums,but this was the most interactive and interesting in every sense its a genuine case of you just have to go and experience it yourself

They will never be forgotten thanks to the hard work of this museum.. We were given tickets as a gift to ground zero museum. Although not on the site of Groun Zero this must visit museum tells so much about what happened after the impact. So many more people have been affected and this allows pepple across the world to ensure they are never forgotten. This museum supports families and individuals who still today suffer as a result of things you cannot imagine. They do this by sharing their knowledge of what was found and discovered during the clear up. An emotional but knowledgeable visit that has helped me understand the impact on everyone involved. please support by making sure you visit. I will be returning with my son.

the best museum I have ever visited despite its size.. The ground zero museum is only in one room but what a lot they have packed into this room, Do not go to New York and come home without visiting this wonderful little museum, the two members of staff really put their hearts and feelings into their commentary and made everything some to life, the sensitive way they deal with everything is a real credit to the museum. you alos feel like you are helping the victims in your on little way by the proceedds going to the children of victims ( 20,000 children lost a parent on this awful day) one of many facts they tell you.

Respectful rememberance. A tiny museum with a big heart. My 13 year old son and I visited NYC for the first time and visited this museum to pay our respects to a part of New York's history. It presented the reality and impact of the terrorist attack in a very respectful, moving way.

If you only go to one place in NYC, go here!. Hands down this was the most, powerful, intimate, and emotional experience that my family had during our tour of New York City. Unlike any "museum" we've been to, the tour group was small as was the exhibition space, which allowed for our children (age 7-14) to interact/touch/examine artifacts and get up close and personal with the incredible photos captured during the Ground Zero clean up. I'd recommend following up the Museum Workshop experience with a visit to the Ground Zero site.

Most moving and intimate museum...A must see!. Gary Marlon Suson has shared a positive tribute to 911 through his photography and artifacts at the Ground Zero Museum. This maybe the smallest museum in NYC, but has the most impact on those who perished and those who strived to recover post 9/11. This small 1100square foot showroom is very intimate and allows you to feel the emotion(and some artifacts) and relive the tragedy of this horific day. Make sure you reserve your tickets today so you don't miss this realistic experience through the eyes of professional photographer Gary Marlon Suson. Tickets sell out fast....get yours today so your don't miss the #1 Must See in NYC!

WOW it was are lucky day. What are the chances that one of the employee's would be sick and Gary Marlon Suson would be doing our tour? I am sure the tour would have very good anyway but this was a special treat for us 6-adults 1-teenager everyone of us came out of the tour with a different story that touched us the most. The museum is very small and intimate but every square inch of it is action filled. The tour is both audio and video so it is very relaxing and easy to enjoy. If you only have the opportunity to see one thing while in New York City see this museum tour, you will walk out of there with knots in your stomach. The hard part is finding the studio it is on 14th street nowhere near Ground Zero, when you book your tickets on-line they will send you directions, follow them closely, the museum is nothing to look at from the outside, but just wait till you get inside!!!!!

This is an amazing, inspiring story of the resilent stories of the 9/11 recovery shown through Suson's touching photos. This museum is a must see if you are visiting NYC. The inspiring stories of the triumph of the 9/11 recovery is so powerful. Suson takes you on a journey through his photos and artifacts that you will never forget, as we never should.

A Hidden Gem. Gary does an amazing job of not only capturing timeless photos of the 9/11 events and aftermath, he also narrates and provides supporting information on each photo in a self-guided tour of the museum. This is a must-see for everyone and is done with amazing taste. You can also purchase a variety of pictures and books at the museum. I was happy to hear that much of the proceeds of the ticket price go to a variety of charities set up for 9/11 victims and their families. Make sure to purchase your tickets ahead of time because they do SELL OUT!

Touching and revealing. We went to the Museum after reading the commentaries on Tripadvisor. Make sure to reserve your turn as it quickly gets sold out. It was a very good decision to go. It's a small museum with well-recounted history in good taste. The photographs are powerful and emotional. My teenage boys went with us and truly appreciated the experience and how it was told--they were very young when it all happened. Each photo had its history and after two quick videos, you tackle the small museum at your own pace. You will learn a lot, appreciate a lot, and simply understand a lot more of what happened that day and during the months that follow.

skip this museum. Not near to the real ground zero at all!We went to the real ground zero site and took some time to figure out it is the wrong place. Have to take the taxi to go to the museum. Hard to find. Just one room like a hotel room size in a remodeling build. About 20 people were packed in the tiny room for about one hour. There are about hundred photos and some artifacts. Nothing is impressive and special if you followed the news right after 9.11. Il feel the whole visit is tainted with the photographer's self-promotion and the steep prices. Very disappointed.

Monumental & Moving - A True Requiem. Had one day in NY before we flew back to UK and choose to spend 2 hours of it at this gem of a museum. Gary Marlon Suson has created a unique tribute to those who perished and those who strived to recover post 9/11.The museum is small but this belies the huge impact it will make on you during your visit. It enables you to truly see & feel what those who experienced the reality of 9/11 and its aftermath, saw & felt, albeit seconhand.A masterpice - i was truly humbled by the images that Gary has displayed. we were lucky to meet he man himself on the day we visite dand i feel privileged to have shaken .his hand.If you are in NY - I urge you to visit this museum - it will make a lasting impact on you!

A must visit in New York City. This was truly an experience that enables someone to understand and reflect on 911 ... the events of the day and impact to the city of New York. The museum is small and intimate and allows each individual to absorb the pictures and information at their own pace. The Museum photos and artifacts give you many perspectives about what happened. Strongly suggest you visit the Museum before going to the site to learn about the development effort ... it helps make the connection on past, present, and future.

Very thought provoking and deeply moving.. This experience was one of a kind. The pictures with audio comments and the artifacts were very moving. It was well worth the time and money if you are interested in a close up of the aftermath of the 9/11 tragedy.

Very interesting and powerful museum.. This small, intimate museum can provoke some strong thoughts and emotions. The photos and artefacts capture the moods and struggles of the emergency workers during the cleanup after 9/11 very well. Several tell moving stories of these workers, as well as victims of the tragedy itself. Even though I didn't know anyone affected by this, this museum still almost moved me to tears. I would definitely recommend this to everyone.

Very Moving. I am so glad we did this tour. It only takes 2 hours of your time, and I recommend it to everyone, whether an American or not. I have definitely walked away with a greater insight into what it takes to be a hero, and the shear scale of what happened that terrible day almost 10 years ago.

Put it top of your list. This is a must for anyone visiting New York.The 2 hours flew by and the good thing is after the introduction by the guide you are left alone with your own headphones to study all the different photos etc. It is certainly an emotional place but the people who have put so much work into this deserve our support. Chelsea Market is just around the corner plus a large Apple store so there is plenty to do in the area. I would recommend booking your tour in the morning and then have lunch at Chelsea Market. It's a great place for food.

Moving displays of artefacts and photos, predominantly the photographer's own 9/11 journey. We needed to change our original booking date and were very surprised to have to “beg” for this indulgence and then be charged $18 for the privilege. Quite difficult to find and when we did get there we were made to wait in the street for 15 mins (it was cold and raining) until everyone else who had the same time as us arrived.Just 1 large room with soft seating and soft lighting. Each artefact in the museum is numbered and there is an audio clip to explain the relevance or significance of the item. Very much about the photographer, Gary, his journey, his experiences and his thoughts. At some points it almost becomes so much about him you lose sight of what this is supposed to be about.Lots and lots about the fire-fighters and their traumas, very little about anyone else who suffered, lost loved ones or died. A deeply moving place (as you’d expect anything related to 9/11 to be) with some unique items from the subway station and ground zero itself. We’d suggest it’s not suitable for children under 12 as there is nothing for them “to do”. The ones in the museum when we were there were distracting to other visitors

If you're ready to get back in touch with your emotions from 9/11, you should check this out.. I was really impressed how they made such a small space work. The stories were amazing as were the photos and artifacts on exhibit. They made a self guided tour really work. we drove into the city for this and there was a parking garage only a block away. If you're ready to relive your emotions from that day, its definately a great place to go.
Very enlightning. So glad we booked tickets to this museum would recommend this very highly do arrive on time some people turned up late so missed watching a short film at the start.

The images and artifacts from this exhibit are wonderful.. I highly recommend this compelling and sensitive portrayal of a time in our nation that must never be forgotten. Gary Suson has captured the images of this day that must be shared for all of us to see. The photographs and artifacts are presented in a sensitive portrayal that captivates the viewer. I am a fourth Grade teacher, and I feel that all ages would benefit from the experience of visiting this unique museum. Thank you Gary. You have had a profound impact on my life.Meg EilersMattituck, NY

A well kept secret that should be revealed as the museum humanizes the events of 9/11 and insures that we don't forget!. You need to purchase advance tickets online or by phone as only a certain number of people are allowed on each tour. Not a very large museum, full of photographs that were taken by Gary Marlon Suson, the official photographer during the recovery of Ground Zero. There's a film that is shown and then a short talk by a guide. Then, with headsets you're free lo listen to a description of each item in the museum at your own pace. There's about 100 photographs and displays. If you can fit it into your schedule, take the last tour in the afternoon as it affords more time as there is not a constraint of getting people out for another group to come in. (If they are not in a hurry to close for the day.) Bring your camera as you're allowed to take pictures. There's a coat rack outside the room and backpacks will have to be put on a shelf. A negative comment I heard was that it was only a small room, but I guarantee you that you won't have enough time to get through the displays and photographs that are housed in the museum in the time allotted, if you really want to see it all. The photographs portrayed a very difficult time in our history in a very moving and sensitive way.Thank you Gary Suson~you were able to humanize the most horrible event in our present day country's history and your "images will insure that people never forget"

A touching tribute to all who lost their lives on 9-11-01. I had not talked to anyone who had been at this museum or had even heard about it. I found it online, and as a retired firefighter, planned to see this museum on my next visit to NYC. I was not disappointed. I bought my tickets online through Zerve, who sent me the e-ticket along with very clear directions to the museum. Do not confuse it with the 911 museum/memorial which is planned for the site of the twin towers.Gary Suson's photos and narrations were very tastefully presented and displayed. The artifacts were displayed in cases around the room and there were a few items for sale. I did buy an autographed copy of his book at the museum. The two young ladies who conducted the tour did a great job.

Very insightful. Well worth a visit as it gives a true insight into 9/11 and the following months. Amazing pictures and artifacts. Small museum but this creates a powerful atmosphere. If you are going to NYC go here!

Pervasive Air of Exploitation. The material presented was beautiful and touching and the guides did an excellent job, but the entire enterprise is tainted with the photographer's self-promotion and the steep prices. Details about any charity organizations are vague, and compared to other attractions in the city the museum is wildly overpriced. Felt a lot like they were pulling our heartstrings to open our wallets. Head for St. Paul's chapel across from the actual site instead.

A very moving experience.. We arrived at the workshop not knowing what to expect. You stay in the room thay you first go into. We were given a audio tour and watched two short video's before being allowed to wander at our leisure. You can touch some of the exhibits and can take photo's of everything apart from one of the exhibits. We didnt think that it would take two hours but it did.The tour brought tears to my eyes several times, it was a very moving experience for both me and my husband and we thought it was worth what we paid. All the money made goes back to the families who lost relatives which we thought was good.There were some children in the group we were with so it is open to people of all ages.It is definately worth a visit as you will not find another museum like this in New York.

Stunning experience.. This was such a good thing to do before going to see the WTC site itself. The studio is full of so many moving pictures and artefacts from the 9/11 recovery. Was a poignant reminder of the heartbreaking work that went on for so many months after 9/11 when I imagine most of us had put it all to the back of our minds.The exhibition is powerful and sensitive and is truly a must see.

Worth the 2 hour visit. What an unbelievable exhibit. If you are in New York you should not leave without visiting this museum. It is small. Do not be surprised when you arrive and you do not leave the room you first enter. The time listening and viewing the artifacts and pictures make you forget the size of the room. You have plenty of room to spread out and not bother anyone. This will be an emotional 2 hours as you get a closer look at the lives that were lost. I wiped many a tear during our two hour visit. The $25 cost may seem high but I left feeling I should pay more as some of the proceeds to go back to the families that have had their lives forever changed by this terrorist attack.

Average. I was disappointed in this museum. I felt I didn't truely experience anything more than I had through various other sources about the event. I didn't leave feeling enlightened our moved. The Tribute center at ground zero was much better in every way and very moving. I reccomend skipping this museum.

A totally different museum experience.. This was the first attractions we visited in NYC and it was an amazing experience to get so up close and personal with real people and artifacts from 9/11. When you first enter the room it is nothing like you expect but the intimacy of the environment is perfect to allow you to gain your own understanding of what you see around you. When we were there we actually met the photographer who owned the museum, it was great to see that this meant so much to him and wasn't just a money making scheme. I can highly recommend this to anyone who has any interest in the people who were involved on that day that changed the world.

Its a pretty good atraccion, but Overrated in TripAdvisor. Is really emotional Workshop Museum, I can understand that for a lot of people is one of the best attractions in NYC because all the emotional charge that has, but for me the MoMA or the MET are by far better attraccions. Should be in the TOP 20 of NYC things to do and not in the TOP 5

A Must See. A moving and poignant memorial to 9/11 which manages to address a delicate subject with both sensitivity and sincerity, Gary Marlon Suson's outstanding photos and exhibit capture vividly the humanity and courage of those closest to Ground Zero. Proceeds are shared with charities established to support families affected by 9/11 and photos were collated with official FDNY approval. Never to be forgotten.

A fantastic gem of a museum.. Don't be put off by the size of the venue. This atttraction, in the Meat Packing district, will hold your attention for as long as some of the largest attractions in NY. We received an introduction by the photographer who contributed and instigated this project. The artifacts include parts of the plane and remnants from the collapsed buildings, in a meaningful and sensitive manner. You get to touch certain items to help 'heal' and connect with this devastating event. A must see.

Loved the Image of the Bible Found with Genesis 11. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop was fantastic. It is located in just a small room, but you'll be surprised at how much there is to see and hear on this tour. It starts off with two short videos, followed by an hour and a half to go around and observe the photos and artifacts, and you will definitely use all the time available. You wear headphones and each photo or artifact has a number next to it, so you simply press the number that you want to hear, and you will hear an explanation from the photographer himself. The photographer was the official photographer for 9/11, so nobody else was allowed to take the photos that he did. They also let you hold actual items that they obtained from that site. They allow you to take pictures almost everything as well. Overall, I really enjoyed this museum and definitely recommend it.

The highlight of our trip!. Visiting this museum was one of the most incredible experiences that I have ever had. The museum has artifacts from 9/11 and countless photos of the recovery at the site. It was unbelievably touching and a raw account of what went on at Ground Zero. While it was incredibly sad, and I'll admit, I cried throughout my time there, I left the museum with a true sense of hope and love. The museum is a tasteful and very loving tribute to those lost in the 9/11 attacks and reminded me of the love and compassion that exists in the world, in particular in very trying times. This museum is a must-see and an experience that every American should have!

Incredible...a must see attraction. This museum is not located near the WTC which is very confusing to the first time visitor of NYC; however, once we figured out where it was located (meat packing district) it was very easy to find. This museum is different than most (in a good way) and the photographer was on site to answer questions, etc. Definately worth seeing.

A must for anyone visiting NYC!. Like me, many people witnessed the horror of 9/11 within the comfort of their own surroundings. This museum brings home the reality of the terrible act which led to the loss of almost 3000 precious lives. However, it also reminds us of the many inspirational people who were involved in the recovery efforts, as soon as the first tower was hit and for many months thereafter. Rather than focus solely upon tragic events of that awful day this museum provides an extremely sensitive insight into the less publicised (but no less poignant) months of recovery afterwards. Upon entry to the museum, which is set in an intimate space in NYC's Meat -packing district (less than 10mins from Ground Zero by Subway), you are shown two short videos about the events of 9/11 and the aftermath. You can then walk around the museum at your leisure (within the tour time slot) viewing the numerous photos/artefacts and listening to the associated stories via a self guided handheld audio tour. You are able to take photos (no videos) of all except one item in the museum; the story behind this piece will no doubt bring a tear to even the toughest of eyes. Photo postcards and REQUIEM - a book by Mr Gary Marlon Suson (the owner of the museum and photographer of all the amazing photos) are also available to purchase. Mr Suson actually came into the museum towards the end of our tour and he kindly agreed to sign the REQUIEM book that I had purchased. In summary, if you are planning a visit to New York and have an interest in what happened after the towers collapsed on 11th September 2001 then a visit to this museum is a must. Mr Suson is an awe-inspiring photographer who (in my humble opinion) captured not only evidence of the many hours of hard recovery work conducted by members of the NY Fire Department and associated authorities, but also the true emotions involved with such a chilling task. I would highly recommend a visit to this museum. Although obviously harrowing at times, this museum left me with a great sense of hope and became the highlight of my 5 day trip to NYC!

More than a hole in the ground - a hole in our hearts.. This was the highlight of my high school students' visit to NYC. We are from a small town, and many of their family members are volunteer firefighters. It was something special for my students, who already honor the sacrifices of firefighters, to really understand the brave efforts of the 9/11 rescue workers. As we wandered the room listening to the stories behind many of the photos and artifacts, no one was immune from emotion. I've been to the Anne Frank Museum, which served as a model for this. The Ground Zero Museum shows the same restraint and tact in dealing with a difficult and sensitive subject. Tickets were $25, with part of the proceeds going to help those affected by 9/11. It was well worth it.The Museum is on the second floor of a building. There is an elevator as well as safe storage for coats, purses, and bags. An interesting touch was the bowl of chocolates in the bathroom - as one guide told us, chocolates are good to fight depression. I know chocolate is no cure for tragedy, but this human touch was somehow cheering.Also, make sure not to look for this attraction near the WTC site. It is to the west, in the Meatpacking District.

We will never forget..... Tastefully done, once inside you are instantly transported to september 11th. Not a dry eye in the room. Mr. Souson has done something wonderful for all the families who have lost a loved one to this senseless act of violence, he has given them a place to grieve.

Respectful and Emotional Living History. Tastefully designed, informative, emotional, ticket price is set at right amount. There is a small shop with memorbilia for sale. I don't remember food or drinks but you won't want them there and there's tons of places around outside.There are restrooms. Be prepared to maybe feel a bit sad / down afterwards.

Moving Experience Not to be Missed. An amazing 2 hour experience! Inspirational stories - we were a bit worried that this would be depressing but it's far more about healing! The tour guides were fantastic and were very caring - at least one of our party had so obviously lost someone on 9/11 and she was very well cared for. Being able to touch some of the artefacts - including glass from the windows - was a unique aspect of the tour. Our entire group spent the whole time in silence - something else I have never experienced in a group of 25 people! A MUST see for everyone visiting or living in New York. A truly amazing, evocative and unforgettable experience!

Excellent place to visit. Very small museum with a big impact. Very well done. They only take small groups, because the space is one room. But there's so much packed in this one room that you'll spend two fascinating hours here.

Very respectful and quiet. Highly recommend it.. Very small space filled with photos and artifacts. Individual audio units so you can go at your own pace and in whatever small area you like. You don't have to listen in any order. The photos are amazing. There are even small stools you can move around if you want to sit for a while and think. The venue is NOT at Ground Zero. It is in the Meatpacking neighborhood, not far from the Chelsea Market. Absolutely recommend this. The eyes were pretty moist.

It was the best part of the trip. This museum was amazing it made me see how terrible it was for people who suffered on the day of 9/11. But also how nobody could do anythink. I am really glad this museum was opened because now people like me get a chnace to see how devestating it actually was.

It's an excellent experience and It shows alot about the victimes who have suffered in 9/11. I think it's an amazing place to go to find inner stories and view pictures of 9/11
I would deffo suggest this to the public to come and view

A very moving and memorable experience---a must see for all!. This was my 2d visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. My 1st visit was over 2 years ago with my then 14 year old (youngest) daughter. According to my youngest daughter, this museum was the most memorable part of our 2008 visit to NYC. At her urging, I brought my 18 year old (eldest) daughter to this exhibit. My eldest daughter was also very moved by the wonderful photographs that Gary Marlon Suson took of the Ground Zero recovery efforts by firefighters and police. The photographs and artifacts allow you to not only visualize but also feel the heroism and compassion of the people involved in the recovery effort. This is a "must see" activity for teens and adults.

An emotional trip. I was not really sure what to expect when we visited the museum. I was a bit taken aback when we entered, because I thought that it would be more than just one room. The visits are held at intervals of 2 hours and our group consisted of about 25 people.The experience started off with a short video and then a talk about the museum, which in the main consists of the evocative photographs taken by Gary Suson with accompanying narratives by Gary and the people who were there together (you're supplied with indivual headsets), together with some of the tools used by the rescuers and some of their odd finds.I know that it doesn't sound much of an attraction, but it was one of the most emotional places that I've ever been to. The narrative about the Deutsche Bank building was most disturbing. The museum has nothing about the actual attack, but instead deals with its aftermath.I would not recommend this museum for anyone under the age of 16, but for everyone else it's a must.

Interesting and touching a well thought out place. I really wanted to visit this museum due to reviews my other half wasn't so sure. It was a must do experience from the introducing video to the museum. The audio tour was informative and touching and tears were shed, although i wouldn't say it was depressing at all. We both had a great (if thats the right word) time and would visit again.

A moving reminder. When I went here there was not a tour like other members mentioned. But the photos are moving and I am not sure I missed anything by not having a spiel. It seems that the point is simply to be reminded, which this does visually very well. The construction scene at the actual spot has nothing to suggest the past events so this is what you see when you go to Ground Zero.The crowds here were solemn and polite rather than pushy.The gift shop area was a little cheesy but you can just breeze by it if this is not for you.

Pulls heart strings.. My wife and I had planned on visiting ground zero on our NYC trip. we were unaware that construction of the new freedom tower is so far underway. We went into the Workshop to get a feel of "New York". A great memorial to those that lost their lives in a terrible day in American history. So much respect is given in this place and the many quotes on the walls bring the memory of this day back to your mind. A must visit.On a side note, on staten island there is another memorial to staten island residents who lost their lives. I would very much recommend visiting this site if you are going that way!

Our #1 highlight of our NYC trip!. We were reluctant to visit due to the cost ($25 per person) and it being a very small museum. But the photos, relics, etc are full of information. The tour is 2 hour and a bit is self-guided. It was an experience of a lifetime. My hubby is a fireman in California and we were sooooo glad we did go. It is NOT at Ground Zero and is a bit out of the way in the Meatpacking District but easy to get there via the subway. PLEASE do not go to NYC w/o visiting this museum. Very moving and personal.

A Must See!. This is a very small museum and you have to buy your ticket in advance, but it was well worth the cost and the two hours. The photos and exhibits are moving, memorable and give a new insight into 9/11. It's tough, but I truly did leave with a positive feeling and a bit of awe.

Moving, meaningful and an experience I will never forget.. The museum is really open at Tour times and last for up to 2 hours. Everyone is given a headset and remote to type in numbers next to the exhibits to hear about the item from the man himself who took the photos and opened it - Gary Susson. After a brief introduction to the museum we were left to wander on our own. We were able to hold a few artefacts and it is clear that this is a place for healing rather than gory details. I spent almost the whole 2 hours there, soaking up all the information and stories and holding back the tears on more occasion than one. At the end, I was lucky enough to speak to the man himself Mr. Gary Susson and I was honoured. This man has done so much for New York by having this museum open. The museum next to the Ground Zero site, pales in comparison as it focuses on the event and not the lives and mostly looks like a souvenir store, but this one - although it does have a few items for sale - is so much more.

Not quite what I thought it would be.. I found this museum online at Zerve and then read the reviews here. The museum is a small room in Chelsea, on 14th Street. The tour of the room is well organized from start to finish with good directions. The guide has memorized the script and she did a good job, very assertive and sensitive at the appropriate times. I wish I could agree with all of the superior rating reviews but this would not be high on my list of recommended stops for visitors to NYC. There is a good deal of self promotion involved for the photographer, Gary Suson. There are some emotional stories told and written on placards by various artifacts that came out of Ground Zero or were donated by survivors. You hear the tour guide’s speech, see a video and then are able to walk around a small room and see the artifacts. There is a certain commercial element imbalance that I was uncomfortable with, books and book marks etc for sale. The guide mentions that some of the proceeds go towards the victim’s family but there is not mention or documentation, charts etc. of how much and the contribution thus far. I went to the staging area near Ground Zero where a store front across from St Paul’s’ Chapel has been set up with the models of the memorials and what is to come there, and there were statistics on the wall with a time sequence and videos playing. I felt that was more meaningful and the admission fee was a donation. I couldn’t really recommend seeing the Ground Zero Workshop Museum, for me, something was off.
A MUST..... You must have this on your must to do list when in NYC... its dosen't take much time and be sure to get a keepsake to bring back home...
A must-do on your trip to New York. This was a very emotional experience & felt a bit like walking into a church - the same sense of awe and respect. Thank you so very much for the experience.

The most amazing experience I have ever encountered.. This is a beautiful museum created for the Survivors and Victim Families. It's sad but not depressing. When you go be prepared because you will cry but you will also smile. The tour is very personal because you will be allowed to actually touch some of the recovered artifacts and here personal stories what go along with the pictures and items. If you get the chance to visit New York City do not miss this tour. It is so worth the cost.

A Must See for Everyone!!. Incredible work of art from start to finish. Moving experience that I will never forget. I laughed, I cried, I was angry and I somehow found peace all within a two hour tour. Every person should see this exhibit so that we are always reminded of the goodness we all possess. Never Forget!
A Must. A visit to this museum is a must. You will probably leave crying, but go anyway. Go to remember those we lost and honor the brave who saved lives.

Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a small, but very interesting & important MUST SEE museum in NYC.. This was a very emotional and informative interactive museum about the Ground Zero recovery period. There are amazing photos, images, and artifacts from that tragedy presented in a very tasteful and sensitive way. It's a small museum. so reservations are necessary. It's a non-profit exhibition with money going to the FDNY Foundation. I highly recommend a visit.

A MUST TO VISIT. What can I say .... from start to finish this museum was amazing. The whole idea behind it really hits home and you have to ask "why" and take on board the message that is being conveyed. The staff were friendly, helpful, caring and passionate about their museum. It may be small, but don't let that put you off. Its cosy, but understandably when family and friends of victims go there to try to find some answers and peace. The photos are amazing and tell a story of not only the terrible thing that happened on 9/11, but of the team work, courage and determination of the persons at the site. If going to New York you have to go here. Well worth the money and a lot more.

Should not be missed.. 'The Biggest Small Museum in New York' is how its advertised, and its spot-on. One room packed with so many memories, memorials and moving pictures taken by the official photographer during the recovery period. Some of the memories and items bring you to the verge of tears, yet the whole atmosphere is personal and uplifting that you realise this is perfectly done. The tour guides are excellent, supportive and approachable. I cannot express how lucky I feel to have taken this tour and experienced so closely such a important museum site

Awesome. A small space filled with unbelievable pictures and stories- we had the pleasure of meeting Mr. Suson during our visit and he was gracious enough to sign the books we purchased and spent quite a bit of time talking with everyone in our group. If you're in the city you have to make the time to go see this

Remarkable. I can highly recommend this tour and it was obviously a pleasure to meet the photographer himself. Quite simply its the most remarkable tour I've ever been on - I haven't cried so much since Lady Di's funeral. It was good to set these emotions free.

One mans work incredible. Only a small museum, but so much infomation, you can listen to as much or as little as you want via the head sets. There are even artifacts you can hold. Well worth the entrance fee. If you want to know what it was like go, listen to the information then go downtown and visit the site.

The highlight of our week in NY. This is an amazing place...unlike any other. The personal stories behind each photograph or item makes the experience of the recovery at Ground Zero come alive. A truly moving visit and important journey for everyone who comes to NY.

Breathtaking. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is one of New York City's best kept secrets. It captures the emotion that occured through out the rescue process and the recovery process of the September 11th Attacks. Mr. Gary Suson did a fantastic job, this museum is filled with his photographs. The museum contains Mr. Suson's photographs and artifacts like the glass, shovels, steel crosses and stars of david from the building's steel and much more worth seeing. The tour guides there are kind and very knowledgeable. You must order your tickets online though.

NYC's best kept secret!. GZMW was an amazing experience for my 15 year old and I! We got a behind the scenes look at some of the acitivty that took place after 9/11. The stories told about the photos and artifacts made me smile, cry and gave me a deep appreciation fo rthe way so many pulled together to bring healing to the families involved. I heard many stories that the media did not share. The staff went above and beyond to make our experience meaningful! Don't miss it!

A no-brainer. Buy your tickets today. I give it 100 stars.. This small museum on West 14th should be a must for anyone making a trip to New York as well as residents of the city. It's simply amazing.My wife and I visited it last week. It's so many things wrapped up in one small room. Despair, anger, sorrow, inspiration, compassion.....the list goes on. The photographs and artifacts are amazing and are made to come to life with the narration by Gary Marlon Suson via the handheld receiver and headphones each guest is provided. There are so many breathtaking and heartbreaking stories in the museum that it is difficult to identify just one as the marquee exhibit. Just go......just go and see it all for yourself. I promise you will not regret it.One note...when we were buying tickets from the museum web site, the one day we could attend was sold out. It was the only sellout showing for the next few weeks. Just my luck. I really wanted to go, so I contacted the museum directly and they were kind enough to add us to the list as overflow but told us we might have to stand during the intro video (which we didn't even have to do). Later, I noticed that one of the tour companies that appear on line was selling tickets for the date and time I wanted. DO NOT BUY FROM THEM. I personally watched a family of five be turned away even though they had a "ticket" for that day and time. The tour companies sell you tickets first and worry about space available later. This family was agreeable to coming back the following day, but I suspect others might not be able to be as flexible. Buy your tickets directly from the museum and no one else to prevent this from happening to you.Again, this is an incredible place to visit. Because of its content, it feels wrong characterizing it as an "attraction," but it is certainly a needed reminder for us all of the events of that day and the physical and spiritual recovery process that followed.

Never Forget becomes more than words at this special place. When you are planning a vacation and thinking about all the fun things you want to do choosing to visit a museum dedicated to the memory of one of the greatest tragedies the world has ever seen seems contradictory.I admit I was initially reluctant to visit this site but despite how difficult it is to experience there is no greater way to understand the gigantic impact this day had on the lives of so many.I will always remember what I saw at this museum and what I was allowed to touch. It becomes much more real when you see pieces of the twin towers in front of you than what you see on tv.I remember when I walked into the room my first thought was "wow this place is small" and I thought how am I gonna spend two hours in here.Well I did easily. I don't want to get into the details of what you see and hear but simply offer this suggestion prepare yourself to relive that day at a volume much louder than you lived it on 91101.Thank you to all who are responsible for this museums existence.

Interaction with History. Just seeing where the twin towers used to be in NY isn't enough. Visit this meusum and you'll get a front row seat to the after math of 9/11. This interactive workshop will help you to gain a better understanding of just how trying this was for all Americans whether you lived in NY or CA. The tour guides are very knowledgable and Mr. Suson really documented his time at Ground Zero in way for the world to understand.

A Must See for All!. This "GZMW" consisted of a short introductory film and an amazing audio tour of artifacts and pictures from the recovery effort during Ground Zero operations. This tour evoked emotions in me that I thought were long gone concerning this event. Had the opportunity to meet Gary Suson who was the official photographer of these operations. An up close and personal look not only into the rescue efforts, but also the lives and emotions of the rescue workers themselves.

Very moving experience. My husband and I attended the museum today. It was a very moving experience. It is a small and quaint museum but the impact is huge. The pictures Mr. Suson took and the artifacts he collected are stunning. The audio portion of the museum is narrated by Mr. Suson himself. He explains in detail who is in the picture or where the artifact is from. The museum shows a very personal side of the tragedy and those that were impacted the most by what occurred on that September morning. We were fortunate to meet Mr. Suson who was at the museum during our tour. He was kind and willing to talk to anyone who wanted to speak with him. We purchased a book and he graciously signed it for us. Thank you Mr. Suson for sharing your work and your experience of ground zero. We will never forget!

A New York must visit. This intimate and touching display of photos and artifacts from Ground Zero which records the events of 9/11 and the subsequent rescue efforts with sensitivity and respect is a must for any visitor to New York. Going along to the Ground Zero Workshop Museum really brings home the stark reality of 9/11 and the devastation that was cast upon such a powerful city. However, despite the sadness and unavoidable lump in the throat the display also demonstrates the hope, pride and strength of all New Yorkers.As a visitor to New York it is well worth taking time out from the hustle and bustle of midtown Manhattan and taking a quiet couple of hours to take stock of the effects of what happened on that fateful day.

A picture is worth a thousand words. Very well done. A tasteful and respectful memorial. Amazing artifacts and photos. I can't imagine the emotional strength it took to record those images! A must see on your Ground Zero pilgrimage to honor those that lost their life that day as well as those that have continued to struggle with the aftermath of that terible day. Thank you Gary Suson for helping us understand.

Not as good as I thought. This museum is small with an interesting range of pictures taking by Gary Suson documenting the FDNY tremendous efforts after this shocking event in 2001, he has narrated a commentary for the pictures & the artefacts he has on display. The entrance fee to the museum is $50 for two & if you buy Mr Susons book that is another $50. No mention is made of how much of the proceeds from the Museum are paid to the families of the 9/11 disaster. Visiting the museum is an emotional jourrney, I think Mr Suson should advertise how much of your entrance dollar is paid over to the survivors and their families. I feel there is too much made of the emotional element of the event and I find myself quite disappointed after my visit & I am not comfortable recommending that you visit

A very emotive experience. We visited the workshop museum last week and found the experience very emotive.  After the introduction video, you are given a personal head set which enables you to continue your "own tour at your own pace". For the next 90 minutes, you are left with your own thoughts. There is no need for conversation as the pictures say a thousand words.We booked our tickets on the day via our hotel, but we may have just been lucky. I would suggest booking your tickets on line with the workshop before you arrive in New York to ensure you don't miss out. The tours begin at 1100hrs & 1300hrs most days and cost $25 each per adult. There is not a lot to see around the workshop area, but we went into the nearby Chelsea market for a bite to eat as we were slightly early.We decided to get a cab afterwards to ground zero itself. The church opposite "the site" has an exhibition which is worth a visit. The official museum is due to open fully next year and is also worth a look as well whilst you are there. If you need any further information, please feel free to get in touch.

Well worth the time to explore. We chose this museum as part of our Explorer Pass package that we purchased during our recent trip to NYC. It is certainly off of the beaten path in the grand scheme, but easy enough to find based on the information in the Explorer Pass guide book.I went there with my wife my mother-in-law, and all three of us felt deeply moved by the pictures, descriptions, and artifacts that are part of the museum. The memories of that tragic day and subsequent months are shown in a way that you could never imagine.I feel that the Mr. Suson and he staff have done everything possible to educate all of us on the aftermath at Ground Zero. Everything is very well put together with the utmost respect of all parties in mind.We spent just over two hours going through all of the artifacts, and we were even lucky enough to meet Mr. Suson at the very end of our experience.I highly recommend you adding this museum to your next trip plans in NYC.

Makes you appreciate the courage commitment and dedication of all 911 rescuers.. This museum gives you an inside depth into the rescue and recovery process after the events of 9/11. You have the opportunity to spend as much time as you like looking at pictures and listening to recorded messages. You are allowed to take pictures!

Took my 10 year old. He was amazed and so was I. If you have one museum to visit while in NYC, this is it!. I took my 10 year old son as I wanted him to understand the tragedy of September 11th. He is mature for his age and we did a little research on that day before we went. The museum is in a small comfortable setting. I loved the audio tour....but it is not a usual audio tour. You walk around and look at the pictures in any order you please. If the picture is numbered 55 then push 55 and it tells about the picture. We were able to meet the photographer, Gary Susan and he was so nice to my son and signed pictured for us. This is one of the most fascinating museums I have ever seen. You would be doing yourself a great injustice if you miss this. It is a great way to honor our fallen Americans. Good job Mr. Suson. Thank you for the autographs and opening our eyes. It was a pleasure to meet you.

Amazing photos and artifacts, supplemented with audio narration and emotion. Excellent. Wonderful small museum, suitable for children and adults. Brings back the emotions of the event, and provides personal glimpses into the rescuers and the victims and their families....a very talented photographer put this together, and all proceeds go to families of the victims. Excellent overall

Do not leave New York City without a visit to Ground Zero Museum Workshop. We simply cannot forget what happened on September 11. As time passes we tend to forget the impact of those terrible hours and days. In his photographs Mr. Suson pays tribute to those who would not rest until their job was completed. Every inch of the museum is interesting, moving, well-planned, tasteful, comforting, thought-provoking. The staff members are unobtrusive, well-informed and empathetic, as this is an emotional experience. Please do not miss this...and, we will never forget.

Moving experience. A great small museum, and a very emotional experience with captures the mood of 9/11 perfectly. Even though it may have been a little hard to find, it was a fascinating experience. Excellent, friendly staff members.
Powerful and moving experience. This was one of the best tributes to the 9/11 ground zero rescue efforts. The artifacts are real. The pictures and the tour was great. I give it 5 stars

A Genuinely Moving Experience. This is a small and intimate museum, filled with artifacts that you can see up close. The photos are spectacular and emotional. Many of the artifacts can be held and examined closely. This museum is a little off the beaten path, but well worth the time and effort to go see. It will touch your heart.

MOVES YOU TO TEARS. I am a travel agent from Canada that took a tour group to this museum, and it truly moved all of us. When you walk into the room that has all the pictures and artifacts from the 911 tragedy you can feel the seriousness of the event. A hush came over the group that were there. The two ladies that did the presentation and answered questions were so well informed and treated the museum with unbelievable respect towards the event and the people that lost their lives.The pictures that Gary Marlon Suson took were so incredible and were done in such a way not to invade anyones "moment" and he gave dignity to the people who lost their lives.If you want to see a true picture of what happened that tragic day in New York this Museum should not be missed. You will feel the true emotions of that day by walking into this museum.
A must see. A very intimate, amazing, & emotional exhibit. I recommend everyone who visits New York City to visit this museum. Well worth the money.

An absolutely amazing and emotionally moving 'must see' attraction.. If you visit New York City and don't visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop, you have missed one of the best attractions. This small but moving exhibit is educational beyond imagination. The pictures and artifacts show you a side of 9/11 that you won't see anywhere else. It is full of 'Oh my goodness' moments. Don't miss it!!!!

AMAZING! a MUST see while in nyc.. Easily the smallest attraction I visited while in NYC, but hands down had the biggest impact and was one of the highlights of my trip. This museum is inspiring, and in such tradgedy restores your faith in humanity. This museum was very hands on and the self guided tour allowed you to spend as much time as you wanted at particular artifacts. This is something you cannot miss out on while in NYC.

Wow! the biggest little museum is just that!. We went because we thought we should and how glad we are that we did! The people running this are totally genuine, people who show true emotion and feelings for the loss suffered by so many people - they supply tissues and have even put chocolate in the restroom for a bit of comfort!The photos by Gary Suson are truly amazing, the photography is done tastfully with no images of the actual planes hitting or injured humans or animals but at the same time are moving and emotional. Luckily for us Mr Suson was there when we visited, still working. He is not only honoured to have been the only man who was allowed to take photos but the comentary he recorded for the displays was done with true dignity, feeling and respect. Mr Suson is the instrumentor behind this museum, after getting inspiration from the Anne Frank museum, he wanted to give the world the insight that that gave for the holocaust for 9/11. He most certainly succeeded.None of these people are glory seekers, they are all there because they care. This museum provides an insight to this terrible disaster for those personally affected and for those of us that weren't. It is a truly humbling experience and makes you open your eyes to what could happen and truly appreciate those you love.

glad we went. Much different than I expected. Very small and very moving and yet informative. We have 2 older teens and it was great for our family... not recommended for people with small kids. You get a set of good headphones and a remote control number panel to listen to the story behind each photo, item display so that you can at your own pace listen to the facts behind the pictures, etc. Excellent and convenient and not everyone in the way trying to look at the same thing. I was unsure since a family of 4 costs $108 for a couple hours, but was glad that we took the time and spent the money to view it.

A Gem of a Museum. We highly recommend this thoughtful and informative museum. Visiting from the UK we thought we had seen many news reports and could understand some of the magnitudeof 9/11. However, this museum gave us such a deeper insight into the tragedy of the event and the lasting effects of 9/11 on all those involved in the attack and its aftermath. It was very tastefully done and the audio guide made it personal and informative. The photography is excellent. Two hours went by quickly and we were very glad we had made the effort to visit.

Moving. I thorougly recommend this museum. As other reviewers have said, it is truely moving and found myself in tears at certain points. I was surprised by the effect it had on me. Definately make sure you check this one out when in the Big Apple. Extremely well done!

Very Interesting as well as emotional. My wife and I had only a limited amount of time when we went to the museum workshop. The presentation is very informative and the pictures taken by Gary Suson are unbelievable. But even better than the pictures which speak a thousand words are the stories behind these pictures. While the tour is 2hours in length, we were only able to be there 1hr, as this is not at ground zero but several blocks or a short subway ride away, and we wanted to see the actual site....hard to see anything or to understand with all the construction. At the museum you will understand and be enraged at the cause of this. Nothing could be truer than "NEVER FORGET'. If you are going to Ground Zero.....you must go to the Museum Workshop!

Your 1st stop. Make this your first stop to learn, see and hear about Ground Zero. A truly moving and powerful time in an intimate setting where you can feel the power of the photos as described by the photographer.

A must for all visitors to the city. A very moving experience, a must for all visitors to this great city.
This was definately one of the highlights of my trip. The curator of the museum managed to create an atmostphere that helped to paint a picture of what it must of been like during the aftermath of such a tragedy.
I would definately visit again .

Deeply moving and powerful museum. Dont miss it.. This is museum is a must see. The photos by Gary Marlon Suson capture the aftermath of 9/11 in an incrediblely moving way. After a brief film and introduction,the tour is conducted by "tourmates"-you pick the photo you are interested in and listen to the incredible story behind it. We stayed the whole 2 hours and,by chance, actually had the opportunity to meet Gary Marlon Suson himself. A quietly unassuming gent.

One of the best things about our trip to New York. This is the most intimate, personal, emotional, respectful museums I have ever visited.Fantastic indepth layout but still really considerate of victims and their families.You get a real insight into the events of September 11th and the devastation it caused.Appeals to everyone whether directly affected or not.Both guides were also excellent - informative but thoughtful

Emotionally sensitive approach to human tragedy.. The Ground Zero Museum provides a thoughtful balance between eye-witness accounts of the rescue teams, photographs of the aftermath, and, from the Towers themselves, flotsam and jetsam which have now taken on a significance far beyond their original purpose. With its focus on the specific and the individual, the museum handles this tragedy with a sensitivity to which we can all relate. Its universal themes of family, friendship, love, loss and the ties that bind provide a unique way of approaching the rescue immediately following the attack. It is by not addressing the larger question of "why", that visitors are left enuncumbered to consider the human dimension and by so doing, the loss is made even greater.

Amazing Museum! A Must-Do in NY. First of all, although the museum is very small comparing to the usual museums we go to, it is amzing and has enough pieces to fill a really big museum. It shows some amazing stories, and lets you understand the big story behind the events after 11/9. rather than telling the usual story about the terror attack. The two girls that guided us through the museum were great! They answered every one of our questions in a professional way, and also were very friendly and kind. I enjoyed every second of the museum, and I will recommend everyone to go and check out this wonderful museum!

highly recommended. At first we were surprised by the size of the museum-it is just 1 room, but the experience that we had was amazing. It was organized by Gary Marlon Suson- the official photographer of Ground zero site inspired by museum of Anne Frank in Amsterdam. We were shown a very touching movie, explanation was given about all exhibits and then we were given the headphones, so that we could listen to a short story behind each one of the exhibits: all sorts of things from the place of tragedy that were collected and photos that reflect the size of it. You can touch and feel all nearly all exhibits! Amazing experience, made me learn more about this tragic date, feel the grief of the american people and understand how much it means for the country and how it unites the nation.

Very moving audio and artifacts. Roughly 100 audio clips and many more photos from the official Ground Zero photographer. Also has many one of a kind artifacts recovered from site, including piece of AA plane.

A must see!. I've visited many nice museums in NYC and I have to say this was by far my favorite one!! There are many photos of 9/11 and you get to choose which ones you want to hear about (you get a headphone and a remote and just press the number of the photo).It was a really moving experience and I think everyone should see this. "Let's never forget."

Spectacular!. I was in New York on Monday October 11, 2010 on a day trip with a friend just to sight see and go to attractions. She actually found this museum online and thaught we would both be into it. I am a career firefighter and she is a paramedic. I am very into the service and this museum was one of the coolest, interesting, infomative places I have ever been.I will and would recommend anybody visiting New York to find this place. It is worth every penny and every minute of time. I learned soo much and was shocked about the story behind the pictures. It definately makes you think and for someone in emergency services makes you open your eyes even wider.The staff/tour guides were excellent!! I want to thank everyone for the opportunity to visit this museum. I will definately be back in the future. Again great job keep up the good work and stay safe out there!!Constantine D. SypsomosDeptford, New Jersey

Breath-takingly sad but well put together. Absolutely breath-taking. Arriving late (it is in an area we weren't overly familiar with) the two women working that day (a Sunday) were very helpful and understanding. After two very emotive videos and a powerful intro from one of the curators, we were handed our audio guides and headphones and left to wander around the gallery plugging in numbers relating to photos and artifacts. The photographers voice (Gary Marlon Suson) is used throughout the tour as he relates to each item, a very soothing voice good for storytelling I found it comforting.The raw emotion overpowered me at the end of my tour, seeing items such as a calendar, stopped clock and teddy bear it made it easy to relate personally to the tragedy. The layout was very fitting, softly lit and well spaced it was very respectful.We went that night to the world trade centre site which I saw back in 2006 before the new building work has started, and it was sad but interesting to be able to relate what happened to the towers.My advice would be take tissues, beware of the animal related stories and try to listen to as much info on as many items as possible. A very sad but fitting tribute to ensure we don't forget, and continue to support those affected by 9/11.

Must do while in New York. The ground zero museum workshop is small and that's why they limit the number of people per group so reservations are required. The pictures and the stories associated to them are a reminder of such a tragedy that day was. It is a very nice museum and the staff is very helpful at answering questions and telling stories. It is a must do when in New York.

The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a must see for you New York trip.. It was a bit unclear what we were going to see, but it was worth every moment. The audio tour really helped our 14 and 12 year old understand the seriousness and sadness of 9/11. What you'll see at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop is presented with sensitivity and respect towards the victims and their family members.

A must see in NYC. What an awesome museum!! My husband and I just spent the weekend in NYC and visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. It was a very emotional experience and one that I will never forget. It really put a face with 9/11. I would highly recommend taking time to visit this museum while in NYC. All proceeds go to benefit the victims of 9/11.
Moving. Tells the horrible story of what happened on 9/11. If you go to New York this is a must. Remember to reserve in advance.

A very sobering museum that is a New York must do.. I visited the museum on 9/11 with my sister and friend. Gary Marlon Suson was there and a couple of New York firefighters paid a visit while we were there. The museum although small and intimate is an invaluable record of the horrendous event and its impacts on the people affected by 9/11.It is not flashy but is all the better because it is honest. The staff there are superb and Mr Suson is a very brave man to continue to live his experiences from Ground Zero with dignity and passion.

Intimate, Poignant and Memorable. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop Tour is a different kind of museum. Enclosed in a second floor walk-up (elevator available), the artist has filled a room with exclusive photographs, and artifacts retrieved during the 8-month Recovery Period after the fall of the World Trade Center in September 11, 2001. Gary Marlon Suson was the only person authorized by the Uniformed Firefighters Association, the city firefighters' main union, to be present and take photographs of the Recovery. Gary's pictures are intimate, professional, private and personal. Gary was also allowed to collect a range of artifacts that would have been otherwise disposed of, that tell the tale of lives lived, and lives lost. To bring the pictures to life, visitors are provided an audio tour, where the artist provides his story about how the picture was taken, what was happening when the picture was taken, or a story around a particular artifact displayed. There's nothing not to like about the Museum. The room is intimate and comforting, providing an emotional haven.Photographs inside the museum are allowed, videos are not. Don't bring a lot of baggage with you inside the museum, there is just not a lot of room for large backpacks swinging around!Visitors are allowed to take full advantage of their two-hour timeslot, then are cleared out, to allow for the next group of visitors.

Sincere and Respectful. If you want to know what it was like at ground zero and wish to support charities for rescue workers and families, this is where you need to be. We lucked out and Gary Suson was there to sign one of a limited edition photography collection book "Requiem" for us. It is a beautiful and if you can get one of these books, definitely do, it's worth it. You meet at the building, go up to the exhibit room where you will find places to sit. Excellent footage and videos are shown for 15 minutes after a short introduction. You are given headphones for the audio tour and the photographer narrates each of the artifacts and you may move through them as you please until the end of the two-hour time block. It really is some fantastic photography to give you a sense of connection for this life-changing event.

Make the time to visit this museum. I planned my family's NY trip around entertainment and shopping but I wanted to take some time to reflect on the events of 9/11. After reading all the reviews on Trip Advisor I booked our tickets. Gary Suson managed to pack so much emotion into a very small space. I couldn't believe some of the artifacts that I was looking at, it was a surreal experience. The museum was tasteful, never exploiting the victims of 9/11 but instead putting a face to those who did their best to help in the aftermath. When you are in New York take the time to visit the Ground Zero Museum, you have to experience it for yourself.

Incredible. Word cannot describe this place. The stories, images and artefacts provide a unique insight into the clean of ground zero and the incredible human stories. I found myself getting choked up many times and at one point had to sit down due to the overwhelming emotion. The whole place is respectful to the victims of 9/11 and those who were there afterwards.Every visit to New York should include this workshop, it will profoundly change your understanding of what happened in 2001.
Touches the soul. An oasis of tranquility,where you can remember the events of that awful day,and the recovery period. Simple and intimate. Unmissable.
Must Do. This museum is AMAZING. It is very small but overwhelmingly powerful. Gary Suson has my utmost respect! There are not enough adjectives to describe his work.

Very moving experience. My wife and I both have fond memories of looking out from the observation platform atop the World Trade Center. And the memories of the towers coming down are still so fresh in our minds. So we decided to visit the museum and we're pleased to report that it didn't disappoint. It was oh so heart rending and moving and the organisers have done an excellent job to achieve this in such a small space. It's not open to the public so you do need to book the tour and allow 2 hours to do it justice.I hope now that New York does justice to the memory of the individuals lost and to the towers themselves when the memorial gardens and new World Trade Center open. And although the loss of so many firefighters in the atrocity was appalling - and this is the focus of the museum - I would hope that at some point there could be a wider focus in memory of the office workers, plane passengers and officers of the NYPD who were also taken away from their families at that time.In my view this was one of the highlights of our visit to NY and should be a must on any itinerary.

Ground Museum is a must. I visited The Ground Zero Museum on 8/19/10 with my 20 year old daughter and her friend from North Carolina. Both were young at the time of the attack and neither realized the enormity of the impact on those directly and indirectly affected by the tragedy. The visit was instrumental in educating them, as well as myself, in understanding what was involved in this clean up effort. The emotional toll and human effort was very well documented and sensitively presented. Without a doubt, emotional but so well presented I feel the museum is appropriate for young school children and a must for those who visit NYC. Thank you to the staff for their time answering questions and to Mr. Sousan for sharing his phenomenal work and presentation!
an amazing place !. amazing little museum that has so many unique pictures and artifacts
