What an insight. Me and my partner went to this tour thinking of what we have read, This is a remarkable insight into the recovey of 9/11 very moving and emotional will be refering this to my friends

This museum experience was the most intimate and personal one I have ever had at a museum. Heartbreakingly beautiful.. The museum is located in a small loft in the meatpacking district. At first glance, I thought we may be through the museum within a 1/2 hour because of it's size, but we were there for over two hours. Marlon Suson, the photographer, was even present for the tour. Each photograph and artificat has it's own story you get to listen to on your own headset. I think everyone was affected after leaving. The whole experience was an incredible reminder of 9/11 and I would highly recommend this museum to anyone. The big museums are not as personal. Will never forget!

Don't Miss It. If you have any interest at all in learning more about September 11th, 2001 you MUST SEE this interesting place. Though called a museum, it is the photographer's studio, really. Don't be put-off by the neighborhood it is in, it isn't all that desirable. However, the 100 photos and artifacts chosen to depict how the events of September 11th changed the people of our world are incredibly moving. The workshop is narrated by Mr. Suson himself and he brings honesty and understanding to the terrible events of that day and the recovery from it.You'll meet outside on the sidewalk and will be taken in by a host. A brief video will be played and you'll be invited to sit in comfy chairs to watch and listen. The remaining time is yours to go around to the exhibits. All are numbered and correspond to the narration on the audio tour. When we toured, I didn't want to miss a single exhibit!Our kids (10 and 13) also found the museum a great experience and were totally absorbed for our entire two hours there. I do wish we could have had another 15 minutes, as I felt a little bit rushed (however I was the last person done, so not sure what that reason was!!). We did start our visit about 5-10 minutes late due to the fact that we were waiting for some late-comers to arrive (they had two hosts working, so I would have thought one person could have waited for them and let the rest get started).Mr. Suson did come in during our time at the museum. He's very personable willing to visit. Rating our NYC visit, this museum was way moving and interesting compared to almost everything else!!!

A sensitive and educational experience. Recommended by someone who had been, we chose this over the one by Ground Zero. Based around Gary Suson's intimiate photographs of the recovery, the museum is a tiny yet highly informative exhibition. It is the size of an apartment and fits in about 30 people so makes this a very personal experience. I learnt alot about personal experiences and seeing artifacts recovered and the stories behind them made 9/11 more real for me.

Major highlight of my trip to NYC. This museum is well worth the time and money spent to see it. The images and stories are touching beyond words. There is no other venue that offers this amount of an up close and personal account of the recovery effort at Ground Zero. I highly recommend this museum!!! I would go again...

Just GO. A neccessary stop on your NYC trip.. Of all the attractions in NYC that I visited, this was by far the most memorable.With a small group of 20, you are lead to the main photographer (also NYC firefighter) of 9/11 - Ground Zero's old apartment, where he shot many of the photos seen.There are many photos, artifacts from the recovery, and all this is mostly a self-guided audio tour. I cried, I laughed, and saw every other participant in my group do the same.It really put things into perspective, and was done with extreme dignity and respect for those lost, and who sacrificed everything in the event.

A must see! This will leave a lasting impression.. We were surprised to find the location of this museum with so few people, dont be put off by the exterior, inside is an oasis.Someone meets you at the entrance of an old building and takes you up to the 2nd floor where there is a wonderfully light and tastefully furnished room - no more than about 15/18 people- with numbered photos and artefacts which you can listen to their history on the headsets provided after a brief presentation followed by a film by the sole official photographer of the recovery following the fall of the two towers. Definitely allow 2 hours. Moving and so glad we did this. I went with my 16 year old daughter who wasm't initially keen but it really gripped her and was so grateful to have gone. Do this before visiting the site which is a few stops away on the subway. You must book before you go. Stop for lunch at the nearby Chelsea Market building, also worth seeing.

Don't miss it!. Very small and initmate and we easily spent 2 hours here. My 10 year old was very moved, as I explained to him he might be. He didn't think he would be, and was surprised when he was moved to tears by some of the photos. You get your own earphones and the photographer, Gary, narrarates each photo for you. You go at your own pace and in any order. You are able to touch a few things and everything is done very tastefully. We even had the wonderful opportunity to meet Gary and shake his hand and thank him for his wonderful work and for sharing it with us in such an amazing way. You must go here and experience this museum...the best, biggest, little museum.

amazing experience. you wonder where you are when you pull up outside this obscure building in Chelsea and then wonder how you are going to spend 2 hours in what seems like a very small room but fill it we did and some! This museum represents a very personnel experience of the official photographer to the site for 2 years as clearing the site and the search for remains took place, it avoids the actual event and concentrates on what it was like to work on the site during 2000-2002, my 2 teenagers did not mutter a word or ask to leave once, a very humbling and strong reminder of 9/11. Highly recommend.

Touching. I really didn't know what to expect when we signed up to go to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I was amazed by all of the pictures and artifacts on display. Thank you FDNY for having Gary capture this important part of history for everyone to enjoy.

If you do nothing else in NYC. do this!. Visited this with my partner and 10 year old son in March. Tastefully created and respectful of those who were lost and their loved ones. Only a tiny room but the contents kept us there for 2 hours. Well recommended!

A look at the tragic events of 9/11 from an up-close/revealing perspective. . .. My wife and I loved this museum. The events that took place on 9/11 should never be forgotten. This museum helps capture not only graphical pictures of the aftermath but also the emotions and heroism of those who experienced it. If visiting New York City, I definitely recommend touring this museum.

This museum tour left me speechless. I bought tickets for this museum not knowing what to expect. I knew it would be touching and emotional, but I never imagined just how memorable and life-changing this experience would be. I was in New York City for only three days, but I'm so glad I made time for this tour. The photographs taken and displayed by Gary Marlon Suson capture so much emotion that visitors leave the museum with a better understanding of 9/11, a deeper sympathy for the victims' families, and an immense respect for all those who dedicated themselves wholeheartedly to the recovery effort. We all remember where we were and what we were doing that somber 9/11 day, and the museum transports us artfully and respectfully back to that moment.Thank you to Mr. Suson and to the wonderful tour guides for providing a healing environment for families as well as for all those who were impacted by this inhumane tragedy. The museum is a must-see not only for all Americans but for tourists from the world over.

amazing amounts of compassion. This museum was for sure a must see while in New York . It really gives you a better understanding of that terrible event in our countrys history. Gary did a great job getting the museum together. His work is totally noticable. everyone at the museum was very knowledgable and willing to answer questions. This museum was truely breath taking.

A great place for those who were not there, to experience 9/11. Having lived far away from New York City on 9/11, I needed to be a part of what the city experienced on that day. This one room exhibit of pictures and artifacts combined with respectful set up by the guides and terrific audio to explain what is being displayed and it's significance really helped me to process this horrendous event in history. The two hour time frame is perfect for quiet contemplation and learning. Cameras are allowed. A moving experience...too good to miss.

Simply Outstanding. If somebody would have told me this was a one room museum I probably would not have gone. That would have been a huge mistake. This is a must see "attraction" while in NYC. The staff is incredibly friendly and knowledgeable. The DVD shown is very moving and the displays could not have been done better. While a bit cumbersome to schedule your time to go to the museum, I now understand why it is done the way it is. It makes the experience much more meaningful to share the time with only a small group of people.

A moving experience. The museum is small and cozy but packed with photographs and artifacts. The collection and audio tour are very moving and the atmosphere is respectful. It's well worth a visit to the museum before going to the ground zero site.

A Very Moving Experience, Highlight of our trip to NYC.. We are a family with 2 teenagers who found this small museum to be the highlight of our 4 day trip to NYC. The photos, artifacts, and stories captured by Mr. Suson will remain with us forever. It was a healing experience in many ways for my husband, a fellow firefighter who may not have lost anyone he personally knew, but lost "brothers" in his heart. Each item has a story and it felt very personal with the unique way it is presented listening through the headsets. I highly recommend this tour...and we must never forget 9/11.
Do not miss if you're planning a trip to New York. This was wonderful, respectfully done exhibit. It's a very emotional two hours but something every American should experience.

Very Humbling. I would recommend this museum to anyone visiting NYC. It was a moving experience to see the pictures and many of the artifacts discovered at ground zero. This is now a part of American History and no one should ever forget.

Small, unassuming, off the beaten track - but SO moving. My boyfriend and I booked a trip to the workshop before we went to NY and when I got there I was a little perplexed by why it was not near to Ground Zero.Max group size of 24 this is well worth a visit. The museum workshop is set in a small studio and is a very tasteful collection of artifacts and photos from the recovery operation at Ground Zero. Set up by the only official photographer for GZ, this gallery is really moving. After a small introduction and video each visitor is given a headset and hand held device. As you move through the series of artifacts and photo's each numbered, you can listen to descriptions, thoughts on each piece by simply putting in the number.I personally found this a very moving visit which has helped me know more about the historic events of 9/11. It doesn't contain any footage or photo's of the attacks nor does it feature any photo's of victims at the site.

This museum honors the victims and heroes of 9-11. A must see!!!. The tour includes an audio tour with the photographer, Gary Suson, who was with the fireman in the cleanup of 9-11. Mr. Suson retells the moments and gives insight into the people of 9-11. The photographs honor everyone involved, and you don't see people jumping from the buildings. Artifacts from 9-11 are present. The information presented in this tour is accurate and free from political bias unlike Annie's from Uncle Sam's Tours. Proceeds from this museum benefit the firemen's families who were victims of 9-11.

Simply Amazing. This is not your typical boring museum where you just look at a bunch of pictures, it is an immersed experience. The museum is filled with amazing artifacts from 9/11 and ton of images defiantly worth a thousand words. This museum really inspired me and helped me fell the emotions felt by the fireman during the recovery period. I even got to met Garry Suson while I was there and he is a very down to earth and caring guy. Plus the money goes to 9/11 funds. So get your tickets right now.

A highlight of our trip!. The photos are absolutely stunning and, coupled with Gary Suson's poignant narration, create a very moving and meaningful experience. The intimate size of the museum also allowed our daughter who has autism to fully participate in the experience. It went very well and our family will never forget our time there.

AMAZING photos and artifacts that capture 9/11 and how America came together after this tragedy.. This workshop on 14th st at 5th ave was the most amazing thing i have been to. It truly is a little museum with a big impact. The pictures and artifacts are truly magnificent! Gary Suson is an amazing photographer!. He captured the love that went into looking for those lost in 9/11. There are real radio calls and touching stories of those looking for loved ones and the NYPD, FDNY and other people and dogs that helped in the recovery. The things you will see in this museum can't be seen anywhere else. This is a MUST SEE and definitely bring a camera. It is a nonprofit workshop benefitting different charities.

Very good, informative and sad.... I enjoyed these 2 hours very much. It is such a tragedy but I think we all need to be reminded of what the World has become. The pictures and stories are very well done.

An amazing tribute to the human spirit!. Our family visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop on our recent visit to New York city. I have to say that this was my favorite museum experience. We went to the Museum of Natural History, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the MOMA. Still this one room museum on the second floor of a plain building in the meatpacking district of New York was the best. A personal glimpse into the events on Sept 11, 2001, Gary Suson's photographs captured the emotion and enormity of that day that will never be forgotten. Make sure you book well in advance, this workshop is well worth your time. Even after almost 9 years the artifacts, audio recordings and photographs will take you back to that day in September.

Must see - - Ground Zero Museum. On our recent trip to NYC, we went to see Gary Susson's pictoral museum of the Ground Zero recovery efforts. It was an absolutely moving experience that focuses on the extraordinary human efforts behind the horror of 9/11. This was a wonderful learning experience for my teenagers because it shows the real story of humanity behind this TRAGIC event. Gary Susson's photos and narrations focus not on the "gory details" but rather the uplifting human stories of the professionals and volunteers who worked tirelessly in the face of one of nations worst tragedies. Well worth the nominal entrance fee in a city where you pay $25 for a hamburger!!

Very well done!. My family and I just attended this workshop, this morning. We decided to book this event on our trip to NYC b/c of the positive reviews here. It was all very well-organized and respectful. No images of the planes striking the towers were shown b/c the guide said it would not be healing in any way. We found out, this morning, that a camera crew from CNN would be filming inside the museum, today. Every attendee is given a set of headphones and a "remote control". The guide explains what you will be doing and that expressing emotion is perfectly okay. A video segment is shown with images and audio for about 10 minutes. After that, you are free to move about the room to view photos and artifacts while listening to information on your headset. You may choose what to listen to and type in the number on your remote for that display. You go at your own pace and multiple people may be listening to the same display at the same time. There were kids in attendance, today, also. It was not meant to be scary in any way. You may take photographs of everything except for a piece of one of the planes (out of respect). The experience is very personal b/c the museum is very small. You have about 2 hrs for the whole experience and may purchase postcards, the photographer's hardcover book, or other items. There is a bathroom available and some chocolates, if you need a natural "anti-depressant". The experience is very educational and shows real artifacts found at Ground Zero. A few artifacts are passed around. The exhibit even pays respect to the rescue dogs. I purchased the book and some postcards to frame in my home. The photographer, Gary Sussan, was the only official photographer allowed to stay at Ground Zero during the recovery efforts. You may not have seen most of these images and artifacts, before. Also, there are no images of bodies, so the experience is not gory or shocking in that way. It was a very moving experience.

Deeply Moving. A sensitive and respectful tribute to those who lost their lives that day. New York was on my list of travels to pay my respects to the victims of 9/11 9 years after that horrendous day, as it altered the course of many lives worldwide, mine included. Visiting this Museum enabled me to do just that.

Insight from Someone who really had intimate experience with 9-11. We have all either been directly touched by 9-11 or have grieved for those who have. This small one room museum is full of intimate photos and objects with a moving audio that you control as you walk from item to item. It helped me to have the Gary Suson's comments from his personal observations and better understand. It again renewed my admiration and compassion for those who were so intimately involved in loss, rescue and continue to clean up the aftermath. God bless these people and it's worth a detour to this museum. We visited the Memorial next to ground zero and walked it's audio tour and also visited the small Trinity church that houses so many momentos.

This museum is an awesome tribute to the workers that gave their life to save others.. The is an experience that I will remember for the rest of my life. My family - wife and children ages 20,17,and 15 were moved by the presentation. Marlon Suson did a tremendous job capturing the effort, heartache, and tragedy that surrounded ground zero. If you want to get a true perspective of 911 make this one of your stops when visiting NY.

Thought provoking and well worthwhile. We would highly recommend this workshop to anybody with an interest in the impact of the events during and after 9/11; in many ways it is better than visiting the site itself, although you should do both. It wouldn't be right to say that we enjoyed it, because that is the wrong word to describe the emotion, but it was emotional and, I suspose, inspiring. I suspect more for Americans of any belief, who can take pride in the selflessness of their fire fighters, police and others who worked so hard after the event. For everyone else, it was life-affirming to see what people will do to help others. I don't think it is suitable for young children, although there were young children there who were no trouble and the staff entertained well, they were just bored. Do go and make your own minds up about it.

An amazing look at Ground Zero through the eyes of the official Ground Zero photographer. Gary Suson, the owner of this museum and official Ground Zero photographer, takes it's visitors back to 9-11 and captures the devastation and emotion through his camera lens. The artifacts and photographs on dispaly at this museum give you a sense of what it must have been like to be "in the hole" as he calls it. You experience a piece of the raw emotion of being at ground zero. Each photograph and artifact is explained by Suson through a pre-recorded audio device you receive when you walk in. You will have time to find out more about whatever picture or artifact of interest. You will never forget 9-11 or your experience at this museum once you visit. Expect to spend about 2 hours taking in all the pictures, artifacts and information provided. It's a must see!

Intimate and intensive.. I honestly did not know what to expect when I made the Ground Zero Museum part of our City Explorer Custom Pass selections - it was my boyfriend's idea to include it.The museum is located in the old meatpacking district, now a an epicenter of vanguard design and fashion - it shares the building with various artists/designers studios.We were met downstairs in front of the building by the museum's tour guides. Once upstairs we were shown into an area no bigger than 40 x 30 -the museum is tiny! Yet it became immediately apparent that the size is kept small on purpose as it creates an intimate experience. After receiving our headsets and electronic tour guides, the tour started with two videos about the curator and photographer Gary Marlon Suson, whose work is displayed on the walls of the space. Annie our tour guide let us know in advance that getting emotional was perfectly alright.Well, we all did, and in the almost two and half hours we spent in there we all experienced the same terrible frustration and loss of nine years ago, and shared the ongoing anger and sadness that this act of violence continues to weigh on the citizens of NYC: one by one these fearless rescuers are succumbing to cancers and diseases because of ground zero's pollution. We were fortunate to meet Mr. Suson in person, and can honestly tell you we shook hands with a hero. His dedication to preserving the courageous rescue efforts at ground zero has brought us intimately close to their stories of loss, sacrifice and miracles.

if you visit 1 museum on your trip to nyc- make it this one. a personal and touching experience that encapsulates the tradegy of 9/11 whilst highlighting the love and passion demostrated in repsonse. this museum is a unique gem. it is a must if you want to honour the memory of everyone the world lost that sad day and get a sense of what ncy battled with in the months after the attacks. thank you gary for showing us all the hard work and determination that went in to the rescue effort in new yor long after the tv cameras had left. we are so pleased to have met you and been able to witness your portrait of the lost and heros of 9/11. and thank you annie for you soft kind words whilst we stepped gary's time capsule.

So we never forget .... This museum captures much of the emotion and horror of 9/11, without the media hype. The photos taken by Gary Suson deserve to be seen. From the moment youenter this small photo-museum, you know you are reviewing hallowed ground. The audio-tape descriptions by Mr. Suson are invaluable .... they set the mood for each image. The entire experience is done with what I would call a "light touch." Themuseum guides don't dwell on the terrorists ---- but focus on the heros who arrivedin the following weeks. It's a memorial and a museum, done with real sensitivity.

Most moving experience of my life.. My most memorable part of my visit to NYC. Respectful, valuable, priceless. God bless all of you involved in this project for doing it. Much needed attraction if I can use that word. A must for everyone to visit.

A memorable, emotional and thought provoking expereince. This museum didn't even feature in our NY city guide, it was only via word of mouth that we found out about it and I would say it was the most worthwhile thing I did whilst in New York.The museum is very intimate and the limited number of you there at one time really adding to the experience. Centred in the meat packing district, Gary Suson has created a homage to those killed on September 11th 2001 at the World Trade Centre site. Other than one picture of the south tower collapsing on the morning everything else in the museum is based on the clear up operation and the search for survivours and bodies amongst the wreckage. Being the only photographer allowed onto ground zero after the third week from the collapse - this is a very unique insight into a world many of us would never have seen.There is a very informative audio guide, spoken by the photographer himself, for all the pictures and some of the objects to which recounts a story of the time the picture was taken or details behind the object. You can listen to as many or as few of these as you feel although having listened to all of them myself, I would recommend taking the time and listening to each story.We met Gary at the end of our time there, he was a very down to earth and friendly man, giving us tips on dining and other places to go and see! He took the pictures and set up this museum, but it is all charity based work he does here for the NY firemen and women and survivors and children of 9/11.Overall I would say this was by far the best day in New York at any museum. It not only gave me a better understanding of 9/11 but also made me realise the impact of this on New York but also the world as a whole - after all we did enter into a war which still rages on today because of it.

Very moving presentation and collection of artifacts and photographs. On our arrival and entry our two museum employee hostesses were very enthusiastic and friendly. The museum itself only allows up to 24 people for a two hour session. This setting allows for a very respectful time to reflect on the events that happened in our Country on 9/11/01. After the initial presentation you move around the room at your own pace using the provided headsets for the exhibits. There are items to touch, some to see and more to reflect on in the very peaceful one room workshop. There is nothing graphic shown and no need for it here. The simple and common items recovered and collected tell a much better story. Mr. Suson's photographs show complete respect for the families and pay tribute to the members of the recovery efforts.

Intimate Experience. Gary Suson did more than an excellent job in making real to the rest of the world the cruel reality of the terrorist attack on America on that awful morning of September 11. His images are very human, and the museum presents them and the rest of the artifacts in a respectful but realistic way. I recommend everyone to visit and sponsor this place. We should never forget!

Exceeded my expectations by a mile.. Visited in early June 2010. I expected a huge museum but it is one room manned by two very nice girls who do pre-booked tours. Luckily I was in time for the last that day which started at 1pm. After an introduction by one of the guides who explained that the museum was private and established by the NY Fire Department, we watched a video and could then wander around the exhibits with an audio feed which explained each of the numbered items. There are many photos. In fact the museum focuses on the work of Gary Marlon Suson, the only photographer allowed on site to record the recovery phase to which this museum is devoted. Gary narrates the audio feed and his descriptions and explanations of the items and the background to his photos is often wrenching and always fascinating. I did not expect to learn so much or be so moved. There are items you can handle and you can ask any question. Many victim's families have visited and their responses form part of the narrative. As the room is so small and the tour groups need to be small as a result, this is an exceptionally intimate experience. I cannot recommend it highly enough. It helped me as an Australian to better understand the impact of 9/11 the people of New York. I must admit to thinking at times that they were making too big a deal of it, given that so many other countries endure worse tragedies routinely. In fact, the response of the city to this event is an inspiration.

Excellent experience that will leave you with a greater appreciation for the recovery and heartache after 9/11.. Gary Suson has captured the sights and emotions of the Ground Zero clean-up and recovery better than words could ever express. The photos and items recovered from the site along with the stories behind them were truly remarkable and would move anyone to sadness and tears for the families and friends of loved ones lost on 9/11. The museum is deceiving at first because of it's size, but I got more out of the experience than any other museum or tour that I have ever been on. This is a must see if you are visiting New York and I commend Mr. Suson for his dedication to the workers at Ground Zero and the City of New York. May we never forget!

Breathtaking. I had goosebumps the entire time. We were lucky enough to have Mr Suson there and speak for a few minutes.. his work is just amazing and he did an excellent job capturing emotion in his photos. This is a must-see for any trip to NYC!! But be prepared to get a little emotional..

Very emotional and respectful presentation that we will will never forget. My wife and I visited this museum and I must say it was the most important day we had on our visit to Manhattan. The photos and narrations that the officially appointed photographer Gary Marlon Suson are amazing, emotional and compelling. We were luck enough to meet Gary that day and after the visit we both were glad the FDNY picked the right person to do this very important job . We were able to better understand just how hard all the people involved worked to give the famlilies some closure.
very emotional. If you want to get a feeling of what NYC felt like when Sept 11 happened - go to this museum. It brings everything flooding back. A very emotional experience.

The biggest small museum in New York. Not knowing what to expect and wanting an understanding of what happened during and after the period of time of 9/11, this was a perfect collection of artifacts and photography from the man officially named as what i would call 'the memory collector' (Gary Marlon Suson) for you google lovers. This commercial space is located in the meat packing district (which is perfect as its next to some great designer stores, around the corner from Hogs and Heifers - the bar used in the movie Coyote Ugly and a 2 min walk away from Chelsea Market which is full of bakeries and places to eat/drink) The room is bright, welcoming and full of wonderful unique photography and artifacts - from a clock stuck on the time of day to a very rare thick sheet of glass, each photo/item has a number next to it, after the introduction DVD and an explanation of how the interactive room works you are left to your own devices to listen to the story behind each item, there are some amazing stories and simply stunning photographs that you simply need to see. I truely believe this is a must for anyone who wants a visual and audio experience of the events on the day and the cleanup operation that followed 9/11. Thankyou so much.

Great Experience!. We experienced a very high level of customer service at the museum workshop. The photos are extraordinary, and very respectful of both the 9/11 victims and recovery workers. The technical equipment used for the self guided tour is very high quality and easy to use.
Ground Zero must do.... if / when you visit NYC. The pictures and artifacts are amazing and a reality check to the world today. Will be amazing when its finished.

Something everyone should experience. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a place that everyone should visit if they get the chance. The photographs, memorobilia, and stories create such strong emotions that I believe that anyone who visits will share. It is truly an amazing and awe inspiring experience. My entire group will recommend the museum to anyone for years to come and we will "never forget." My only complaint is that I wish we had more time in the museum than just 2 hours because I feel that I could have spent another 2 hours and still have been entertained, for lack of a better word, the entire time.

Ground Zerp Museum - A Must Visit. My wife and I were in New York City recently and visited the Ground Zero Museum. It was very moving and interesting. We believe that everyone who has a chance should take the time to visit this museum. The artifacts and especially the video makes this a very emotional expierence. Mr. Suson, the photographer and creator of the museum, happened to be there during our visit and gave us better insite into the aftermath of that terrible day. We were pleased to learn that part of the cost of our admittance goes into a fund for the families of the thousands of innocent people who were murdered on 9/11.

This is a wonderful museum that you can feel up close and personal with.. The photographs that Gary Suson took of the 9/11 tragedy are so real and come to life in this museum. During this museum you listen to Gary Suson's voice as he describes each photo and the reason he took the photo.

Inspiring, Heartfelt, Deeply Personal. My wife, recent college grad daughter and I visited the Ground Zero Museum and found it to be one of many highlights of our first ever trip to New York City. Small but mighty is the best way to put this intense museum that captures the real heart of those who participated in the post-tragedy recovery. The audio tour format was nice because it allows one to explore each of the many photos and artifacts in the museum. We highly recommend this tour.
Incredible experience.. I defy anyone to visit this museum and take the tour and have dry eyes at the end of it.A testament to the city and the heroism of its population.Awe-inspiring.

Felt like you were there!. This workshop was fantastic! At first we weren't sure as it was away from Ground Zero itself and we made it to our destination but had to wait til minutes before it started til someone came out to brief us on what was to happen. About 20 people went up to the second floor "gallery" or sorts and were given headsets to listen to videos that they played of original radio conversations had on Sept. ll, 2001. Then we got to walk around the room and key in the number next to each photograph or exhibit into our personal device and heard the story behind the photo or exhibit as relayed by Gary Marlon Suson, the only photographer allowed at Ground Zero during recovery operations. The artifacts were magnificent from glass from one of the top windows of the Twin Towers (three inches thick) to a clock found stopped at the precise time the bldg. fell. It is a two hour tour and it was a quiet, respectful place. One of the highlights of our trip. At the end, you feel like you were there and experienced a lot of what went on. You certainly felt like you had a glimpse into the lives of the families left behind and the rescue crews and what they went through following that tragedy.

A MUST SEE IN NY. We weren't sure what to expect but had read the great reviews on trip advisor so trusted that the tour would be good. We were not disappointed!! We were lucky enough to have Gary and Sean (retired FDNY chief) to take our questions also. This museum left a lasting memory with us and we will highly recommend it to anyone.

not to miss!!!. I spend a lot of time traveling to NYC with friends & family, and have to say that this is one of my favorite things to do. Don't let the small space fool you...you will spend up to 2 hrs. pouring over artifacts & pictures. The pictures & tributes are tastefully done-moving stories highlighting the heroic efforts of the men & women who helped with the recovery of victims. It gave me peace, admist the violence & destruction and gave us a sense of hope and brotherhood.

A very moving exhibit.....but a little off in a way...... I guess I am glad we went to this Museum - we had high expectations after reading all of these reviews. I am glad that this museum exists - it has important artifacts and photographs. I don't know how anyone could leave this workshop without having shed a tear or many. I am grateful that Ms. Susson has made these things available to the public - but we got the impression that he feels that he is a celebrity because of his access - he sells his autographs - and although the room is small - a great deal of precious space is used to flog a variety of items that he has signed. It was a little off-putting. The audio that accompanies each display is very good - but there are times when he makes it a bit too much about him, you know what I mean? We were a litte put off as well by the number of religious symbols and references - as this is not a church musuem and religion, (or lack thereof) is a very personal thing - and which certainly gives comfort to some people - this need, want or belief in it should not be assumed. He really does try to honour those who work personally affected on 9-11 - and this is a good thing. It appears his ego got in the way a few times - but maybe we would all be like that. Maybe celebrity gets to everyone if they are interviewed enough times.The guide made a few errors. She said "St. Peter's Chapel" instead of "St. Paul's Chapel" and there were a few other inconsistencies - however she was pretty good overall.I was glad to have a reason to explore the meatpacking district - but I don't believe I would go to this workshop again or

Moving experience with one small exception. We made a special trip to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop after reading glowing reviews. We expected the small room with audio descriptions of the individuals at Ground Zero and artifacts from the World Trade Center destruction of 9/11. We read about how Gary Suson had access to the site during the recovery and cleanup operations. We especially expected a very moving experience and we got one. There was only one distraction during the 2 hours we spent there. Instead of stepping back and letting Ground Zero be the center of the story, it often seemed like Gary Suson was the center of the story. The pictures where he just described the events (such as the search dogs or the 2 firefighters looking for their brother) nearly brought tears but the scene with a man praying was more described as how lucky Gary was to be able to "fire off a few pictures" and catch a good pic rather than truly try to capture the emotion of the moment; or how dangerous it was for him to be walking backwards on the rubble while getting a great picture which seemed to trivialize the fact that the men walking in front of him were carrying a dead victim; or how this picture or that picture is so famous. I really admire the hours he put in and the emotion he captured. But in this setting I do not want to hear about being in the right position or luckily avoiding debris hitting you and let the enormity of the event reveal itself unencombered. That being said, I would recommend this to everyone. Holding a piece of metal from the debris or especially for me, seeing a piece of the airplane that hit the building will bring home the events of 9/11 in a tangible way.

Well worth the time & money. This is such a moving and special exhibit to be a part of...yes, the price seems a bit steep..but after 3 days of doing several other tours - it was well worth the price. This is the attraction you will keep talking about when you get home. When you go to the actual site it is so sad that there is no real tribute or special place of observance after almost 10 years. Go to this museum and you will feel so proud of the rescue workers and all involved in the recovery and clean-up. Plus, the location is really cool - Chelsea is a great neighborhood that we wouldnt have seen if we didnt go on this tour!
Very moving and very interesting.... Really moving, interesting exhibit. The room was smaller then I expected, but the photos and artifacts were very moving. Highly recommend to see it

A moving, important tribute and reminder.... Others previous reviews have provided accurate detail about the tiny size and giant heart of this important gallery/tribute, so I'll try not to repeat. Suffice it to say, the raves are well-deserved and if you are disappointed going to Ground Zero and finding very little there at present (other than St. Paul's), please don't miss this experience. The staff are kind and professional and set just the right tone. This is an intimate, personal experience and the set-your-own pace and casual seating throughout allow each visitor to have a very unique experience. Worth the money. An easy walk from the subway stop. A nice area. One of the highlights of my 5 days in NYC.

When you first walk into the tiny.... When you first walk into the tiny appartment the first thoughtcthat goes though my mind is how can we spend two hours in here? Well that question was quickly answeredAll the photographs and audio descriptions were great. The photographer, Gary Suson was there and it was cool to meet Him. The musuem was laid out very well and very interesting. It is kind of far from ground zero, but a very short subway ride from ground zero to the musuem. It was great, however not appropriate for young children because they will get very bored and not truly understand the photographs.

Awesome!! Great job!!!! Well worth the $$. OK, I have to admit when we arrived at the museum, my first thought was "oh my gosh, I paid this much money for this little museum?" BUT . . . it was awesome and VERY well worth the money. Mr. Suson was actually at the museum the day we went, introduced the museum, and was available to sign his book. He has taken an aw inspiring timeframe in his life (and ours), and made it come to life for each and every person. His work is exceptional, and I would consider myself very critical when it comes to spending my hard earned money. Mr. Suson, you and your staff are doing an excellent job and should be making every person touched personally or otherwise, very proud! GREAT JOB!!!! EXCELLENT WORK!!! SPEND YOUR MONEY TO SEE THIS MUSEUM!! I would/will return for another viewing.

Humbling Experience. This Museum is not at Ground Zero and not for young children. It is situated in the meatpacking district.We were not sure what to expect but all I can say it was a fantastic experience and strong emotions were present throughout. The photographs and the relics told the horrific story of this awful day and the days after. The stories of brothers searching and people pulling together.We both felt very humbled and it was an experience that you cannot put into words. Do visit and experience this Museum its not macabre it is a positive experience of comradeship and admiration for all those who were part of this awful event.

A definite "must see". This poignant and thought-provoking museum can be a little hard to find. But do read the instructions on its location as it clearly states that it is NOT near Ground Zero. The museum's creator, Gary Marlon Suson, was the only photographer allowed 24/7, go anywhere access to the site following the disaster on 9/11 as it is now called. If you are looking for the sensational or even an explanation, then you will be disappointed, for this museum is dedicated to the memory of thoise who lost their lives that terrible day and those who toiled long and hard in the days, weeks and months following. The photographs and exhibits are thought-provoking and a poignant reminder of that awful event. Each exhibit/photograph is accompanied by a number and the explanation of it is then able to be heard in the recorded audio guide provided. Some may consider it morbid, but that is the one thing it is not. Do go and see it, you will not be disappointed.

A beautiful tribute to the Americans who lost their lives on 9/11. Gary captured the human side of this horrific event. Every photo, artifact and story brought the viewer closer to the connection to the real people who died, and those who worked to bring about some relief and closure to their families. Although the most horrific event in modern times, this attraction does not dwell on the horror or the terror of the event, rather the amazing events that followed. A must see for NYC tourists.

Breathtaking!. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is a must see on your next visit to the city. We left with a new understanding and persective of what actually took place in the long months following the attacks. The photos and stories are very touching, and make you feel very proud to be an American.

Moving and emotional experience. We were not sure what to expect, but this experience exceeded our expectations. The location is small, but in no way feels tight as you explore the many images and artifacts in a well controlled environment. The stories come from a different perspective - those of the men and women who dutifully and respectfully conducted the horrific task of recovery in the weeks and months following the attacks. Mr. Sousann happened to be at the museum during our session and his insights were memorable and heartbreaking. You cannot help but be emotionally changed for participating in this experience.

More than just pictures. I was very happy with my experience at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I booked my ticket online after reading other Tripadvisor reviews. First, it is a VERY small space but don't let the small size fool you. There is an abundance of items to review and most of the items have audio commentary available. In the 2 hours I was there, I was not able to listen to all the audio commentary available. The photos and artifacts are very well presented and tactfully handled. But the best part is the audio commentary as it really helped me connect to the images and items at the Museum to personal stories of victims and rescuers. I followed my visit by a quick subway train down to St. Paul's Church near the World Trade Center site which turned out to be a perfect combination.

Speechless..... Anyone who knew the exact place where they were on that fateful morning of 9/11 or for those that have forgotten, should come to this tiny museum that speaks greatly on the hope, determination, honor, sadness, anger, and love that was experienced by those who were involved in the recovery period post 9/11. Mr. Suson's pictures go beyond what words can describe. You leave the museum never thinking of that day the way you did when you first walked in. Mr. Suson not only has a story behind every picture he has in his museum, he has collected artifacts from Ground Zero that are on display. Unlike other museums you are able to hold certain artifacts which makes your experience there even more personal.Before going to Ground Zero, I would highly recommend going to this museum because your experience just won't be the same.

Rivetting,sites and sounds of a Brotherhood. My wife and I and 2 friends went to see the museum on 12/30/09 not knowing what to expect. We spent almost 2 hours in the museum. The waythis was presented allowed me to feel and see the images and artifacts on a personal level. I felt like I was in the museum by myself. With the individual headsets for listening to the recordings,I could immerse myself in each picture and artifact. I felt like i was there with my brother firefighters. Gary Suson was able to capture the essence of the moment. He was able to capture the emotions and feelings in pictures and with sound. It was a gret honor meeting Gary in person and expressing my feelings in person. Thank you, Fire LT.,Paramedic, Dusty Hoffman ( retired).You can take as many still photos as you want ,no video.There are only 20 visitors at a time and you are not rushed.You are able to touch some of the artifacts and come close to many more that very few people are able to do. You are scheduled for a 2 hours period if you want to take that long,The room is small but filled with so much.

very good account of the post 9/11 clear up operation. went with family - teenagers of 13/15/17. Definitely a well put together museum capturing the clear up operation after9/11. It is a small quiet area and possibly less suitable for small children although numbers of groups are controlled and limited. If you are on a tight time frame could be difficult to fit this in and visit ground zero so plan well - it is not far on the subway but not a lot else in the area to tie in with it. I would recommend taking a lunch nearby as great near by typical Diner or other eateries - although did not actually eat there. If in a rush ground zero actual site is a definite visit and perhaps captures more the event and has some memorial sites. I found the children visiting did get restless after an hour but there is 2 hours worth of audio etc to listen to while there. Definitely my wife and I glad visited ( and from research felt it was the best place to go) and were moved although would have liked to see more of the actual immediate aftermath events/stories etc. The price is quite high but be aware at least it is a non profit organisation.

A Very Moving Experience. We visited on 31 December 09 and found this to be a very moving and unmissable experience. When we arrived we thought that the smal room where we were given an introduction was just the first room of the museum, but it soon became apparent that it was the entire museum. However, we were pointed towards a few important pictures and exhibits amoung more than one hundred, each with a very personal story. After two short films, Gary Suson introduced himself, and talked about his expeiriences. It was evident that the museum is an important part of his own method of coping with the trauma of providing the only photographic record of the ground zero recovery. We were left to explore the individual exhibits with an audio guide, with Gary on hand to answer questions and talk about his work. The whole exhibition is very tastefully displayed and gave a real insight into what the rescuers encountered in their mission to recover the victims of the 911 atrocity. We were moved to tears.

Ok, but your time is better spent elsewhere. I chose the Ground Zero Museum based on all the glowing reviews, but I have to say I was disappointed. Watching free TV shows on the topic provides a more moving experience than shuffling around a small, crowded room looking at snapshots and debris from the site.

Touching and unusual. The museum was one of the best things we saw in NYC! It was very touching to see some of the consequences of 9-11, and one of the things that made the museum
very special was the way it was arranged which was touching in an unusual way.

Rare and moving photography. This is a great exhibit. Highly recommended. You can go at your own speed - viewing and learning about each of the photographs at your own pace. My family thoroughly enjoyed the workshop and were deeply moved by Mr. Suson's images.

A New York visit isn't complete without visiting this site. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is located just a short distance from Ground Zero itself. The workshop gives a group video presentation which is followed by time for individual touring. The staff is friendly, very knowledgeable and very enthusiastic to answer any and all questions. Both civilian and military alike will treasure the experience gained by visiting this extraordinary site.

Educational, moving and very worthwhile experience. I prebooked this which was wise as the Museum Workshop is very popular. Only a small group are allowed into the Musuem for each session. The session lasts up to two hours. We were lucky to Have Gary Susan present on the day. The museum is intimate which is to my mind a perfect way to present the information on show. The whole experience was very moving but also very educational. I have to disagree with an earlier review in that I feel that this museum workshop is suitable for children from 14 years upwards.
educational, sincere, moving. A well organised and appropriate way of honouring those who died in 9/11. It was suitable for our children ages 6 to 16 years

Wonderful Experience for all ages. My husband and I recently took our 6 grandchildren (ages 4 to 16), daughter and daughter-in-law to this musuem and everyone throught it was superb. We were very fortune that Gary (the photographer) actually dropped in during our tour and personally authographed the book that we purchased there. I would highly recommend this "small" museum to everyone. It was so informative and the children especially thought it was heat to be able to hold some of the items from Ground Zero.

Well worth the time and money - Never Forget!. I'm not usually emotional about tragedies throughout the world, but this experience makes what happened on 9/11/01 VERY real and personal and shows how something horrible can bring out the good in people. When you walk into the room, you will probably be like I was... "this is it?!". But after about 10 minutes in there, you will forget you are in just a room and start to connect to this experience and recognize the power in the photography and exhibits displayed here. If you do 1 thing in NY, this is it in my opinion. Fairly inexpensive and any profits go towards a good cause, not to long, easy to get to via public transit and totally worth your time. On a side note, we exited the museum and went to the left and enjoyed the sunset at Highline Park, overlooking the Hudson and Hoboken and it was beautiful, so if you do a tour in the afternoon, I would highly recommend doing the same!

A Tastefully Done Tribute to 9/11!. It gave me chills to see such a nicely put together collection of items from the tragic 9/11 sight! It was also nice to be able to walk around, and even touch many of the items, while listening to touching stories on the headsets at your own leasure! Many times I was moved to tears, as were others around me, as we moved about the room! I will not forget my experience at your tastefully done exhibit! I would certainly recommend it to anyone planning on visiting the New York City area!

Must see in NYC. Even though it was only a few 7 years ago, with the fast pace of life you do start to forget. The museum is a reminder that many lives were totally changed in a short hour of time. Was thrilled to see that artifacts were saved and that the photographer had the insight to realize this was a part of history and should be saved. In our throw away society this is often over looked, but they gave this museum another layer of intensity. This was recommended by a friend and I have since recommended to others.

A Must See in New York!. I would definitely recommend the Ground Zero Museum Workshop tour as part of your visit to NYC. This is a unique experience in an intimate setting that brings you closer to the aftermath of the World Trade Center terrorist attack than any other place I've visited. Though its contained in a small room, I spent 2 hours listening to the stories behind the photographs and various objects recovered from the site. Is also appropriate for older children as everything is displayed with great care and dignity. Spectacular!

Don't miss this one. Unforgettable.. Personal, intimate portraits that detail the humanity of 9/11. Small room, big impact. One of my favorite experiences in NYC. The photographer himself was there during our visit, which made it all the more meaningful as we talked to him. A masterful presentation.

Cool place. First off, I do recommend everyone go here. The photos this guy took were amazing and having some artifacts from the WTC is pretty cool. This "museum" is in one room thats probably only 700 square feet in size, I was expecting something larger. Secondly, this attraction takes about two hours to do. I don't recommend people takes kids here as anyone under 16 will most likely be bored.

Incredible two hours. This collection of photos of the recovery effort is a wonderful memorial to the NYC 911 victims and a tribute to those who had the difficult tasks of the recovery of the remains from the rubble. Be prepared to be moved and reminded that we must NEVER FOGET!!

A Must See if in Manhattan. This museum may be small, but it is full of heart and dedication to those who experienced 9/11 up close. There are no photos of planes crashing in to the towers or the towers collapsing. This is about the people who survived or lost a loved one. The photos and artifacts are one of a kind and amazing. The group watches a video together and then you wear your own headphones/tour mate and experience the story behind each artifact and photo. Give yourself an hour or two and don't rush. Buy your tickets online and make a reservation. You can visit the World Trade Center Site after the museum which is not far by subway or taxi.

Amazing - the best attraction in NYC???. My wife and I have just returned from a 5 day NY trip in which we pretty much managed to get around almost every major tourist attraction. For me this museum was the best thing we saw and I have to recommend it to every NY visitor. The museum is based on the photographs of the offical FDNY photographer Gary Suson (who was there to answer questions) for the 9/11 tragedy. Needless to say it is a very emotional experience but done in a touching and humble way, and all proceeds go towards families and charities connected with 9/11 - the stories behind the tragedy and the recovery period were very moving indeed. Book a trip to this museum next time you're in NY, you will most certainly not be disappointed.

Moving Tribute to Brave 9/11 Heroes. I found this tour on Trip Advisor and it was one of the most moving and informative collections of 9/11 history and artifacts. It was small and intimate, but packed with wonderful photos and information. The self-guided tour was perfect. You have a headset and remote which you punch in the number of each exhibit to hear narration by the photographer, Gary Suson. We were honored by his presence that day. We found him humble and informative. What an enriching experience.

Fantastic. Walking in and seeing such a small room you wonder A) what you've paid for and B) how you can possibly spend 2 hours in there. What you get is a thought provoking but not upsetting experience, it's extremely interesting, suitable most ages and worthe every penny and minute you spend in there. A highlight of our trip.

Never Forget!. 5-StarsMoving and Important - REMEMBERThe Museum was a very moving experience. We had the privilege of meeting Mr. Suson and that enhanced our visit. The entire world should be exposed to these moving, terrible moments in our history so that we do never forget. Zerve was also very helpful when we had to make a change. Thank you

A very moving experience. We visited the workshop on 22 October and were so lucky that Gary Suson conducted the tour that day. It is a very moving collection of photographs of the recovery and artefacts which were recovered from the site. It really is a must see for everyone

An amazing, overwhelming & emotional experience - A 'must see'. We visited NYC from the UK and both my husband and I felt compelled to visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. The tour is a tasteful representation of events and Gary Suson's pictures tell the heartbreaking story of 9/11 in a way that truly touches the heart and soul. Both my husband and I were lost for words and I don't think we spoke for a hour afterwards as we were so moved by the experience. I would say this is an abosolute 'must do' for anyone who visits New York - what people went through on and after 9/11 was truly horrifying and everyone should know about it.

An emotional and moving place.. I didn't know what to expect before I got there and I couldn't believe how small the room was. But there were so many beautiful pictures and moving stories, it was really incredible. The staff was very friendly and the infamous man behind the museum was there himself. Gary Marlon Suson was also very friendly and so appreciative of those who came to see his work.

Beautiful, moving photos. My two sisters and I visited on Oct. 3. A heavy rain shower had spoiled our plan to walk by the Ground Zero site so we hoped that this museum would make-up for missing the site. It more than succeeded. As stated in many reviews the museum is very small. That was not a problem. We were able to take our time and view as many photos as we wanted. Not only were the photos heartbreaking, beautiful and educational; the commentary on each by Gary Marlon Suson added both emotion and information.My only worry is that the museum staff may be allowing in too many people for each timed viewing. While our group was still manageable it was slightly crowded. We were among the last to leave so had plenty of space to get close to the photos we couldn't easily access earlier. There was a very small group waiting for the next tour as we left, so maybe our group was unusually large.No matter what, it was worth the ticket and allowing the full two hours.

'THE HIGHLIGHT OF MY TRIP'. My wife and I visited NYC for the first time in Sept. We visited the "must see" attractions, which were nice. Thanks to Trip Advisor, we learned about the Ground Zero Workshop Museum and thankful we are. What I most enjoyed about this tour is that we learned the magnatude of what went into the cleanup of Ground Zero and how it affected the cleanup workers and cadaver sniffing dogs. This tour was well put together and well worth the visit. The only negative is that the pictures were a bit overpriced but I still purchased the ones I wanted.

An amazingly small but memorable museum that you MUST vist!. During a recent family trip to New York City, we made reservations to visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop that my sister had found on-line. Upon arriving at the small 2nd floor workshop, I was immediately turned off by the single room that the entire museum was placed in. To boot, it was quite warm and I was not looking forward to spending time in the small confined space sweating like crazy.Let me say that I was blown away by the presentation and content that the workshop had to provide. After a brief movie introduction and talk by one of the very friendly docents, we were left to roam through each display at our own pace, utilizing the audio device to get specific information about the items that were being presented.This museum is the work of one Gary Marlon Suson who was the only person allowed into the depths of the great pit where once stood the twin towers, to be the official photographer of what had taken place. With pictures and specific artifacts that were recovered, Mr. Suson takes you on a personal tour of each of the pieces, providing you with a story for each and every item. Some stories are longer, and some short, but ALL of them will blow your mind. I can even say that on multiple occasions I teared up from what I was privileged to be viewing.This place is a MUST SEE for anyone visiting New York and looking to see a realistic tour of what took place on September 11, 2001. We visited one other museum dedicated to the horrific 9/11 experience and while it was moving, nothing compared to what we saw at the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. I wholeheartedly recommend it! You will not be sorry!One final note, as we were leaving we were privileged to meet Gary Suson and he was quite humbled and very grateful for everyone that can share in what he personally experienced during his time.

Emotional but Important. As the wife of a serving Firefighter I knew that this would be an emotional experience but also one which was uplifting too. The museum is set out in a way that you are able to learn all about the terrible events of 9/11 almost first hand. It was very moving to see how this awful event unfolded before us all , but filmed and told in such an understanding and sensitive way that makes it an absolutely essential place to experience. The museum itself is set in a fairly small area and is quite intimate so is only open to small parties of around 10 people at a time, so it is advisable to book in advance. It was uplifting because you can also read about how those involved are comming to terms with what happened and how life goes on after it. I would recommend this museum as no matter how far away you were on that date it was an event that touched all of us and it makes us realise how much people give through their work for others without a thought for themselves. The ultimate sacrifice.

Moving tribute to the workers at Ground Zero. Before I visited this museum, I had not taken on board how much work and effort was required to search through the remains of the Twin Towers and that there was life after the tragedy. It was fascinating and very moving to learn about the NYC firemen's very brave efforts at Ground Zero and to learn their own stories and of their official photographer, Gary Suson who gave many months of his time to document it all. The museum although very small makes for an intimate visit, with no more than 20 or so people allowed in at any one time. I can't recommend it more highly and hope that Gary's photographs will be included in the museum proposed by NY at the Ground Zero site.
We Will NEVER Forget. An amazing, emotional experience! A must see for everyone.

A must see. A sensitive, intimate collection of artifacts and photos of the clear up operation at Ground Zero. The headset commentary allowed you to work round the display at your own pace, the personal stories told in words and pictures made the events of 11th September all the more real without sensationalising.
wonderful and moving place. am so glad we visited this small museum, could have spent longer there, Very moving and intimate place

Amazing. The museum workshop, words cannot express. Must be seen to appreciate. Guide needs to follow the museum rules, no cell phones, she was on th ephone the majority of our 2 hour tour, lound enough for me to hear through my headphones. She was also, packing and unpacking boxes, the tape noise off the roll was way annoying(9/14/09 12 noon tour)

Amazing Experience - Respectful, Deeply Moving, Fascinating. I would never have expected that such a small room could hold so much. When I first sat down with my friends and we learned that the entire two hours would be spent in that one room we just looked at each other and wondered how we would 'get our money's worth'. Well, shame on us. We got back more than we gave. We were the last tour of the day and so were able to stay longer than the allotted two hours. Even with that extra time I could have stayed another hour. Mr. Suson provides wonderful narrative to the pieces via an audio tour. It is not maudlin or sappy - but respectful, to the point, informative. And a bonus for us - Gary Suson himself came into the studio and we were able to speak with him personally. It was a treat to have him sign our purchases and take pictures with him.

A MUST see. Very moving.. This museum is the smallest big attraction we visited. The museum is filled with artifacts from Ground Zero. It is presented in an extremely respectful and artful way. What a way to memorialize one of the worst tragedies in our nations history.

A most powerful experience. I recently had the opportunity to visit the Ground Zero Museum Workshop in NYC. I was shocked to discover it was only one small room, and could not imagine what would take two hours. I was amazed and wished I had had more time to spend there. The museum is one of the most powerful exhibits I have witnessed in dealing with a time in American history that found us all searching. The photographs depict the tragedy and personal stories of the common man. Although there was one photograph of the actual tragedy as it occurred, the rest were the spirit of the American people and the volunteers who spent countless hours giving of their time for those whose lives ended on September 11. The artifacts only added to the atmosphere, and although it was somewhat depressing, the spirit of the American people lives on through the wonderful work of Mr. Suson. Kudos to him and the staff at the museum!!!

A MUST SEE!. I realized there where many aspects of 9/11 that I had not gave much thought to. I did not realize the lasting health affects of the searchers, including the dogs that helped with the search. I also did not realize the fathers and retirees that had such a grim task of searching for their sons. The trip to your museum was at the request of my 15 year old step-son and you made it a worthwhile journey for us all. Thank you Mr. Suson, for bringing these images to us all, thank you for helping give closure to those who need it and enlightenment to those who did not know.

Moving Images & Stories of Ground Zero Recovery. The museum is set in quite a small, intimate environment. The tour starts with a commentary/ televised introduction of Gary Suson & his role as the official Ground Zero photographer. Visitors then use the audio sets whilst walking round to view the photos & various artefacts recovered from the Twin Towers site.Although I found this a very emotional tour it also contains some very interesting facts about the recovery of Ground Zero. It is not in anyway morbid, but is very moving.Credit to Gary Suson who spent 9 months documenting the recovery by photographs, of course the visitor doesn't see death/injury that Gary must have been subject to on a daily basis - I really don't know how he did it.

A must see, unforgetable experience.. This unforgetable experience is a must see for all. The staff truly does a fantastic job of making it a comfortable environment to view these artifacts and touching stories.

Unique Perspective from Someone who Saw it All. Amazing artifacts that really put a human face on the tragedy of 9-11. Gary's pictures and stories are an experience unique to him and really give a hard look at what the recovery period was like. Well done.

Moving and sensitive tribute. We visited the museum on 10th August 2009. Although only one room, there is a display of moving photographs and many artifacts found during the clean up process at the World Trade Centre site. Upon arrival there is a short commentary, followed by your own time with an audio unit which you can do in your own time which was a very sensitive reminder of how tragic this event was. This was done on our first day in New York which we had booked a month earlier on the net in Oz after reading a newspaper review. Worth doing. Just a small group of people. Will affect some more than others. Hard to say it is "fantastic" given the nature of the museum.

GREAT INTIMATE EXPERIENCE. We took two of our children ages 10 and 14 to the Ground Zero Museum. It was a fantastic intimate experience. The museum is small, but packed full of very moving photographs. Our group was only about 13 people. We were given an introduction and headphones to walk around the room listening to the background of each photo taken. We then took a cab to Ground Zero, which was very hectic and busy. It was a very nice way to get a real feal for what happened on 9/11 before actually seeing the site. Very moving and a great experience for our children.

Great Experience. I really liked this museum as it was very interactive and well done. I was worried that it would be very emotionally draining and while it was emotional it was not overwhelming. I really like the headsets as they were easy to use and the narrative for each items was so well done. Thank you so much for taking that time to put this all together. I think I could visit 10 different times and each time come away with something new that I learned.

Awesome Experience of the Ground Zero Recovery. Outstanding visual and auditory experience of Ground Zero Recovery. Although the room holding the exhibit is small, the experience is intense and personal instead of cramped or crowded. There is a lot to take in and the approximate 75 minutes alloted to review the individual pieces is reasonable, although you could spend twice as much time time and not be bored. The individual audio capabilities that keys to the individual exhibit pieces is a crucial element of making this a very satisfying and personal experience for my family (children ages 17, 13, 11). Reviewed by Brian Toolan

ground zero workshop. This is a must for anyone visiting New York City. This museum workshop is small, interactive to a degree and exceptionally educational. My 11 year old son said it was the best museum he has ever been to . Do not miss this , it sets the bar for memorability.

Touched by God's Presence. My family enjoyed listening to the stories about the wonderful pictures displayed. It was a privilege to meet the photographer as well and chatting with him was insightful. I was touched by the "cross photo" and the "Genesis 11 chapter from the Bible." It reaffirmed God's presence. He is here to comfort and help us walk through the difficult times. I forgot to explain to my family that this wasn't going to be a regular museum, but a small room of the photographer's collection. It was cozy. I think that added to the remembrance of all the people that perished and all the people that volunteered. When we got back home, I was pleased that my children shared with others about their experience at the museum and the stories they heard. We also went to Disney World, D.C. and Philadelphia, so having them share about the "Ground Zero Museum" as a highlight of our trip was a blessing. My children are 23, 21, 15 & 12. Thank you for sharing the photos and helping others to remember.

Well worth it. This was truly an amazing experience. The stories you learn about the recovery efforts are simply incredible. I would highly recommend this museum. The space is small but it is filled with Gary Suson's amazing pictures of the Ground Zero recovery efforts and the stories you hear bring them all to life. Be sure to reserve your ticket(s) in advance. There is limited space and same day tickets aren't available.

Absolutely a must do for anyone visiting NYC!. Despite the museum's small size, the emotions and quality of the photographs and exhibits are huge. A very powerful reminder of all that we lost. NEVER FORGET!

Very emotional. This is a very tiny museum with a lot emotion. To see the museum you must buy tickets in advance. You cannot just stop by. The ticket price is 25 dollar per adult. It's not recommended for jung children. You can touch original artifacts and you can see original photos taken from Gary Suson. He was the one and only photographer to go inside the WTC after the attach and during the recovery process. The photos are amazing and they tell sad, interesting and funny stories what you have never heard in the press before. It's a good place to remember and to find peace.

Worth a trip to NYC!. This was amazing! The hair on my arms still stands when I talk about it! Even our children (10 &11) thought it was great b/c it was done in such an easy and individualized way. It was not gruesome at all. It was sad, but in a loving way. It's purpose is to help heal. It is spectacular, informative, and moving! A must see while in NYC!!!!

A small museum with great significance. My family visited this museum on Aug 1, 2009. The museum is in a room the size of a living room really, yet there was enough room for the 20 or so people in our group to move around easily. There is quite an impressive collection of photographs of the aftermath from 9/11 by Gary Suson who was the only official photographer at Ground Zero during the initial months after the tragedy. Suson has a wonderful narrative voice which he uses to tell stories of each of the photographs and artifacts included in the museum (including actual window glass from the towers and desk items found in the rubble). The stories of the victims, survivors and families make each picture come alive. You can pick and choose what you want to learn about with the self-guided headphone set. The entire experience is very touching. What we did not like was waiting outside to get into the building. Do NOT go early as you won't be able to go inside until your tour time and we were 30 minutes early, unfortunately. Our tour started 15 minutes late (more standing and waiting outside) and we were told by one tour guide that another guide was doing some "spiffing up and cleaning for us" which was strange since we were the first tour of the day. Still, the whole experience takes about 1 1/2 hours. There are posters, postcards and books for sale and some of the money goes to the victims' families. I would have purchased the book but it was too large and heavy to carry around all day (a low rate shipping option would be nice). My family rated this experience a "B" overall but upgraded it to "A" when we unexpectedly ran into Gary Suson at the small church by the actual Ground Zero site and were able to talk to him more about the museum. He is quite personable and has many interesting and emotional stories to share about his experience.

Appropriate for children. At first, we were hesitant about taking our 12 year old to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop, concerned about its deep emotional content. However, we were thankful to have brought her, as the exhibit was moving, yet appropriate for children of all ages. Children are able to grasp the magnitude of the tragedy without being over-exposed to the harsh reality of the horrific pain that so many have had to experience because of this event. The room is welcoming, with places to sit for anyone who has tears to shed. The initial explanation given by the guide is in-depth and enlightening and the short video shown before viewing the exhibit is eye-opening. The artifacts were extremely thought provoking, and having been given the opportunity to touch some, made the experience much more real. The museum was tastefully set up. It was the account of Gary Marlon Suson, the brave official photographer for the Uniformed Firefighters Association & Uniformed Fire Officers Association (FDNY). He managed to document history, take these incredible pictures, and collect these meaningful objects while trying to grapple with the extremely emotional content of what he had to photograph. At the end of our tour, we got the opportunity to meet Mr. Suson, and my daughter asked him questions. His responses were sensitive and definitely age-appropriate. My family was truly amazed and moved at what we saw and experienced that day. It is a must see, and we plan on visiting the museum again on future trips to New York.

Respectful rememberence. You cannot visit New York without visiting this insightful look into the recovery process that took place after that terrible tragedy inflicted upon innocent people of the world and New York city. The poignant display's of Gary Suson's images respectfully give us a glimpse of the amazing job the recovery workers did, and help us to try and understand the magnitude of what took place.We must never forget, this museum will serve to ensure that generations of people from all over the world will remember......This visit was probably the highlight of our visit to New York, my husband and 16 yr old daughter would agree, although we wish there was no need for such a museum to exist it it the most respectful and touching display I have seen. Thanks Gary, we were also lucky enough to meet Gary and have a permenant reminder in his beautiful book to share with our family and friends back in Australia, so they too can share this experience and never forget
