Amazing Museum. Although this will be the smallest museum in square footage you will ever visit, I assure you it will be the largest in terms of information and heart! The stories, photographs, and assorted items from that tragic day are all on display. You form a very personal connection with the families and rescuers who's lives changed forever. My family and I (2 grown children ), had the opportunity to meet the photographer / museum owner, Gary Suson. The many difficult months he spent photographing the ruins and rescuers still shows on his face. Be prepared to shed a few tears, but don't worry, they have plenty of tissues and chocolates to help you through it!

Amazing, truly the BIGGEST Small museum in the world.. This museum was fabulous. New York offers other amazing tourist hotspot museums like madame tussauds and ripleys, but the ground zero workshop topped it all for me. You get to witness artifacts that you never thought would be shown to the public. The people there are kind and generous, they really treat their guests with respect and gratitude. Clearly this museum is not looking to make profits, but more to share the story with the people. It is DEFINITELY the biggest small museum in the world. 100% recommended, you would be missing out if you didnt go!

Must see on any trip to NYC!. We attended as a family of four with two daughters aged 11 and 10. At first glance, the room appears too small to offer a 'value for money' experience. However, after subsequently being totally absorbed in a new depth of emotion and a discovery of highly interesting and hitherto unknown (to us) facts, two hours passed by so quickly. Make no mistake about it, this was a fabulous experience, very sensitively presented, highly emotional and often deeply disturbing. Everyone appeared to be so absorbed that you could have heard a pin drop as each of us tried to deal with what we were seeing and hearing - in disbelief, shock and horror whilst at the same time in complete admiration of the courage and selflessness exhibited by all the emergency workers and rescuers. Our daughters were too young to watch the horrific events unfolding on that September day in 2001 and whilst we have made them aware of it over the years since, it is difficult to tell how tragedies like this are seen and processed through the eyes of a child. We wondered whether they would wish too see this tour on our trip to NYC, but with tears rolling down their innocent cheeks, we witnessed first hand the impact of the unlikely marriage of evil (the perpetrators) and heroism (the emergency services) on their developing characters. We were just about the last ones to leave - our group was fortunate to meet Gary Suson towards the end of our tour and that made it even more special. A great big thank you to him for such a respectful presentation. None of us will ever forget this tour for as long as we shall live. Of course, we wish this tour never had reason to exist at all. In conclusion, this tour is most highly recommended - we then went on to the museum at the WTC site itself - both are compelling and offer similar but different perspectives of 9/11 - and deep and lasting memories.

An absolutely fantastically moving experience.. I had seen this trip before my husband and I had gone to NYC and had planned on a visit. We walked there from 5th Ave and we extremely lucky as we got there 15mins early. What we hadn't realised was you needed to prebook and we hadn't. Fortunately there were spaces available. Once we got inside we understood why there is the need for advanced booking, as the room is small for a 'museum', however it is perfect for this museum. We were in luck again as Gary Susan was actually there so we got to speak to him and he told us about his experience in person, which was amazing. The photography and information that goes with them is fantasically presented and very moving. This was one of our last visits of the holiday and my husband said without a doubt the best. This is quite hard to comprehend as it was such a tragic event that you are seeing but the way the whole thing is presented is a fantastic way to really understand everything about the whole impact the World Trade Centre had on so many people.

Amazing Exhibit-Must See in NYC. This was a truly moving experience. I am a firefighter in Texas, and this was my first trip to NYC. Amazingly, there is very little seen or said about 9-11. After visiting this museum/workshop (it is called a workshop because it is interactive meaning you can touch and hold items in the museum) I now see why. Most in New York want to forget the events of 9-11, without forgetting the people affected. This museum does this in a wonderfully sobering way. I don't want to get into a lot of detail here, whereas it is kind of like a good movie, I'll give away too much! You must see it for yourself to truly understand and appreciate what Mr. Souson and FDNY have done by creating this tribute to all those affected by the tragedy of 9-11.

Read this!!!. Wow! As soon as you walked in, you knew. 2009 stood still and it seemed as if 9-11-01 had never left. The staff there was unbelievable, sympathetic, and showed great respect for every victim and family member affected by 9-11. They spoke directly from their HEART. The tour guide spoke beautifully. She spoke about the loss, the triumphs, the heartaches, and the love during that time. I swear if you stood still, you could hear the echoes of sadness and cries from each photograph. I can't tell you what was there because you have to experience this yourself. You see things on t.v. and only can assume what people were feeling but here you know exactly what they were feeling. Every photograph has a personal touching story. My God....I can only hope those who were lost on that day joined God quickly and peacefully. The loss of life and the lives changed on that day will never ever be forgotten. It is a must trip a must!!!!! A must!!! NEVER FORGET!!!

Truly Moving!!!. If you get a chance please go and visit the museum, they only let a cretian number of peple in at a time as the museum is quite small but the way it has been set out is very good, this place will stay in your mind weeks after you have visited.It was one of the mos moving experiences that i have had in a long time and i guaruntee that even the hardest of people will shed a tear.A true mark of respect to all those who lost their lives on taht terrile dayGo and you will see what i mean

WONDERFUL!!. This was a wonderful museum to visit! It was very nice to meet the Gary, the man who took the pictures. I loved that every picture and artifact had a story and it was told to you in Gary's own words. You leave having a greater understanding of the tragedy that was 9/11.

You must go!. I had a lot of trouble taking my 4 teens and husband, but finally got it. It's worth it! It will give you a new "inside" view of what happened on 9/11. Every piece there has its own story, some very touching... At the end my five guys were very quiet, and that tells me a lot!

Great Museum. When I visited New York, I went to the Ground Zero Museum in the Meatpacking District. It's small, very small, but has a big impact. The photo's are amazing and the presentation is great. I met the photographer Gary Marlon Suson as well at the end of the tour. If you want to get an unforgettable experience, I would recommend to visit this museum :)

Very eye opening and humbling experience- Highly recommended. When we first arrived to the outside of the museum in the meat packing district, we didn't think it looked like much and we thought perhaps we overspent for tickets on something that may be minimal for viewing. We even wondered how a two hour tour was going to be utilized fully for one room of items. HOWEVER, we were so wrong. It started with a video with phone call recordings from individuals at WTC and images post incident taken by the artist, Gary Suson. The tour is a self-guided audio tour that brings each visitor to every photograph and artifact on display. Each nook and cranny and portion of wall space is occupied with images and artifacts that tell a very emotional and potent story that will bring tears to your eyes. It was a good experience for my children who were just babies when the incident occured. It was even a good experience for my husband and myself as we were able to feel the emotions of what photograph or item was intended to convey. We were able to learn about specific individuals involved in the rescue efforts which personalized them as individuals who were just downtrodden and weary from what they had to endure. Seeing the artifacts from the WTC restaurant and gift shop or even items found in the debris just made it even more emotional. Again, it is a small museum but don't be fooled by size. It is a wealth of information and personalization of those involved with 9-11 that you didn't get in the news. You leave very humbled. The artist and the gentleman who hosted the tour were sensitive and informative individuals. We highly recommend it and it's definitely worth the cost for admission.

Small But Very Interesting. I found this museum to be very informative and somber. It was like time had stood still I loved all the stories that Gary told about each picture and artifact. I work in downtown Chicago and that day it was like a war zone after the towers had been hit…so for me this was something I needed to see… Chicago had not been attached that day, but it could in the future and I am glad that Gary create this museum. People should never forget nor should they believe we are safe…after visiting the museum it reminds you not to let your guard down for a minute. Thanks Gary for being brave enough to go to ground zero and take pictures of the men and women who were brave enough to put their lives in jeopardy to try and save anyone who might have survived…a day with your help that will never be forgotten….

Very emotional AND well worth your time!. This small museum is filled with a HUGE impact of artifacts and photographs taken during the 9 month recovery effort of 9/11. I truly appreciated the narration from the photographers point of view, as he reflects on capturing the moment and the feelings that were going on during the time of the photograph. We are fortunate to have this museum as a promise to our country to "never forget"! We were blessed to have a visit from the photographer at the end of our session and enjoyed talking to him about his impact and legacy he is sharing with us through his pictures!

A time to process.... My wife and I are from Indianapolis and like every American remember where they were when they heard the news. I was driving to a client site on I-69 and my wife was at home with our daughter. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop allowed us to process 9.11 and remember the fallen. The intimate setting and pictorial account was very powerful. The narrative accounts of each picture was very personal as Mr. Sason provided a context to each picture. I would recommend a visit for sure. After we visited the site, it was lunch time and we walked over to the Marketplace for lunch and to process further.

Better than visiting Ground Zero Itself. If you're interested in the events of 9/11, you must visit this little gallery. When I first walked in I thought I had wasted my money, but I soon discovered that the stories behind each of the photos made the event come to life.Be sure to reserve in advance. Enter 'GZtwit' for $4 off Twitter discount.

A most emotional experience. One small room, lots of photographs, several artefacts plus individual commentaries on each photo, all combine into a powerful,emotional experience that joins you the visitor to the victims of 09/11, their families and the extraordinary emergency services. Tears flow freely, and afterwards don't plan on doing anything else for a hour or so, because your brain won't cope! An unmissable museum.

One of the most spiritual and emotional experiences in my life.". Well organized display of photographs and artifacts from Ground Zero. Gary Suson pours his soul into telling the story of spending eight months with firefighters, policemen, and volunteers in the aftermath of 9/11. His narration explains in detail what he saw and how he felt as he photographed history taking place. My friend, a retired United Airlines flight attendant, felt the need to go there to pay her respects. Not only is it an emotional experience, but also a spiritual one as Gary told the story of finding a page from Genesis 11 about the Tower of Babel. Visiting the museum first made seeing the actual site and St. Paul's Church even more meaningful. Every American should visit this museum to fully understand what happened that day, what we lost, and why we should never forget.
It made such an impact on us.. We loved this museum - it was such a different perspective from any other reporting.

A very moving and compelling experience.. My family and I visited on 6/22/09. All of us which includes my wife and 4 boys were moved by the video as well as by the numerous photos and artifacts of the 9/11 trajedy and its aftermath. What was also impressive was the courage and resolve of the people who participated in the recovery effort. Our visit was about 2 hours long and it was time wll spent.

Thoughtful, respectful, helpful, healing, feeling connected. Very well thought out, carefully put together, and really made going to the WTC site much more meaningful. At the actual site you cannot see much with all the barricades and draped fencing around the perimeter. It was almost impossible to figure out where the buildings once stood even though we had visited them several times in the past. We did not see written stories or many displays around this very active construction site. My group did not lose a loved one on 9/11, yet really appreciated the opportunity as fellow Americans, to spend special time learning more about that day, entering the time zone of 9/11 and feeling more a part of it, touching a bit of it, and paying respect to all those our hearts have poured out to over the past 8 years. There are comfortable sofas for anyone who wants or needs to sit and view the pictures and artifacts from them and listen to an audio tape explaining each one. The room was small enough that someone sitting on the sofas or in a wheelchair would have adequate access to the pictures/memorabilia mainly hanging on the walls. There were individual audio units to listen to stories about each of the 100+ exhibits. If you are hearing impaired, the video is not captioned and the audio players are not conducive even to those with mild losses. They are not set up with telecoil/induction loop/infra red systems, but you can request a written transcript which is very helpful. If this is the case, I would advise extra time which you might be allowed if you are the last session of the day (1pm?) (that's what we did so my hearing impaired daughter had more time to read the transcript). Dress cool in the summer months as it gets a bit warm in that room, and I highly recommend visiting this wonderful exhibit if you can.

Speechless!. Hard to describe in words. There is so much to take in that it takes a couple days to process it all.This Museum is put on by the official photographer for the World Trade Center site. They only allowed one person to be on-site and take photographs. One of the best parts of the museum is the audio clips that describe what is taking place in about 100 photos that Gary Suson took.They use the proceeds to help families who have lost loved ones and also to help pay for medical bills of the workers who helped clean up the site that now are having medical problems from the fumes that they were exposed to.One of the best things to do in NYC hands down!

a must for anyone wanting to learn about the ground zero recovery. We found this small museum fascinating and informative. It is just a small room filled with artifacts and amazing photos, After an intro video and talk by your guide, you are given headphones and a self guided audio tour lets you hear stories about each picture and artifact.

Tasteful and Touching -- a New York must see!. When we visited the Ground Zero Museum Workshop we anticipated a somewhat commercialized venture that exploited both victims and rescuers. Instead we were pleased not to find it a museum setting at all, but more of an intimate memorial to what was a terrible tragedy. The self guided tour, well interspersed with boxes of kleenex, allowed us to glimpse in our own personal time and space what it must have been like for the rescuers during those horrific months following 911. Expect to find unbelievable artifacts and stories you won't see or hear anywhere else.

Highly recommended museum done with dignity & respect. GO, you won't be disappointed and is worth every penny. This was a very moving experience and full of photos, memories and experiences. It's a small room and at first you think is this it?! but the walls are crammed full of photos, objects, stories etc that there is so much to take in. The audio tour is great and takes you round each item and you can spend as long as you want listening and reading each one. We both found this really moving and it took us 2 hours to finish.I would recommend this to anyone visiting New York. We then went onto visit the Ground Zero site ourselves. We booked online and feel it is worth every penny.

One of the best museums in New York City. This is one of the best museums in the city. The workshop is very intimate and you are able to look at photographs and artifacts at your own pace. During my visit Gary Marlon Suson, the creator of the workshop personally welcomed us and answered questions about his photographs. Visiting the workshop is a very moving experience. Every detail of the museum is tastefully displayed respect to those who worked tirelessly in the World Trade Center recovery. This is a wonderful museum for locals as well as individuals visiting the city.

very well put together. I have recently returned from New York City following a 7 night break with my family which includes three teenage sons. I had done some research prior to visiting and was keen to visit this museum. You have to pre book your tickets as they only allow small groups of around 25 at a time. We arrived at the allocated time to be met by our very helpful guide. We were taken up into the actual museum hall which is quite small. We took our seats with around 20 other guests and were given an explanation by the guide about what the tour entailed. I soon realized that the room we were in was it, I do not know what I expected but was a little shocked at how small the place was. We watched two moving videos of the background of how this museum worked and how it had been put together. We then were free to walk around looking at some very moving pictures and listening to our own headsets we listened to some remarkable but some times emotional stories of individuals that were involved some how on the day or the very many long days after 9/11.There is nothing but tributes at this museum, not one glimpse of a plane hitting a tower etc just a very well put together group of pictures and artifacts retrieved from the twin towers and surrounding area. My wife and I, as well as our three son’s, walked around listening to our headsets intently, all at our own pace and all starting at different points. After an hour, we all came to an end and sat down in the middle totally silent for a good few minutes. After we had all finished gathering our thoughts, one by one, we all said that this was a fabulous tribute and insight into the events on 9/11. We did many of the tourist things that you do in NYC that week and nothing was disappointing, this is a truly amazing city. When we got home grandparents and friends asked our sons what the best part of the break was and every one said this museum. We are a close family and have spent many vacations together all over the world, you always remember the good times you have as a family. This afternoon at this wonderful museum will stay with me and my family forever.Thank you to the wonderful people that have sympathetically put this project together. God bless everyone who has been impacted upon by the events of 9/11. If you have not visited, all I will say is you must!

This was a unique and moving experience. This is a small museum, all in one room, but has so much information. The 2 hour tour starts with a pair of videos and a brief overview by the well-prepared and compassionate tour guide. There is plenty of time to explore the materials at your own pace, with the help of a self-controlled audio tour done by official Ground Zero photographer Gary Suson, who owns the museum. And there is a lot of material, including many amazing photographs and personal artifacts from the World Trade Center site. It is all about the recovery efforts and the people involved, as opposed to the horrific events of 9/11. It was personal, tasteful, and moving. Very well done, definitely worth a visit.

Powerful and Beyond Words. Emotionally overwhelming and an experience that will stay with me forever - this is an absolute MUST see and do when in New York. Seeing my 14 year old son take all of this in and it affect him as much as I is something I'll never forget. To actually hold a piece of glass from the Towers and see a piece of the airplane really brought this horrific event home. An extremely respectful and beautiful tribute to all of the survivors, recovery personnel and loved ones who passed away on September 11. I will definitely visit again. Thank you for creating such a beautiful memorial of photographs and artifacts to share with the world. Peace be with you all.

A must see for every American. This Museum is so well done and really brings back 911. Our group was very touched and felt this was very much a highlight of our trip to NYC. I think every American, should visit this site.

The most rewarding experience I had in New York. I'm sure most people can remember where they were when 9/11 occured (unfortunately). I can and had always wanted to go to find out more about that day and to understand the follow up that took place afterwards. Recently I had the chance to visit New York for the first time and was lucky enough to find this workshop and amongst all the other ususal activities a first timer would do in NYC I found this personally the most rewarding. This is a must do activity - without a doubt !

Never forget. Me, my fiance, his army buddy and wife traveled to NYC specifically to see the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. The size of the place might be small, but it definitly made a HUGE impact. While we were there we had the chance to meet Gary, so it made our experience ten times greater to actually meet the photographer who shot each picture. This is definitly not a place to miss! We're bringing more people up to the museum in just a month!

A must see in NYC. I would highly recommend this emotionally packed museum. It is easy to see that all involved in this endeavor have put their heart and soul into it. The photos really paint a picture of what happened on that that day and the the search that continued for survivors. Besides the photos, you are able to pick up and hold artifacts form the site. Our tour guide answered all our questions and encouraged us to stay as long as we wanted. This museum is even more important now that you can't get close to the actual 911 site. I would not miss this tour.

small museum, big experience. this place isn't anywhere near the trade center. they do take walk-ins, but it's better to make reservations. they only have a set number of people they can take in each tour since it is so small and there are limited number of headsets. it's basically just one room with the exhibit inside. the workshop/exhibit includes a video in the beginning and many artifacts from ground zero...including a clock that stopped ticking when one of the planes hit. it is full of photos from gary susan, who was the main photographer at ground zero. awesome sobering experience. at one point, many had tears in their eyes. they do NOT include any images of the actual attack, only "healing" images of the recovery.

Not to be missed,Ground Zero Museum. My wife and i went to the museum to get a better understanding of how 9/11 affected the people of New York. We had watched on TV as the terrible tradegy unfolded,and as we would be in New York thought it would be a good idea to visit the museum. We were not disapointed,It is a very emotional experience. The museum may be small but it leaves a very big impression. if you are going to New York make this a must place to visit

Excellent exhibit - don't hesitate...visit!. I had some friends in NYC who hadn't even heard of this. I originally mentioned going to a "ground zero" museum and they discouraged me prior to looking at the website for this museum. I am so thankful that I saw the reviews of other travelers on Trip Advisor. I went ahead and visited, and I am thankful that I did. It is a very powerful and professionally-handled exhibit. The intent isn't to make a quick buck off of someone else's pain. The photographer is the only person who was allowed into the 9/11 site during the months and months of removal. Although a difficult experience to capture on film, I am so glad that he did. I learned so much more about the families of survivors, the NYC firefighters, the search dogs, etc. that I would have never known w/o attending. I would encourage everyone to visit this while in NYC.

Favorite part of my trip to NYC. This museum was so small, but had a huge, powerful affect on you. I can't put into words what I felt after leaving it. The pictures there are breath taking. It was great to have the audio to listen to Gary talk about each picture or artifact. I would highly recomend this museum to anyone to go to when they are in the city. Thank you to them for putting this wonderful museum together.
Very Tastefully Done. A great memorable experience! It's very small but has such a big effect. Highly recommend!

Never Forget. Amazing! This exhibit can only be described in one word! Sure there are enough artifacts to fill an entire warehouse but this exhibit allows you to be in a more intimate setting allowing you the opportunity to connect with each piece!A must see!

the best museum in nyc...... i had my first visit to this museum today. gary marlon suson really got it right. as the official photographer for the 9/11 recovery he set up this small but powerful museum of very moving photos and actual remnants from the site. if you want to experience the emotion behind the recovery efforts then this is where you want to go. i don't think anyone could leave this museum unchanged. what a respectful tribute to both the victims of the attack as well as those who put their heart and soul into finding them.

Emotional, tasteful and enjoyable. My two children were too young to understand the magnitude of this tragedy when it happened. I wanted them to understand the immense impact it had on so many lives, and the museum did just that. What I was so impressed by was the way it was presented. It was very informative, respectful, emotional and enjoyable. Even though emotions ran high at times, it was tastefully done and appropriate for the children. It’s a must see!!

Small museum - Huge impact.. I recently visited the Ground Zero Museum and can say that the emotions evoked from the experience will remain with me for a long time to come. I have a much better understanding of the event and the sacrifices made by those who where involved and who experienced first hand the aftermath of this despicable terrorist crime. While this is a privately owned and operated museum, it is "not for profit". The photographer, Gary Marlon Suson is also the owner and operator. His images of the ground zero site and recovery efforts are incredible and emotionally provoking. Beyond operating expenses, moniies raised go to support seven assorted charities each month, each one unique.Mr. Suson's passion for the musem and what it represents is extreme. If you have the opportunity to connect with him...do so.

IMPORTANT TO SEE. We just returned from N.Y.C. We bought tickets for the Ground Zero Museum Workshop based on recommendations from other trip advisor members. All I can say is, Wow! Very moving experience. The museum itself is only one room. As you enter you think, "How on earth is this going to take 2 hours?" Amazingly enough we just barely finished seeing and listening to all the many stories associated with each item and picture by the end of the time. Even the kids,(10 and 12), really got a lot out of it. I didn't hear ,even once, "when are we leaving?". Gary Suson was there that day, to "fix a toilet", I think. He was very down to earth and even spent time talking with the youngest of our gang in depth about a few of the pictures. A definite "must see"! P.s.- This museum is NOT AT GROUND ZERO! It is in the "Meat Packing district" a quick subway ride away. Our thanks go to the dedication of Gary Suson for making all this available for the public to experience.

Best Museum Ever!. My partner and I were on our first visit to New York from Northumberland, England and I had read reviews about this museum just before we left for our holiday so we decided we would go. We just turned up on the day and although it is not advisable to do this, best to book in advance, they very kindly booked us in that day and we only had to go away for a coffee for an hour or so, the girl even recomended a good coffee shop up the road, until it was time to go back for the tour. The audio equipment used so you were able to go round at your own pace and listen to the narrative form Gary Suson himself, who was the only official photographer allowed into the ground zero site during the recovery operation, was excellent and informative and extremely moving. We shed some tears while we were there but we also learned a great deal about this disaster. This is a great place to learn about humanity. We were overjoyed to meet Gary, we didnt realise he would be there so this was a great bonus for us. There was an opportunity to purchase his book which is an amazing chronicle from this man,s experiences. This is a must go place!!

Never Forget 9-11. My husband and I went to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop yesterday and highly recommend it. Although it is not what usually comes to mind when you think of a museum- it is just one room- but, it is loaded with incredible photographs and artifacts from Ground Zero. Our tour was small with only 8 people which was nice as we could move around easily. The tour begins with 2 short videos, then each person gets a headphone with an audio remote. You move from one item to the next at your own pace and hear commentary from Gary Susson, the photograper. The items are displayed very professionally with numbers. Our tour guide, Louis, gave us a very good introduction pointing out items not to miss. We were fortunate that Gary was on site yesterday and graciously answered questions about his experiences. I would not recommend this activity for families with very young children, but it is definitely a must-see for anyone else visiting NYC. You will not be disappointed.

needed more time. As we live on the other side of the world I was unsure how this museum would effect me as I had already visited ground zero? I was moved almost to tears, by the wonderful pictures & great side stories on the audio commentary. What I found amazing though is how so many rescuers are now sick or dying from their heroic efforts!!! Even the animal rescuers have either died or are sick from the toxic air. We were ther for the 2 hours and the next tour was about to start so we did not get to hea all the audio but the pictures & 9/11 artifacts spoke in large volumes.Great job by some wonderful dedicated people

if you have time to waste. A few nice pictures, but $25 is too much for a tiny room. The museum is a private house studio settled up as exibition. Very expensive and too much talks about the owner, Gary Suson, instead of the 9/11.

Little Museum Makes a big impact. The ground zero Museum Workshop does an excellent job of bringing the emotions of that day and the recovery into focus. It is amazing what can be done with just a small amount of space, some excellent photos and a great audio presentation. We were showing friends around New York. They had less than three days and I was nervous about reserving tickets for a specific time to visit this museum because we had so much to see and do. It was one of their favorite stops and we all talked about it for the remainder of the trip and beyond. Worth the time and the money....lasting impression.

A Different Perspective. I avoided the other Ground Zero offerings available and booked this off the back of recommendations on Tripadvisor and it was a good choice. It was sensitive without being over-emotional or sensationalist and showed a side to the tragedy that I had not seen much of previously, focussing on the recovery efforts by the fire dept and other groups. It helps that group sizes are kept very small as the bulk of the time spent in the museum, which consists of 1 small room, is a self-guided audio tour of 100+ photos and exhibitions. I came away with a much greater appreciation of the work carried out post 9-11, particularly in circumstances where many of the workers had themselves lost friends, family and co-workers.Book in advance because places are limited.

A museum worth seeing. This small and intimate museum showcases the enormity of the World Trade Center recovery efforts in thoughtful photographs and artifacts collected from the site. The individual stories are moving and poignant. Visitor groups are limited size and given timed entrances, so be sure to make reservations ahead.

A great 2 hrs; moving, informative & compassionate. Having previously visited New York on a couple of occasions we were looking for something new, and were very impressed by the reviews of the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. The reviews were right; this is a very well thought out and compassionate dedication to the 9/11 victims and recovery workers.

The Best Little Museum Ever. This museum is small but the impact is powerful!!! The photos put you in touch with what was happening during the recovery period. Be prepared for a very emotional experience, for me the Search and Rescue Animals had the biggest impact. My group had the good fortune to meet Gary Souson, what a humble man. He has documented a tragedy in American history but was able to interact with everyone on a very human level.

Very touching. We were lucky that went we went, Gary Suson was there to reply to any questions. You first are given your audio-guide then watch a short video with a CNN interview and some pictures that you can find at the museum. I was surprised that the room is really small but you can be there for 2 hours if you listen to all the audio. The overall experience was very touching and I really enjoyed to see and touch some artifacts and the photos. I highly recommend it to anyone visiting NYC!

Just Go. Words cannot express how incredible this museum is. It is something that you just have to experience for yourself. It is such a contrast to all of the tourist trap aspects of New York City. The museum is small and hard to find, but definitely worth it. My advice is to visit this museum before heading to the ground zero site itself (they are two completely different locations). Make sure to read the information on the website prior to going--they do sell out and try to add more tours if possible, but don't expect to show up without tickets and get in. There were many disappointed people there the day I went. The museum is small and they will not let additional people in on the tours.

Do not miss!. Do not leave NYC without a visit to the GZMW! This is a very tasteful, sensitive tribute to 9/11. The entire museum is just one small room, but we were the last to leave at the end of the 2 hour tour, and could have stayed longer. Gary the photographer was there, and he took the time to speak to us, which made the visit even more special. This visit is so emotional and moving, don't forget your tissues! As this museum is borne out of such tragedy, we were unsure if it was the right thing to do amongst all the other tourist attractions, but we are so glad we did, it was a truly humbling experience and one not to be missed.

A MUST-SEE when going to the World Trade Center site. I read about the Ground Zero Museum Workshop on Trip Advisor and decided to check it out on our visit to NYC last week. Having last visited there in June of 2001, my family and I knew we had to go back to the World Trade Center site to pay our respects. After viewing the work being done there, seeing the massive hole in the sky where the Twin Towers once stood, and reminiscing about our previous trip, it was time to go to our tour. It is a short cubway ride and short walk from there to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. Upon our arrival we were led into a room that was lined with photographs and artifacts, all taken on 9/11 and at Ground Zero during the subsequent recovery process by photographer Gary Suson. Gary was there that day, introduced himself to the group and briefly outlined what we would be seeing/doing in our two hours there. What transpired from there was an experience I will never forget, a photo essay and narration of an insiders view of America's darkest day, and the subsequent recovery. Gary has us walking in the boots of those men and women who worked so diligently to bring closure to the victims' loved ones, and one can't help but be moved by the experience.

An emotional must-see!. No trip to MYC is complete without visiting this small, quiet, but well-presented museum which is very thought provoking even if you have not been directly affected by the events of 9/11. Gary Suson happended to be there the day we visited and we enjoyed the chat we had with him. The room is small, but we thought that if the photos and artifacts had been spread out more in a larger one the atmosphere would have been lost. Thoroughly recommended.

This was fantastic!. As a group of 25 (13 kids and 12 adults) from Wyoming, we visited the museum on the morning of July 3, 2008. The entire experience was so moving and educational for all of us. It is really amazing to see and makes you feel as though you were there with Gary taking the pictures. The story accompanying each picture is quite touching and emotional. As we watched the events unfold on TV on September 11, we knew we were far away from all the destruction but being in the workshop really made us aware of what all New Yorkers went through that day and for so many months after. This is definitely a MUST SEE when visiting New York! Thank you Gary! May God Bless all who were affected by September 11th (near and far).

So glad I went. Went to this museum based on trip advisor reviews. It was well worth the money. Even though the museum is not large, it took the entire 2 hours to visit, and I didn't want to leave. When you first arrive, you watch a short video; then you are free to browse and listen to the audio tour. Everything is tastefully done and it was a very moving experience. Because of the size of the room, only a small number of people are admitted at a time, so advance reservations are a must.

Ground Zero Museum - A Must See!. If you are planning a trip to New York, New York, the Ground Zero Museum is a must see. I personally visited there myself on July 4, 2008. It is small in size, but large on remembering and honoring the lives of anyone touched by the events of 9 -11. I had the honor of meeting the founder of the museum, Gary Suson. He was the only official photographer allowed at the Ground Zero site. Through his photographs, stories, and artifacts from the site itself, you can ultimately get a feel for the range of emotions felt. Although you can no longer see the Ground Zero site itself, the museum can almost make you feel as if you were there. The museum elicits an emotional response from almost everyone. It is very touching. Gary Suson's book containing pictures and stories that you see in the museum is a very special souvenir. As I sit and go through the book here in my home, I am reminded of the powerful stories and heroic people that faced that dark time in America's history. All proceeds from the museum and sales go to charities that help victims in some way from that day on 9 - 11. So honor yourself by going there to see the true strength and spirit of the American people.Debbra Sellers7-29-08

Simply Stunning. This small museum was somewhat difficult to find, small, and a bit cramped. All that said, this was the most unbelievable thing we did in NYC. This was our first trip, and very little can top seeing the Statue of Liberty for the first time, but this museum did it. We bought a few posters from the museum, and when we unwrapped when we returned home, my wife and I could still barely talk about them without getting choked up. This was a life-changing two hours and nothing we saw topped it - Wicked, Ellis Island, Statue of Liberty, Wall Street, Times Square - nothing...

Most Important thing to do when in New York!. This is a must do thing whilst in New York. We went to see it late on the evening before we went home and only 2 out of our party of 4 went. Unfortunately the other 2 really missed out by not seeing this. The photographer Gary was there when we went and he was great. Every article has a story and you would have to be totally cold hearted not to be touched and moved by this workshop. Both my brother and I found it really interesting and moving. It brought home the magnitude of the disaster and the effect it had on New York and all the families of the people killed and involved with the recovery. No one should foget the importance of this disaster.

Very touching. Just Go. Seriously - My wife and I went on our honeymoon. We never had any particular connection with what happened on September 11th, but after attending this Workshop we felt personally connected to city and the victims of horrific day. We were lucky enough to go when Gary Suson, the actual photographer and narrator, was there. He gave us a very nice introduction. Go.

A Must See in New York. I recently visited the Ground Zero Museum in New York. Upon arrival at the location, I was not sure that it would be worth the cost; however, after beginning the tour, I was stunned. It is a small museum but very well planned and organized. The self-guided audio tour is incredible. It is the voice of Gary Suson explaining the photograph or museum artifacts collection. I highly recommend the museum before visting the Ground Zero site.Wanda RhodesCorinth, MS

Amazing and Inspiring. Just returned from my first trip to New York and Ground Zero was a must see from the beginning, only heard about this museum from a work colleague not long before we went so decided to book it. Booked over the internet which was very easy to do as you cant' turn up on the day and expect to be able to go in. Located in the Meat Packing District it doesn't look much from the outside but don't be fooled when you go in you are surronded by some amazing and moving pictures and artefacts from that horrific day in September. You are allowed 2 hours to go round looking at everything at your own pace and you can easily spend longer than that, it is all about the amazing recovery work that went on afterwards.Can't speak highly enough of this excellent museum and would go back there in an instant, definitley one of if not the highlight of our 5 day stay in the city.

An experince that touches your heart.. The Ground Zero Museum Workshop is an important place to visit. Many people come to NY and want to see Ground Zero. Make sure you go here as well...you'll have a greater understanding of what went on after September 11th. This is more than just a place to see some amazing photography. It's an experience. There aren't many places I know of - anywhere - that can move you quite like this. It's very personal, intimate and filled with so much feeling. Being able to meet and speak with Gary Suson, the owner and artist behind it all made it even more special. This place really touches your heart whether you're a New Yorker or from out of town. I want to tell everyone about this place. I loved it and will be back again.Dr. Dave LevinNew Yorker and Ground Zero volunteer (7 days a week for 3 months straight)

A Thought Provking and Moving experience. This would have to be one of the most moving and thought provoking museums that you could go to. Only a small museum but full of very interesting stories which really give you an idea of what happened and how it affected people. Highly recommend this museum to anybody. Thank you to the lovely people at the museum for making this experience fantastic.

An astounding impact on anyone who visits. I would definitely recommend a visit to the Ground Zero Museum Workshop. It will have an astounding impact on anyone who visits. Two of my friends and me were fortunate to have a private visit at the museum. In the beginning two short videos are played, one being a CNN interview of Gary Marlon Suson, the official photographer for the Uniformed Firefighters Association & Uniformed Fire Officers Association (FDNY). Each photo and artifact grouping has a detailed narrative that can be heard through a hand held audio device that is personally controlled. This allowed each of us to go at our selected pace during the self-guided portion of the exhibit. Although the size of the museum is small, it has a significant amount within it. It took us approximately 2 ½ hours because we didn’t want to miss a single narrative, photo, or display. We met the photographer, Gary Marlon Suson, and he took the time to answer many questions as well as share many personal experiences during 9/11. If you’re in New York, the Ground Zero Museum Workshop should be visited. Such a cataclysmic time in our history can be difficult to present without dismay. However, Gary has achieved presenting the events of the 9/11 recovery very respectfully and intimately.

Best Part of our NYC Trip. First learned of this tour through our Hotel Concierge, who raved about it - which made us skeptical as nothing ever lives up to the hype - but it actually was an amazing experience. We were suprised that 2 hours went by so fast but the stories behind the photos/artifacts were mesmerizing. We had our own guide who explained the history behind the museum, watched a short film and then were allowed to pick up + hold wtc artifacts - then we listened to the stories in the hand held audio units. We got to meet the photographer of the museum's images, Gary Marlon Suson, who had stopped in for a few minutes and he was very hospitable to us, answered questions and signed some photos we bought. Can't say enough about this "experience" (it's an experience not an attraction) and despite all the wonderful things we saw (and ate) in New York this is the one thing I will remember the most. Definitely go and see this exhibit - you won't regret it. Non-commercial and very intimate...

Simple, discret and tasteful. Was slightly disappointed when entered the museum to see was only the size of a lounge but don't be fooled, the contents and displays are simply awe inspiring. You are provided with a audio tour handset and headphones after an initial introduction and allowed to roam at your own pace. You can not turn up on the day and expect to get in, this is available as an advance booking only. Tickets can be purchased via www.groundzeromuseumworkshop.com.I would definitely recommend you visit the website and try to arange time to visit during your stay. We were lucky enough to meet Gary Suson the creator and photographer on our visit.You are allowed to take photos if you so wish, but I found I spent more time listening to the audio for every display and felt this wasn't the place to take photos.

Everyone should see this.. It's hard to describe how this little museum has such an impact on you. I had not realised just what 9/11 meant until I visited this museum. The stroies behind the photos and artifacts will leave you feeling like you were actually there. This museum is not very well known and relies on word of mouth, so go and visit and tell your friends. Money from the museum is distributed to several charites, one of which helps towards cost of treatment of the rescure workers who got sick after the recovery operation. A visit to this museum really made my trip and I am so glad we found out about it.

So much more than I ever expected. I'd been to New York City many, many times before and peered into Ground Zero many times, too; but I had never heard about this museum until just recently, and decided to check it out.Nothing I could write here would even come close to capturing how many stories, how much emotion, and how much insight you will discover in this one room. Don't be fooled when you first walk in - it really does take 2+ hours to go through what's in there. The audio guide is done by the owner himself, and everything is presented tastefully and powerfully.Even if you've seen Ground Zero, you haven't seen anything until you see this museum. And even though you may think you've seen a million images of 9/11, you've never seen anything like the ones in here. It is truly a privilege that the public is able to get an inside view like this.$25 seems like a lot to pay for a one room museum, but by the time I left, I felt like it was worth so more than that. And I've gained a whole new appreciation of what it was like not only for those who were a part of the event, but also for those whose task it was to clean up over the following months.

A must see!. This one room museum is a must see when visiting New York. There is so much to take in. The room is covered in photographs and artifacts from that day. each has a number which you type into on your self guided audio tour.. Although I didn't lose anyone in 9/11 I felt that I had gone on an emotional journey. The images and artifacts capture powerful moments, moments which should never be forgotten.

Most meaningful experience in New York. My daughter and I have just returned from a weekend visit to New York City. This was our first visit to this metropolitan city and we had many things that we wanted to do and see. We both have a strong interest in people, their experiences, their feelings etc. so a trip to Ground Zero was at the top of our list. As I was doing some research for our trip, I ran across the "Ground Zero Museum Workshop" located at 420 W. 14th Street (between 9th and 10th Avenues) in Manhatten. This "attraction" is a gallery compilation of images and remnants from the Ground Zero Recovery that was produced and curated by Gary Marlon Suson-the official Ground Zero Photographer for the Uniformed Firefighters Association. He is the author of the book "Requim: Images of Ground Zero".When photographers were banned at the Ground Zero site approximately 2 months post 9/11, Gary was invited to come onto the site with camera in hand to document the remaining months of the recovery effort. He captures many very powerful and poignant images that each tell a story relating to the individuals and events of 9/11. The gallery space, however small, was packed with 100 separate displays (either photographs or groupings of actual items recovered from the site). Each display is accompanied by a self guided audio tour narrated by Gary Suson. A video of images and his actual CNN interview started the tour, then everyone was left to themselves to look, absorb, and reflect on the events depicted in the displays. The tour is supposed to be 90 minutes, yet my daughter and I spent 2 1/4 hours going through the gallery , listening to every one of the audio exerpts. Following our self guided tour, we were allowed to photograph items in the gallery space.It was alot to absorb in one afternoon, yet for me was more meaningful than our visit to the actual Ground Zero site, which we did following the "museum". Prices are very reasonable andit was money very well spent. I highly recommend this attraction to all visitors to and residents of New York City.
